If you are expecting some super heavy duty miracle worker products, then I think you will be disappointed.

This is the greatest utensil I own.  As others have mentioned, it gets into the squarish corners of a pot (for example, All-Clad) as well as it makes a great stirring spoon with more area than a regular spoon for mixing a huge pot of sauce or even a stockpot of soup.  This is even my favorite stir fry spoon.  It has a slight angle to it which is also great for mixing things.  About the only possible nits are that All-Clad handles, in general, are not that comfortable and, if you are left-handed, the angle is going the wrong way.  On the plus side, it is brutish sturdy and will mix the heaviest/thickest stuff I have put it in without bending.  I certainly can't say that about other brands I own that will bend.I wish All-Clad didn't discontinue this.  It is just so awesome.  I will never use the regular spoon if this is around.  Hopefully, someone at All-Clad will smarten up and offer this again.  If I could only have one All-Clad product, this would be it.  It is that good.

First, this product exudes quality and high-tech.  It should, of course, considering it costs as much as some tablet computers.  The packaging is over the top, and it even includes a tiny toolset, although I found too tiny to actually be useful.  Installation was an absolute piece-of-cake.  Easy push buttons for the wires and very clear instructions.  It is also a very nice-looking product.  The configuration was to my expectation considering its technical complexity.But... after the novelty wore off, my liking of this thermostat fell flat.My first major annoyance is that the thermostat temperatures is just off.  Significantly off.  Like 3 degrees.  Sometimes, even 5.  Yes, that is a big deal to me because I have several thermostats and thermometers and heat rises, so I expect certain temperature differences in my house.  The reason is not that the sensor is off.  Using a very accurate and precise thermometer, the Nest is correct.  It's just that the Nest, being an electrical device, IS actually warmer than the surrounding room/walls.My next complaint, which has become a major irritation, is that the unit's automatic display turn-on is terrible.  The Nest display turns off to conserve energy (like I could actually care).  It has a sensor that detects when you approach it, and it "wakes" up.  The problem is that maybe 1/2 the time, it doesn't.  I stand there waving my arms, hands, moving in and out waiting for it to wake up, but I shouldn't have to.  It should just display the temperature and settings all the time.  It does have an auto-dimming sensor which works like a champ but which is defeated by the time-out display turning it completely off.There are other irritations such as it doesn't show the humidity even though it has a humidity sensor in it.  You can only read the humidity through the phone app, which IMO is one of the lamest apps I have run in a long time.  It takes an entire screen just to show one number: your setting.  There was a "quick info" mode in the last version, but it wasn't really quick and took far too many clicks and sub-menus and only worked in landscape mode.  That would give you the ability to view the humidity and turn on/off the fan.  That feature seems to have been removed from the app recently.  This reminds me that it is so cumbersome to use the wall thermostat to turn on the fan that I just don't bother.  Now that it seems removed from the app, I really don't bother.  Technical support, while friendly, took almost a week to respond.  No bonus points there.So, in the end, it is cool to show your friends that you can check your home's temperature (which is actually several degrees off) on your phone and you can even change the temperature on your phone, but do I really need that?  The answer is no.  I am a total computer geek, but I value simplicity and ease of use.  In many ways, I miss my old thermostat that tells me (accurately) the current temperature and the set temperature without having to wave my arms to activate it.  Turning on the fan with the old thermostat is just 1 button click away.  It's ability to improve my life (or save energy) is just not there.  I do think all these things can be fixed in firmware and a better app, but it is not there for me today.  Hopefully, Nest is listening to customers and will update the software, but based on the recent app update, they are not.

I found this capacitive touch stylus works very well, but not perfect.  The sensitivity is clearly is not as good as my finger, but generally acceptable.  Some others I've used are better.  On my Samsung Android phone, it seems to have a particularly difficult time with the soft keys at the bottom whereas the rest of the screen is very good.On the plus side, with a this or any stylus, it is so much easier and more accurate to click buttons and type keys.  On the negative side, it is something else to carry/lose.  Also, you have to fumble occasionally and switch hands to do multi-touch gestures such as pinch to zoom and rotate.  I found swiping worked perfect.In general, it doesn't seem up to the quality of others that I've used, but not that far behind either.  I consider these consumables to be lost or worn out over time, probably more of the former :(  As others have noted, the clip is very strong.

Wow, I'm appalled at the misinformation in some of the reviews.First, this is a 2-lane PCI Express card which can run at 2.0 speeds.  The 640L uses the Marvell 88SE9230 which is a 2-lane PCIe to SATA controller.  Did I mention that this uses 2 lanes?  You must have 2 lanes (or more) to utilize the bandwidth of the latest SATA SSDs which are capable of 500+ MB/s.  Any 1 lane card or controller will not cut it.  Also, don't be fooled by SATA6 controllers on the motherboard if they are not the native Intel ones.  The vast majority of them are connected by only 1 lane, and you will not get the full bandwidth necessary to use one of the latest SSDs.Next, this uses a PCIex4 (4-lane) connector.  Why?  Because there are no x2 connectors.  There are x1, x4, x16 physical connectors only.  This card works like a champ in a x16 slot BTW (for me anyway).  It also works in a x16 running at x8 or even x2.  The physical slot does not = the number of PCIe lanes being used.  That is because the vast majority of mainstream/enthusiast motherboard chipsets do not have enough lanes.Highpoint has been around a long time, and I have used their controllers off-and-on over the years.  Most cards like this, however, are based on a reference design by the chip manufacturer, so I made the mistake of first buying a nearly-identical (and cheaper) card by Syba.  It was a nightmare.  Endless stuttering, drop-outs and compatibility problems over a wide range of SSDs.  Using the same drivers, this HighPoint card works with everything I have thrown at it and using the Microsoft AHCI drivers or the Marvell SCSI drivers (prefer the latter).Another positive about this card is that it has real locking SATA connectors.  I cannot believe other manufacturers save, what 2 cents, on cheap connectors which your cables fall off (which is a basic weakness of the SATA connector without locking tabs).In short, I am extremely picky about hardware working right, and this card works.  I run many development machines and cannot have them flaking out.  Although this card is arguably a rip-off (costing as much as some motherboards), if you have the need for more than 2 SATA6 interfaces (native Intel ones), then this is about the only card I've found without getting a full co-processed RAID card.P.S.  Shame on Highpoint for the included SATA non-locking cables.  Those are garbage.  Throw them away.  Card is not affected.

I have used probably 30 or more protein powders.  This ranks near the bottom.First, about whey protein:  The cheapest proteins are just whey protein.  Better than that are whey protein isolates (with fat/carbs more removed).  This seems to be somewhere in between, labeled as a whey protein, I would guess it's just a better quality whey protein.  The best is hydrolyzed (partially broken-down) whey isolates which give you the maximum absorption/utilization and minimal/no fat/carbs.The good points are the taste is just OK (nothing to brag about) and it is relatively cheap.  There are definitely much better-tasting proteins out there, but also some worse.  It is somewhat on the mild/bland/artificial-tasting side IMO.Regarding cheap:  It's not really that cheap when you consider that you're only getting 17g of relatively poor-quality protein per serving.  That'll cost you 105 calories.  In comparison, I think the best protein on the market is Dymatize ISO-100 which, for almost an identical sized serving and 1 more calorie, gives me 25g of the best quality hydrolyzed protein isolate.  That's 50% more and a better-quality protein.  That product, in a 5lb jar, costs me more than 50% more, but there are plenty of other top-rated protein powders like ON's Gold Standard which are cheaper if cost is your main reason for buying (but also somewhat false economy since the quality of the protein is important).So, with the Jarrow product, you're just being fed 7g of fat and carbs (almost 1/3 of it on a calorie-basis!) whereas the ISO-100 has 0g of those.  And, it tastes "whey" better.

I did not bother to test this with conventional HDDs so bear with me.  IMO, there is only one reason to pay the premium for this PCIe x4 (2 lane) card, and that is to use with SATA6 SSDs.  As stated, this card uses the latest Marvell 92xx generation controller (a 88SE9230).  Architecturally, it appears identical to the HighPoint Rocket/RAID 640L card which costs fifteen bucks more and has no eSATA ports.  So, go for the cheaper one, right?No.  This one, although using an identical chip and drivers as the HighPoint controller card, has issues.  See my customer images.  This card stutters and stops.  I have not seen this behavior (and not this bad) since the earliest SSDs on the market.  It will freeze I/O for 5 seconds or more (maybe even 15 seconds) randomly.  I don't know what's going on.  Spent many hours shaking my head.  This occurs with both the Microsoft AHCI and the Marvel SATA-as-SCSI drivers (much worse with the latter).Don't waste your time and just get the HighPoint controller.  It has zero stuttering.  A final ding is that although it has eSATA and a cute little heatsink on the controller chip, it has those cheap SATA connectors out the back that don't have a locking tab.  Also, if you need angled cables for your drives, good luck because the two top SATA connectors (which do have lock tabs) require angled connectors, and double-angled SATA cables are next to impossible to find.  BTW, the top connectors are also the ones that are shared with the rear eSATA ports.

This product BOASTS smart chip-controlled USB ports (plural).  LOL.  What a joke.  I like Leviton a lot, but this foray into the consumer electronics market is a flop IMO.  First, throughout the instructions, it says it features "two 5VDC - 2.1A DC powered USB ports" (plural, again).  I understand that there is a lame limitation of a combined 2.1 amps, which is inexcusable in today's modern age.  With the "smart" technology, I figured I would, at least, be able to charge two 1A phones at the same time.We have a household of gadgets from iPods and iPads to Android phones and tablets and even a Kindle.  I was really looking forward to simplifying all the dongles and fighting wires.  Not so.  First, the only thing that would charge above the basic 500mA (1/2A) is our iPad 2.  Sure, it's "compatible" with most of the other stuff (except not Asus Transformer BTW).  That is no better than the slow charging I can get from any port on a computer, laptop, netbook, or nowadays cheap alarm clock, car charger, etc., or even the Asus Transformer itself.  (Currently, we have a cheap 4-port USB dongle for low-power/low-priority devices.)Furthermore, the iPad 2 would only charge while using the right port.  Sure, the instructions say that the right port is optimized for "larger battery devices" (not that I found that to be the case) but then why claim this has two 2.1A ports?  There is nothing smart that I could find about this product.  Only the right port seems hard-wired to support some iPads -- and it's not even labeled as such.Considering the cost and effort to rewire your outlet(s) and that manufacturers are constantly changing their products, I cannot honestly say this product is worth the money and effort, especially that Leviton grossly overstated this product's capabilities.  I might be willing to give it 2 stars if they clearly stated that this was just a 1/2A charger x2 ports with the limitation that the right port is clearly marked somehow as also compatible with the iPad 2 at 2.1A and there is nothing smart about it and that by using the right port with an iPad, you cannot use the left port to charge an iPhone just like they have in the picture.  But, they didn't.

First off, this drive is wholly incompatible with Marvell SE9130 controllers.  After hours of reading/surfing, this appears to be a problem with any of the first generation Marvell controllers 91xx and most SSDs.  Those controllers, however, work perfectly fine with my old SATA2 Intel and OCZ SSDs.  I have been using SSDs for many, many years.  So, on with my review.  I used this on a Windows 7 64-bit machine Core i7 using the motherboard's Intel SATA6 ports in AHCI, all usual SSD optimizations done.Out-of-the-box, this drive did not even meet the manufacturer's specs.  It is rated for 540 MB/s read and 340 MB/s write (sequential).  I smiled when I saw 550 MB/s reads, but then frowned once I saw it could barely muster 255 MB/s write.  That's down almost 100 MB/s from spec.  OK, for all you that are new to SSDs, with all the current crop of SSDs, the manufacturer's performance specs are a 1-time deal when the drive is brand new and NOTHING has ever been written to the drive.  Once it has, the drive will drop down to a significantly slower performance level.  In essence, it is truly "up to" the published specs.So, I proceeded to put about 60GB of files onto this drive.  128 GB is not very big, but my typical OS, applications, and some pics, music, and what-not is about that big, leaving about 1/2 left.  SSDs really do not like to be run full due to wear leveling algorithms and the drive itself needing free space to rewrite and combine small files into its internally large blocks.Well, I was shocked to see the speeds plummet to only 142 MB/s read and 136 MB/s write.  Actually, I was impressed with what seemed like good write speeds as I looked for and grabbed some directories of files to copy.  But, seriously, this is only after maybe 10 or 20 minutes of use!  You can look at the ATTO and HDTune results in the customer photos.  I then deleted all the files, quick formatted it, and let it sit for 1/2 day to allow any TRIM/garbage collection to take place and restore the drive's performance.  This is the "TrueSpeed" Plextor talks about.  Well, after 1/2 day of sitting powered-up, essentially no difference, and in fact, maybe a hair worse.So, I give it 2 stars for performance.  I have older G2 Intel drives and Intel 320 drives that have been literally beat on for years (Vista without TRIM, TrueCrypt encrypted, RAIDed, etc.) that have better performance without ever needing to run Intel's SSD Toolbox to restore or secure erase/reset them.  Yes, the garbage collection in Intel's early SSDs is really that good (before they went to 3rd-party controllers).  So, next I began looking for the equivalent of Intel's SSD Toolbox or Samsung's SSD Magician.  This retail product is supposed to come with a CD with utilities, etc.  It's also supposed to come with an Installation Manual.  Maybe that information was on the CD?  I will never know because mine did not come with either.  Minus another star.  Down to 1 star.Hours of surfing later, I finally found the Plextor SSD tool.  But, alas, it is in their forums.  So, I have to create an account in order to access it.  But, WTH?  The link to the file gives a 404 Not Found.  This is despite it being posted by one of the moderators/admins only 5 months ago.  I eventually found some discussion (on a different forum) that the Plextor tool doesn't support the M5/Pro drives anyway, and that they are working on it.  I'd take off another star for terrible support, but there aren't any stars left.Well, it seems nothing is going to clean up this drive which was rendered useless after about 20 minutes of use.  Compared to this drive, honestly, I will stick with my older Intel G2 drives which give comparable write performance (years later) and 2X the read performance, despite being SATA2.

This card works fine with conventional/older drives.  It has the advantage of using conventional AHCI drivers (from Microsoft or Marvell) or Marvell's SCSI drivers (the latter is a huge plus for hot-swap).HOWEVER, and it's a big however, I have spent the last several weeks trying to get SATA6 drives to work (namely SSDs), and they just plain don't.  I've used all 3 types of drivers on Vista and Windows 7, 32-bit and 64-bit, and I consistently get massive crashing, hanging, read/write errors, and so-on.In sum, it works with older SATA2 (3 Gbps) drives and SSDs just perfect, but I did not buy a SATA2 card.

I've used many, many quad sets of Corsair Vengeance memory in recent builds.  This is the first set that wouldn't even POST or boot when using the XMP profile/manufacturer settings.  I suspect this is just a defective set, but it in unnerving and time-wasting to have to troubleshoot this.  I give it two stars because it is likely bad and not just poor memory which would deserve zero stars.I wasn't expecting to overclock these, but I did expect them to run a their rated speed/settings.  The best I could muster was 1600MHz CAS10.  I liked the blingy red heatsinks, but for the same performance, I went with the cheaper Corsair Vengeance 1600MHz sticks which were thirty bucks cheaper and actually run at their rated speed (like other 1600MHz and 1866MHz Corsair Vengeance quad sets that I've run).  I suspect they are identical chips, just binned slightly differently, and these shouldn't have made the cut.  And, yes, I've had these motherboards up to 2133MHz, but with other O.C. memory.Update: Before returning, I tried individual banks of 1/2 (two sticks) in different banks and in different motherboards.  Same results.  No two sticks would boot at rated speed/timing.

I'm not going to cover the merits of using a Sonicare electric toothbrush.  Just use them.  Plain and simple.  You will save more in dental costs than you will spend on them.  I have been using them for probably over 15 years, and they are must-haves.  Everyone in my family uses them.  I have also used every major generation of Sonicare toothbrush and several models within each.This Essence 5600 is styled like the original first generation.  Unlike the first generation which used NiCad batteries, this uses NiMH batteries which was used in the second generation.  The original first generation toothbrushes used an open sort of toothbrush head with a plate behind the brush.  This was actually a good head, although it rattled/buzzed if you made the little plastic guard/plate touch the moving brush head.  No big deal.  With these you occasionally had to unscrew the head and clean them out (with an old-style toothbrush).However, Philips/Sonicare has discontinued the original style head and gone with a "universal" head that fits both the first and second generation toothbrushes.  That is what you get with this model.  Unfortunately, despite the more effective and more comfortable head, these are plagued with the problem of mold, bacteria, and just general funk under the rubber seal.  The rubber seal just doesn't seal at all.  Moisture gets in the heads, and shortly, there will be massive black and pink hairy things growing inside.  Just truly disgusting which is why you see some aftermarket (non-Philips) seals being sold.  Further, it is just next to impossible to clean these second generation heads.  See my remedy at the end.The third generation (current) is truly the best.  They went with Li-Ion batteries.  The handles are smaller.  The heads no longer have a "compartment" in which to grow mold and bacteria.Unfortunately, with the progression of each model, Sonicare keeps adding more features which I don't like.  I find quad pacer useless and annoying.  All of the additional massage and pulsing modes and what-not are just irritating because it makes such a simple device much harder to use.  For example, instead of a simple on/off, you now have to push the button twice or cycle through these modes.  This is important because if you push a button twice to cycle it and turn it off while it is in the middle of changing modes, instead of it turning off, it turns on, and your spit and toothpaste go flying, so now you have to clean your glasses, the mirror, and pretty much everything within 3 feet.Anyway, sorry to digress, but I have UNIVERSALLY found that the best model with in each generation is the most simple one without all the feature-laden whistles and bells, ridiculous UV cleaners, etc., which just drive up your cost both initial and in consumables.So, in sum, this has good battery technology, but you will have to be careful not to leave it in the charger and make sure you run it down.  In other words, you will have to run it like a usual Ni-MH battery product to get the maximum life of maybe 3-5 years.  If you don't, then you can kill it is 1-2 years.  I like that this is a simple version and easy to operate.  It has a nice grip and travel pouch.  It it also is relatively inexpensive if you are new to Sonicare, but your next one will want to be the Li-Ion versions.  What I really don't like about this is the terrible toothbrush heads which get funky.  My best recommendation for dealing with this is as follows.  (Disclaimer: this is not recommended or supported by the manufacturer.  Use at your own risk, yada, yada.)  Get some small, sharp scissors or a box cutter or utility knife and cut off that rubber seal -- which doesn't seal anyway.  Then, after you brush your teeth just run some water down in there to rinse it out.  Without the seal, it will dry, and not get so funky.  At least 10X better, although it looks kinda MacGyver'ed.

I am a big Post-it fan.  While I like the general concept of this, the dispenser kind of wrecks it.First, a minor pet peeve is that the tape roll is taped down with Magic tape.  To get that tape off which is recessed down in the dispenser is a lesson in frustrationful packaging and ultimately wastes about 8-10" of the roll.Next, the "cutter" just doesn't cut clean.  It cuts ratty, or not all the way, or crooked.  Assuming you are more of a neat-freak to begin with and that is why you are organizing and labeling things in the first place, this doesn't "cut it".Next, there is no way to measure out equal strips.  Not a deal-breaker though.Finally, you can't write on it while it is in the dispenser through a small slot/opening -- maybe an inch and a half worth.  So, you must first "apply" it to something like a clean table, then remove it and place it on your item.  Because the sticky goo is just so-so, you lose stick applying and reapplying your label.On the plus side, however, it is a thin tape strip which conforms better to things like bottles, jars, canisters, etc.  Another product to consider is the full-adhesive Post-it notes (which are full adhesive and not just a strip at the top), but I found those only really work on flat things.  On any sort of curve, ultimately, the flatness of the Post-it note wins and it lifts off/falls off.This Post-it tape works better in that regard on curved surfaces and therefore warrants a 3 star rating from me.

I am an ounce-of-prevention is worth a pound-of-cure guy.  My current favorite is Crest 3D White mouthwash, so I was excited to try this new Crest Pro-Health Clinical mouthwash.I did not have any of the burning experienced by others, but this stuff is just weird.  After about 20-30 seconds, you feel blobs of gunk floating around in your mouth.  I don't know if it's itself coagulating or dissolved parts of my mouth or both, but a mouthful of white, stringy blobs is gross.  It takes quite a bit of rinsing to get all of the yuck out of my mouth.  Performance-wise, it does seem to be effective, and hence the 3 stars.I have tried other mouthwashes in the past that also dissolved my mouth, but with those, there was a slough-off later after using it -- not while using it.  The Crest Clinical is somewhat of a turn-off in a nauseating sort of way because of this.  Definitely try a very small bottle first as I was tempted to throw it out many times.  I will stay with the Crest 3D White for now.I have also recently tried the Colgate Optic White mouthwash, and while I love the Optic White toothpaste, the mouthwash (which performs well) borderlines on burning and tastes like bleach.

This cable worked excellent with no issues.  It has a male SATA power connector to connect to newer power supplies.  On the other end it has a female Molex connector to connect to older drives and some internal components as well, for example, I had a brand new USB 3.0 PCIe plug-in card, but it needed power to its older-style Molex connector.What I also like about this cable is that the ends are just straight.  Many are Y-connectors or SATA connectors where the wires come out the side.  The problem when the wires come out the side is you have a 50/50 chance of them pointing the wrong direction.  I like to keep things tidy, and this cable worked like a champ.

I really like Quest protein bars.  They are among the healthiest protein bars out there.  Most other bars just pretend to be healthy, but are actually loaded with fat and carbs, especially sugar.The texture of all of them are just stiff PlayDoh.  This has the advantage of no chocolate coatings, etc., to melt all over and make a mess.  In fact, these taste better when they are warmer/softer.  IMO, the taste is not great, but good enough.  Also, the flavors only somewhat resemble their names.With that said, the taste of the Peanut Butter & Jelly version is just OK.  Considering it is one of the highest calorie (210) and highest fat (10g) of the Quest bars, I don't think the variety of taste justifies it.  There are others such as Chocolate Brownie and Cinnamon Roll and Coconut Cashew or even Chocolate Peanut Butter which taste better and are more healthy.  Sure, you can get sick of just one flavor, but there are plenty of healthier Quest bars.

I love this toy, and I say that as a 40 year old‚Ä¶my six year old will get it for Christmas, but I‚Äôve been testing it strictly for reviewing purposes (yeah right).  Furbacca speaks both Wookie and English (bilingual!) and is genuinely funny, plus his fur and bandolier are awesome.  I will say that you really need the app to get the most out of this toy as that is where the bulk of the interaction takes place, so if you don‚Äôt have a wifi enabled device for your child, this may not be the best option.  But if you do, this is a great toy that should provide hours of creative play.

Personalization is the name of the game with this Playmobil hockey set.  With the ability to add team stickers and additional players, your young hockey fan can set up the game the way they want.  My 6 year old boys absolutely love banging the puck around while pretending to be their favorite players, but I should point out that this isn‚Äôt a traditional bubble hockey set up; there aren‚Äôt rods that move players across a fixed range of space.  Rather there are little tabs at the back of each player that children can grasp to move the player around.  I don‚Äôt see this as any issue at all, but if you are looking for a more traditional set, this isn‚Äôt for you.

Bottom line the is a fast router, but I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve noticed a significant improvement over the Linksys WRT AC1900 I was using previously, so I wouldn‚Äôt necessarily recommend rushing out and buying it if you already have a current gen wireless router.  However, if your equipment is outdated and you‚Äôre looking for something more powerful, this is a great option as it offers all of the bells and whistles you would want, along with a companion app that makes set up and tweaking a breeze.

I‚Äôve heard some people describe the Playmation Marvel Avengers as I live action video game‚Ä¶and I get where they are coming from, but to my mind a better description would be an active book.  Why?  Well, primarily because this toy relies on the users imagination for the overwhelming majority of the visuals.  Unlike a video game, in which artists and programmers have created a world for you, here you decide how everything looks and behaves; sure there is a story that guides you along, but it‚Äôs really more of a loose boundary for play rather than a hard and fast railroad track.I have twin six years olds and they love this set ‚Äì they don‚Äôt have the patience for board games, but they love something, anything that gets them up and running around, and the fact that they are cast in their own Avengers ‚Äúmovie‚Äù, well that‚Äôs just the icing on the cake.  This toy is really the best possible blend of technology and imagination, story and free play, and is unique in my experience.  I highly recommend it.

I really, really wanted to be able to write a glowing review for the Roomba 980, but after a month of use I just can‚Äôt bring myself to do so.  First, by way of background, I have been using the Roomba on the first floor of our house, which is roughly 800 square feet less a bathroom, and furniture the Roomba can‚Äôt fit under; it says it vacuums about 650 square feet and that feels accurate to me.  Three quarters of the floor space is hardwood with the remainder carpeted, and we have four kids and a 25 pound beagle, so regular vacuuming is definitely required.  Finally, I received this (very expensive) vacuum for free through the Amazon Vine program.Set up is a breeze, although, as other reviewers have pointed out, the Roomba‚Äôs inability to connect to a 5Ghz wireless band is a glaring oversight.  Likewise, the app is intuitive and makes scheduling cleanings, or kicking off an ad hoc cleaning, a breeze.  Also, the help function is outstanding, offering clear instructions, as well as contact and part information.As for cleaning, when the Roomba completes a job, the quality is excellent, it gets very close to baseboards and furniture, and pulls up far more dirt and debris than I would have ever thought possible.  However, that ‚Äúwhen‚Äù is the problem.  Frankly, an almost $900 vacuum should be functioning perfectly 99% of the time, yet 50% of the time I find it wedged in an opening that is just a bit too small, or backed into a corner it can‚Äôt get out of, or most infuriating, just sitting in the middle of the floor with its battery dead.  Moreover, it doesn‚Äôt seem to be learning as it goes along, it cleaned perfectly the first two days, then got stuck or ran out of battery the next three, then cleaned for two days, failed for one and on and on.Ultimately, this is a product, that if it ran seamlessly, would be of great benefit to my family, both in time savings and mitigating seasonal allergies.  But for me to recommend a $900 vacuum, it is has to be operating flawlessly essentially all of the time and in my experience, it has nowhere near that kind of up time.  It is possible, perhaps likely, that future firmware updates will improve the Roomba 980s efficiency, and if that‚Äôs the case I will update my review accordingly, but as I sit here writing this, my recommendation would be that if you really want to spend a lot of money on a top of the line vacuum cleaner, buy a Dyson.  Yes you lose the time savings, but you‚Äôll save a few hundred dollars (at least) and you won‚Äôt have to deal with the aggravation of expecting a clean floor and getting a half or quarter clean floor.

My kids aren't in highchairs anymore, although I almost (almost) wish they were with this beautiful, functional highchair.  We picked up this one to use with our niece, and it provides a great deal of versatility without being an ugly monolith in your kitchen.  It blends into the background nicely with pleasing wood rails and muted colors; the best compliment I could give, really, is that it feels more like an additional piece of furniture than a baby accessory.

The Braven 805 produces great sound in an attractive package and offers tremendous battery life and the ability to charge other devices via USB, which is a smart and genuinely useful function.  My only real complaint is that in endeavoring to make as clean an interface as possible, the designers actually made it more difficult that necessary to pair devices.  Instead of providing a dedicated Bluetooth button, you need to long press the play button and wait for a tone, which to be fair is hardly rocket science, but I nonetheless found it difficult to get my phone and other devices to pair with the Braven.  Absent and deep technical understanding of Bluetooth technology, I can‚Äôt say definitively if this is a problem with the speaker, but given that I had the problem with multiple devices, I feel confident that a dedicated Bluetooth button would have at least removed one variable from the equation.To be clear though, once I got those devices paired, the sound quality is fantastic and the battery lasts far longer than I would ever need it to (the specs say 18 hours, which I believe but didn‚Äôt independently validate).  This is a great option when you need a speaker outside or in a part of your home removed from your AV equipment.

This is a really fun toy that offers a great, and in some ways more practical take on RC cars.  Instead of the traditional rubber wheels, the Terrain Twister has, pontoons, for lack of a better phrase, with corkscrews on each side.  It uses these screws to pull itself across an impressive variety of terrain, including water.  In fact, if there‚Äôs any downside to this toy it‚Äôs that it doesn‚Äôt perform well on traditional RC surfaces (i.e. hardwood, sidewalks and asphalt) because the screws don‚Äôt generate enough friction.  You also need to be careful using it on asphalt and concrete because you can really gouge up the screws.So far we‚Äôve had a blast with this toy and can‚Äôt wait to try it out on the snow this winter.

This is my first air purifier, so I have no basis for comparison, but I can say that it has significantly reduced my son‚Äôs seasonal allergies, even the central air conditioning is on.  Set up is barely more than plugging it in, and on the lower fan settings it is so quiet you forget that it is running.  My son has gone from waking up sneezing with itchy eyes, to a wake up routine that is more like January than August, including no more racing for his daily dose of Zyrtec.  Ultimately, that‚Äôs all the evidence I need that the AeraMax is doing its job, and doing it well.  When you add in the sleek look and unobtrusive operating volume, I would highly recommend this unit if you are looking for an air purifier for daily use.

What is perhaps most impressive about this set is the sheer volume of stuff that you get, including 610 cards and six dice total, along with well written instructions.  I picked up this set because my 12 and 9 year olds have played Pokemon for years and have recently made a foray into Magic, and I thought this would be another fun option for them, and something that I could participate in on a level playing field.  The 12 year old and I picked up the game pretty quickly, but the learning curve was a little steeper for the 9 year old, although she eventually caught up.  Of course every kid is different, but the recommended age of 8 and up may be a little aggressive.  Overall, gameplay offers a lot of variety and moves along at a nice pace.  I don‚Äôt have experience with other card games so I can‚Äôt really offer any compare/contrast, but we are thoroughly enjoying this set.

I tend to be a very aggressive brusher, which can be murder on my gums, so my dentist has often recommended an electric toothbrush.  I‚Äôve tried a few and always been somewhat ambivalent about them after the initial novelty.  However, I strongly believe the Philips Sonicare 5 will be a different story.  Put simply, your mouth and teeth feel exceptionally clean after you use it; honestly, it‚Äôs akin to the slick feeling your teeth have after a trip to the dentist, and it achieves that clean while still being gentle on your gums.  As a further benefit, it holds its charge for a long time.  I haven‚Äôt put the three week battery claim to the test, but I‚Äôve used it for a week without bothering to plug it in with no ill effects.  Finally, because there are three speed settings, you can customize your brushing for what is most comfortable for you, rather than the one size fits all approach of most electronic toothbrushes.All in all a great product, I highly recommend it.

‚ÄúTin Men‚Äù is based on a fairly intriguing premise, namely that the U.S. military creates robot drones controlled by soldier who upload their consciousness into the machines for the duration of their patrol.  This allows the U.S. to conduct bloodless (for them anyway) interdictions across the globe with the only risk being the relatively nominal expense of the occasional destroyed drone.  However, when someone figures out how to trap the operators in the drones, the equation changes in an eyeblink.This is territory that has been mined before, no least by Joe Haldeman in ‚ÄúForever Peace‚Äù, however, the separation of mind and body in a definitive way is a new and interesting wrinkle.  Unfortunately, author Christopher Golden never convinced me that the operators were experiencing the profound existential dread that would come from having your consciousness cut off from your physical body.  Moreover, they both recognize the situation and accept it far more quickly than seems reasonable.  As such, I found myself far more interested in the (significant) action involving flesh and blood humans.  There‚Äôs nothing wrong with this, but it is clearly not intended to be the core focus of the book.  Moreover, since the hook here is a really cool an innovative technology, one would think the author would really spend some time fleshing out what the drones look like, how they are armed, what their specs are, etc., but overall I found their description rather cursory, and as such I never felt all that invested in the concept.Golden does deserve credit for tackling some serious question about the scope and price of America‚Äôs global footprint, which is often glossed over with the unabashed jingoism that makes most military fiction unreadable in my opinion.  Moreover, he comes up with a genuinely unique hook on a subject that is at the front and center of America‚Äôs current military policy.  However, at the end of the day, the story just wasn‚Äôt developed enough to truly draw me in.

This is an excellent filet knife for two reasons.  First is sharpness.  Filet knives are used for making (often) long precise cuts and if the blade isn‚Äôt sharp and/or doesn‚Äôt hold an edge at best you will end up with a ragged cut and at worst you‚Äôll slice the palm of your hand wide open.  With this KitchenAid knife that hasn‚Äôt been a concern as it has thus far shown a razor sharp and durable edge.  I‚Äôve been able to slice up chicken cutlets both cleanly and quickly.  Second is flexibility.  This knife has a high degree of flexibility which allows an easier grip and a flatter cut, creating filets with even thickness which is critical for even cooking.All in all this a high quality, and good looking knife I expect to use for years to come.

This toy is a great and in my experience unique, combination of building and action toys.  Essentially it is a Nerf dart gun, but by including K‚ÄôNex kids can change the look and feel of the toy at their whim.  Moreover, they are fairly complicated modifications; this isn‚Äôt a cheap toy where you can move four pieces and get a different look.  It takes thought and planning to put together the multi-step, multi-piece designs,  Also, somewhat surprisingly, the K‚ÄôNex portion of the toy holds up surprisingly well.  I was concerned that it would fall to pieces at the slightest tap, but it actually holds up pretty well during rough and tumble play.  My only complaint is that while the box clearly advertises four different configurations, there are only instructions for one build included.  That‚Äôs not to say kids can‚Äôt figure things out based upon the box, but how long is that box going to hold up?In the end though this is a minor quibble with an otherwise unique and fun toy.

Brother Printer MFCJ6925DW Wireless Color Printer with Scanner, Copier and FaxThe Brother MFCJ6925DW is very much at the high end of personal printers, and is frankly more than adequate for a small business setting.  So while I highly recommend it for what it is, if you only need to print your Christmas card labels and taxes once a year and the occasional coupon, this is way more printer than you need.However, if you find yourself doing a lot of scanning, faxing or are a heavy printer, this is a great machine.  Generally speaking I find setting up a new printer aggravating because there are so many moving plastic parts, and there was no exception in this case, but that‚Äôs really to be expected.  Wireless set-up was a snap and I was able to get the drivers on my machines with no issues.  Printing is fast and of excellent quality.  One of the selling points of this model is it‚Äôs use of high efficiency inks, and while I haven‚Äôt had the printer long enough to put that claim fully to the test, I have printed ~75 color PowerPoint slides with no signs of fading or inconsistent color.To my mind the best feature on this printer that you won‚Äôt find on many smaller models is the top load feeder.  If you are dealing with legal or financial documents, either scanning or printing, the ability to drop them in the feeder and let the machine cycle through them is vastly easier than scanning one page at a time.In summation, this is at the very top of the personal market, and would work just fine in a small business setting, but you definitely get what you pay for.

We were already using a memory foam mattress (Tempurpedic), so I wasn‚Äôt sure if I would notice any difference with the Serta Killner, but I have to say that thus far I have been quite pleased with it.  For starters, while all (as far as I can tell) memory foam products have a chemical odor out of the box, the Killner‚Äôs was relatively mild and dissipated more quickly than I have experienced with other mattresses.As for comfort, there are three key elements that I have appreciated.  First is the cool action memory foam; while our old mattress had a similar feature, it wasn‚Äôt anywhere near as efficient.  I hate waking up hot, but with this mattress I consistently feel comfortably cool; I would like the feeling (in regards to temperature) to old pre pillow-top mattresses.  In short you don‚Äôt wake up feeling like you are in a sauna.Secondly, the way the foam is engineered (and I don‚Äôt claim to understand the technical details) the edges hold up much better than our old mattress.  With other memory foam mattresses, I have found that the bed effectively collapses under you if you sit too close the edge or move towards it over the course of the night.  With this mattress I can lean against or sit on the edge of the bed and it holds up quite well.Finally, this mattress gets the mix of soft and firm just right.  The reason all memory foam mattresses work (in theory) is that they conform to your body, thus reducing or eliminating pressure points.  That‚Äôs in theory, however, and often they can get the balance wrong and you end up feeling like you are falling through the floor or lying on a slab.  For my taste the Killner offers the right balance between give in support.In short, this is an excellent mattress at a very competitive price point.  I highly endorse it.

I am not the target demographic for these headphones; they cost more than my stereo receiver and I never would have even considered buying them.  That said, my demo may have shifted because these sound so good I‚Äôm not sure I could ever go back to plain old earbuds.  The sounds these headphones produce is rich and hits low bass and high treble without being loud.  They are extremely comfortable and fit snugly over the ears without feeling tight, although I will say that given they are padded and fit around the ear, they do start to make me feel hot after a while, but they are effectively earmuffs so that is hardly surprising.The headphones work in two modes powered (requires a single battery) and unpowered.  The unpowered mode produces excellent sound, but in my layman‚Äôs terms seems somewhat less crisp.  The powered mode produces a much richer sound and also actively dampens ambient noise.  I decided to stress test this mode by wearing them while I mowed the lawn with a gas powered more.  I‚Äôm not going to say that I couldn‚Äôt hear the mower, but it was dampened enough that I could hear the music I was listening to, something I could never accomplish with earbuds without completely blowing out my eardrums.  I would imagine that the effect on an airplane would be comparable, and probably filter the bulk of the cabin noise.There‚Äôs no denying that these are high end headphones, and I can‚Äôt say that they are for everyone.  But if you are a serious audiophile I can say that you will not be disappointed with the Bose QuietComfort 25 Acoustic Noise Cancelling headphones.

I have read a lot of post-apocolyptic stories. I mean A LOT. This one does not involve vampires, werewolves, aliens, or unusually crazy people. It is such a great story. This was very well written and the narrative was easy to follow. I have recommended this book to a lot of people, including my friend, the librarian!

This book was very well written. I enjoy reading YA books for their ease and subject matter. This one was thought provoking and a little disturbing. I finished it weeks ago, but I still think about it (in a good way). I would recommend this book to anyone

I‚Äôm somewhere between underwhelmed and disappointed with this seed.  In spite of preparing the ground as suggested, watering regularly and fairly favorable growing conditions, I am only now, three weeks after planting, beginning to see shoots of grass.  Moreover, if the shoots I am seeing are any indication, the coverage will be mediocre at best.  Scotts makes great fertilizers and weed control products, but I have been consistently disappointed with their grass seed for years now.  Unless the shoots I have suddenly kick into overdrive and both sprout and spread, I will have to re-seed again, albeit with one of Scotts‚Äô competitors.

The author deserves credit for trying to intertwine two stories, one from the perspective of animals and the other from the perspective of  a 13 year old boy.  However, as other reviewers have pointed out, the two stories never quite mesh, and interestingly, my daughter and I both found the wolf arc to much more compelling.  The writing is well targeted at 9-10 year olds, in that it is challenging without being overwhelming, and avoids the condescendingly simple language one often encounters in books for this age group.  ‚ÄúOld Wolf‚Äù is a book that will particularly appeal to children who are interested in animals/wildlife/nature and is interesting if ultimately not completely satisfying read.

I turned to my eleven year old for a target audience review (below).  He absolutely devoured the book and was eagerly looking for the second volume as soon as he finished it.  I have a tough time reviewing YA books as the writing is by definition, juvenile, but the plot was robust enough to carry the story, and the writing was good in an age appropriate way.In this book, the main character, Michael Malone, discovers he has the power to alter reality after saving a dog from jumping off a cliff. He then is recruited by a top-secret organization called UNICORNE. I enjoyed meeting Michael, his classmate Freya, his mom, and his sister.  My favorite part of the book was when Michael accidently makes one of the UNICORNE agents into his au pair (and then his doctor, and then his French teacher) by altering reality. One of my favorite characters is Freya, because we both like to draw dragons and like dogs. Overall, it was a great book.

These are easily the best pair of safety glasses I have ever owned.  The padding around the eyes means they both fit comfortably and snugly enough that sawdust or other debris can‚Äôt work its way around the edges of the lenses.  Furthermore, the tinting is just right; enough to keep the glare off when working outside, but not so dark that they are dangerous to use indoors.  Finally, while I have admittedly only been using them for a few weeks, they strike me as being durable and well-constructed.  I definitely envision using these for years to come.

The fact that this is cordless and has a lithium ion battery is a great feature and makes the FloorMate very convenient to use.  That said, I wasn‚Äôt all that impressed; it left our floors clean, but not so much that I would want to spend a significant amount of money on a job that is fairly easily done with a mop.  First off, it left our floors much too wet and on top of that it‚Äôs not very maneuverable and basically useless on stairs.Our house is almost entirely hardwood, so I really wanted to like the FloorMate, but the simple fact is that it is just not anywhere near as convenient, or as effective, as a mop, which costs maybe 10% of what it does.

First off, I have to say that this thing is absolutely whisper quiet, the only way I could tell it was actually working was by putting my hand behind it.  I think this is important because the XBox 360 used to be so loud when the fan got going and the XBox One has been a huge improvement in that regard; I certainly wouldn‚Äôt want to add a peripheral that created a bunch of noise.  That aside, I think this does a nice job of circulating air, and for the price I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a bad investment, but with a little tweaking it could have been much better.First off, I don‚Äôt understand why the fan doesn‚Äôt vent forward.  It‚Äôs hard for me to envision a scenario where someone would have their device with more space behind than in front.  Mine is in a cabinet, so having it blow forward would have been great.  There is certainly value in having the air circulate within the space, but a forward vent would have, at least in my opinion, provided much more cooling for the buck.  Second, there is a temperature display which shows the ambient temperature and the temperature of the exhaust air.  This is kind of cool, I guess, but out of context it doesn‚Äôt really tell me anything.  I think we all know that cooler is better, but I certainly don‚Äôt know what the safe operating temperature for an XBox is; it would have been nice if the numbers were green, yellow, red (or even green/red) so that the user would know if their machine was really straining.Again, for the price I think this isn‚Äôt a bad investment, particularly if you have your machine in a tight space.  However, it‚Äôs somewhat disappointing that a few simple design changes could have made it much better with very little cost impact.

This is a pretty set that we gave to our nine year old daughter for her birthday.  She's probably a little young for the set, but it based upon quality and look, I would say that 9-15 is probably the sweet spot for this set.  The look (hearts) definitely reads tween/teen to me (even thought the ring is clearly fitted for a woman) and the quality, while more than adequate for the price, is much closer to costume than true "jewelry", although I will grant that that is an amorphous definition.The color of the stones was quite nice; if anything they were a little deeper green in person and the earrings, chain and pendant were well assembled.  All in all a nice little jewelry set.

If you are a serious PC gamer, this 24 inch HD monitor is a beautiful display option.  The set-up was easy and the picture is absolutely gorgeous (through HDMI).  I tested it with a Lenovo gaming laptop playing (what are admittedly last generation games) Dishonored and a heavily modded version of Skyrim (including a number of significant graphical upgrades).  I encountered no issues with rendering or blurring, and I have to say that if you are going to game at a desk (as opposed to plugged into a TV) the 24 inch monitor felt like just the right size; big enough to enjoy the game without being overwhelming.All that said, this is a very pricey piece of equipment, and I unfortunately lack the technical expertise to compare it to other monitors in the class.  That said, if it is within your budget, I can‚Äôt imagine that you will find yourself disappointed.

It may seem odd that I'm writing a review for weed killer in February in snowy New England, but I've been using Ortho Weed B Gon Max for years and it is hands down the best product out there.  It has killed every weed I have ever come across, including crabgrass, and does so incredibly fast.  All but the smallest clumps of crabgrass will be withered and gone within 48 hours of application, and while the crabgrass takes longer to go away, it is still visibly dead.In particular I like this sprayer system as it allows me to target problem areas without drenching my entire lawn in chemicals.  Long story short, this is the best, most effective weed killer on the market.

This was a very comfortable mattress, and it carries price point that is practically unbeatable, but before I get to the heart of the review, a few notes about set-up for the sake of full disclosure.  First, as many others have alluded to, this mattress comes packed up at roughly a third of its full size and takes a while to spring back to its final shape.  I opened it up on a Tuesday and didn‚Äôt have time to deal with it until Saturday, and it was plenty ready to go; I‚Äôm reasonably certain it would have been fine on Thursday, but I cannot say for certain.  Second, I used this mattress on top of the foundation for our existing memory foam mattress; these are rigid and framed in steel and are not akin to a traditional boxspring.That out of the way, both my wife and I found this to be a very comfortable mattress.  Being a hybrid it definitely had a little more give and transferred a little more motion than our TempurPedic mattress, but neither was an issue.  The cool layer worked as advertised, and is, to my mind, and absolute must for any mattress that involves memory foam.  The product is so dense, and you move around so little (because you aren‚Äôt getting sore from pressure points) mattresses without some sort of heat wicking quickly become uncomfortably warm, even in cold climates.  As a matter of personal taste, my wife and I prefer a slightly firmer mattress, so we went back to our old one, but that is in no way an indictment of this mattress.  We moved it to our guest room and have already had two very satisfied visitors, and I expect many more in the future.Finally, for the quality, this mattress is almost absurdly inexpensive.  At ~$400 there is nothing on the market that I am aware of that comes anywhere close to the same value.  If you told me this was twice as expensive, I wouldn‚Äôt bat an eye, and I would still consider it on the cheaper end of mattresses.  When you consider that there are any number of mattresses that start out at $1000 for the base models and rapidly increase from there, this is a remarkably good deal.Sweet dreams.

I‚Äôve been using a Foreman Grill of one type or another for probably 15 years now, but this one is by far my favorite.  The problem with old grills was that they excelled at grilling meat, at one temperature, and they were a pain to clean up because the plates were fixed.  With this device the temperature settings are variable, waffle plates have been added so that it‚Äôs not quite such a uni-tasker and the plates are removable, which makes clean-up so much easier.  All the while, the fundamental concept of these devices, that they let fat cook off and slide away, is preserved.  For instance, cook bacon on this and you get flat crispy strips, that, while certainly not healthy, aren‚Äôt swimming in their own fat either.  It‚Äôs also great for families as you can whip up grilled cheese and the like much faster than in a frying pan.Overall this a great kitchen gadget that is versatile enough to fulfill a number of tasks in an efficient, easy to clean package.

I realize the title of this review isn't terrible creative, but there's no need for fancy descriptions when you have such a great toy.  The level of detail is amazing and the quality is beyond compare.  My twin four year old boys have played with almost nothing else (except perhaps as opponents for the fearsome dragon and noble knight) since we got it, and even their ten year old brother will try to get in on the act.  My only (small) complaint would be that the wings pop out a little easier than I would like; while this isn't an issue now, I'm afraid the sockets will wear out over time and exacerbate the problem, but time will tell.Simply put a beautiful, fun toy that should lead to hours of imaginative play.

There are many things I like about this bag, magnetic clips, and abundance of pockets and strong security, but I think what I like best is that it keeps your laptop right up against your back.  The benefit of this is twofold as adds another layer of security for your machine, but it also makes ergonomic sense as it doesn't pull the bag away from your body as much as some other packs do.  Beyond that, this bag shines in the way it keeps your devices secure, the top flap pulls way down the front of the bag and is secured by magnetic clips that seem gimmicky at first, but that actually work great and won't wear out or snap the way plastic clips can.  Likewise, there are tons of pockets for your other devices (I would be comfortable carrying an SLR camera in the main pouch) and plenty of room for documents, etc.Aesthetically, the bag has a great look, although it might benefit from some additional color choices (the gray is a little bland).  That one minor quibble aside though, I can confidently say I'll be using this bag for years to come.

This is a comfortable easy to use bag that is a great option for anyone with a SLR camera and multiple lenses.  While the ability to store up to five lenses is perhaps overkill for most amateurs, the ability to flexibly store a variety of sizes and shapes is greatly appreciated.  Additionally, there is ample space for chargers, other electronic devices or just a snack.  Perhaps the only downside would be for serious hikers; you can't reasonably carry this bag and a traditional hiking backpack.

The remote itself is a nice universal remote with all of the wonderful form factor you'd expect from Logitech.  However, the core of what is being marketed here is the ability to use your smart phone as a remote, and while that sounds good in theory, in practice it doesn't really work.  The reason for this that I, like most people (I think), use my smart phone simultaneous to watching TV, so I don't really want to use battery life, or stop what I am doing to change the channel.  So while the app is pretty easy to use and set-up, I'm definitely not knocking the interface, but using it ends up being intrusive.  If you are absolutely certain you want to use your phone as a remote, I suppose you'll be satisfied, but I think most people will quickly sour on the experience.

I'm hardly an expert in wireless connectivity, but I have used a few different types and I can endorse this as a solid, easy to use device.  Set-up was fairly standard and it should be mentioned that the form factor is nice as I don't feel compelled to bury the router somewhere out of sight.  I can't say that I have observed significant increases in speed (although I was pretty happy with what I already had, I expect people upgrading from older devices may feel differently), but I am definitely getting improved range.

I really, really want to be able to give this remote five starts, because it does some things really well, but a few critical, frankly glaring, gaps in it's capabilities prevent me from doing so.  That said, first, the good.As with all Logitech devices, the form factor is top notch.  The remote feels great in your hands and everything is place logically (I will concede the Fast Forward/Play/etc. buttons would be a little more comfortable below the screen, but I adapted without much trouble).  The centerpiece of the remote, is of course the screen, which is crystal clear and features haptic feedback.  There are three primary functions for the screen, which are accessed by sliding between difference "Trays" for lack of a better phrase:1. Turn on devices based upon a profile (i.e. turn on TV, Receiver and Cable Box and Set TV to HDMI1)2. Favorites, this is where icons for your designated favorite TV stations (up to 50) can be found3. A touch enabled field which can used to swipe to perform an activity (i.e. swipe right for channel up)You can also access more specific controls via a series of menus, for instance if you want to change the HDMI input, or, unfortunately, access a keypad.That's where the remote starts to fall down, it has this beautiful touchscreen, but that screen offers me less functionality than my old Harmony One.  First off, the lack of an easily accessible number pad is inexcusable.  No matter how visually appealing the favorites tab is, I won't always want to scroll through 50 icons (or access the guide) to change the channel, and getting to the number pad is a pain in the neck.  Job number one for Logitech should be to provide a firmware update that makes the number pad an additional tray like the one's detailed above ASAP.Second, I sometimes want to have two activities active at the same time, for example, have my Xbox and cable active at the same time so that I can toggle between the two.  The Harmony one supported this by allowing me to manually add buttons to the screen so that I could quickly switch between HDMI1 and HDMI3, now I have to tediously open up the menu, select the device, scroll to find the desired action, select it, and then navigate back to the home screen.  It is baffling that with a much more powerful device, featuring a bigger and more capable screen, Logitech has seen fit to offer less capability than found in the Harmony One.  Again, this should be fixable with a firmware update, but only time will tell if Logitech pursues this course.Finally, the lack of a hard "Skip" button is a pain; it has been replaced by a long press on the rewind/fast-forward button, which, if you aren't paying attention, will inevitably lead to unwanted actions.  Considering that most cable boxes will register the backward skip as a 5-15 second rewind, a function that I personally use constantly, I am befuddled by this decision.  There's no fixing this problem, and I would live with it if everything else worked perfectly, but right now it feels like the straw that broke the camel's back.There is so much potential with this remote, and frankly, it just looks so cool, I want to give it five stars.  However, there are so many critical gaps in functionality, there is no way I could recommend anyone spend $300+ on it when you can pick up a Harmony One cheaply that will provide better functionality in a slightly less appealing form.  If and when Logitech pushes any updates I will append my review, but for now I can only say that this is a very cool but fundamentally flawed device.

At face value, this is a bike mount for Android smart phones.  It is durable, easy to install and closes securely.  I would definitely have no concerns about my phone being in this mount while biking.Except that it doesn't accommodate my phones (Galaxy GS3) when it is in its case, which means that in order to use this mount, I have to remove the case, which is a pain, but also risks me dropping the phone in the worst possible environment (garage, road, hard packed bike trail) with no protection.  Considering everyone with even a lick of common sense protects the $500 devices they carry in their pockets with some sort of case, that lack of space to accommodate a phone in case seems like a glaringly obvious oversight.Ultimately, I won't be using this mount because I don't want to deal with the hassle, and risk, of removing the case, even though the design is highly functional and easy to use.

I love the idea of this book, an anatomy of mythical creatures, but the execution does live up to the promise.  The surrounding story is rather dull, and the illustrations, while well executed, are fairly bland.  Not a total disappointment, but nowhere near what it could have been.
I don't have any experience with similar products, so I can't offer any points of comparison.  That said, my face certainly feels cleaner after using this and it's not at all damaging or too rough.

I don't doubt for a second that this case would protect my phone from a fairly serious impact.  The unibody soft/hard case is unique in my experience and insomuch as I can assess is more than durable enough for use in areas with high potential for damage like construction sites, warehouses or just hiking.  However, as other reviewers have mentioned, the lock and volume buttons are far too stiff and really make normal office/home use of the phone a bit of a pain.  To be fair, if you need a high level of protection, this isn't a deal breaking problem, but it is annoying enough that I will probably go back to my old two piece case.

I've used Jabra corded earbuds for the last six months or so, so I was really excited to use the Bluetooth version, and they did not disappoint.  First off, if you have used Jabra earbuds before, these fit pretty much exactly the same, which is to say, they are exercise comfortable, by which I mean they stay firmly in place and aren't uncomfortable, but I wouldn't want to wear them for working at my desk or other non-pysical activities.  My biggest complaint is that you can't skip tracks using the device, you have to manually go to the device you are hooked up to.  I should also note that while I don't doubt the complaints about cutting in and out, I wear my phone in an armband when I run and haven't experienced this phenomenon, so proximity may play a role (although there is no excuse for a  Bluetooth device to be limited to such a short distance).  On the balance, these are great sport earbuds, and if they had the ability to skip tracks they would be solidly five stars.

Internet radios this size (I would call them countertop units) seem to have all converged on similar style for the time being.  An offset full color display, tuning knob and buttons, relatively painless wireless set-up and a remote of some sort.  In that regard the Grace unit reviewed here is pretty unremarkable, but it is a good looking and more than adequate device.  As I alluded to above it hits all the points you would expect, and produces decent, if not exactly spectacular sound from it's internal speaker (although I run mine through my stereo).  As one would expect, Pandora and a host of other listening options are available, as well as the ability to plug in your MP3 players.Again, there isn't a ton out there to differentiate this unit from every other internet radio out there, but it is good looking and provides all the options one would expect.  On the balance, it certainly isn't a bad choice at all.

This is a pretty cool little device to either replace or upgrade the stock sound card in your laptop.  Installation is a snap, just plug it in and follow the instructions, and I was genuinely surprised at the improvement in sound quality.  I'm not a huge audiophile, so if you are looking for technical specs, there are much better reviews available, but I will say that the improvement is more than slight; there is a marked, real upgrade.  The only downside to this device is that it is a little awkward hanging off the side of your laptop.  If you move your machine around a lot, there is always the risk of banging it into something, and potentially damaging it and/or the USB drive it is plugged into.  Accordingly, the people who are going to use this device to the fullest are those who keep their machine in more or less the same location all the time.  Other than that though, there is no denying the sound quality.

On the balance, I really enjoyed "Demi-Monde: Winter", the idea of populating a military simulation with some of history's worst sociopaths, and giving them free reign to wreak havoc after their own fashion, is simultaneously original, interesting and not wildly far-fetched.  Moreoever, the central conceit, that real humans can become trapped within the simulation is plenty believable to allow for the suspension of disbelief.  However, where there is potential for this proposed four book series to fall down, is the plot device that will drive future books.  I don't want to provide any spoilers, but in essence, this device shifts from the sci-fi basis of the novel and moves it closer to a sort of fantastical mysticism.  Now, to be fair, it may be that in future books this element will be re-grounded in the hard foundational hard sci-fi of the book, or it may feel more organic, and less grafted on as the series progresses.  However, with only one book to form an opinion on, I can definitely see this dichotomy becoming a problem in future installments.That said, for now I am willing to take things as they come.  The book is clearly meticulously researched, with historical figures acting in a believable fashion, without being carbon copies of their real world counterparts.  This is no minor accomplishment, as the author has taken a host of real life personalities and forced them to interact in entirely unexpected ways.  Moreover, the fictional characters are well drawn and blend surprisingly well with the electronic doppelgangers.Overall, this was a nice first start to a very original series.  Time will tell if its central premise proves compelling in the end, but for now "The Demi-Monde" represents and excellent first step on what promises to be an interesting journey.
Nice, sharp edge, comfortable grip, overall a very nice pair of scissors.  Plus with the titanium bonding the edge should last for much longer than a normal pair.

This drive can supposedly be reformatted to work with Windows operating systems, but I had absolutely no success with my Window 7 machine.  Not only did it fail to recognize it as an external drive, but the FAT32 reformatting software on Western Digital's website wouldn't install properly.  I would strongly recommend buying a dedicated Windows device instead of banking on this one, which is a shame because it's not much bigger than a wallet and is very portable.  That said, it did work just fine with a friend's Mac.

There's nothing particularly fancy about this putting green, but it gets the job done.  The surface putts nice and true and the pre-printed distance markers really help you think about what power you need at various distances.  Furthermore, the gravity return of the ball is a nice touch, although I wish the return track ran out further as balls tend to spray out randomly if you are putting from the furthest distance.  The mat rolls up easily for storage, making it ideal for use in a smaller space, or if you like to putt in your living room but don't want it out all the time.  Ultimately it hits all the points you would expect out of a putting green at a reasonable price point.Jake Mohlman

This is a really nice goal for youth soccer players; my older kids are 5 and 8 and while the 8 year old usually plays on full size nets, this is more than adequate for home practice, and it is ideal for the 5 year old.  Moreover, the easy set-up and tear down makes it perfect for yard use because it is easy to take down and set-up repeatedly, so you don't feel compelled to leave it up all the time, resulting in dead patched in your lawn.  The included bag also makes for easy transport to and from practice.  All in all, a really well thought out, well designed youth goal.

This is a pretty cool machine for die cutting paper for crafting.  I am not a crafter myself, but my wife is, so I got this item from Vine and set it up for her...what a colossal pain in the neck.  The provided documentation is atrocious, and if it weren't for the review of another Vine customer I might have given up; however, very solid set-up guidelines are available from You-Tube, and once I saw that I was able to get things working in relatively short order.  After the pain of the initial set-up, there is still a bit of a learning curve in terms of properly seating the paper, type of paper, etc. to maximize the abilities of this machine, but I don't think that's unreasonable given how sophisticated this device is.  I'm blown away at the precision of the cutting and the variety of options; the functionality borders on industrial, and I could certainly see this device being used in a small paper shop or craft store.Setting aside the frustration of set-up, this is a pretty neat device, but brace yourself to get over that set-up hump or you will give up before ever seeing that functionality.

This little oven is a remarkably versatile piece of kitchen equipment, that I probably would have never thought I needed, but now find myself using more and more every day.  It is a very effective toaster, with different settings for toast and bagels, and a six slice capacity which is appreciated in my household of six, but as I said in the title to this review, on the balance it is really an oven that toasts rather than the other way around.  With dedicated settings for baking, broiling and pizza, it offers a great alternative to heating up the entire oven for small food items.  To me, the perfect example is chicken tenders; normally if I wanted a few to throw on a salad, I would have had to heat the entire oven, which is incredibly wasteful given then small size of the item being cooked.  However, with this unit, I can heat up a much smaller volume, saving energy and wear and tear on my oven.I will concede that the settings are not immediately intuitive, and a little work on the interface wouldn't be a terrible idea (too many combinations of button/knob, or rather a lack of flow in how they are laid out).  That said, once you have them down after the first few uses you won't give it another thought.  My only real concern is that the unit is not very well insulated, so if you use it to bake/broil for an extended period of time the outside gets very hot.  I don't think it's a real fire risk (it's not THAT hot), but I think there is a potential for a minor burn, particularly for a child who might not know better than to avoid the sides.That said, with a measure of prudence that frankly should be applied to any kitchen appliance, this is a tremendously useful and versatile addition to any kitchen.Jake Mohlman

When we remodeled our master bath, we put in super-deep cabinets. That means that the wall-mounted mirrors are a long way away. My husband wanted a close-up mirror he could use when shaving, and we were glad when we found this one.The mirror is good quality. He uses the "normal" mirror most of the time, but the magnifying side is also sharp and clear. The hardware is sturdy. The mirror extends and swivels easily. This is not a lightweight mirror or mounting. In fact, you need to be sure to mount it on a stud or anchor it well so it doesn't pull out of the wall.The brushed nickel finish looks really good with our other brushed nickel hardware (faucets, towel racks, etc.).

We loved these fixtures when we saw them at a local lighting store. Unfortunately, they didn't  have any in stock. Amazon to the rescue! We bought two of these 3-light fixtures and one 4-light fixture in the same style, all in brushed nickel. All three arrived quickly in excellent condition and they look great in the bathroom.We put LED bulbs in all three fixtures. Keep in mind when choosing bulbs that the bulbs will be visible, at least partially, so choose bulbs that look nice with the fixtures. We chose some super-cheap LED bulbs at Lowe's ($2 each) that are perfect. Lots of light, and they look good, too.

We recently remodeled our master bath. My husband has a bad back and wanted a grab bar in the shower, but I didn't want one of those ugly things that look like they belong in an institutional setting. This was a great solution.We bought Delta Lahara faucets, and bought the matching towel racks, toilet paper holder and this grab bar. The grab bar matches everything beautifully, without losing any functionality. This bar is heavy and sturdy.The only downside is that it is pricier than other options, but considering what we paid for the rest of the bathroom, a few dollars extra for a grab bar that looked nice didn't seem like a big deal.

This is a clever idea--a box of nine assorted Hershey's candy bars, with 12 wrappers to quickly customize them for a gift giving occasion.There are three Hershey's Milk Chocolate bars, three Special Dark and three Cookies 'n' Creme. The wrappers cover birthday, congratulations, thank you or "write your own message."The wrappers are nicely designed and printed, and come with silver stickers to seal them, so with this kit on hand you are ready for those occasions when you need a quick, small gift for a friend or co-worker.The freshness dates on the candy bars I received are 8 -11 months in the future, so you could keep this on hand for some time for those gift giving occasions that spring up. Of course, that assumes you can keep them around that long without eating them. ;o)Because there are 12 wrappers and only nine bars, you could also buy a few extra candy bars and use them with the spare wrappers.

When I have tried microfiber towels in the past, I have not liked them. However, these dishcloths are absorbent and soft. They work great for general cleaning, such as washing windows, dusting and wiping counters. Because they are soft, they will not scratch delicate surfaces.I threw these in the washing machine and they came out looking like new. They have become my go-to cleaning and drying cloths in the kitchen. They look, feel and work great!

The color is beautiful. These dishcloths are a deep purple and they look fantastic.I washed them before using them. They came through the wash fine--no shrinkage or running colors.The dishcloths are absorbent and work well for typical kitchen clean up, such as wiping the counters. I think they would work well for washing dishes, their stated purpose.These dishcloths work hard and look great! I love having them in my kitchen.

This lightweight shapewear is comfortable, once it is on. I had a hard time getting it on without it bunching up. Taking it off was easy.It fit snugly, but wasn't tight. It stayed in place and stayed comfortable. Because it is lightweight, it wasn't too hot to wear.This is not the kind of shapewear that really holds you in, but it does give you a smoother line under your clothes.I will wear this, but I do not plan to buy another one.
