It is okay, but not my favorite shapewear as it doesn't really "shape."

The shirt is well-constructed and looks good on. The tailored waistline is flattering, and the shirt fits well. The buttons are concealed, giving the shirt a smooth look. It goes well with jeans or dressy slacks.Because the shirt includes a small percentage of Spandex, it has a little stretch. The shirt is not constricting and movement is easy.It washes well and looks good out of the dryer. It did not shrink in the washer or dryer.The one thing I do not like is that the shirt is thin and you can see right through it. If you are not wearing this with a jacket (and perhaps even if you are) you may want to wear a camisole with it.

These gloves are sturdy and hold up well. My husband used them while scrubbing a toilet bowl with a pumice stone, and the pumice did not damage the gloves. However, the gloves are thin enough that you have a good sense of touch through them.That is important, because hubby also works with plastic models, and these gloves are useful for handling small model parts while also handling paint, chemicals, etc.The fit was snug, but not uncomfortably so. They fit very well.if you need gloves for cleaning, painting, handling chemicals or other substances, keep a box of these around the house, garage or workshop.

This wrap is great for wearing after you step out of the shower. Trying to use a towel doesn't work well, because most towels are smaller than this wrap and do not have the Velcro closure to easily hold them in place.The microfiber fabric is soft and comfortable. Terrycloth would be more absorbent, but I am not using this to dry off, just as a cover up between showering and getting dressed.The Velcro closure holds the wrap in place with no irritation from the Velcro or the elastic band in the top of the wrap. I was concerned it would be too long, as I am just 5'1", however the length is just below my knees. The width of the fabric at the hem is about 64" and the length is 30.5"This is a nice wrap to use as a cover up, after a shower or at the pool.

The only ProActiv product I like and use is their refining mask. This is similar, but much better. After using it just once, my skin felt smoother. I had a few breakouts and the mask reduced the redness and appearance of them.The mask has a slightly gritty texture and the feel of a fine clay mask. There is a sandalwood scent that is light and pleasant.The directions on the package are confusing and contradictory. In one place it says the mask can be used 2 - 3 times a week. Immediately below that, it says to start with one application daily, then gradually increase to two times daily if needed. The 2 - 3 times a week direction seems right--you would not want to use this daily and certainly not more than once daily.I have used other Benzac products and been impressed. This is the best of a collection of good products.

I like Tresemme shampoos and conditioners, so I was looking forward to trying this. The directions say to use a small amount, one or two pumps, rub it on your hands, then apply it to the ends of your hair. It seems to make my hair slightly smoother, but I did not notice a big difference.There is a strong scent. I did not find it offensive, but it is strong. I noticed the scent as soon as I opened the mailbox, because the container was not well-sealed and product had leaked into the envelope.This is okay, but there are other products that do the job better.

These earrings are beautiful and comfortable to wear. They are so lightweight you won't know you have them on.The gold plating is elegant and has a beautiful tone and color. I have worn them several times and have not seen any wear.These are my new go-to earrings and I wear them often.

There are lots of buzzwords on the label: wholesome, organic, gluten-free (Huh? Is there syrup WITH gluten?), low glycemic, Non-GMO, etc. But the bottom line is that this is still sugar and should be consumed in moderation.Fortunately, a little of this syrup goes a long way. Do not expect it to taste like coconut. It is made from the coconut tree flower, not coconut meat.They say that it can be used as a 1:1 substitute for sugar, but you may find you can use less of this syrup than you would sugar. It is sweet, but it has a more complex flavor than plain ol' sugar. There are definitely tones of brown sugar/caramel here. A little bit on your waffles or pancakes is delicious.If you are looking for something different from high fructose corn syrup to put on your pancakes, give this a try.

I print mailing labels for products I ship in my business. I have used a variety of brands of labels, and Avery labels are always good quality.These labels are usually used with my Endicia software, and printed with my Brother laser printer. They line up well and are easy to work with. Avery offers templates at their website, but many programs (e.g., word processing, spreadsheets, mailing software, etc.) include templates for common Avery labels.I have never had a problem with Avery labels jamming or peeling, even in a hot laser printer. The labels have a smooth finish and the adhesive works well.This package is a good value. Unless you are a very high-volume user, 1500 labels should last a while.

This shampoo cleans my hair and scalp without leaving any residue. Additionally, my hair has very few tangles after shampooing, something that wasn't true with other shampoos (including the ones that contain conditioners).The scent is just "okay," but it is light and not noticeable.The shampoo lathers well and leaves my hair smooth. I will continue using TRESemme when this bottle is empty.

I have a hard time finding purses I like. This one is great! I have used it for about a year now and, although it isn't used every day, it has held up well during that year and still looks brand new. So, what makes this purse great?First of all, it looks nice. It is not real leather (of course) but it is attractive. The top closes with a zipper, which is more secure than the ones that only have a snap or no fastener at all. The stitching is tight and neat, and the handle is attached securely.There is an exterior zippered pocket that is perfect for holding my cell phone. There are also interior pockets for holding items you want to get to quickly.The bag is perfectly sized for carrying a tablet (such as my iPad) and/or a paper notebook or book. The bag is roomy and holds a lot, but doesn't feel or look bulky.And then there is the price. I hate paying a lot of money for purses, and this one is a great value.The next time I need a purse, I will skip shopping all over and settling for something that is sort-of what I want. Instead, I will come straight to Amazon, buy a Scarleton and get a purse I know I will love.

I was having severe pain from a pinched nerve in my neck when I discovered this product on Amazon. At that point anything seemed worth a try, so I ordered.This really works! Although I don't think it could have cured my pinched nerve (that took physical therapy) it definitely helped to relieve the pain.There are tabs so you can adjust how the device fits around your neck. You can also choose not to inflate the top ring if three rings make it too tall for your neck.What I found worked best for me was to fully inflate the bottom two rings, then open the channel to the third ring and pump several times. Immediate relief!The pump is easy to work--just remember to close the release valve before you start pumping. If the valve is open, the rings will not inflate.The cover is soft and it did not make my neck hot or sweaty. I wouldn't say it was "comfortable," but my neck felt much better with it on than with it off.

I bought two of the two packs, and have been using the cables for 6+ weeks. They work great, and you can not beat the price.I have purchased and used many AmazonBasics products over the years, and I am impressed with the quality and value. There has never been one that was not well made, none have had to be returned, and they all just did what they were supposed to do.Paying $20, $30 or more for a piece of cable seems ridiculous to me. Avoid the rip-offs and buy these.

Running the air conditioner in the Texas heat gets expensive. I wanted a fan that could help cool the family room (where we spend most of our non-sleeping time) without running the A/C constantly. My neighbors have a Lasko fan that is very similar to this one, and I was impressed by how well it worked.First of all, kudos to Amazon for super-fast delivery. I am a Prime member, but got it in one day, not two.The fan was packed securely, but easy remove from the box. All of the parts arrived in perfect condition. The assembly instructions were simple and I was able to attach the base in just a few minutes, working by myself. (HINT: Put the top of the fan on the floor, using the styrofoam ring from the package to hold it steady.) The base is steady on carpet as well as hard flooring surfaces.There are three speeds and even the lowest speed cranks out a stream of cool air. Although a fan does not actually cool the air, this one provides enough air movement that you feel a nice cooling breeze. (Crank it up and it feels a little windy!) I always run it in the oscillation mode to really move the air around the room.Ionizers seem like a gimmick to me, so I don't care one way or the other that this fan has one. If the blue light bothers you, turn off the ionizer. It shouldn't really make any difference.The one negative is that you need a clear line between the remote and the fan to use the remote. No waving the remote in the general direction of the fan while clicking a button, you need to aim carefully. Of course, you can also use the timer to let the fan turn itself off automatically.This fan is an excellent value. I plan to buy at least one more for my upstairs office.

The Slim Waister is a quality garment. It is comfortable, and gives a smoother line under clothing. The problem is that it is an awkward length. The waist rolls down instead of staying in place. If it were longer (ideally) or shorter, I think it would stay in place better.The fabric is comfortable, even when wearing the Slim Waster all day. If not for the problem of the waist band rolling, these would be perfect.

First, the basics: The planner includes monthly and weekly pages for July, 2015 - July, 2016. Each month gets a two-page spread with the entire month, followed by a two-page spread for each week. There are tabs dividing the monthly sections, so it is easy to find the date you want. There is ample room for notes. The three-year reference calendar in the front of the planner contains calendars for 2015 - 2017 all on one page. The back of the book includes pages for notes and contacts, a list of holidays and a map of the US and Canada showing area codes and time zones. The area codes are a bit small to read easily, but the time zone reference is handy. There is also a plastic pocket bound in to the back of the book, giving a place to put receipts or other small pieces of paper.This is a useful planner, but what about aesthetics? The cover is described as "faux leather," and it is more faux than leather. However, it is very soft and smooth and has a nice feel. The wire binding is orange, and there are pops of orange in the design. It is simple and attractive.The size makes this a bit large for most purses, but it fits well in a portfolio or laptop case.With the wire binding, you can open it to lay flat, or even fold it "backwards" so that the current week is on the outside of the planner and immediately accessible.This is a functional planner that looks very nice.

We use this rug on the hardwood floor in the foyer. It is beautiful and well-made. The colors are vibrant and the stitching around the edges is solid.The rug feels soft and plush. As I have with other rugs, I put a non-skid pad under the rug to keep it from sliding on the hardwood. Although the non-skid pads did not work with the rug I had in the same spot previously, this one stays in place nicely.This rug is an attractive and functional addition to the room.

I often end up plugging devices in all over the place, wherever I can find an open outlet. This (mostly) solves that problem.The stand will hold three items, so I can charge my iPod, iPad and iPhone all at once. My Kindle Fire (1st gen) doesn't fit in the slots, but I can charge it along with two other items by placing it next to the stand.Although I have not yet traveled with this charger, I see it being very handy in hotel rooms, where they seem to think we do not need access to electrical outlets. Finding one is usually manageable, but I am always worried that I will leave a device behind when I have the laptop plugged in one place, the iPad charging another, my phone in the bathroom, etc.It would be nice if the slots to hold the devices were a bit larger, but that would also make the charger bigger. The blue light would be annoying in a dark room, so I will have to cover it somehow when using it in a hotel room.Overall, this is easy to use and does what it is supposed to do. There are a couple of design tweaks that could make it better, but it is a useful device for anyone who needs to charge multiple small electronics.

Do you ever search for an answer with no luck, then suddenly have the solution appear, fully formed, in a flash of insight? Me, too. This book is about where those insights come from.The authors have conducted research on the topic, and their findings are interesting. Even better, they share ideas about how you can have more insights and creative ideas.Although written by scientists, The Eureka Factor is very readable for non-scientific minds, too. I like that they give practical ideas for putting their research to use in life, not just the lab.If you want to understand more about the brain, and how your brain can be more creative, pick up The Eureka Factor.

These gloves fit my somewhat small hands perfectly. They fit snugly, unlike some thicker, bulkier gloves.I use the gloves when doing household cleaning, and they protect my hands from the cleaning solutions. The texture makes it easy to grip things, even when my hands are soapy.The gloves are made to be worn on either hand. The gloves are disposable, but they can be worn several times. This box should last a long time!

If you like to be awakened gently, and not jolted awake by a blaring alarm, this clock radio is a good choice.The first thing you notice is that it doesn't look like other clock radios. The round face is lighted. The light comes on 30 minutes before the alarm time, and gradually gets brighter. It can also be turned on at any time for use as a bedside light. While not bright enough to read by, it is certainly bright enough to use while settling in at night or if you need to get up during the night. The touch controls on the face make it easy to turn the light on and off.In addition to the light, there are three choices of alarm sounds. Two are nature sounds (e.g., birds chirping) and the third is FM radio. There is a snooze feature. Tap the top of the device and the alarm stops for nine minutes.One negative is that there is no battery backup. When the power goes out, you have to reset the clock. However, I found that it didn't lose my alarm setting.It is easy to set the time, and the controls allow you to set the time ahead or back (nice for turning the clock back when daylight saving time ends).The brightness of the display is adjustable, so you can make it as bright or as dim as you wish. If you need a better view of the controls (e.g., to turn on the light or turn off the alarm) just touch the front and the controls illuminate.I have been using this for the last few weeks, and find it a pleasant way to wake up.

UPDATE 7/4/15: I wore three pairs of these shoes while pressure washing the driveway and sidewalks. They were FILTHY with dirt and mud. Threw them in the washer, let them air dry, and they are as good as new! I love these shoes!-------After buying several pairs of the Skyscape lace-up shoes, I bought a pair of slip-ons to wear on a flight. Love them! They are perfect for travel as they are comfortable to walk in, and they slip off and back on easily.The Skyscape shoes are some of the most comfortable I have ever owned. Although I do not have the shoe obsession that many of my gender possess, I own six pairs of Skyscape shoes (four lace-up and two slip-on). I wear them all the time.What you might want to know about fit: I usually wear a 7 Wide. In the lace-up versions of these shoes, I bought a 7-1/2 M because W is not available and I hoped that going up a half size would give enough room for my wide feet. They fit great. Many people say the slip-ons run large, so I bought 7M. They fit well when wearing thin socks or no socks, but they are a little snug when wearing thicker crew socks.

We usually use St. Ives facial scrub, but decided to give this a try. Very glad we did.Although it doesn't feel as gritty as St. Ives, it does exfoliate well with its wee scrubbing bits. The cleanser is soothing, with a gel consistency and a light citrus scent. Olay describes the scent as citrus-mint. I didn't really notice a mint scent, but there is a mild (pleasant, not burning) tingle when using this scrub. That might be from the mint.This scrub cleans and soothes the skin without being too abrasive or leaving a soapy residue. It feels good to use it. I think I have a new favorite!

Scotland is one of the places I want to see soon, so this book got my attention. It is an excellent reference for planning a trip to Scotland.There are four sections:  Plan Your Trip: an overview of when and where to go  On the Road: specifics of where to stay, where to eat and what to see, organized by region  Understand: history and culture of Scotland  Survival Guide: practical information, including a directory, glossary and indexThe guide includes lots of maps, including a pull-out folding city map of Edinburgh. There are suggested itineraries for trips from five days to two weeks.I started by reading section one, to get the big picture of what there is to see and do. Since then, I have been skipping around the book, reading about the different regions of Scotland and what they have to offer.Scotland is a beautiful country, and I can't wait to see it. Meanwhile, this book is helping me to prepare so I make the most of my trip.

I got this monitor to connect to my laptop for certain tasks, such as presenting webinars, where I need an extended desktop. I also connected the Fire TV Stick so that when I am not using it with my computer I can watch Amazon Instant Video.The picture quality with this monitor is excellent. Although my laptop does not have a Data Port connection, the picture doesn't flutter or hang up when browsing the web or watching video.The height, angle and orientation of the monitor are easy to adjust for comfortable viewing.I am using this with a Dell Inspiron laptop running Windows 7. It did not work as "plug and play," but I installed the driver from the included disk and everything worked. Easy installation.This monitor works well for computing and watching video. It is an excellent addition to my home office.

This is a great idea, but it doesn't work as well as I'd hoped. When I used it to take my husband's temperature, the readings were reasonably consistent (within .1 degree or so) but my readings were off by .5 degrees or more.It is easy to use. Just turn on the power, then press the thermometer button. There is a screen that shows when you are at the correct distance from the person's forehead, and the reading is taken. It is up to you to position the thermometer properly--an illustration on the device shows where to aim the light to get an accurate reading.I think that with practice it is possible to get more consistent readings; however, this is one of those things that you need to be able to trust. Having to get the technique exactly right in order to get an accurate reading is a problem. Also, it does seem to work better when taking someone else's temp than taking your own.If you decide to use one of these thermometers I would recommend practicing before anyone gets sick so you know how it works and can use it properly.

This book is great for people who like to know a little bit about a lot of things. I am one of those people.The sections do not have to be read in order--just pick up the book and read a few random pages.There is not depth to any of these guides. You are not actually going to be qualified to be a gastroenterologist, Formula One driver, butler or even a Casanova (!) just by reading a couple of heavily-illustrated pages. However, there are some great tips waiting to be picked up on health, sports, art, food and drink and other topics.If you are a fan of those TV shows about how things are made, or you just like to learn random things, you will have fun with this book.

This is handy in at least two situations. It is nice to have a way to tote my iPad, a notebook and a few essentials when I go to meetings. This little case has pockets for a tablet and paper, as well as a zippered compartment for keys, credit cards and other must-haves.When I travel, I like to have something to hold items I may want during the flight, including iPad or iPod, earbuds, magazine, notebook, etc. This case holds things together in a compact space that easily slips into a larger bag or backpack and can be pulled out for the flight.It appears to be well-made and should hold up through a lot of use. The materials and stitching feel sturdy, as does the zipper.This is a small case, so you can not carry everything you would toss into a large purse or computer case. However, for those times when you need to have easy access to a few vital items, this case in an excellent choice.

I am a sucker for office supplies. I love pens, notebooks and cool fasteners. Index cards are right up near the top of my list of favorite things. (Okay, that's a little weird. I embrace my inner office supply geek.)I grabbed this product as soon as I saw it. The note cards come in an acrylic tray, making it easy to keep them nearby on the desktop.The cards themselves are not very heavy--more paper than cardstock, but they have a nice feel to them. The cards are printed with a small grid pattern, so you can use them for sketches as well as lists and notes. They have a space for the date at the top right, and the days of the week printed in the top left corner. A metallic copper edge on the cards give them an attractive look when they are stacked in the tray.This is a new product and I have not seen refills with only the cards, however, they may become available at some point. Even if they don't, the tray holds standard 4" x 6" cards, so another style of card could be used in the tray. Of course, they probably wouldn't have that cool copper edge!

There is a cool factor with this grater. The color and style make it an attractive addition to the kitchen.So does it work? I used it to grate cheese and loved how easy it was to use. The cheese was finely grated and the ratchet made quick work of grating a block of hard cheddar.The only problem came when it was time to clean the grater. It comes apart and can be put in the dishwasher; however, taking it apart is tricky. There are two buttons (one on each side) that have to be pressed while pulling the ratchet mechanism out. I found it difficult to press both buttons with enough force while also pulling out the mechanism. There is a similar release on the compartment where you put the food to be grated, but that was easier to work.Once disassembled, the grater is easily cleaned on the top rack of the dishwasher.For quickly grating a bit of cheese, you can use your old-fashioned cheese grater. When you have a lot of grating to do, or you want to impress your guests, reach for this grater instead.

This is a relatively short book, but there is a lot of "filler." I learned much more than I wanted to about people and events that had little or nothing to do with the theme of the book.For me, one bright spot is the telling of the author's participation in a two-day wirewalking class with Philippe Petit, who walked between the twin towers of the World Trade Center in 1974. The description of Petit's instruction and Fusselman's experience in the class made me wish I could take such a class from him, even though I have a fear of heights. Because such an opportunity is highly unlikely, I will settle for being inspired by watching and listening to him on film and video. That is something I probably would not have done had I not read this book, so I thank Amy Fusselman for awakening the interest in me.Other parts of the book were less interesting to me. Was it worth reading? Overall, yes, but had it been longer, I do not believe I would have read the entire book.

When it comes to cat litter, there are three major criteria:Will they use it?Does it do away with the odor?Does it work without a mess?This litter scores on all three.We have two cats. I added some to one of their two litter boxes, and that box saw the most action. Clearly, the cats like it.We noticed no odor from the box. The male cat had developed a habit of not covering, but he does with this litter. Definitely a plus. I also do not like it when the litter has a fragrance, as that is sometimes almost as bad as what it is trying to cover. This is free of fragrance.With some litter, they "dig for China" and toss litter all around. They didn't with this, and I didn't notice a significant amount of tracking.We are very happy with this litter, and the cats are, too. Now I just need to pick up another package for the upstairs litter box.

I have a Microplane Zester/Grater that works very well, so let's compare the OXO to that one.The OXO grates to a fine zest, but the Microplane zest comes out a bit finer. I don't see this is a pro or con for either one. Both do a very good job.There are a couple of things I prefer about the OXO. It is easier to clean than the Microplane because the grating surface is not curved. Both clean pretty easily, though, so this is not a major point.The way the Microplane is made, you have to hold it in your hand to zest or grate. The OXO has an angled handle and the end is flat, so you can place it on a cutting board or counter and grate without holding it in your hand. It makes grating and zesting a little easier. (Of course, you can hold it to zest if you wish.)One feature that many will like is the the OXO costs a few dollars less than the Microplane.Both graters work well, and I will continue to use both. If you are looking for a zester, consider the OXO. It is well-designed, effective and will save you some cash.

I love the recipes in the previous Artisan Bread in Five Minutes a Day books, and this is a great addition for those who need to get gluten out of their diets.The concept works as advertised: You stir up some ingredients, let them stand for a bit, then bake a loaf of bread or put the dough in the refrigerator until you are ready to use it. By preparing the dough ahead, you always have some ready to go, so you can make bread with just a few minutes of work. (The five minutes doesn't include standing time or baking time, just the time you work with the dough.)This book works much the same as the others in the series. The difference is in the ingredients. There is one extra step here, where you mix up the flours that go into the master recipe. The basic all-purpose flour is a combination of:white rice flour (or brown rice flour)sorghum (or oat flour or amaranth flour)tapioca flour or starch (or arrowroot starch or cornstarch)potato starchxanthan gum (or ground psyllium husk)The options are given in case you have difficulty locating a particular ingredient, or just prefer one over another. Most of the ingredients should be familiar to anyone trying to cook gluten-free.There is also a whole-grain version of the flour mixture, and some recipes call for the addition of other flours, such as coconut flour.If you love bread, but are trying to avoid gluten, you will love this book. The recipes include many familiar, traditional breads, as well as flatbreads, pizza and pastries (even cinnamon rolls!). There are beautiful color photos for many of the recipes, and the directions are simple and clear.

I have used several Seventh Generation products, so I was eager to try this one.The scent is light and pleasant, not strong and chemical.The spray top can be set to stream or mist. Either way, there is more control than you get with aerosol cleaners.It cleaned oily fingerprints from drawers, and got dust and dirt out of intricate designs on wooden bed posts.This is a cleaner, not a polish. It will not leave your wood shiny, but it will be clean and without the sticky residue many of those polishes leave behind.This is another excellent product from Seventh Generation.NOTE: Although some reviewers have mentioned using it on wood floors, the bottle says not to do so.

Tasha doesn't play, so she ignored this. However, Simba loves to play, and he went right after this toy.The random motion kept his attention for quite a while. He jumped at it, grabbed the wand in his mouth, swatted at the feathers, and got smacked in the face by them a few times. All in all, a good time was had.At first I put it on the kitchen tile floor. It moved about until it got on a grout line. That kept it from moving freely. It did better on the carpet. I think the best surface would be something very flat and even, and Simba seemed to have the most fun with it on the marble hearth.So far the feathers have survived several play sessions. Simba can be a bit destructive, but he has not managed to eat the feathers yet.If you have playful kitties, this should keep them entertained.

Our two kitties always have two bowls of dry food available. Currently, their favorite is Nutrience Natural Healthy Adult Cat Food, 18-Pounds, Turkey, Chicken and Herring. They were happy to try the Pride food when I put it out, and the first bowl disappeared quickly.After a couple of weeks, they have decided that they prefer the Nutrience food over this Pride food. They still eat both, but this one clearly has come in second. I think if I only put out the Pride food they would happily eat it, they just like the other a bit better.The food seems to be tasty (I am relying on the cats here, as I have not tasted it.) and made of quality ingredients. So would I buy another bag? Maybe. As I mentioned, they always have two foods available, so I would consider this as a second flavor to keep on hand. One strike against it is the price. It is more expensive than many other foods that they like as well as this one. However, one thing to keep in mind if you are considering this as the primary food for your cat(s) is that they typically need to eat less of the quality foods than the "low-cost" foods. This can bring the prices closer together, so it is worth comparing the cost per serving. Even considering that, the Nutrience (also a quality food) that they prefer is much less expensive than this one.

Installation is easy--just slip it on the shower pipe.The caddy is lightweight metal and plastic, but the construction seems solid. There are two shelves, two hooks (for shower puffs or washcloths) and two hooks for razors. The top shelf has round holes to hold shampoo or body wash bottles upside-down.The blue trim is attractive and gives the caddy a different look than others.The one negative is that if the weight of the bottles is not well-balanced, the caddy tips. It would be nice to have suction cups to hold the caddy in place.Overall, this is a nice caddy and a good value.

This set is attractive and useful. It is definitely a good set of cookware for the price.I love the bright red color and the glass lids. Even better, the lids each have a small round vent in them, to let heat and steam escape while you cook. That is a nice feature that can keep the pots from boiling over. The handles on the pans and lids are sturdy and easy to grip.These pots are a bit on the small side, so they are best suited for singles and couples. The Thermo-spot heat indicator is not really needed, but it does slightly change when the pan heats up.All of the pieces clean easily. Although T-fal says you can put them in the dishwasher, they are easy to clean by hand.Most of my cookware is Chantal, but I like having more non-stick pieces to fill in. I use this set regularly and like it.

UPDATED (Added one star): I brought this food out again and fed it to Nigel now and then. He seems to like it now, but still won't eat it consistently.=====Nigel is a picky eater. With a new food he usually eats it well once or twice, then never eats it again. I could not get him to eat this food at all. Usually when that happens, I can feed him a few pieces as if it is a treat. It may take a couple times of him spitting it out then picking it back up before he eats, but I can get him to try the new food. Not this time. He would not go near it, and would not take the food in his mouth at all.He loves the Natural Balance Pumpkin and Chicken Meal Formula with Papaya Dental Chews for Small to Medium Dogs, 13-Ounce. They have become a favorite treat for him, and they seem to help his breath. I thought he might enjoy this food also, but no.If your dog is less picky, this might work out better for you. One note about the packaging: It does not have a perforated tear line to open the bag (you have to cut it open), and the bag is not resealable.

I didn't find any earth-shattering revelations in this book; however, I enjoyed reading the stories and picking up little nuggets of wisdom and inspiration. I liked it a lot.There are 75 lessons in the book, each short enough to be read in just a few minutes. Although you could read through the book page-by-page, a better way might be to scan the table of contents and go to the lesson that calls to you at that moment. Or just open to a random page and begin reading the next lesson.Whether a particular lesson is exactly what you need right now, or just a nice reinforcement of something you already knew, the book is an easy, pleasant read.Pick it up, read a few pages and turn your light bulb on.

I was looking forward to reading this book, but the reality was quite disappointing.The authors come across as shallow and self-absorbed. James clearly has family issues and Claudia has relationship issues. They both write a lot about death and dying.I finally said "no" to forcing myself to finish reading this book. Reading it made me depressed and angry. Stopping made me feel better. So I guess I did learn something from it.

EDITED TO ADD: There have been questions about this, so here goes: These treats are made at a plant in Colorado. The package does not say that they are made in the USA, but the company has confirmed that to me. They say the packaging will be changed to note that they are made in the USA. We now return you to our regular programming. ;o)---My 11-year-old miniature poodle can be fussy about what he eats. We had not found a dental chew that he would eat consistently until these. Most just become dog toys, and he plays with them from time to time but never actually eats them.The first time I gave Nigel one of these treats he took it into the other room and left it on the floor. I thought we had another treat fail until a little later when I saw that it was gone. On subsequent days, he ate the treat right away without playing hard to get.Normally, Nigel's breath could peel paint. With just a few days of using these treats I started noticing a difference. His breath is not spring fresh, but definitely better than it was.I like that the treats are chewy and not hard. I think that one reason he doesn't eat the other dental chews is that they are hard and it may be uncomfortable to chew them. These take some chewing to finish, but they are not hard and crunchy.Although these treats are pricy, Nigel likes them and they seem to be good for him. The one negative is that they have a fairly strong pumpkin smell. One treat isn't bad, but it is kind of overpowering when you open the bag.I will continue giving these to Nigel as long as he likes them and eats them, but I may try some of the other flavors to give him some variety.

This product is a mild astringent that works well to clean my face. It has a mild citrus scent, which I found much more pleasant than the scents used in many similar products.The tonic is refreshing, and leaves my skin feeling clean, with no residue.It is recommended that you use this as part of a "system." I am not a fan of buying multiple products and having a complicated regimen, however, I liked using this tonic after washing my face at night. It removed any makeup or dirt that washing didn't get.

My very finicky miniature poodle only eats Beneful. I have tried many other foods and he generally won't eat them more than once.He has not fallen in love with this food, but I have been able to get him to eat it. That is a major accomplishment!This seems to be a good food. The first ingredient listed is chicken, followed by brown rice and whole grain oats. The pieces of kibble are very small, perfect for small dogs.The bag has a Velcro closure, so it is easy to close and stays closed.My dog likes this food. If your dog is more normal than mine, he will probably love it. ;o)

I am a long-time Judy Greer fan. When she turns up on a favorite TV show (Big Bang, Two and a Half Men, HIMYM, etc.) it is always the sign of an entertaining episode. And her performance in The Descendents was amazing. She is usually not the star, but always memorable. Although the book includes her story of how taking $20 made her so anxious that there were...unfortunate physical results, she apparently has no problem stealing scenes from her co-stars. ;o)Judy gives us a glimpse into the life of a working actress, telling a bit about auditions, life on location, etc. I would have liked even more of this, to learn about some of the interesting experiences she must have had in her career. Not a tell-all, just a few more good stories.There are good stories here about her life away from the set. Judy shares some of her day-to-day life with a husband she adores, two step kids she is learning to relate to, a dog with digestive issues, and parents with whom she has a close and loving relationship. Oh, and her friends, who are just as crazy (in a good way, of course) as Judy.This is a light, fun read. I enjoyed reading it and even laughed out loud a few times. Take a look at IMDB if you don't know where you might have seen her. Then, while you are recalling her performances and smiling, get a copy of her book.

I read a lot of books about influence, personal branding, creating relationships and similar topics. If I get a couple of good ideas, I consider them worthwhile.Denise Brosseau defines seven steps to becoming a thought leader:Find Your Driving PassionBuild Your Ripples of InfluenceActivate Your AdvocatesPut Your "I" on the LineCodify Your Lessons LearnedPut Yourself on S.H.O.U.T.Incite (R)EvolutionSomething I appreciated was that Brosseau recognizes that many of the people reading this book may already be on their journey to becoming a thought leader. The Getting Started section includes a checklist of 30 building blocks. She suggests checking off each one you have already mastered, then gives "permission" to jump to the section you need now, rather than working through the book from beginning to end. The checklist is a simple diagnostic that can help you determine where you need to put in more effort and what you have accomplished so far.Becoming a thought leader is not something that happens overnight. However, with the ideas in this book you can start building your authority and reputation today.

Getting advice on inventing, manufacturing and marketing a product from someone who has been there, done that is valuable. In this book, Lori Greiner provides a road map to go from idea to success. Chapters include:Is Your Idea a Hero or a Zero?How to Get FundingThe Truth About PatentsThe Dream Becomes Tangible - Manufacturing and PackagingBeyond Brick and Mortar (about QVC, of course)Keep the Dream Going - Expand and Diversifyand many othersEach chapter includes the basics, but it also includes insights from Lori's experience that give you the benefit of her experience. There are also tips highlighting the most important points in each chapter.Reading this book and following Lori's advice won't guarantee that you will become a millionaire, but you will certainly have a better chance with this book than without it.

We have two cats. One of them is a 13-pound Siberian. About 11 pounds of that is hair, so having something to help control hairballs is important. Of course, if he doesn't eat it, it doesn't matter if the ingredients are high quality or if it helps reduce hairballs.I put out two flavors of dry food everyday. When I mixed this with their turkey-flavor food, the bowl was empty in no time. They have largely ignored the salmon food in favor of the bowl that included this food.So both kitties love this food. And it seems to work on the hairballs.Love the bag, too. The resealable bag uses Velcro. Awesome! No struggling with those seals that never seem to want to seal.The food is a little pricy. You  may want to consider buying the 7-pound bag instead of the 3.5-pound bag, as the price per pound is almost 30% less.

Are you wondering how to get attention for your Internet business? This book lays out 10 simple strategies for helping customers discover your business without spending money. (There are also a few ideas you can use if you have a marketing budget, but the 10 basic strategies are free.) Each strategy also includes bonus tips, showing how you can take the strategy further.The book is a quick read, so you can put what you learn to use right away. Additionally, the book is professionally edited and designed, so it is easy to read and nice to look at.Want to attract more customers? Try one, two or more of the strategies in this book.

I love caramels, and keep a few Werther's Chewy Caramels in my candy jar at all times.The Lancaster Soft Cremes are not exactly caramels, but they are wonderful. These candies are softer than caramels and melt in your mouth. The flavor is rich, creamy and buttery.According to the package, one serving is seven candies. That seems like a lot. I usually have one or two for a sweet treat after dinner and can't imagine eating seven in an entire day. Seven pieces have 180 calories, so that's about 25 calories in each piece. Not bad for such a decadent treat!Lancaster Soft Cremes will not replace my Werther's Creamy Caramels, but they will definitely have a place in the candy jar along with them.

Both Post-its and Evernote are very useful products; however, combining them seems to complicate both unnecessarily.These Post-its are very nice for use as originally intended: make notes, stick them to things. The colors are very bright and vivid--I love that! These are Super Sticky Notes, and they do seem to adhere well, even after sticking and unsticking a few times.Where they lost me is with the idea that you should make a note on an appropriate colored Post-it, then photograph it with your phone and upload it to Evernote. Really? Why not just make a note in Evernote?These Post-its are more expensive than most. Whether that is because they come with a free month of premium Evernote service or just because of the Evernote name, I don't know that they are worth the price as a routine purchase. However, if you want to give Evernote Premium a try, and you like Post-its, go for it.

Bringing any new dog into your family can pose challenges, and there are also challenges unique to adopting a rescue dog. Although it is written especially for those who have chosen (or been chosen by) a rescue, this book covers about any issue you may encounter with your new canine family member.The author clearly has a lot of love for dogs, and that shows in every part of this book. There are lots of stories about the dogs that have been a part of her life and even some adorable pictures!Dogs love to please their humans, but despite our best intentions we may set them up to fail. Bonding with Your Rescue Dog gives you the knowledge and skills you need to create a lifelong bond with your rescue dog. Read it today--your doggie will thank you!

TED Talks feature the best-of-the-best speakers with powerful messages. If you want to learn about being a better public speaker, studying TED presenters seems like a good place to start.Talk Like TED teaches nine secrets on how to give a great TED talk (or any talk). They are:1. Unleash the Master Within2. Master the Art of Storytelling3. Have a Conversation4. Teach Me Something New5. Deliver Jaw-Dropping Moments6. Lighten Up7. Stick to the 18-Minute Rule8. Paint a Mental Picture with Multisensory Experiences9. Stay in Your LaneMost importantly, there are lots of examples to go along with those nine secrets. And every TED Talk is as close as your computer, tablet or phone.Maybe you will never give a TED talk. That's okay--you will still benefit from the lessons in this book. In fact, even if you do give speeches or other formal presentations, your communication skills will improve and you will become more persuasive when you apply the nine secrets.

For certain there are provocative elements for its day contained within the narrative of "The Couch" like patricide and incest but by today's standards they are quite dated.  The film plays like a homage (rip-off?) of Hitchcock most notably "Psycho" but that comparison only demonstrates why this film is lacking.  Puzzling because Robert Bloch who wrote the story that was the basis for "Psycho" wrote the script here based on a story by Blake Edwards and Owen Crump.  I think you can look no further than the flat direction of Crump and a ham-handed lead performance by star Grant Williams who won't make you forget Anthony Perkins' Norman Bates.  A curio at best that earns its obscurity.

I bought this one for my mother because I knew she was a big Ronald Reagan fan.  She explained to me that the stage play this was based on was quite the scandal in its day and the film was considered morally objectional in some quarters at the time of its release.  In a day where "Fifty Shades of Gray" is considered appropriate Valentines fare I had to check out this allegedly salacious exercise.  Having seen it the film is as harmless as "Teletubbies".  The film concerns itself with the growing relationship between aspiring actress Sally (Eleanor Parker) and nice guy G.I. Bill (Reagan).  Sally has foresworn love because her heart has been broken one time too many and Bill has seen his share as well but is ready to take a chance again.  The kids next door chemistry between Parker and Reagan is evident and you want their characters to make a go of it.  Eve Arden is on hand for comic relief as Parker's man crazy pal and Reagan's ex.  The film's stage origins are obvious taking place the majority of the time at Parker's apartment but it does not feel stagy or claustrophobic.  A genuine sleeper for romantics of all stripes.

Melissa McCarthy is absolutely fearless.  She could take the safe route by making sequels to "Identify Thief" but chooses to extend herself and fly without a net.  There is no doubt that she is up to the comedic requirements of her role as CIA handler turned field agent but who knew that she could master the physical aspects of the role.  Props also to Jason Statham who lampoons his action hero persona here by playing a real twit.  I also liked Miranda Hart as McCarthy's nervous colleague from Langley.  The central plot involving an arms deal is serviceable but superfluous being the vehicle for the comedy and action.  Along with "Kingsman-The Secret Service" these are the best espionage comedies since "True Lies".  Look fast for McCarthy's real life spouse, Ben Falcone, as a tourist with a hankering for Popeye's.

Director William Conrad reasonably ratchets up the atmospherics in his house of horrors picture.  For sure the twist ending delivers the goods.  What I can't help thinking is this film could have been so much better if it were tightened up a bit making it more effective.  There are long dead stretches where nothing much happens which robs the film of its true potential.  Regardless, a decent offering that is much at home over some lesser flicks this Halloween season.

This flick has the ingredients for a decent shocker.  Spooky chateau.  Eerie shrouded guys.  Paganism.  Black magic.  Donald Pleasence. What it lacks is a coherent narrative.  The storyline is so ludicrous that all potential scares are deflated from the enterprise.  One plus is that siblings played by David Hemmings and Sharon Tate make for a creepy pair.  Tragically murdered before her prime Tate reminded me of a young Keira Knightley.  Despite its flaws the film is watchable.  Regardless, a disappointment when you consider the star power in this one.  David Niven and Deborah Kerr are definitely in paycheck mode here.

What director William Conrad successfully attains in this Hitchcock homage is a foreboding sense of the supernatural.  For a goodly part this account of a couple possibly reincarnated from doomed ancestors from a century ago is effective if not for some telegraphing of the twist ending by star Troy Donahue.  Regardless the film is mostly a success and Conrad has gathered a terrific ensemble.  High point is Joey Heatherton salaciously swiveling her hips and posterior to a jazzy ditty playing on the radio.  Conrad's unmistakable voice can be heard in cameo on a police radio.

I was skeptical when I heard two actors were playing Brian Wilson.  Having now seen the film and how it's structured it's a terrific concept.  The film flashes back and forth in time with Paul Dano playing Wilson during his peak creative period and John Cusack playing him probably 25 years later while his psyche is fragile and his life is being dominated by Svengali like "medical guardian", the parasitic Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti).  It's a brilliant conceit that meets it's fruition when the two distinct Brians  compliment each other and meld into a single entity towards the film's heart wrenching conclusion.  I was fortunate to have seen Brian in concert three times including the masterful stage recreation of "Pet Sounds" in 2000 and I can say conclusively that both actors have channeled his essence in their performances most notably Cusack.  Cusack has Brian's ticks and mannerisms down pat but compromises none of the humanity in the process.  There are plenty of villains to go around aside from the aforementioned Landy.  You have Brian's vicious father Murry and his cousin, Mike Love, who in Machiavellian fashion wanted to wrest control of the Beach Boys going as far as kicking Brian out of the band during the notorious "bed" period.  The film's most prominent hero is Melinda Ledbetter (Elizabeth Banks) who sees sweetness and sensitivity in Brian and attempts to extricate him away from the controlling psychotherapist.  One of the film's other successes is how director Bill Pohlad establishes time and place.  The recreation of the "Pet Sounds" and the aborted "Smile" sessions is nothing short of jawdropping.  This is probably the best musical biography since "The Buddy Holly Story" in 1978.  Undeniably the best picture I've seen this year and probably some other years.

Never have the troubles that plagued Northern Ireland been portrayed as succinctly as shown in "71".  The hostilities between the Catholic and Protestant population isn't as cut and dry as would be assumed more akin to the quagmire that was Southeast Asia that ran concurrent with the events portrayed in this film.  There are divisions within the Catholic militants likewise with their Protestant counterparts.  Throw into the mix loyalists, collaborators, and British undercover operatives you would be hard pressed to discern friend from foe.  The film focuses on young Gary Hook(Jack O'Connell), a British conscript sent to Belfast to police the unrest.  Separated from his platoon during a skirmish with Catholic locals Hook has to navigate the hostile landscape of the strife torn city to get back to the safety of his barracks.  His fear and anxiety is palpable and his every step is a potential landmine.  Director Yann Demange helms this tautly intense film with an assured hand allowing the audience to view events through the frightened eyes of Hook.  The success of the film is that it offers a fresh perspective on events in recent history that can't be explained in black-and-white terms.

This has to rank as one of the most boring films I've ever seen.  Nothing of consequence happens in this inert exercise and if it did I blinked.  Story never gets off the ground and the direction by actor Alan Rickman is plodding.  Workmanlike performances by Kate Winslet and Matthias Schoenaerts are left dangling in the wind.  Romance between the two characters is never truly developed ergo no spark in the tentative love scenes that are contrived here.  The best thing you can say for the film is it is a handsome looking period piece but that only goes so far. Narratively speaking the film could have used a little chaos to attain viewer interest.  The cinematic equivalent to a sleeping pill.

Unfortunately, the dubious reputation of this film precedes it.  In reality it's not a latter day "Heaven's Gate" but more a marketing challenge.  Truthfully, how do you sell a Depression era Shakespearean tragedy?  If you can cite a flaw in the film it's the flat performance by Jennifer Lawrence in the title role.  Lawrence work is okay in the early stages of the film but at the film's crucial midpoint she goes awry.  In demonstrating the malevolence of Serena Lawrence resorts to a comical faraway stare not unlike a refugee from a Kubrick film.  Regardless, this misreading does not prove to be fatal because Susanne Bier's direction is fluid and the script, based on Ron Rash's novel, is tight and literate. The picture looks great and the period is evoked nicely.  I'll take this ambitious offering over most of the cookie cutter fare offered up by Hollywood any day.

Despite the unique setting this film doesn't break any new comic ground but gets a pass for good vibes.  The plot concerns a milquetoast reporter (Robert Morse) and a womanizing photographer (George Maharis) jettisoned to an underground naval base in Antarctica cooking up a scheme to coerce a Russian scientist (Michael Constantine) to defect by flying attractive women into what was previously an all male conclave.  The cast is engaging notably Anjanette Comer as a Kiwi stewardess and Yvonne Craig as Morse's fianc√©.  Tackles Cold War politics with a feather duster as opposed to a sledgehammer.  A piece with "The Russians are Coming, The Russians are Coming" which came a few years later.

I came.  I saw.  I liked. How can one not with the Osmonds blaring over the opening credits.  What was it all about?  Closest I can figure is it's a dark comedy advocating abstinence.  How else do you account for the fact that all of the victims with one glaring exception are promiscuous nubile teenagers?  Sure our nominal protagonist, Ponce (John David Carson), gets deflowered by Angie Dickinson but everybody knows that there has always been a double standard in Hollywood with the boys and girls.  As a thriller it shows its cards much too soon.  I figured out whodunit by reading the back of the DVD case. That said the titillation factor is primary here with the cloak and dagger aspect an afterthought.  Some seem genuinely surprised that Gene Roddenberry would be connected with this enterprise but if anybody remembers the barely there outfits of the female characters on "Star Trek" it shouldn't be a shock.  Regardless, see the film for the terrific performances by Rock Hudson, Dickinson, and Telly Savalas.  Not to all tastes for sure but those with a skewed sensibility this may be for you.

A young associate buyer (Ann-Margret) goes to Paris for the ritzy department store she works for.  In the process she garners the attention of a department store heir (Chad Everett), a high profile designer (Louis Jourdan), and a jaded news reporter (Richard Crenna).  The burning questions are who will she pick and will she maintain her virtue in the process.  If you don't know the answers then you haven't seen enough of these kind of flicks.  Undisputable formulaic fluff but in fairness the film doesn't have the pretensions of pretending to be anything else.  This film wasn't meant for me but my wife loved it.

It may be a surprise to some and a shock to others that renowned British comedian Terry-Thomas made a predominately dramatic film.  On the same token some of his fans will welcome this departure from form and others incensed when you consider that the distributor of this DVD, Sinister Cinema, is marketing it as a straight comedy.  You would then ask how does he do?  Quite well, thank you.  Terry-Thomas finds himself quite adept in assaying the more serious elements of the story while appropriating elements of his comic persona in his portrayal of an inspector for the World Health Organization. In a nutshell his work here isn't on the level of an Alec Guinness ("Bridge on the River Kwai") but comparable to Peter Sellers ("Hoffman") when they strayed into the dramatic.  The film is diminished somewhat however by trite movie-of-the-week plotting which concerns the manhunt for the carrier of the smallpox virus.  The main story is straight out of "Quincy" or "CSI" ending up in James Bond territory.  Reservations aside I would recommend this as a must for Terry-Thomas fans which in a perfect world should be everybody.

Terry-Thomas' status as one of Britain's renowned comedians is only diminished by the long shadows cast by Peter Sellers and Alec Guinness.  This double billing is a terrific primer for his inimitable brand of stiff upper lip tomfoolery.  The highlight of this set would have to be "Make Mine Mink" where Terry-Thomas plays a retired army major who along with his fellow boarders decide to pinch and fence mink clothing and donate the proceeds to their landlady's favorite charity in order to alleviate the monotony in their lives.  Best bits are a cheeky reference to "The Third Man" and a deliciously funny ending.  "Too Many Crooks" has its moments but it isn't as fresh as "Make Mine Mink".  The scenario has Terry-Thomas as a tightwad businessman whose wife is mistakenly kidnapped by bumbling hoods who think they've nabbed his beloved daughter.  His reaction is priceless as he refuses to pony up a penny of the ransom.  Highlight would be the scene where he repeatedly rushes into his burning house to recover money he hid under the floorboards.  This film probably influenced "Ruthless People" some years later but this is the better film by a tick.

The most distinct impression you get from "The Night Digger" is the obvious influence of Alfred Hitchcock.  There's a certain psychosexual aura that permeates the proceedings but, alas, director Alastair Reid has the minutia of the Master down pat but is at a loss in the suspense department.  The nature of the misogynist killer, Billy Jarvis (Nicholas Clay), is revealed much too early depriving the film of a much needed pulse.  That said this film should be seen for the terrific performances of the leads.  Patricia Neal has never been better as the physically and emotionally scarred caregiver Maura Prince.  Probably in her mid-forties at the time the film was made and recovering from a life threatening stroke Neal makes Maura a pillar of strength even while the character she plays is breaking up inside.  Neal even uses the effects of her stroke to her advantage imbuing dimension to her performance. Pamela Brown avoids clich√©  managing to engender some sympathy as Maura's mean spirited and controlling adoptive mother.  Clay's work recalls Anthony Perkins' turn as Norman Bates in "Psycho" and makes Billy wholly original and empathetic.  "The Night Digger" is ultimately a film that falls short of its lofty ambitions but worth checking out.

Preceding the opening credits the makers of the film proudly herald that this film was made without the cooperation of the U.S. military establishment.  My first thought was this was another post-Vietnam anti-military film in the mode of "M*A*S*H".  Before you get your dander up what is offered onscreen  is so insignificant and negligible as to give mediocrity a bad name.  This is an enterprise made wholly out of cynicism designed to burn your brain cells.  Don't waste your time on this forgettable tripe.  Anthrax is preferable.

This trilogy of short films directed by John Ford is informed by his earlier works set in Ireland.  Whereas "The Informer" and "The Quiet Man" were outright homeruns this exercise is an admirable but decidedly mixed bag.  The first entry, "The Majesty of the Law", is a whimsical account of a proud Irishman consenting to his arrest for assaulting his neighbor only on his terms.  The story here is funny but a little thin.  The middle film, "A Minute's Wait", concerns a passenger train that is constantly delayed is the most successful recalling the classic Ealing comedies with an Irish sensibility.  The final story, "1921", about an attempt to free an Irish rebel set to be hanged by the British occupation forces for treason juggles the dramatic and humorous to a mostly successful result.  This film is a must for Ford enthusiasts and for those unfamiliar with his work should check out his earlier films set in Ireland.  Noteworthy in the cast is the presence of Godfrey Quigley and Paul Farrell who appeared in Stanley Kubrick's "A Clockwork Orange".

I have read reviews describing this film as lightweight formulaic fluff which does it a disservice.  Both this film and "Where the Boys Are" starred Dolores Hart and were helmed by Henry Levin.  Despite the levity contained within both there are cogent observations made about love and sexuality particularly from a young woman's perspective.  This film focuses on three stewardesses and their efforts to land a man.  Donna (Hart) is a cynic looking to grab a rich beau. Bergy (Lois Nettleton), the elder of the trio, is a lonely heart looking for a kindred soul.  Carol (Pamela Tiffin) is the romantic of the bunch just looking for a husband.  All get more than they bargained for.  This is a really good film with intelligent characters and believable situations that I wholeheartedly recommend.  Noteworthy is that this was Hart's final film before going into the convent.

This is that rare bird that defies criticism and goes down as smoothly as a gondola ride through the streets of Venice.  David McCallum delivers an affable turn as the genial but naÔve tour guide and he also warbles a delightfully bouncy tune over the opening credits.  Sylva Koscina is a sprightly vixen who missed her calling as a Bond girl.  Tammy Grimes gives a saucy turn as a sexually insatiable schoolteacher.  Everything is tied together by the lush panoramic views of Italy and Switzerland.  The cast and crew didn't so much work on this film but got a paid vacation.  This film would be a good companion piece with "If it's Tuesday it Must be Belgium".

You have to give writer-director Philip Kaufman ("The Right Stuff", "The Unbearable Lightness of Being") the chutzpah award for imagining this existential superhero satire.  The problem is that the film is so clunky and unwieldy that the whole enterprise falls flat.  It neither succeeds as a cult item or as camp because virtually nothing works.  It has the feel of a glorified student film.  One thing in its favor is that Jon Voight does project a certain degree of charisma but it's lost in the morass.  To answer my rhetorical question Van Vooren was a Belgian bombshell who made a couple of appearances on "Batman" and had a bit in Andy Warhol's "Flesh for Frankenstein".

Released in the wake of William Friedkin's reviled "Cruising" this flick was dismissed in its day by the critics as being misogynistic, homophobic, and generally unsavory.  This is harsh criticism when you consider the film's blandness and lack of style is more prominent.  This artsy entry in the woman-in-peril genre makes one almost long for "I Spit on Your Grave". High point is Talia Shire manages to stave off embarrassment.  Elizabeth Ashley isn't so lucky in a scenery chewing turn.  The film's ineffectiveness comes as a genuine surprise when you consider this was the debut directorial bow of Gordon Willis who lensed "The Godfather" among other stellar achievements.  Equally shocking is that the score by Maestro Ennio Morricone fails to register a reaction.  All told a waste of time and celluloid, a colossal bore that doesn't have the decency to rise to the level of mediocrity

This is an uproarious Western parody at turns raucous and bawdy.  The fun is so infectious that Frank Sinatra in the title role seems to be having a great time.  The Chairman of the Board demonstrates adeptness at broad comedy which is genuinely surprising showing a side of himself that I've never seen before.  Terrific comic ensemble with George Kennedy as a dopy sheriff and Lois Nettleton as a randy schoolmarm as standouts. A laugh riot from start to finish.

For starters this has to rank with "Abraham Lincoln, Vampire Hunter" as one of the strangest films ever made by a major studio, in this case MGM.  I have nothing against offbeat offerings but just because a film has a skewed sensibility doesn't necessarily make it good as is the case with the fore mentioned vampire movie .  Regardless, I was intrigued by this film's goofball premise.  In order for it to work, though, you need compelling performances by the main actors and the makers of the film get a spirited turn by Stacy Keach in the title role.  Keach makes believable his account of the state executioner who offers the condemned tender loving care before he dispatches them to the ethereal fields of ambrosia.  A lot of the dark humor is hit-or-miss but the script hits enough bulls eyes for me to recommend.  The film's relative obscurity demonstrates why they don't make many like it or why Metro isn't a big league player anymore.

John Milius' masterwork is old school in the best sense of the word.  As grand as the film is it is also highly literate recalling the collaboration between David Lean and Robert Bolt on "Lawrence of Arabia".  The beauty of the film is its scale doesn't overwhelm the characters.  Larger then life performances are offered up by Sean Connery as Berber chieftain Raisuli and Brian Keith as U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt.  Though neither man shares the same frame you sense the kinship laced with begrudging respect these two have for each other.  Candice Bergen has never been better as the kidnapped American widow offering up strength and tenacity.  It's almost unheard of in films of this type to see women with this kind of intestinal fortitude.  Add to that sumptuous cinematography by Billy Williams and a superlative score by Jerry Goldsmith you have an epic for the ages.  Milius had the temerity to make this film when the concept of gunboat diplomacy was frowned upon.  At the 1975 Oscars the film was virtually ignored.  I think Goldsmith got a nomination for his score.  Along with "The Man Who Would Be King" that year contained two offerings of a long lost genre that stand the test of time.

"Cop" is a case of a film with a lot to offer that just misses the brass ring.  Pluses would be a none-too-surprising superlative turn by James Woods as a cop on the edge on the trail of a serial killer.  Woods eschews crime film clich√©s playing Lloyd Hopkins as a man who has seen too much with his anger and emotion barely contained and bubbling to the surface.  I also liked Lesley Ann Warren's performance of a feminist poet who vainly masks her pain and sensitivity.  Director James B. Harris, Stanley Kubrick's production partner for his early films, adds a gritty nourish veneer to the proceedings keeping the film on a smooth track.  If one were to quibble it would be with a trite central mystery.  Adapted from a James Ellroy's novel this is not as an assured narrative as "L.A. Confidential" would prove a decade later.  Regardless, a better than average venture with a lot to recommend.

I'd like to preface my review by saying this is a potentially great film tainted by a weak central performance by Bette Davis.  As Aggie Hurley Davis gives a mannered and affected account of what she construes  how an Irish housewife conducts herself day-to-day.  Davis is as convincing  an Irishwoman as Barbra Streisand would be. Her turn suggests the Bronx by way of Vassar.  That said the film more than compensates for this deficiency in many ways.  Paddy Chayefsky's teleplay, adapted here by Gore Vidal, demonstrates an innate understanding of the human condition. As shown previously with "Marty"  Chayefsky empathizes with the working classes giving them dignity and feeling their pain.  Ernest Borgnine is terrific as the Tom, the patriarch of the Hurley family who innately loves them but harbors dreams of his own.  Debbie Reynolds as Jane, the sensible soon to be married Hurley daughter, gives probably the best performance of her career projecting poise and strength.  Barry Fitzgerald as Uncle Jack plays Barry Fitzgerald or at least a variation of the Barry Fitzgerald we grew to love in "Going My Way".  The film disappoints only when you consider it could have been so much more.

I love these films released prior to the MPAA ratings system where subject matter considered taboo is discretely alluded to and danced around.  The topic of sex is referred to but never shown.  The scriptwriters would have to cleverly tiptoe around the subject which makes for a more satisfying experience than if graphic sex and nudity is on display.  Our main character is Eileen (Jane Fonda), a 22 year old virgin debating whether to give up the ghost.  For reasons too numerous to recount this sets off a chain reaction of comic events  involving Eileen, her brother Adam(Cliff Robertson), and a poor slob from Philadelphia named Mike (Rod Taylor) which include lies, half-truths, mistaken identity and whatnot.  Clothes are ruined and people inexplicably end up in bathrobes and girlfriends are on a one-way flight for Pittsburgh.  When the laughter subsides you're left with a lot of food for thought about sexual attitudes circa 1963.  New York looks fabulous and Peter Nero offers up a terrific score.  If you are looking for a satisfying film experience this comic chestnut fills the bill.

Mincing no words this movie is a colossal bore.  Save for Vittorio de Sica and Edward G. Robinson  the characters are noxious none more than Robert Wagner and the heist at the center of the film is pure cookie cutter.  Raquel Welch's function  is to ride shotgun and slip in and out of skimpy outfits and swimwear.  The Italian scenery is nice but not enough to keep you awake. Even the Animals title tune is mediocre.  Welch fans should skip this one and check out "Fathom" where her physical assets are more highly exploited and she's given something of substance to do.

Most reviews tag this film as a sex comedy when in reality it is more of a comic observation about the sexes.  The film debunks the wide held belief that men have a one track mind and want one thing from women.  Pause for a moment and think about the relationships between men and their mothers and you get the picture.  Sure men think they yearn to be like Hugh Hefner yet truth be told they desire nothing more than a home cooked meal or a listening partner than a roll in the hay. On the reverse coin women think they can view male-female relationships with cool detachment as represented by Kim Novak's post-grad sociology student.  That is, of course, if the male isn't represented by cool hunky nice guy James Garner.  The film has a funny astute script that makes cogent observations and the cast is uniformly excellent.  Ultimately the film comes down as a celebration of marriage and fidelity.  A great snapshot of male-female relationships circa 1962 that hold true to this day.

This intoxicating account of the IRA at the turn of the twentieth century attempting to purloin gold bullion from the allegedly impregnable Bank of England to bankroll activities keeps you enthralled throughout.  Intricately plotted and detailed the film has you in its grip having you guess the ultimate outcome.  The art direction and costume design perfectly evokes the Victorian Age and add to the overall ambiance.  Terrific ensemble cast notably Peter O'Toole in his film debut as the Captain of the Royal Guard and Albert Sharpe as an elderly sewer scavenger who proves to be integral to the plot.  A genuine sleeper not to be missed.

I don't get the animus directed against this flick.  It's not going to be confused with "Citizen Kane" but then it was never intended to be.  It's an easily forgettable light-hearted romp that goes down smooth on a hot summer's night delivering a few thrills and chuckles along the way.  Burt Reynolds is in his classic sly good-ole-boy mode and he's abetted by agreeable co-stars.  Nobody's extending themselves here but they are having a good time and letting the audience in on the party as opposed to at their expense.  Lighten up, critics!

This flick plays like a Euro homage to Sixties style World War II action extravaganzas like the "Dirty Dozen" and "The Great Escape".  The film lacks the panache, humor, and irony of those esteemed epics and what you're left with is a lot of gunfire and explosions.  Things blow up real good, though.  Not bad as a time filler but nothing iconic on display either.

Despite a promising central premise and a good cast "Sam Whiskey" never gets off the ground.  That can be attributed to flabby direction and an inert script.  Burt Reynolds can also take responsibility for the film's ineffectiveness.  In one of his earlier films he displays none of the charisma and sly charm that later made him a matinee idol and number one box office draw in the Seventies.  To call this film a disappointment would be an understatement.

It's unarguable that "Rent-A-Cop" is a trite formulaic exercise that wallows in cop movie clich√©s.  The reason I recommend it is for the indelible kinetic chemistry between Burt Reynolds and Liza Minnelli. Burt's world weary good-ole-boy shtick and Liza's bubbly hyperactivity emit sparks not unlike those demonstrated in a previously maligned flick from the Seventies, "Lucky Lady".  This is an instance where you ignore the naysayers and enjoy the movie.  Another undeserving film assigned the "BOMB" rating by the Leonard Maltin movie guide.

The only thing these two films have in common is that they have the words great and bank in their respective titles.  Neither film is particularly memorable but work as decent time fillers."The Great Bank Hoax"-Small town bank is embezzled to the tune of $100,000.00 (a lot of dough in 1979) so the bank executives scheme to rob the branch to avoid the taint of scandal.  Supposed parallel to Watergate but the metaphor was lost on me.  Fitfully amusing but not outright.  Highlight is Burgess Meredith's turn as a wily bank vice president."The Great Bank Robbery"-Western parody about competing forces attempting to heist the gold from an impregnable Southwest Texas bank.  Film is more frenetic than funny but not without its moments.  Noteworthy is the diverse cast (Zero Mostel, Kim Novak, Clint Walker et. al.) and a script by William Peter Blatty who would subsequently write "The Exorcist".

I was two years old in 1966 when this series premiered and four when it finished its run in 1968 so I have no first hand recollection of it.  I discovered it in the early Eighties when I attended college and it ran on the local UHF channel during summer break.  It was all the rage among my peers for its irreverence and campiness.  When the "Batman" film came out later in 1989 one was forced to reevaluate the Caped Crusader in respect to director Tim Burton's darker vision.  Christopher Nolan conception of the Dark Knight in his superlative trilogy offered the most definitive version of the Batman ethos.  In light of what transpired since the "Batman" series left the network airwaves how does it hold up today?  Remarkably well in my humble opinion.  I think the best way to view this series is  in sequential order taking note how the series evolved over the course of its run.  You will see its shift in tone is gradual and not that dramatic.  It is then you will see that every one of the 120 episodes, good and not so good, is of a piece to a satisfying whole not unlike the initial "Star Wars" trilogy or Peter Jackson's "Lord of the Rings" cycle.  For sure there are some clunkers like "Surf's Up, Joker", the sexism of "Nora Clavicle's Ladies Crime Club" and John Astin's  misinterpretation of the Riddler but they aren't a deal killer.  I paid $99.99 for this set and consider it a bargain.  If anything the series is a font of delicious trivia when you consider all the guest villains and cameos. Bring on "The Green Hornet"!  I conclude by leaving with this question-How many episodes do you physically see Bonnie, Commissioner Gordon's receptionist, in the flesh?

"Our Mother's House" is about seven young London siblings living in a semi-decrepit Victorian house who conspire to hide their religious  mother's death and their efforts to carry on normally.  The normalcy as comprehended by the Hook children would be one prescribed by their fundamentalist mother's beliefs.  Things go relatively well until their fun loving father, Jack (Dirk Bogarde), returns to the fold.  Jack initially agrees to keep the children's secret but it is soon learned that he has an agenda of his own.  There are not enough superlatives to describe how good this film is.  With the exceptions of Pamela Franklin and Mark Lester I had never heard of the young actors playing the Hooks but director Jack Clayton corrals terrific performances from the tykes.  These kids are the heart and soul of the film and they shine individually and as a unit.  Bogarde in his own right is superb engendering a semblance of sympathy for a character that is essentially an unredeemable heel.  The film is unremittingly dark and moody that builds to a crescendo that is genuinely shocking.  This film is relatively obscure but any adventurous cineaste looking for new and intriguing fare "Our Mother's House" is a good place to visit.

"Made For Each Other" has a terrific beginning and end that is ultimately dragged down by a leaden midsection.  The center of the film concerns the courtship between lovelorn Pandora (Renee Taylor) and Giggy (Joe Bologna) that is totally tedious and underdeveloped.  What makes matters worse is there isn't much onscreen chemistry between Bologna and Taylor and they're married in real life!  This film contains terrific comic moments that don't add up to a satisfying whole.  A disappointment when considering the talent and potential involved.

Abrasive comedy some would call loud, possibly shrill, but I liked it.  Wacky over-the-top humor that may not be to all tastes but it registered with me.  Terrific ensemble cast with standouts being Rob Reiner as the nervous asthmatic younger son and Sid Caesar as the delusional uncle who still thinks he's fighting World War II.
