Second directorial effort by star Alan Arkin, the first being "Little Murders", and he demonstrates an assured hand in orchestrating the broad antics in the film.  Dismissed in the "Leonard Maltin Movie Guide" with the BOMB rating which I consider harsh and inaccurate.

This alleged comedy about two shore patrolmen (Tom Berenger and William McNamara) escorting a sexy ensign (Erika Eleniak) for transport to the brig elicits a collective yawn.  The film is mundane to the extreme in both character development and plotting with the only reason to watch is the obligatory nude scene by Eleniak.  This is surprising because the film was helmed by Dennis Hopper who does offer an amusing cameo as a lingerie salesman.  I can't imagine Hopper's much maligned "The Last Movie" (unavailable on DVD) being this dreary and uninteresting.  The type of movie that would put the pharmaceutical company that manufactures Ambien out of business.

Director Richard A. Colla attempts miserably to fashion an Altmanesque account of the comings and goings of a Boston police precinct.  What this film lacks is Robert Altman's ability to corral large ensembles with overlapping dialogue and multiple story threads.  The  result here is a group of talented individuals left to flounder in the mire.  Even Yul Brynner fails to register as a homicidal maniac.  Burt Reynolds is given virtually nothing to do save for a tender scene with his character's deaf wife.  Do yourself a favor and check out a Sidney Lumet police procedural or even "The Choirboys".  Seriously.

The model for the classic gangster film was cemented by "Little Caesar", "Public Enemy", and "Scarface" and refined by "The Godfather Saga".  When the film code relaxed its standards by the late Sixties the Brits introduced a new language to the organized crime genre but the public wasn't quite ready for it.  Films like this one, "Get Carter", and "Sitting Target" introduced a harsh realism and brutality that made Cagney and Bogart seem tame in comparison and laid the groundwork for later films like "The Long Good Friday" and "Mona Lisa".  The character of Vic Dakin that Richard Burton portrays here is unlike anything he's tackled before or after, a virtual human powder keg with a short fuse.  Vic rules the underworld with his personal patent of viciousness and intimidation that gives enemies and associates pause.  This is an excellent performance by Burton careful not to overplay the character assaying Vic's innate ruthlessness despite the fact he's portraying a doting mama's boy with sadistic sexual proclivities .  The main plot threads concern a payroll robbery involving Vic that goes awry and the police efforts to nab him.  This is edge-of-your-seat stuff and there's a brilliant closing shot though it may be lingered on too long.  Recommended for Burton enthusiasts of strong constitution.

"The Moonshine War" is a good film saddled with an unevenness of tone uneasily mixing the comic with the dramatic. Set in the waning days of Prohibition in Kentucky the film concerns itself with the efforts of a revenuer to confiscate the liquor manufactured by a young moonshiner.  One problem is the key part of the revenuer from Louisville  played by the usually reliable Patrick McGoohan  doesn't seem to know whether to mine his character for humor or ruthlessness and that's not mentioning his curious accent.  Fortunately Richard Widmark as a disgraced dentist turned moonshiner steals the show recalling his cackling starmaking turn in "Kiss of Death".  Almost equally good is Lee Hazlewood, better known as the songwriter of "These Boots are Made for Walking", as Widmark's henchman.  The scene in the diner where Hazlewood forces a couple from Cincinnati to give up their clothing at gunpoint is priceless.  Ostensibly Alan Alda as the bootlegger whose supply everyone wants is the lead of this venture but in an appropriately understated turn wisely cedes the spotlight to his more colorful costars.  The bottom line is this is a better-than-average film easily enjoyable if you're not expecting anything special.

Set in Tennessee circa 1972 the film concerns the feud between two rural clans, the Feathers and the Gutshalls, over a piece of desirable land.  The patriarchs of the respective clans, Laban Feather (Rod Steiger) and Pap Gutshall (Robert Ryan), exploit their offspring in continuing the squabble starting with petty vandalism which then escalates to rape and murder.  This is a smoking powder keg on the verge of exploding and there's no apparent civil law to impede it.  The theme of blood wars on display here has its American precedent in the famed Hatfield and McCoy feud.  The patriarchs instigate the war illustrated in the film using their offspring as cannon fodder and the inevitable  outcome is there are no winners leaving the respective parties to oversee the body count.  This is a gut wrenching film almost Shakespearean in its level of tragedy that also uses the then ongoing Vietnamese conflict as a parallel. It is also a good showcase for then fledgling talent that includes Jeff Bridges, Gary Busey, Randy Quaid, and Season Hubley.  "Lolly-Madonna XXX" is another unsung gem from the Seventies when American filmmakers took chances and challenged their audience.

The average network affiliate newscast consists of equal parts calamity, sports, and weather with local interest pigeonholed in for a few insignificant moments.  The news honchoes convince themselves that they are offering the bloodthirsty public what they want while reaping the rewards of increased ratings.  Lou Bloom (Jake Gyllenhaal) has no such pretensions making the natural career progression from common thief to nocturnal journalist.  He's a cold-hearted parasite and makes no bones about his intensions.  What he does want is financial compensation for his artfully constructed videotapes of murder and mayhem and a little bit of legitimacy for his efforts.  His employers need him more than he needs them and he knows it.  The decline of television journalism has been obvious for decades as demonstrated in 1976 with Paddy Chayefsky's "Network".  What director Dan Gilroy adds to the conversation is a high tech aura and acknowledgement of the influence of reality television.  The film makes its points forcefully sometimes a bit too bluntly but never redundantly.  Gyllenhaal's work here is a piece with the lovable rogues who've graced the big screen in the past careful not to overplay his hand making Bloom somewhat charming and empathetic if you judged him by his own criteria. Sort of like a devil with a camcorder and police scanner. Gyllenhaal is matched by Rene Russo as Nina, a Diana Christenson type who purchases Lou's ungodly product more from inate knowledge of marketplace than from any moral criteria.  "Nightcrawler" reminded me of an underrated film from years ago called "The Public Eye" where Joe Pesci played a freelance still photographer in the Forties who took salacious pictures of New York after dark and sold them to the local tabloids at the back door.  Pesci's character parts with Gyllenhaal's in that he was oblivious to the exploitative nature of his activities and regarded his photography as art.

Basically this is three-films-in-one.  Unfortunately none of the films are wholly satisfying as a stand alone particularly the way the narrative is structured flashing back and forth from time and place creating an unsettling feeling.  Perhaps it would have worked if the stories were told in linear fashion but more than likely scenarist Graham Moore bit off more than he can chew trying to convey too much in a limited amount of time.  Matters aren't helped by star Benedict Cumberbatch's turn as mathematician  Alan Turing which struck me as mannered and affected just the kind of performance Academy members would consider bold and daring.  The primary gist of the film is supposed to be about Turing and his team of wonks attempting to crack the Nazi Enigma Code.  It's kind of laughable because you get the sense here that nobody other than Turing does much of anything being content to bask in their leader's glory.  Equally laughable is that once the code is cracked Turing would be taken seriously as a war strategist.  There are some good performances in the film particularly by Keira Knightley as the sole woman on Turing's team, Charles Dance as the supervisor of the project who would have sacked Turing if he had his druthers, and Mark Strong as an MI6 agent.  Some would say I'm nitpicking but considering the superlatives accompanying the film I was a tad disappointed.  To its credit the film is never boring and kept me relatively interested but frustrated at the wasted potential.

Those looking for a conventional crime thriller should look elsewhere because "The Drop" is more character study than mystery.  One has to follow the deliberate pace of the film to reap the maximum rewards.  This film has one of the best ensembles of any film released last year.  The setting is the rough streets of Brooklyn where if you aren't tough you must have the pretense of toughness just to survive.  Chechen gangsters run the rackets and use the taprooms to deposit the receipts from their illegal operations.  The bar employees don't know which night the drop is going to happen until it actually does.  At closing time on the night of the drop at Cousin Marv's the bar is held up by two armed gunmen which sets off a chain of events that resonates.  It's secondary as to the identity of the stickup men and who their collaboraors are.  Foremost this is a film about complex personalities none more so than Bob (Tom Hardy), the bartender at Cousin Marv's.  Bob at first strikes you as a simple gentle guy but as the film unfolds  darker shadings start to emerge which can be explained as survival instincts.  Marv (James Gandolfini) seems to be a disagreeable sort but even he has good qualities such as a devotion to his dying father.  There's a mysterious quality to Nadia (Noomi Rapace) the waitress with an ambiguous past who Bob takes a shine to.  Then there's Eric (Matthias Schoenaerts), a local psychotic who may talk a good game but is probably full of bluster.  Most impressive is Hardy who gave two of last year's best performances in this film and "Locke".  Hardy knows how to dial it down and capture the soul of the characters he plays and mesmerize an audience.  Schoenaerts is no less impressive and his tension filled confrontations  with Hardy literally suck the air out of the room.  It's fitting that this was Gandolfini's last film because it is a piece with the gritty work he is best known for.

"The Godfather" imagined a world where organized crime was run like a legitimate business.  "A Most Violent Year" reverses the logic and supposes that in order for the private entrepreneur to thrive they must adopt the ways of the Mafia.  The setting is New York, 1981.  Abel Morales (Oscar Isaac) is a fledgling home heating oil magnate who's looking to expand.  He puts a large deposit down on a piece of property with the contingency that if he doesn't come up with the remainder in a week's time he forfeits the down payment.  Timing couldn't be worse for Abel.  His competitors are employing mobster tactics hijacking his delivery trucks and assaulting his employees.  On top of that the district attorney (David Oyelowo) is making an example of Abel by investigating his business practices on the most specious grounds.  Abel prides himself about being above reproach but his present situation causes him to reconsider his approach.  J.C. Chandor's film is a fascinating account of doing business in an ethical cesspool.  It has a lot to say about how we conduct our affairs in America and the fine line that has to be nudged just to survive.  Isaac is nothing short of brilliant as Abel demonstrating his turmoil with few histrionics.  Jessica Chastain as Abel's wife Anna nearly steals the show in a performance that suggests Lady Macbeth.  The daughter of mobsters Anna subtly manipulates Abel to act in the ways of the world as opposed to his idealized vision of it.  A telling scene shows Abel hitting a deer in the road.  Abel hesitates in putting the wounded animal out of its misery before Anna pumps two slugs into it.  A fascinating film that may be misconstrued as a traditional gangster film in the Scorsese tradition instead of the work of a visionary up-and-coming auteur.

We can herald this film because director Tim Burton has challenged himself by employing a conventional narrative to tell the story of Margaret (Amy Adams) and Walter (Christoph Waltz) Keane.  Theirs was a marriage of convenience in that Margaret needed a stable domestic situation to support her young daughter.  Because Walter was an inept artist he needed Margaret's artistic vision to compensate for his inadequacy.  As a woman in the Fifties Margaret wasn't taken seriously in the art community but Walter had the charisma and gumption to appropriate her works as his own.  Because her paintings sold like hotcakes Margaret was willing to hold her peace even as she simmered inside.  Walter on the other hand was wallowing in his newfound celebrity and as time elapsed began to believe  that he was the creative sparkplug behind Margaret's work.  "Big Eyes" recalls "Ed Wood", the last time Burton tackled an artist on the periphery of the American cultural scene.  In both cases the artists are savaged by the critics but have acolytes whose opinions resonate years later.  I wasn't particularly impressed with the artwork displayed here but one has to remember that Norman Rockwell and Andy Warhol were sneered at by the cultural scions only to be revered by the general public.  "Big Eyes" isn't a great film but it is a very good one that kind of falters in the homestretch.  Adams is a model of consistency evolving from a timid housewife to a woman with intestinal fortitude in reclaiming what was taken from her by the end.  Waltz's performance is more problematic in that he succeeds in the early segments as a caddish manipulator but  later in the film chews the scenery in embarrassing fashion particularly in the courtroom scenes. As always Burton knows how to evoke time and place and Danny Elfman offers up a decent period jazz score. An ambitious film demonstrating that Burton is still on his game.

Cheryl Strayed's (Reese Witherspoon) life is in tailspin.  After her beloved mother (Laura Dern) passes at the tender age of 45 Cheryl finds cold comfort in the twin evils of indiscriminate sex and hardcore drug use. In a moment of clarity Cheryl finds inspiration in a pamphlet for exploring the Pacific Crest Trail.  Cheryl makes the  decision to hike the entirety of the Trail though she has no prior experience to prepare her for this daunting task.  When her trek begins Cheryl is making little headway but as time elapses Cheryl picks up small survival tips to help her go the duration. Cheryl not only has to battle the harsh terrain and unwanted sexual advances of men she meets on the Trail but ultimately herself.  Jean-Marc Vallee's film has an interesting structure in that as Cheryl progresses in her goal we flashback to her unsavory past.  This suggests that Cheryl isn't so much running from her past but attempting to transcend it making her a better person in the process.  Witherspoon's performance is wholeheartedly in synch with her director's artistic vision demonstrating guts, determination, smarts, and tenacity.  Witherspoon's work here is truly inspirational probably the best of her career.  In essence Witherspoon is flying solo but Dern shines in her few scenes.  "Wild" demands the same perseverance from its audience that made Cheryl's journey so transcendent.

Another great vehicle by Jason Statham that bypassed theatres and went straight to video.  For those following his career he offers up his best work in these underappreciated gems.  If you don't believe me check out "Blitz", "Chaos", and "Redemption".  I think the reason these films are hard to market is because the studio honchoes have pigeonholed him as an action star in the Schwarzenegger-Stallone vein that when he departs from form they are at a loss. Adapted by William Goldman from his novel "Heat" and previously an unsuccessful film starring Burt Reynolds this is more a noir than an action film though it does contain fight sequences.  Statham plays Nick Wild, highly paid bodyguard for hire who is also a compulsive gambler.  The fact that he chose to settle in Las Vegas doesn't help his addiction.  When a call girl acquaintance of his is brutally beaten by a mobster's son Wild acts instinctively instead of intuitively.  Statham gives a terrifically  brooding performance which is matched by a seedy Vegas ambiance.  You would think the gambling mecca had been mined by filmmakers of all freshness but director Simon West offers new perspective.  I would behoove you to check this film out along with Statham's brilliantly villainous turn in the just released "Furious Seven" as contrast.

"Ender's Game" is a terrific learning tool for pre-teens and teens giving them valuable lessons on the morality of warfare.  Like any endeavor we should abide by a morally humane code of ethics when engaged in combat and battle exercises.  This theme runs throughout the film making a cogent argument unlike the cynical "Hunger Games" movies that decry violence yet wallow in it at the same time.  Good performances offered up by a stellar cast led by Asa Butterfield ("Hugo") who gives a mature and knowing turn that belies his tender years.  If I were to fault the film it would be over length and though the effects and art direction impress they add a certain sterility to the proceedings.  Regardless, an intelligent film for its target audience that offers them food for thought to chew on.  I received this as a Christmas present from my brother which I found curious.  I had avoided it because I thought it to be a young adult title.  Granted the younger crowd would appreciate it but older audiences may like it as well.

This film doesn't just hold you in suspense it grabs you by the lapels and forces your attention even if you want to look away.  Director David Fincher stylishly films Gillian Flynn's source novel of the ideal marriage  rotten at its core in such a way that you're left dizzy and examining your own relationships when the movie is through.  It's not only an exploration of good loving gone bad but an indictment of our media culture among other things.  Nancy Grace probably had her attorney on speed dial after viewing this one.  "Gone Girl" is helped immeasurably by a great ensemble cast led by Ben Affleck and Rosamund Pike.  Affleck continues the personal winning streak he's been on since "Hollywoodland" some years ago in his portrayal of Nick Dunne, the seemingly ideal husband who harbors personal peccadilloes that renders him sympathetic to pathetic as the narrative unfolds.  It's Pike in a starmaking turn who astonishes most as Amy whose sudden disappearance the film centers on.  In lesser hands this enigmatic character could have been one dimensional but Pike puts a human face on a character you'll love to hate.  Among The supporting players Tyler Perry stands out as a defense lawyer who bears more than a striking resemblance to Johnny Cochran.  Nobody gets off easy in this take-no-prisoners exercise and too much dissection would ruin the suspense for the uninitiated.  The film is quite graphic in the language and sex department and there is one particularly gruesome depiction of violence but those of strong constitution would be behooved to check this film out.

Dreary account of a young couple (Michael Ealy, Joy Bryant) falling in and out of love with each other in modern day Los Angeles.  The film makes no cogent observations about the pitfalls of romance and the leads are as dull as dishwater making Rob Lowe and Demi Moore, the stars of the original film, seem like Laurence Olivier and Vivien Leigh.  Comic relief is offered up to a point by the usually dependable Kevin Hart and Regina Hall whose characters' tumultuous relationship is offered as contrast all for naught. The original film was no masterpiece but at least it wasn't as pointless as this exercise in futility.  Film commits the mortal sin of being not only mediocre but also easily forgettable.

Sincere account of the Allied effort during World War II to recover artworks stolen by the Nazis that ultimately fails to resonate.  Director George Clooney has the minute details of this footnote in history down pat but the film falls flat because the script that he collaborated on with Grant Heslov doesn't fully flesh out the characters.  This omission reverberates  when you consider the array of talent (Matt Damon, Bill Murray, John Goodman, et al.) Clooney had  at his disposal.  It doesn't quite negate but hinders in a way the message of the importance of preserving humanity's artistic achievements that Clooney is trying to convey. I was genuinely moved by the film's closing scene of a grandfather admiring the recovered artwork with his grandson in tow some thirty years after the events portrayed in the film. The film needed more moments like that.  I can also appreciate the earnest effort that was put into this project but would recommend it at best as a dry history lesson.

It's interesting that a lot of reviews compare this film to "Birdman". It's probably because both films center on the theatre and have ambiguous endings though there aren't as many flights of fancy on display here.  If nothing else see this film for Al Pacino's masterful performance as Simon Axler, a once renowned actor who is losing his feel for performing and is contemplates suicide. After a stint at a mental institution he reconnects with Pegeen (Greta Gerwig), a thirtysomething lesbian who's burned the torch for Simon since she was a child.  Simon's relationship with Pegeen reinvigorates him but it comes at a cost.  Pegeen proves to be a selfish manipulative parasite who causes Simon more anxiety and complications than his fragile psyche can handle. On top of that Simon has to deal with Pegeen's disapproving parents and former lovers.  This is a carefully calibrated turn by Pacino of a man on the verge of emotional meltdown and he wisely dials it down.  Pacino could have howled at the moon as he was prone to do in previous roles but allows his raspy voice, age lined face and mournful eyes do the talking for him.  Gerwig is equally fine making a potentially obnoxious character not only palatable but somewhat endearing.  Good supporting cast but I'd give a special shout out to Nina Arianda as a woman who hilariously tries to contract Simon to kill her husband.  Last year Arianda distinguished herself in the relatively obscure "Rob the Mob" so here's hoping Hollywood is taking notice.  Director Barry Levinson expertly juggles the comedic and dramatic elements of the film based on a Philip Roth novel. Octogenarian Buck Henry co-wrote an acidly wicked script fifty years after he helped create "Get Smart" with Mel Brooks and contributed to "The Graduate" screenplay.  Which leads me to the question as to when they are going to issue on DVD Milos Forman's first American film "Taking Off" starring Henry.  I don't know if you can categorize any endeavor of Al Pacino's as a small film but "The Humbling" is an exceptional undertaking.

This lethargic account of the affair between Hollywood swashbuckling leading man Errol Flynn (Kevin Kline) and underage chorus girl Beverly Aadland (Dakota Fanning) never gains traction.  The culprits would be lackluster script and direction and a woefully miscast Fanning who never develops chemistry with Kline.  Kline and Susan Sarandon as Aadland's enabling stage mother are quite good but can't compensate for the film's shortcomings. A lot of reviewers take issue with Fanning being too old for the part but both Kline and Sarandon are close to seventy.  Last year Sarandon played Melissa McCarthy's grandmother in "Tammy".  It's like an episode of "E! Hollywood True Story" without the panache.  Universal partnered with the Lifetime Network for this flick and it shows. Not a bad film but glaringly bland and mediocre.  Made me long for "My Favorite Year", a 1982 film where Peter O'Toole played an Errol Flynn type actor trying to make a comeback by appearing on a TV variety show.

They've promoted this film as "Mary Poppins" meets "Death Wish".  The reality is that there are only three victims as a result of Miss Meadows' marksmanship and they were all vile predators.  The film isn't particularly gory either.  You could probably get a PG-13 rating if not for one particularly exuberant lovemaking sequence.  Ironic isn't it?  The filmmakers afford Miss Meadows with a backstory that includes childhood trauma reminiscent of a certain caped crusader.  Katie Holmes is ideal in the title role expertly demonstrating the gray areas of her well scrubbed girl-next-door persona.  She seems to be channeling the dark angst that she experienced while being married to Tom Cruise.  This film is at turns wickedly macabre and sweet in its own way with the potential to achieve cult status.

Though Terence Malick's name is connected to this film it is definitely fledgling director A.J. Edwards' show.  Malick's influence is apparent but Edwards demonstrates enough unique flourishes to distinguish this work as his own.  Described by some as an art film I would characterize it as an exercise in artistry.  An art film connotes that watching this film is akin to viewing a museum piece which Edwards' film certainly is not.  The film is brimming with life appropriate to its early nineteenth century rustic setting.  Technically the film is a marvel with luxurious black-and-white cinematography, crisp editing, and evocative sound design giving you the you-are-there effect.  The beauty of the film is its technical proficiency doesn't overwhelm the actors who are uniformly excellent.  Though the adult performances (Jason Clarke, Diane Kruger, Brit Marling, Wes Bentley) are terrific the focal point of the film is young Braydon Denney as Abraham Lincoln.  Denney exhibits strength and stoicism in a turn that belies his tender years.  It's not only possible but plausible that this boy would grow up to be the  Great Emancipator.  If I were to quibble it would be that some of the characters speak of young Abe in messianic tones usually under hushed breath.  Some may fault the film as taking liberties with history but accounts of Lincoln's early life are somewhat speculative.  I think what is paramount is the essence be captured and niggle about the details later.  I'm glad this film was made and hope a wider audience gets a chance to see it.

They must have written this script forty years ago and kept it in mothballs until Bill Murray was old enough to play Vincent McKenna because this character fits the sly old Irish dog like a well worn suit.  I went into this film with a few misconceptions firstly that this was a comedy.  Yes there are sporadic jokes and the occasional funny bit but this film for the most part is poignantly dramatic.  The scenes of Vincent with his wife who has early stage Alzheimer's disease in the convalescent home will break your heart.  Secondly, curmudgeonly Vincent is a creature of habit who doesn't change his spots rather it's those around him who are effected by his presence.  Terrific ensemble the best being Naomi Watts as a brassy pregnant Russian hooker and young Jaeden Lieberher as the shy youngster Vincent takes under his wing for better or for worse.  I usually damn with faint praise juvenile actors by stating that they are unaffected and natural but Lieberher gives an admirable turn reminiscent of a young Haley Joel Osment  and more than holds his own with Murray.  This film satisfies from first frame until last.  If you don't believe me consider the closing credits where Murray lays in a beach chair lip synching Bob Dylan's "Shelter From the Storm".  In lesser hands this would be the equivalent of reading the telephone book but Murray is brilliant.

I've been an ardent film buff virtually my entire life.  Few times have I  said to myself after leaving the theatre that this is something special that this pushes the envelope of what is possible and impossible in making a film.  A few that come to mind are Coppola's "Apocalypse Now", Scorsese's "Raging Bull", and Tarantino's "Pulp Fiction".  I'm not sure if repeat viewings will bear me out but Alejandro G. Inarritu's film may join this esteemed company.  It is rare that a film achieves maximum impact on all cylinders like "Birdman" does.  This flick nails it in all attributes from the technical side to the acting.  The two things that impressed me the most were the camerawork of Emmanuel Lubezki and Michael Keaton's go-for-broke lead performance.  At first I thought the extended tracking shots were  mere gimmickry but after a while they became like a second character not unlike the stellar cinematography of Gregg Toland in "Citizen Kane".  Keaton's work here is mammoth.  His Riggan Thomson is a  movie star who walked away from a successful comic book franchise and is now looking for validation as an actor and a human being in a dramatic Broadway vehicle.  Opportunities abound to chew the scenery and Keaton goes over the top at times but dials it down when requisite.  It is a carefully honed portrait of a man at the crossroads and possibly crosshairs of life and Keaton imbues him with complexity and empathy.  I haven't seen Eddie Redmayne's work in "The Theory of Everything" but I would be hard pressed that it is better than Keaton's work here.  The script is rich in detail giving shape to plot and characterization.  Film and theatre buffs will have a field day with all the inside jokes. Lastly one cannot overlook the film's terrific ensemble none better than Edward Norton's difficult actor and Emma Stone as Keaton's just-out-of-rehab daughter.  In lesser hands these characters would be clich√© but Norton and Stone bring dimension to the parts.  "Birdman" is a great film and will be heralded for its inventiveness and originality for years to come.

In her Eighties heyday Kathleen Turner ruled the roost with terrific movies like "Body Heat", "Romancing the Stone", "Prizzi's Honor", and "The War of the Roses".  Subsequent years were not so kind to our heroine reaching its nadir with "Baby Geniuses" in 1999.  Two time Golden Globe winner ("The Truman Show", "Man on the Moon") Jim Carrey has been riding high of late with flicks like "Yes Men", "Mr. Popper's Penguins", and "I Love You, Phillip Morris".  No swelled head on our Jimbo and when it was time to restart the "Dumb and Dumber" franchise he called on his old "Peggy Sue Got Married" co-star to join in the fun and add a little gusto to the proceedings.  Jeff Daniels?  Yeah, right!  If it wasn't for Carrey carrying his sorry behind in the first film he'd go the way of Julia Ormond or strumming Jethro Tull covers for spare change in Times Square.  It's been a long time, Kathleen.  Great to have you back.

"Ida" departs from most  post-Holocaust films in that it tackles both the twin evils of Nazism and Stalinism in Poland.  The year is 1962 and in its wake are the scorched earth left by the Third Reich and a picture of a deceptively benevolent Nikita Khrushchev adorning a bare wall.  Eighteen year-old Anna (Agata Trzebuchowska) is on the verge of making her final vows in becoming a nun.  She receives a visit from Wanda (Agata Kulesza), an aunt she's never met and a former fearsome Communist Party prosecutor now a prominent judge.  Wanda tells Anna bluntly her real name is Ida and that she is a Jew.  Wanda's intentions for Ida is for both of them to locate the remains of family members who perished during the war and give them a proper burial.  Wanda, a self loathing cynic, hopes to gain some semblance of closure while Ida goes along in hopes of receiving answers to the direction her life should take.  Alas, there's no easy way out as the women find out and their past is doomed to define their futures.  On the surface director Pawel Pawlikowski's film would seem slight filmed in stark black-and-white populated with few characters containing sparse dialogue and coming in at an economical eighty minutes but it's because of its simplicity that it achieves resonance.  For me the film brought to mind "Sophie's Choice" but you could go decades mining stories from the Shoah and still not run out of compelling ones to tell.

Provocative film about the role of faith and religion in modern society.  The film opens with Father James (Brendan Gleeson)  listening in the confessional to a man who was raped as a small child by a Catholic priest.  The man continues by saying that he will kill Father James in a week's time not because he is a bad priest rather by murdering a good priest the message he is attempting to send society will have greater impact.  Father James' reaction is to maintain a cool head and tend to the needs of his flock and do they ever need tending to.  You couldn't find more dysfunction on "The Jerry Springer Show".  This does not deter Father James however because as he sees it Christ served most those whom society deemed most unfit.  "Calvary" is an interesting if imperfect film that casts the mirror on both the clergy and its congregants.  The small Irish coastal village depicted in the film serves as a microcosm of the Church as it stands today defined by both clergy and parishioners.  Gleeson's world weary yet doggedly determined take on the modern priest is mesmerizing. Father James is pious but doesn't blanch at profanity or flawed character and isn't opposed to the occasional pint.  If I would fault the film there were moments that teetered on dark comedy that may have been purely intentional if you've seen director John Michael McDonagh and Gleeson's previous collaboration, "The Guard", but not always successful and at times the peripheral characters bordered on caricature. I wouldn't call this film heavy handed but the Christ allegory is hard to escape.  Regardless, a thoughtful film that raises a lot of questions that compel the audience to take stock of their convictions.  It should be noted that some of the dialogue on display is quite graphic and there is a depiction of violence that may give pause to the squeamish.  I should also note that I'm a practicing Catholic who's navigated the sex abuse scandals and found the portrayal of my chosen faith to be authentic.

A chilly Valentine's Day in Philly and myself and my princess bride are housebound.  I have a collection of unwatched discs in virtually every genre and the missus wanted something appropriately romantic for the occasion.  She didn't want to watch anything maudlin like "The Fault In Our Stars" or "If I Stay" nor did she want to watch anything smutty akin to "50 Shades of Grey".  I didn't want to watch some saccharine Nicholas Sparks adaptation either.  "The Princess Bride?"  I fancy myself a film buff but I had never seen this nearly thirty year old chestnut.  It more than filled the bill.  The success of this film lies in the fact that director Rob Reiner and scenarist William Goldman have an affinity for the mythology of the fairytale.  This is not a spoof or tongue-in-cheek enterprise save for a cameo by Billy Crystal but a gosh honest fairytale with all the conventions intact.  The damsels are beautiful, the heroes dashing, the villains nefarious and everybody lives happily ever after. The film is impeccably cast from the leads (Robin Wright, Cary Elwes) to the support (Mandy Patinkin, Wallace Shawn, Andre the Giant, et al.).  Nice framing device of having a modern day grandfather (Peter Falk) relating the story to his grandson (Fred Savage). A testament to the effect this film holds on audiences is it remains a top seller moving more units than recent films that were wide released.  Devoid of any pretensions this is flat out superb moviemaking.  When you think about it Reiner was on quite a run in the Eighties with this film, "This is Spinal Tap", "Stand by Me", and "When Harry Met Sally".

This is a tale of two movies.  The success or failure of the enterprise falls squarely on the shoulders of young Ellar Coltrane, the youngster tapped by writer-director Richard Linklater to be the film's focal point.  In the early scenes Coltrane is reasonably appealing and naturally unaffected.  The most compelling segment involves his mother's marriage to an abusive alcoholic college professor.  It's when we enter the turbulent teens that the film encounters troubled waters.  During those formative years Coltrane seems stiff and conscious that the camera is running.  More screen time is devoted to his character and he seems ill-at-ease.  It is this uneasiness that makes Coltrane's character seem less appealing. Fortunately the acting chops of the seasoned pros (Patricia Arquette, Ethan Hawke) compensate for their green star.  On the reverse Linklater's daughter Lorelei playing Coltrane's older sister is a model of consistency.  Her character progresses smoothly through childhood and young adulthood and remains appealing throughout.  Without being accused of nepotism Linklater should have looked at the dailies and centered the film on Lorelei's character.  In retrospect "Girlhood" wouldn't have seemed like a bad idea.  This film has received a lot of accolades and more than likely will win Best Picture at the Oscars this year.  This has more to do with aesthetics than artistry.  It's commendable that Linklater attempted to advance the medium but the end result is a mixed bag.  I was reminded of Michael Apted's "Up" films which were much more successful mining similar material in a documentary vein than Linklater's fictional film is.

I groaned when I heard the premise of this film.  Hotshot lawyer (Robert Downey, Jr.) defends estranged small town judge father (Robert Duvall) on a murder rap.  Watching this film it is much more than a routine courtroom drama.  Even the final verdict is ambiguous.  The film's main concern is the schism between father and son and the long hard road in mending fences and letting bygones be bygones.  The film begins with Downey's Hank Palmer getting word that his mother passed in the middle of one of his big money trials.  Justice is of little concern to Hank as long as he clients get off and he has another big payday.  For Duvall's Joseph Palmer the law is unambiguous and  integrity to the letter of the law is paramount.  He would rather be found guilty than violate the Founding Fathers' intent.  There's a lot of emotional tug-of-war between Hank and Joseph before a stalemate between the two is achieved.  Needless to say the performances of both Downey and Duvall are superlative.  Duvall, a national treasure,  illuminates the screen by totally immersing himself into character.  He gives Joseph dimension and you end up rooting for his character even if you're not certain of guilt or innocence.  Never better Downey wisely defers to Duvall but is not without his own moments to shine.  We witness Hank evolving through the course of the film in believable fashion from smug attorney to dutiful son.  The film derives its power from its humanism and is definitely one of the better offerings from last year.

This film seems to draw its influence from Quentin Tarantino, Sergio Leone, and John Woo.  Like those auteurs of stylized gunplay the violence is leavened by a hearty dollop of dark humor.  It felt darkly comic not unlike "Kill Bill" or "Hobo with a Shotgun".  If that weren't the case then this could easily be a dismissible empty exercise of gratuitous mayhem instead of a reasonably inspired shoot 'em up.  Keanu Reeves channels Clint Eastwood's Man with No Name as John Wick dispatching baddies with the efficiency of a killing machine and the requisite minimum of emotion.  Let me qualify that by saying the least amount of emotion you can exhibit if you are avenging the death of a puppy your recently deceased wife gave you. Michael Nyqvist makes for a particularly delicious adversary. Good bits by Ian McShane, John Leguizamo, and Willem Dafoe.  I particularly liked Clarke Peters' droll hotel desk clerk.  The narrative is a little thin but at an economical 101 minutes the flick breezes by at a nice clip.  I wouldn't describe this film as an action classic but it serves its purpose.

This film is reminiscent of the weepies of yore and not in the negative sense.  This account of an absentee dad (Jon Voight) forced to become more involved in his kids' lives once tragedy strikes is poignant and deeply emotional.  As demonstrated in prior films like "Conrack" and "The Champ" Voight shows himself adept at working with children and the bond that develops between he and the kids as the film progresses seems natural and genuine.  There are hints that the film may evolve into a custody battle between Voight and their stepfather (Richard Crenna) but  neither side is vilified and the resolution is very humane. When this film came out in 1983 it was generally dismissed by cynical mainstream critics but time has caught up with this film and there's no shame today in wiping back a tear.

In our busy household, USB chargers seem to be at a premium. Especially since the likes of Apple, Amazon, etc., seem to only think people need a USB cable these days and want you to spend another $20 on a simple plug. This "shortage" has led to my wife and kids poaching my charging station, moving chargers around, etc. Of course, that leads to the inevitable lost charger and the "I don't know where it went... wasn't me..." spiel.Given the above situation, the GE In Wall Outlet with 2 USB ports was exactly what we needed! We have an outlet in our kitchen that is the popular plug-in spot, but this often resulted in someone unplugging someone else's device so they can use a different type of cable (lightning, mini-USB, 40-pin Apple, etc.), which then led to arguments. Such is life with kids. That location was perfect for this outlet, as we only plug in one thing there (besides chargers), which is a phone.On the whole, assuming you have modern wiring (my house was built in 2006), the installation was quite simple. In my case it involved a bit of extra work, as the outlet I wanted to use was a GFI. After confirming I could move the GFI outlet to another location on the circuit (which happened to be the other side of the kitchen counter), it just required some basic outlet swapping and a few tools (a multi-purpose screwdriver and needle nose pliers for straightening out and trimming wires). In total, it was about a 20 minute job, and was not difficult at all. Having the two 2.1a charging ports is very handy, and looks much nicer than oddball USB chargers.My only complaint is that the 'wall wart' of our cordless phone, which we plug in to that outlet, blocks the lower USB port when it is plugged in. So we have to unplug that if we want to use both USB ports, but since it doesn't keep the phone from working that hasn't been an issue.

The Kojo is a bit smaller and "squattier" than I expected, but appears fairly lifelike in appearance from a distance. It is constructed from a nylon-like "pop-out" fabric that should hold up fine in weather. My primary intent is to use the Kojo as a decoy for coyote hunting purposes, but I've not been able to do that at this time (currently not in season). However, I have found articles online that used this decoy with success. In the interim I'll likely stick it in the garden and see if it keeps the rabbits and other critters at bay. May not be as effective as the kind that move in the wind, but should help.

We found these pull-ups to be of excellent quality and fairly true to size. My daughter is 30 months and weighs 33lbs. She is tall for her age (91 percentile), and the "Pull-Ups NightTime Training Pants for Girls" are for girls 2T-3T (up to 34 lbs). We have not had any issues with them leaking, but she will likely size out of them before she hits age 3.Of course, the nice thing about Pull-ups is that they work like underwear. So all of those "false alarms" where she tries to sit on the potty and does nothing are more convenient in terms of not trying to unfasten and refasten a diaper. But unlike pull-ups we've used before where once the side is torn, it's trash, these are nice in that they can be refastened, if desired. The only thing we have found is that the "night time" feature (glow in the dark elements) is really not all that important... she doesn't see them under her gown and blankets.We have actually used these more during the day time. The 'zoned protection' for girls and the designs that fade when wet make those times when you're not quite sure if it has been wet or not much easier to check.But perhaps the biggest test is our daughter, who loves these so much she can often be found carrying one around (for reasons unknown to me). She loves the design, and the Pull-Ups make her feel like she's wearing underwear like her older siblings.

Please note: This item was provided by ZeroLemon for the purpose of review. However, this review is 100% my opinion and experience.The opportunity to review the ZeroLemon Apple MFI 2M Lighting Cable could not have come at a better time for me. My wife recently 'upgraded' to my old iPhone 5, and my son replaced his old iPod touch with a new version that has the Lightening port. Combined with my new iPhone 6, cables can sometimes disappear around our house.What I needed was a cable to keep in my truck. I considered purchasing the $20 'Official' cable from Apple, which I will use for comparison purposes in this review (since that's what comes with the phone). Despite all of Apple's design prowess, that cable has several shortcomings. First, it's white. When a white cable is stretched across your dash, it screams "hey everyone, I have a iPhone, please break into my truck and see if you can find it!" Second, the 'official' cable (in this price range) is only 3.25' long. Unfortunately, that is NOT long enough to stretch from my center console to my dash, or use comfortably while the cord is plugged in. Third, it's white. Did I mention that? Well, when you work outside a lot, you sometimes get dirty hands. White cables do not look so great after being handled with dirty hands. Finally, the official cable is weak, with short plastic connectors.The cable I received from ZeroLemon was the 6.6ft (2M) ‚ÄúRugged Black Nylon‚Äù. When I selected it I was not sure what to expect, since the picture makes the cable look at bit 'plastic'. Also, I was afraid the cable ends would just be a thin metal. Not to over-state the value of a phone cable, but my skepticism was pointless -- THIS is what I've needed in my truck for a long time! First, the cable is a braided black nylon fabric. I'm sure there are normal wires underneath, but the nylon outer casing shields it well and is easy to handle. It has stiffened a bit in the super-cold weather, but is not unmanageable and has not caused any issues with tangling. It easily reaches my dash with the excess curled up in my console, and does not 'stand out' when its just laying there. The aluminum 'crushproof' connectors caps are indeed a sturdy metal, and provide ample area to grasp for connecting and disconnecting. I had no problem using the Lightening end with my Speck CandyShell Grip  case. Finally, I have had NO issues with this cable charging the aforementioned devices OR my iPad Air II, and have had no issues with the cable coming unplugged. This is why the "MFi" certification is important, which refers to Apple's licensing program.For a cable that currently costs the same amount as Apple's official cable, the ZeroLemon cable simply beats it at all aspects of the game. So while you aren't saving any money, you are getting a whole lot more value for it. Add ZeroLemon's 30 day money back 'no questions asked' refund policy and 2-year 'zero defect guarantee' warranty, and you simply cannot go wrong with this purchase. I highly recommend this product.

Pioneer Elite... has to be awesome, right? After all, to be elite means you are 'above all others'... that you stand out from the crowd. In general, I'm underwhelmed. Not that it's bad - it's just not that significantly better than the Yamaha receiver I have, which in itself was a mid-line receiver.Personally, I feel like electronics these days are trying too hard to see how many logos they can apply to their boxes. I don't personally use Pandora, but the Internet radio features are nice. This receiver actually had a lot of features I just don't need or for which I'm simply not ready -- for example, the dual subwoofer pre-outs, 4k compatibility, or 2-zone output. I do not need the Roku compatibility, as I use a Tivo. I happen to have a 5-1 speaker configuration, so really do not need the 7.2 support. Perhaps someday... :) The Bluetooth functionality is somewhat misleading... I thought maybe I could use this in my living room with satellite speakers, but it turns out I'd have to purchase an adapter.On the plus side, the 140w per channel is nice, as are the 6 HDMI ports. I also appreciate the Apple Air-play functionality, though I have that with my Yamaha receiver, as well. The sound was good, and the setup was fairy easy.In general, I give the VSX-44 4 stars. Feature-wise, it competes well in this price range. But for carrying the Pioneer 'Elite' badging, I just don't get the sense that it stands out so much my friends & will be impressed or that sound is massively improved over my mid-level Yamaha. The controller could be arranged a little better, and the on-screen menu could be a little better, though most receivers are somewhat lousy in that department. I would certainly recommend this if you need a budget-friendly 7.2 receiver that's 4k compatible, but don't be fooled by the name.

We were tired of shucking our vacuum cleaner up and down the stairs, and needed something a bit lighter than the Sears Kenmore Buick that we had been using. We had another Hoover Windtunnel vacuum for our basement, which we liked, so this looked to be a promising option.Of the features included we really do not use the brushless bare-floor option often, opting instead to use a stick vac (okay, it's starting to sound like we have a lot of vacuum cleaners!). However, it's a nice option to have. I can't really say if the "Windtunnel 3" technology picks up that much more dirt, but it does seem to fill up quickly. The HEPA media is nice in that it does seem to filter the finer dust and keep it from re-entering the room, but it does get really dirty over time. It's fairly easy to clean if you just rinse it out periodically, but I wish the vacuum shipped with an extra so you could keep on using the cleaner while one filter dries. Of the included tools, the crevice tool is handy. I wish the bristles were a bit longer and softer on the dusting brush, and the 'Turbo tool' works OK for cleaning the couch, but otherwise does not have much use. Perhaps my favorite feature is the auto-rewind and cord storage. Our other cleaner has a couple of hooks that you have to wind the cord around, which is a real pain (iit rarely gets done right). So being able to just step on a pedal and have the cord wind up out of the way is nice.If you ask around or research online, you'll find a lot of opinions, facts, fiction, etc. about bagless vacs. I don't know if they are all true, but it feels more convenient and just as easy to empty. They can be a bit dirtier to empty, but I like the convenience of not having to buy bags and can easily see when it needs emptied. Overall, this is a nice vacuum cleaner. It has some helpful features and has held up well under several months of intense use in our four-family household. I am removing a single star for the somewhat underwhelming tools and the way the HEPA filter can clog up over time, but I still highly recommend this product.

It's a compatible card (purchased via 'Emerging Tech Sales') - so you get that much. But it also had a VERY outdated install of NOOBS on it from mid-2013. That was disappointing for a card that was purchased in December of 2014! The least they could have done is flashed the card with the newer version before sending. This made getting my son's Christmas present that much more difficult and time-consuming to start up. Old OS would not even recognize wireless dongles, etc.

As a former football player (I didn't make it very far), current coach, and father of a football player, I really looked forward to reading this book. In the wake of concussion-related press and whether football is "worth it", I thought perhaps I would find some good rhetoric relative to the game I love. While I do not personally feel the need to defend the game of football, there are others who are certainly looking for answers as to why they should let their children play.On the whole, I believe Edmundson achieves this through his eloquent re-telling of his personal experiences and reflection of what impact those experiences had upon his own life. Some of his stories carried similarities to my own experiences, and provided unique insight into how they might have really shaped the adult I am today. Other stories were perhaps a bit "dated", so the parallel might have been a bit off from my own experiences. Certainly Mr. Edmundson grew up during a unique period of American history, and played the sport during a period in which it, too, was 'growing up'. Some of the things coaches and others said and did during those times would simply not be acceptable today.As you read through the book, each chapter generally (or at times loosely) addresses one bigger idea; Character, Courage, Losing, Patriotism, Faith,  Manliness, and Loyalty. Some chapters do a better job at this than others. For example, the chapter on 'Manliness' may as well have been titled 'Racism in the 60s'. The final chapter, where Professor Edmundson discusses his son, may has well have been called 'How Awesome My Son Was in Peewee Football' or "How I Rubbed Elbows With Howie Long".Perhaps one of the biggest shortcomings of this book, I believe, is in defining the intended audience. Throughout the book, Edmundson regularly recites passages from authors, philosophers, and thinkers. Frequent references are made to Greek mythology and classical literature. As someone who has a degree in English and education, and who has taken several courses in philosophy, I am familiar with many of the authors. I could appreciate the references, despite the feeling that they were a bit long-winded at times. But the real truth is that I felt some of those references slowed the book down. If I had no background with such content, I could see it being perceived as a bit high-brow and overly academic.In the end, if you are expecting 'Friday Night Lights' or 'Our Boys: A Perfect Season', this is not that kind of book. This is more of a psychological investigation into what the author gained (and lost) from his experience with football. I also feel like it served to provide the author some personal 'closure' on his own time with the game, since he can no longer play and his son is out of the game, as well. Since the book is largely based on the author's own personal experiences, the truth is that you may only find some relation to the content. The rest will be defined by your own personal experience with the game.

We wanted to like this product. It seemed like the perfect solution to a problem. Chiefly, what to do when we're "out and about" and need a place for the little one to go? There are all kinds of nasty places out there - gas stations, some restaurants, or lord forbid the outhouse at a park! We had an ancient little potty we kept in the van, but it was pretty "yuck" after previous years of use.So while we thought it would really fit a niche requirement, we ran into a few problems or concerns...Foremost, my wife is a pseudo-germaphobe. I am too, to an extent, but not as much. But the thought of placing this potty seat on a public toilet (especially a nasty one) and then taking it with you? Makes you wanna throw up a little bit, right? I mean, you can Lysol bomb it, but then what? Put it in the dish washer or something (more puke)?! Or soak it in a tub of boiling hot bleach water? I don't care that it has a travel bag... I would almost prefer to teach the squat and hover technique.Second is the concept of "doing business" into a bag. Hoo boy you'd better hope that thing doesn't spring a leak! I mean, I know you generally aren't taking the "doggie bag" with you, unless your intent is to stash the seat in the car for those long road trips when the little one suddenly has to pee (or worse) when, as it usually goes, you're in the middle of no-wheresville USA. But THEN you've gotta pack that bag with you. A bag. Full of pee, or other business... in the car. Certainly it's not something you can (or should) just leave on the side of the road (or the Walmart parking lot - you people know who you are!).In terms of using it as a seat topper, we found this slid around a bit on a regular toilet seat. Like Gap jeans, maybe it just fits some seats better than others. But it's definitely a little concerning. PLEASE check it out before hurriedly plopping your tot on the seat. If it's loose and slides, you could end up scarring the poor child for life. Who wants to go through life afraid of the toilet?!Finally is the question of size. Our little girl is pretty tall for a 2-year old. By the time she hits her potty sitting stride (don't judge - we're working on it!), I really do believe she'll be too tall to use this seat on its fold-out legs. She'll be sitting there with her knees cranked up to her chest like an adult in an elementary school bathroom.So overall, I give this seat 3 stars, because... it's Okay. It's not groundbreaking, but it could come in handy. We'll tuck it into the van for camping trips or trips to the beach where we may have no other option. Perhaps it'll come in handy there. If it does and we have a revelation, I'll revise this review accordingly. Until then... sit tight. ;)

When my wife and I got married, we registered for (and received) a really fancy/expensive cookware set. It was shiny and not Teflon-coated. It looked really awesome. I imagine if we had hung it from a rack and never used it, it would still look awesome. But the truth is that it quickly became scuffed up from use, and is hard to cook on (as a novice) without sticking, etc. We found ourselves buying supplemental skillets and pots to "fill the void" of what our expensive set just wasn't right for.So let's be honest... if you're a professional chef or 'foodie', you're likely not looking for a sub-$100 cookware set. So I don't see any need for comparisons here. But if you are someone who is looking for an "every day" cookware set, or a decent quality "starter" set, this is a great place to start! The T-fal C912SE74 "Excite" set boasts several convenient features:- Nonstick: It generally is. Cooking bacon and eggs, I did not have any issues with the bacon. Eggs clung a little bit, but I likely had the pan too hot.- Dishwasher Safe: So far, this cookware has gone into and come out of the dishwasher clean and without any issues- Oven Safe: This is a bit of a misnomer. The instructions actually advise NOT to use it in the oven (it's not bakeware), but as long as you do and the oven is lower than 350∞, I guess you'll be OK. So not for cooking, but if you wanted to slide a skillet into a warm (NOT hot) oven to keep the contents warm, it should be OK.- PFOA Free: 'PFOA' is "perfluorooctanoic acid". It is a toxicant and carcinogen in animals. If you are using Teflon (PTFE) cookware, you should definitely ensure it is PFOA free. You do NOT want to eat this stuff.- Thermo-Spot heat indicator: This works OK, but as this is aluminum cookware, it heats very fast. It is easy to OVER heat, so be careful as you may want to cook at a lower temperature. But I found the "spread" of the heat to be very even when cooking, which is good. I think the grooves and design on the bottom help with this. Another note on letting this cookware get too hot is that aluminum can be vulnerable to warping if you are not careful and let it get too hot for too long, so that's another reason to keep the temperatures down a bit.Overall, we found the red color to be very attractive in our kitchen. It's nice to see several color options to accommodate everyone's tastes. The pots and pans were light-weight and easy to handle, with the handles easily putting your hands out of harm's way. The glass lids were nice to see your food while cooking, and the big knobs made them easy to remove, though perhaps a bit tricky to store.About the only complaint I have with this cookware set is the somewhat misleading claim that it's a "14-Piece" set. It came with four measuring spoons, which to me is really just one thing. Other photos show spoons and flippers that are safe for Teflon pans, which to me would have been much better to include. The measuring spoons are almost kind of a joke that allow them to call it a 14-piece set, but since I don't COOK with measuring spoons, it's really a 10pc set. If you are buying this type of cookware for the first time, be aware that you do NOT want to use metal utensils on it or it will potentially damage the Teflon surface.

These 'Bird B Gone' Enviro-Spike Bird Spikes are the real deal! Time after time our kids were going out to play, only to come in and ask us to clean the bird poop off their swing set. And once we caught our daughter trying to clean it on her own. You know how those things go. It was disgusting and unsanitary, and was making a real mess of the swing set. Nothing like dropping $1500 on a swing set only to have the kids NOT want to use it!The 10-Feet length (in 2' sections) was perfect for my purposes. It took me 3 full sections and half of another. The staggered screw holes worked great since the top "beam" was really two 2x6's bolted together. I bought some 1.25" coated deck screws so they wouldn't rust and screwed them on. The final section required me to just use about 1', so I had to cut a little off each end so I'd have screw holes. I tried using tin-snips, which was kind of an exercise in futility. How can something cut metal but not plastic? I should have tried a hacksaw or something, I guess, because it did not "snap" off easily. After jabbing myself in the hand a few times, I finally got it.Overall, it looks good. It took a little bit to get used to seeing the spikes, but it works so well. The spikes have held up to some pretty serious wind and even nickel-sized hail the other day. And nobody could be happier than my kids... well... except for me, the designated cleaner of said bird poo.Hooray for Bird B Gone - these things work!

I'm not one of those car-care nuts who spends hours polishing their vehicle. Sure, I'd like mine to LOOK like that, but I don't have the time. Besides, keeping a showroom sheen on a mini-van is kind of pointless. That said, we DO spend a lot of time on the road... driving to practices, events, visiting relatives, vacation, etc. You know, living life. A life that does not have much time for car maintenance, but also does not want its car to look like crud.Here's where Griot's Garage Bug and Smudge Remover comes in. Simply spray it on, do something else for a few minutes, then come back and clean it off. The bottle says 30 seconds, but more than that won't really hurt (ok, don't wait 3 days. Be reasonable). But seriously, once you come back and clean it off with a gentle sponge or microfiber cloth and a hose. Just like that, most of the bug guts, road tar, bubble gum, dried-up bird poo, etc., will be gone. It's not a miracle worker, so don't expect bird guts to disintegrate or pine tree sap to melt away. It's not hydrochloric acid. But it does seem to work better than most other products I've tried, and seems gentle enough on the paint job.Once you're done, load in the kids and go get some ice cream, knowing you save some $$ not having to get that stuff detailed off.

I have to admit, I was skeptical of this light at first. My experience with Rayovac flashlights is generally limited to those plastic lantern-type lights that used the big square batteries and seemed to fill up my grandparent's cabinets at the farm. Having recently spent money to convert my old 4-D mag lite to LED (which worked great), I doubted this would be as bright.Turns out, I was wrong. This light is VERY bright and has a nice hot spot in the center. The cast has a fairly tight center beam with a wide cast (the amount of light around the main beam). The throw of the beam - the distance - was more than sufficient. I was able to effectively light things that were easily 100-150 yards away. I like that this light has two modes - the full and nearly blinding 100 lumen mode, and an 18 lumen "energy saver" mode. The second mode was not effective for much more than looking for something you dropped in your vehicle, but it works well and would certainly be good to use in a tent or other situation where a lower light output is desired.In terms of build, I really liked the rubber head and tail cap, shock absorbers, and aluminum titanium construction. My old mag lite rattles and bumps around in my truck door - this light does not. It is a very sturdy and 'weighty' light that should take whatever abuse you throw at it. It also has a hexagon shaped bezel at the base of the head, which keeps it from rolling. That's very important to me and I was glad to see that feature!Honestly, at this price point, you can't go wrong. Due to the weight it may not be the best "tactical" flashlight, but it's all most people need. You can't go wrong here.

I want to keep this review simple... there are a lot of folks who will post read/write times, discussions of SSD lifecycles, etc. So let me just say that this drive is FAST. My computer, which is only a few years old and still very powerful, was freezing and crashing a lot. I followed the lifehacker articles on cloning your current drive to a SSD, and swapped out the 7200rpm hard drive with this SSD. I removed the old drive, installed this one, and my system booted right up. I DID have to make a few tweaks in the system config for it to know to boot from the SSD, so do your homework up front. But the lifehacker articles are great, and this drive will probably last you 10 years or better unless you are an extreme user (in which case you'll likely buy a new computer first). It's AMAZING how much better my system performs now and how much faster it boots and loads my profile on logon. THIS is how a computer is supposed to perform. Five stars, all the way!

When I wash my truck, I like to do it quickly. I do not like to let it begin to dry out, and I do not like using brushes or classic "sponges", which can pick up debris (like from the driveway) and seem to hang on to it. Another thing is having to constantly squeeze/wring out sponges or even the cloth-covered sponges.Enter the Zwipes Microfiber Wash Mitts. These are great! The microfiber "pile" is soft and safe for your car's finish. What I like to do is put one mitt on each hand, then washing in a swirling motion. I can cover a lot of ground quickly using both hands at once, and since they are mitts that slide over your hand, you don't have to keep wringing them out. Just dunk your hands in the soap bucket and go!Once finished with your car wash, simply toss the mitts and your towels in the washing machine. The "Instantly restores your show car perfect finish" might be a bit far-fetched, and these are large so they don't fit kids as well or those with small hands. But overall I recommend.

This is a very nice combo for the "do it yourself" car washers. I often get frustrated because my F150 dries before I can get it sufficiently wiped down, leaving spots on my truck. The 'Dry Blade' comes in handy, especially on those large areas (hood, sides). That way you aren't trying to remove every drop of water by absorbing it with a towel. The blade is slick and, if you did a good job cleaning, should not cause any scratches. It also works well for window glass, which are often smeared by towels.The Pocketed Drying Towel is simply a large microfiber towel. For whatever reason, microfiber feels weird to me... like it wants to stick to me. But it still does a good job. Overall, microfiber is pretty absorbent and this towel is no exception. While some may complain about it being too large, it's large enough that you don't need 5 towels to get your car or truck dry. The 'pockets' are simply a nice convenience. You put one hand in each, then dry using a 'wipe on, wipe off' motion (see: "Karate Kid"). It is lint-free, as the product promises. Once wrung out, the microfiber dries quickly. I recommend you wash it after each use, of course.Overall, these are a great addition to your car-care arsenal, and should last quite a while.

My son is currently in his 6th year of baseball. One of my challenges in working with him has always been hitting and throwing practice. For throwing, I've always had to be on-hand. And while nothing replaces playing catch, I'm not always available. With hitting, it's just been difficult in our limited-sized back yard to hit much more than whiffle balls. We've always had to go somewhere else, then spend time chasing balls or picking up and re-hitting.Enter the SKLZ Quickster Baseball Combo Net system. This is really two great tools in one package. The quality of this item is typical of the SKLZ brand, and I was not disappointed. The system went together easily, and it is quite easy and fast to switch between the practice (hitting) net and the return (throwing) net. Once I got the hang of it, it also easily collapses for quick storage in our shed or travel to the ball field. I have no concerns about the durability, but would certainly recommend storing it indoors out of the weather. The combo system also includes a storage/travel bag and stakes to keep it from moving.The return/throwing net includes a 'pitchers simulation with strike zone target'. Honestly, my son is not a pitcher at this stage - he's still learning control. However, one of the best features is that the strike zone is adjustable (and removable). I moved it up a bit to use as a target, as if he were fielding and throwing to another player. This gives him an effective target to throw to when I'm not available. Be aware that this is NOT a "pitchback" net. While it is under tension and will roll the ball back (depending on how tall your grass is), it does not 'throw' it back. It just reduces the amount of chasing.The hitting practice net is durable and should last a long time. It is great for soft-tossing balls to him, or for him to hit off his tee and into the net. The netting holes are small enough to catch whiffle balls, while it is deep enough to capture hit balls and return them to the ground. This allows him to hit several balls in succession. And unlike some other hitting systems, it does not rely on a super-deep sock net that balls get all wound up in.The only things I would like to see improved on this system are perhaps better instructions on adjustment of the strike zone target, and perhaps some kind of colored 'zones' on the netting so players can see how/where they are hitting the ball. Also, SKLZ has many forms of "Quickster" systems available for sports such as baseball, golf, football, and soccer. Most of these fit the 7x7' frame. I would love to see the ability to buy additional nets (at a lower cost) to fix the system, instead of having to buy multiple frames.Hands down, this is a fantastic training tool for players of all ages. My son has improved already just from using the pitching target, and I highly recommend it.

I was first introduced to using a roller at my company fitness center. I was having some muscle soreness and the trainer told me I needed to "roll it out". I was initially skeptical, and perhaps even more so after using the roller. It hurt like heck! While the "hurt" subsides over time (especially the more you do it), the trainer told me the fact that it hurt meant the muscle needed it. In a nutshell, the roller helps to improve circulation to damaged muscle tissue, which in turn helps the muscle recover. I have found the use of a roller especially helpful with my larger muscles such as hamstrings, quads, and back. It feels more effective than just regular stretching. The faster recovery time allows for a faster return to the activity, and thus more performance gain.Unfortunately, I did not have a foam roller at home. When I started to work from home full time, I missed having access to one following my workouts. So I was happy to try out the SKLZ TRAINERroller. While I was familiar with the use of a roller, the "self guided" cover is actually quite helpful, as it shows all the different ways one can use the roller including a few ways I had not thought of trying. There are 12 "guided" ways to use the roller that are outlined on the cover.Overall, this roller was comparable in size and firmness to those in my old fitness center, though the SKLZ roller was perhaps a few inches shorter. You WANT the roller to be firm, and this one is effectively so. My only real concern - and the reason for reduction of one star - is that the cover is about 1/2" longer on one end than the foam core. Also the cover is just that - a cover. It is wrapped over the core and electronically welded. This does not inhibit the use of it, but it does move somewhat separately from the roller itself. I do wonder how this will hold up long term, but even if the cover were removed the core would still be usable. It would also look a bit neater had the cover fit a little better. But, I do appreciate that it's easily wiped down and you do not directly contact the absorbent/porous foam.

The Clorox Glass Wipes were an instant hit in our household. There are many times where using a spray cleaner simply isn't feasible or desirable. For example, if you wish to just wipe down your bathroom mirror, a spray requires you remove everything under it (such as toothbrushes, hair accessories, etc.). The Clorox wipes allowed an easy, streak and lint-free job without all the mess. The same applies to our kitchen window, which is above the dish drying rack. And I hate using spray cleaners in my truck, as the overspray gets all over the dash and towel lint is left behind on the windows (you can use newspaper to avoid lint, but I don't get the paper anymore so rarely have any). The Clorox wipes have been great in helping reduce the "film" that builds on auto glass (caused by plastics). In the home, these are great to have on hand when you receive unexpected company and just want to wipe down something quickly without trotting out cleaners and towels. I highly recommend!

These towels have been tested in our kitchen and we really like them. They remind me of the restaurant-quality towels my parents used to use in their ice cream store many years ago. The towels are very heavy-duty and should last a long time, but keep in mind they are for kitchen dishes - not for taking a bath. They are also very absorbent, which is good. For many years my wife and I have used "flour sack" towels for drying and light kitchen work. Those towels are a bit lighter weight and dry faster, but they do not soak up as much or come clean as easily. We do wish they were a bit larger (perhaps 18x30) as these can feel a little undersized at times, but overall they are a very nice product that should be in service in our kitchen for a long time! Thus far we have not experienced any significant shrinkage or unraveling. And as the description suggests, some day when they are too stained to continue using in the kitchen, they'll make great garage/shop towels!

When I bought my computer a few years ago, I made every attempt to "future proof" it as much as possible. This included an i7 processor, HDMI video, 12Gb RAM, etc. I also "added on" two USB 3.0 ports, which was in its relative infancy at the time. What I did not realize or notice at the time was that the computer was short of USB 2.0 ports, and that one of the two 3.0 ports would be in the front. It actually has several USB2 ports, but they are in odd places (3 in back, 3 on top, one on front). Anyhow, fortunately, most things I use (keyboard, wireless mouse, iPhone, camera, etc.) still rely on USB 2, so I've been able to hold off for a while. And the USB 3 ports worked well -- one for my permanent backup drive, the other for my portable passport drive.This has continued to work well until recently, when I found myself not just needing more USB ports, but that most newer things are using USB 3.0. Enter the need for a USB 3.0 hub.As noted in the device specs, the "AmazonBasics" USB 3.0 4-Port Hub provides four downstream USB ports for "plug-and-play connectivity" to your USB 1.1 to 3.0 devices. And it's basically that simple -- plug it in, connect the hub to your USB 3.0 port, and now you have four instead of one. It is small enough to travel with, though the power adapter would be cumbersome if you needed to use it.There are a few things I would like to point out:- the reviews for this item cover 4 different items (4-port USB2, 4-port USB3, 7-port USB2, 7-port USB3). This review is for the 4-port USB 3.0 hub.- the hub I received has a brushed metal look, but it does NOT have a power indicator on the hub OR on the brick, which would have been nice.- the hub I received has a DC power option, which is important if you are plugging in several devices, but is not REQUIRED for low-power devices (keyboards, etc.). You mainly want to use this for devices that charge via USB (like phones, mp3 players, etc.)- the power "brick" is kind of odd/awkward. The plug is turned so that it would not cover up a 2-port outlet, but on my UPS device it prevents me from plugging it in without using an extension (otherwise it blocks other ports).- the Amazon "frustration free" packaging was appreciated, as always.Overall, this is a really nice hub. I would rate it 4-4.5 stars, subtracting for the odd power brick and the lack of anything to indicate it has power (such as a tiny led light). But I had no problems using it, and it has worked well for me.

After having thefts occur at numerous area farms, we were looking for a basic security recording system to help monitor our family's farm property. The Swann SWDVK-425554-US D1 Security Recording Kit certainly fits the bill. It has many positive features that we were looking for in a security system. Foremost, we don't want to have to "mess around" with it often. Thus, the "set & forget" continuous 4-channel recording for up to 15 days+ is a positive. Since we are monitoring outdoors, however, the motion detector feature is not really practical. Wind, horses, birds, etc. will all set it off, and there's (to me) always the fear of missing something.We are still working through the set-up on this, actually. We have to locate power to where we want to mount the base unit while still having plenty of distance to mount the cameras. Since each camera comes with a long cable, that should not be an issue based on our planning. However, we also want to make sure the base unit is also secure. What good is a security system if it can be stolen, as well? As such, we are considering building a lockable box. It won't be like putting it in an anchored/fireproof safe, but if we build a large box we can put a monitor in, as well, then close it up to protect from dust and moisture. Keeping that in mind, you WILL need a display for this, in some capacity.
