Book 2 after The Living, this has Shy and hisfriends finally reaching California after The Big One hit the West Coast.  I don't want to give away too much but now they face a city that has decended into chaos, with zones set up by people fearful of marauders, but mostly fearful of disease.  The US government has mostly walled off California and people are on their own.  But Shy has a mission to accomplish (again, trying not to give away spoilers - you really need to read Book 1 first) and he's determined to finish it.Maybe not as good as the first book, but still a fun read.  Some of the characters (Carmen, especially) seem less well-developed than in the first (she's almost a caricature), and overall they're not as likeable. This book also highlights the 'dystopian' aspect of the books better than the first one did.  I found it slightly less predictable than the first book, but it's still fun enough that I breezed through it in a few days.

I really love this thin little keyboard.  I was initially hesitant to go with a keyboard that was separate from the case, but this is so thin and easy to carry with my iPad that it hardly detracts from the portability and usability.  When I first looked at keyboards in the Apple store they had a similar one, but the surface was very smooth and it was difficult to tell where the keys were and if you pressed them sufficiently.  This one, however, has a slight fuzzy or velvety texture to the keys, making them easier to use.  They also depress slightly - not as much as the keys on my Belkin case - but enough to feel comfortable.  My only concerns are that it's so thin as to almost feel delicate, and I worry about accidentally bending it.  The power switch is also so tiny that it's slightly difficult to turn on and off, but this keyboard is very easy to use and has enabled me to leave the laptop at home for my writing.  Also, a charge seems to last a VERY long time.  I love it.

One of my favorite lines from the movie "Back to the Future" is when Doc Brown asks Marty McFly who the president is in the future.  When Marty answers "Ronald Reagan!," Doc laughs and asks skeptically, "The actor?!?"  And it's funny because we seldom associate actors with being deep thinkers - at least not the kind of thinkers we'd want leading one of the most powerful nations on earth.But Ronald Reagan *was* an actor in the beginning.  Actually, before that he was a sportscaster on the radio, who then landed some roles in Hollywood, even becoming a rising star before World War II came along.  His eyesight was poor enough that he wasn't allowed in a combat role, but his solid good looks were a natural fit for the government training and 'propaganda' films.  And when the plum movie roles dried up after the war, he found work in some less serious films such as "Bedtime for Bonzo," where he co-starred with a chimpanzee.  It's no wonder Doc Brown was dismissive.In Reagan: The Life, H. W. Brands treats us to a fairly detailed (700+ pages) biography of the 40th President of the United States.  He covers his early years with an alcoholic father, his college-forays into acting, and his desire for an ever-larger stage from which to perform.  When his Hollywood career stalled, he became the unlikely spokesman for corporate America on television's General Electric Theater where he honed his public speaking skills.  His political career began as a union leader for the Screen Actors Guild (SAG), following which he was elected California's governor.But his presidency is the focus and bulk of this book, beginning around page 200 and consuming the next 500.  Brands covers it meticulously - almost to the level of minutiae - and frequently compares his impact to that of FDR's, Reagan's early hero.  I was a teenager during the early Reagan years, and saw him as restoring pride and confidence in America at a time when both were at historic lows.  Yet, I knew not everyone saw him as positively as I did: the editor of my high school newspaper went out of his way to criticize Reagan (I wonder how many high school newspapers were so overtly political?).  I was living out of the country (and out of touch with politics) during the final years when Iran-Contra and much of the negotiations with Gorbachev happened, so that was insightful to me.  And while Brands avoids 'falling in love with his subject,' as some biographers do, it's still a mostly friendly bio.  He frames Iran-Contra as Reagan's effort to bring hostages home and Nancy's reliance on astrologers as a possibly over-protective impulse after the assassination attempt, but in other places he is less than flattering and more objective.  That's probably how it should be, but if I had a complaint it's that the book sometimes feels passionless.There will certainly be some on the far right who feel it's not praising enough, and some on the far left who feel it's not critical enough, but I found it to be an informative and entertaining read.  I've read a couple of books by his speechwriters - one was good but too patronizing and the other too presumptuous.  I've read great books about Reagan's handling of the air traffic controller's strike and his near-assassination, and even one about a great speech he gave.  But Brand's book does a good job of approaching 'scholarly' while remaining 'readable'.  I wish it had covered his pre-presidential life in more depth, but I guess that's worthy of a separate book or two.  For those primarily interested in his presidency, however, this one should please most readers.  (I received a free copy from the publisher.)

Shy, a Mexican-American kid from a small border-town near San Diego, is working on a cruise ship and earning good money.  He's dealing with his grandmother's recent death from Romero's Disease when a drunken guest talks to him before jumping overboard.  Shy tried to hold on, but the man seemed intent on ending his life.  But on the next cruise, a mysterious man in a suit wants to know exactly what the guy said before he jumped.  But none of that matters when the ship is hit by a huge tsunami and Shy is fighting for his life... or does it?I had some problems with this book.  First, the story is predictable - it was hard NOT to see where it was headed almost from the beginning.  Second, the profanity is pretty bad (and really stands out in the audio version).  Plus, it begins to drag when Shy and Addy - the snotty rich blonde girl - are adrift on a raft, fending off sharks and trying to stay alive.  And yet, in spite of that, I found the story compelling.  It's heavily plot-driven and the action kept me hooked, but the characters are also mostly well-developed and likeable.  de la Pena is clearly a good storyteller, and I found it hard to stop listening.  I'm even tempted to look for the next two books in the series to see how it ends.

I don't really have a lot of reasons to own a knife like this one, but it's going to come in handy when camping or backpacking.  The knife is VERY sharp as is, but I was pleased to notice the small sharpener built right into the sheath.  The sheath is very rigid plastic and has a large belt clip.  I also hadn't realized there was also a 'sparker' on the top of the sheath, which produced large sparks and we quickly had flames (using a small fire-starter cotton ball soaked in Vaseline [I think?] that my son made).  It also has a small metal slide that moves back to expose an opening to the blade about 1/4" for a line cutter.  I'm not really a knife-guy, but this is a cool knife.

This microphone feels solid and well-made.  I got it for my son, who is a budding musician and wanted to record some songs he's written.  I'm no expert on such things myself, but the microphone itself is just a tad on the smaller side.  I imagined it could be simply plugged into one of his amplifiers but it didn't quite work out that way.  A friend who works in the music industry came by and brought some extra equipment and got it to work for us, so if you're more familiar with equipment than I am you'll know better what you need and what to do.  The one item I thought would be nice was a taller stand, but the small tripod works well enough for most applications.  I also took it over to our church and was able to plug it in without any extras.  As for the performance, I thought it sounded really well (and my friend agreed).  The sound was very clear but it did seem to pick up a lot of extra 'noise' in the background.

I've always felt the KitchenAid mixer was The Standard in this kind of countertop mixer.  I bought one twelve years ago (for my wife, although I think I probably use it more than she does now) and it still works perfectly.  I'm not sure how well this one will last compared to the KitchenAid (I'm not willing to bet it'll last as well) but for $100 cheaper it's not a bad product.The draw with this one for me was the two different-sized bowls - 4.6 and 2.2 quart.  The small bowl almost seems TOO small (my KitchenAid has one 5 quart bowl), but it's nice to have the option.  The attendant downside is having to store 2 bowls instead of one.  The variety of attachments is also nice - 2 beaters, 2 whisks, and 2 dough mixers.  I also like that the bowl can be offset on the stand, making it easier to add ingredients while in use than my KitchenAid, although the attachments don't scrape the bowl quite as well.  Also, the bowl isn't locked into place and tends to wobble when mixing.  Furthermore, I had the impression that the bowl spins, but YOU have to spin it yourself.  It's not a problem - just a misunderstanding I had based on the pictures and description.Personally, I didn't care as much for the speed knob on the back of the unit.  It's quiet enough but I wasn't expecting it to be silent.  It's much lighter than my KitchenAid, which makes it easier to pull out from the back of the counter.  Overall, it's a good product and a decent value, but I expect this one will die before my already 12-year-old KitchenAid does.

My daughter wanted a charger for the truck she and my son drive to school and with dual ports this one seems to work perfectly.  I don't know if there's a specific difference between the two outlets on this adapter other than the output, and it doesn't seem to matter that iPhones are plugged into both sides, but it seems to work (I imagine the one on the right charges faster?).  It's small and is a good value - and perhaps important to note that the ports are on the sides.  It doesn't work in my Honda which has the outlet in the compartment in the armrest because it needs outward or upward facing port.  But this works just fine for what we needed it for.

This is a very nice light and clean smelling women's perfume.  To me it smells slightly floral, but not overwhelmingly so.  It's not as strong as something like White Linen, but a cleaner and lighter smell - very nice.  My wife loves it and it seems to last very well.

This is a very nice looking... um, not quite sure what to call it because to me a "hamper" is a larger recepticle for dirty clothes, kept either in a bedroom closet or a bathroom.  This is a small round canvas container/bag to keep other (smaller) things.  Since it's round (instead of square) it doesn't work efficiently on a closet shelf (too much wasted space in my crowded closets).  It looks nice enough that it can be kept out in the room, but because it's flexible it doesn't stand up by itself.  We used it as a beach bag but at only 13" across (diameter) and 16" tall, it's only big enough for a couple of beach towels (not the larger ones) and some sunscreen and a magazine (and maybe a book, depending on what I'm reading).  The handles are too short - not enough that you can put it on your shoulder - so it's not perfect as a beach bag (maybe if my wife was alone?), otherwise I'd prefer a slightly larger size (and more oval than round).In the end, it looks great - the pattern and color is very pleasing - and it's well-made, but we're still searching for the ideal use.

Before receiving this grinder set at a discount in exchange for an unbiased review, I used Kyocera Ceramic Coarse Mill.  Unlike the Kyocera (which is very difficult to open), this Silva grinder is very easy to pop open.Unfortunately, the Silva grinder has one very big flaw.  Because the grinder is at the bottom, placing it upright gets a lot of spice dust on my counter, making a mess (see my picture).  I avoid this by storing the grinder upside down, but because there isn't a cover for the bottom, it can get grease splatters from cooking in the grinder innards.  This is unsanitary conditions and cause the grinder to "gum up" from grease splatter.It does a great job of grinding everything...  salt, pepper, spices... it handled everything I threw at it with ease.  I like that I can control the coarseness of the grind by twisting right or left.  If it had come with covers for the opening of each grinder, I would have given this grinder set 5 stars.

This does an okay job of cleaning, and it rinses clean.  Even better, it didn't have a strong smell before I put it in the washer.  However, when my laundry was done, the smell is overpowering -- even after a second and third rinse cycle (and going through the dryer).  Even worse, wearing the clothing that was laundered in this was pure torture.  After an hour, I had to take the clothes off because they made me itch so bad.  As I sit here typing this review, I'm rewashing everything with my regular detergent, Tide Pods Free and Gentle Detergent.

I received this wallet at a discount in exchange for an unbiased review.  It comes wrapped in a cloth pouch inside a textured cardboard presentation box, making it perfect for gift-giving.  The box, pouch and wallet are all branded with "Nezarco."  I can smell the wonderful aroma of leather -- and when looking inside the card slots I could see a silver cloth liner, presumably the fabric that protects your cards from RFID theft.  There are two cash slots behind the card slots.  The leather and stitching seem to be sturdy, so this wallet should last a good, long while.

This backpack is constructed solidly.  The stitching, zippers and fabric seem to be sturdy.  The big problem I have with it is the lack of padding on the sides and top of this backpack.  The sides and top is a single layer of canvas.  To be sure, it's quality canvas, but the lack of padding means a single bump could ruin my husband's laptop.  Without any padding on the sides and top, all the other cool features (back venting, extra pockets, opening at the top for headphone wires, sturdy construction, and comfortable back straps) begs the warning to keep searching for a better laptop backpack.

I received this umbrella at a discount in exchange for an unbiased review.  It opens and closes easily, and it seemed to be quality construction...  Until I took it out in the wind.  My weather app says the wind is blowing at 10 miles per hour, and since this is supposedly rated for winds up to 30mph, the wind shouldn't have even stressed this umbrella.  While it didn't turn itself inside out (like most umbrellas do when windy), it refused to stay open in the wind.  If this weren't touted as wind resistant, I would have given it 5 stars.  However, an umbrella that claims to "Resist The Wind To 30mph" should stay open in 10mph wind.

I received this set in exchange for an unbiased review.It worked (and felt) great while scrubbing my back, but after it dried (I hung it on my shower curtain rod), it dried all twisted.  As a seamstress, I know this is a sign that one (or more) layers of shrinkable fabrics were cut on the bias and stitched together with a fabric that doesn't shrink.  Being cut on the bias makes the issue of shrinkage even worse, which results in one of the fabrics twisting.Normally, this type of item would be a suitable stocking stuffer.  Unfortunately, while my scrubber is still suitable for scrubbing my back during my shower (and it still works and feels quite nice for scrubbing my back), I wouldn't feel good about giving this as a gift, knowing what happens with use -- and laundering makes it much worse.To sum it up, if you buy this for yourself it will do the job adequately -- but don't buy it as a gift for someone else.

My husband loves this shirt.  It fits perfectly, the pockets are large enough to fit his cell phone, and it's loose enough for conceal carry.  The fabric is lightweight and would be perfect for Spring, Summer or fall.  The stitching and fabric are quality.

This angel can set atop a shelf or table with your other Christmas decorations, or she can be hung by the attached gold tassel.  She is a beauty to behold.  She comes in a red box that has a clear window on the front of the box.  The bell clapper was tucked tightly inside the top of the angel to prevent breakage.  As soon as I released the clapper, it rang out beautiful and clear.Whether you buy this for yourself or a gift, it is sure to become a cherished part of Christmas tradition.

This is touted as "a healthy alternative to sweet and salty snack options."  If this isn't sweet AND salty, I don't know what is!  The turkey flavor has 600mg sodium and 9g sugar.  The beef has 580mg sodium and <1g sugar.  Okay, so the beef is low sugar, but with that much sodium, both flavors are unhealthy.  As far as nutrition goes, depending on the flavor, these have 11-12g protein, 0-2% calcium, and 4-8% iron.Here are the ingredients for the beef: beef, contains 2% or less of: salt, corn syrup solids, spices, dextrose, lactic acid starter culture, natural flavorings, sodium erythorbate (made from sugar), garlic powder, sodium nitrite, water.The ingredients for the turkey are: turkey, water, brown sugar, dried honey (refinery syrup, honey), contains 2% or less of: hydrolyzed corn protein, salt, fructose, lactic acid starter culture, sodium erythorbate, sodium nitrite, in collagen casing.If you like Slim Jim's, you'll probably like these.  But don't eat them because you think they're healthier than Slim Jim's (or other beef jerky).  It's not!

Eco-Dent mouth wash has a crisp, refreshing flavor and no alcohol to dry my mouth.  I tried it because of the natural ingredients, but I kept using it because it gets rid of the painful mouth sores that have plagued me for years (something I didn't expect, but greatly appreciate).

I've been losing weight (so far, 30 pounds, and 60 more to go).  Needless to say, this has left my flabby body even flabbier, with looser skin.  I was excited with offered this Detox Body Wrap at a discount in exchange for an unbiased review.  It's fairly easy (though messy) to use.* Boil some water, remove from heat, add the wraps (basically extra wide ace bandages) and allow to set for 10-15 minutes;* After the water/wraps have cooled for 10-15 minutes, mix the clay powder with warm water and apply to the desired area;* Remove wraps from water, wring until no longer dripping;* When you burn yourself from wring the wraps, place them in a spagetti strainer to cool further, then wring the rest of the water out;* Wrap the bandages around the desired area (I did my tummy), and secure with the included clips;* When the clips break, go get some safety pins (which I should have got before I started all this), and use them to secure the wraps.* Put a warm damp towel over the wraps (or do as I did and use neoprene wraps, which are better at holding in heat);* Wait at least an hour before removing everything;* Then clean up the mess you made, and measure yourself.As you can see, there were a few kinks.  I needed to let the wraps cool longer before trying to use them, and the clips ALL bent to the point I was unable to use them.  That said, I noticed a definite improvement in my skin tone.  I've attached Before/After pictures (using a "cutout" artistic effect -- lets face it, nobody wants to see a fat, old tummy in Amazon's pictures).  You can see that I still have a lot of work to do, but the after picture showed definite improvement.  While I received this at a deep discount for review purposes, I plan on buying more of this product at full price to keep toning and tightening my skin as I lose more weight.  If I meet my goal weight, I will post picture of the final result.  I expect that will be mid-2016.

I received this yoga backpack in exchange for an unbiased review.  The strong fabric and zippers are quality, as is the stitching.  I expect this to last a good long while.  While I don't yoga, I do hike, and this backpack will be perfect for a day hike.  It will hold a day's worth of food and water, first aid kit, plus a few extras for my foray into the back country..  That said, if you want a bug out bag that will hold a few days of supplies, you'll probably want something a little larger.

This laptop, with its Intel Core i7-6700HQ 2.6GHz. processor (and can turbo up to 3.5GHz), the 16GB DDR4 RAM (which runs half as cool and twice as fast as DDR3) and its NVIDIA GeForce GTX 960M gaming graphic card will handle any game out there with ease.  The Matte IPS FHD display, with its 1920 by 1080 resolution, makes any game look awesome.  It will be awhile before I need to upgrade anything on this, but when I do, the slide-off upgrade panel will make it super easy to add a 2.5" SATA III SSD, a bigger hard drive or upgrade the RAM.Then there are the little extras...  I love the circuit board design behind the keyboard (see my picture).  You can reduce the intensity of the red backlighting by pressing "FN"+ "F3" or increase the intensity by pressing the "FN" + "F4" keys.  The backlighting can go all the way from nothing at all to "bright enough to scorch your retina".  I like it as bright as it goes, while my husband likes the light a little dimmer.  We can both "have it our way."  I love that the touch pad has right and left-clicking features, so it acts more like a real mouse.  Everything about this laptop screams quality and should excite any gamer.

Freddy, my pit mix, is very hard to please when it comes to dry dog food.  Until trying Eukanuba, the only thing he has ever willingly eaten is Hill's Ideal Balance Natural Chicken & Brown Rice Recipe Mature Adult Dog.  Freddy likes Eukanuba even better than the Hill's brand, and I love how healthy this is for Freddy.

I received this backpack at a discount in exchange for an unbiased review.  I have to admit it's quite a bit sturdier than I expected for something that's so lightweight.  I wanted to use this for my 72-hour kit, and (almost) everything from my kit fit into this bag -- except for my flashlight and water.  Unfortunately, the search for the perfect bug out bag continues.If you're just using this for a day pack, it will probably have enough room, and you will love all the extra pockets in this backpack.  If you need it for more than just one day, you'll probably need something larger.

I received this hat in exchange for an unbiased review.  Since the cap is acrylic, I assumed that it would be machine washable (especially since the product description doesn't say otherwise).  Unfortunately, the label says "dry clean only".  Since it's acrylic and made in China, I thought maybe they put the wrong care label on the hat.  I was wrong.  When I received the hat, it was wonderfully soft and beautiful.  As you can see from the before and after pictures, washing this hat made the stitches looked "stretched out", making them look like they are pulling apart, and the pom pom got quite ratty looking.  I'm not sure how the stitches got stretched-out looking, since the hat obviously fits the mannequin head the same (both before and after washing).If you're willing to spend the required money to dry clean this hat every time it gets dirty, you will probably like it.  If not, look for something that's machine washable.

My pit mix, Freddy, literally danced for this canned dog food until I put his bowl on the floor for him.  The entire bowl was empty in less than a minute.  I was a little concerned that the can had much more gravy than shown on the label, but Freddy didn't seem to mind.While Freddy doesn't have any allergies, this food does have a few ingredients that might concern those whose dogs do have allergies.  Here is the list of ingredients (if I misspelled any, please forgive me -- the print was tiny, and by time I finished typing all the unpronounceable names my eyesight was blurry):Meat Broth, Chicken, Chicken Liver, Beef Liver, Beef, Chicken By-Products, Poultry Fat (Preserved with Mixed Tocopherols, a source of Vitamin E), Wheat Gluten, Potatoes, Meat By-Products, Carrots, Dried Beef Pulp, Peas, Guar Gum, Flaxseed Meal, Salt, Calcium Sulfate, Sodium Tripolyphosphate, Potassium Chloride, Natural Flavor, Calcium Carbonate, Added Color, Fructooligosaccharides Vitamins (Vitamin E Supplement, Ascorbic Acid, Thiamine Mononitrate (source of Vitamin B1), Biotin, D-Calcium Pantothenate, Vitamin B12 Supplement, Niacin, Riboflavin Supplement,  (source of Vitamin B2), Pyridoxine Hydrochloride (Source of Vitamin B6), Inositol, Vitamin D3 Supplement, Folic Acid), Minerals (Ferrous Sulfate, Zinc Oxide, Manganese Sulfate, Copper Sulfate, Manganous Oxide, Potassium Iodide, Cobalt Carbonate), Carrageenan, Choline Chloride, Beta-Carotene.Guaranteed Analysis: Crude Protein, minimum 8.5; Crude Fat, Minimum 4.5%; Crude Fiber, Maximum 1.75%; Moisture, maximum 82%; Vitamin E, minimum 50 IU/kg; Omega-6 Fatty Acids, minimum 0.9%; Omega-3 Fatty Acids, minimum 0.1%

I received these hampers at a discount in exchange for an unbiased review.  I love how they fold into a tiny circle, and then pop open into a small hamper.  Each hamper is sized perfectly for a single load of laundry.  With two hampers, sitting side by side, I can now presort my laundry as they go into the hampers, whites into one and colors into the other.  Because they're made of breathable mesh, they don't hold onto the stinky smells of my laundry.  Each hamper has a large side pocket (great for detergent, pre-treatment and fabric softener).  Each hamper has sturdy hampers, making it a snap to carry from my room into the laundry room.The fabric and stitching both seem to be quality and should last a good, long time.  I'll come back in a few months and report whether I'm right about the sturdy fabric and stitching.

I take CoQ10 to protect my liver while taking Red Yeast Rice. While Red Yeast Rice isn't as toxic on the body as statin drugs, it does have the same properties, so it's always a good idea to add CoQ10, whether taking statins or Red Yeast Rice for your cholesterol.This also has BioPerine, which is also known as Piper Nigrum.  It's what gives peppers their spicy taste. So far, so good. It has been found to increase the absorption of a variety of nutrients, including vitamin C, selenium, beta-carotene, vitamin A, vitamin B-6 and coenzyme Q.  Even better. However, it can also increase the absorption of some medications (which can bring them to dangerously high levels in your blood), so check with your doctor before taking any supplement with BioPerine if you take any medications. BioPerine is also an immunomodulator, which can suppress one's immune system. This can be helpful if you have any condition caused by an overactive immune system or inflammation. However, if your immune system is already lacking (for instance, if you you're on chemo or taking steroids), it can be dangerous to take BioPerine.  To sum it all up, if you're relatively healthy, BioPerine should be safe (and likely helpful). If, however, you're taking any type of medication, it might be better to take a CoQ10 supplement without BioPerine -- ask your doctor.Before trying this supplement, I was taking Red Yeast Rice and another brand CoQ10 that didn't have BioPerine.  It did lower my cholesterol, but not enough.  After switching to VivaLabs CoQ10 with BioPerine, my total cholesterol level dropped 50 points in two months.  All my cholesterol levels (total, triglycerides, LDL, and HDL) are now in the normal range, and my doctor  is thrilled.
...these Sock Rocket needles are pointier than I like.  They tend to split my yarn, and I prefer Addi's regular tip circs.
I gave this a chance for a month.  There were no negative side effects, but there was no improvement in my stress level or mental performance either.

This slicer is great.  It works on most soft foods like boiled eggs, soft cheeses and hot dogs (so the kids don't choke on whole hot dogs).  The thing that really surprised me is that it makes great teeny, tiny bread cubes.  To make all the cubes shown in the picture, it took about 5 seconds.This slicer also comes with a great cookbook, with all the recipes using sliced or cubed food.

I received these tweezers in exchange for an unbiased review.  They works as well as my Tweezerman, extracting the finest hairs with ease.  I like that these have a plastic band that slips over the end, which will prevent misalignment during storage.  I did mark it down a star because they have a stiff spring -- I have reduced strength in my hands, and it's a bit difficult for me to squeeze the ends together.

The face is large enough that I can tell the time, even without my glasses, yet you can see from the picture that it looks good on my dainty (5.5-inch) wrist.  However, the band is also long enough to fit most larger wrists.  I love the luminous (glow-in-the-dark) hands, so I can see the time, even when it's dark.  The date is magnified, so I can even see that.  This watch comes in a beautiful leather presentation case, which will make a lovely gift for the lady in your life.Because the hands and the face are both silver, it can be difficult to see the time when in bright light, which is why I deducted a star.

This was not meant for multi-tasking (much).  If I try to do more than a couple things (or have more than two browser tabs open) at once, the computer slows down.  This is likely because the Click 10 has Windows 10 (a resource hog), but only 2GB RAM.  For a multi-tasker like me (who usually has 10-15 things going on at once from my HP laptop), it‚Äôs hard not to multi-task.  For someone like my husband, who does one thing at a time (and does it well), then goes onto the next thing when the first task is finished, this isn‚Äôt an issue at all.Some other thoughts on:* Operating System: This is the first Windows 10 computer I‚Äôve owned.  As timid as I was about the switch, Win 10 is not nearly as difficult as I thought.  For the few things I couldn‚Äôt figure out on my own, Windows 10 has a search bar at the bottom of the screen that allows me to search the computer or the web.  Sorta makes me wonder why I was so afraid to make the switch.* Storage: The Click 10 has 64GB storage. Toshiba erroneously calls it a solid-state drive. In real life, the drive is eMMC, an embedded MultiMediaCard (basically a memory card soldered on board).  It performs better than a mechanical hard drive, but not as well as a true SSD.  Accounting for Windows 10, you‚Äôll have about 50 gigabytes left for other files.  This works for my husband, as he mainly uses it for surfing the net and checking his e-mail.  If you save a lot of files (especially pictures or videos), you‚Äôll want to make more use of cloud services.  There is also a MicroSD card reader, for extra storage or transferring files.* Graphics: The Click 10 includes an integrated graphics engine called Intel HD (Cherry Trail). You will notice worse gaming performance than on a dedicated computer (one that doesn‚Äôt serve as a tablet and a laptop), so not many games work seamlessly here. You can effectively play lighter games like Diablo 3, World of Warcraft, or League of Legends. However, graphics-heavy Windows-type games such as GTA 5, Battlefield 4 and The Witcher 3 will be too much for this tablet/laptop.* Resolution: The monitor has a 1920◊1080 touch display, which makes it easier to read and do other tasks on the computer.  The clarity is what you would expect from this Full HD screen.* Connectivity: You get one micro USB 2.0 port on the monitor (which is where you plug the charging cable) and two full-size USB ports on the keyboard.  This isn‚Äôt a lot, so I am using a USB hub.  You also get a mini HDMI port, making it possible to use the Click 10 to stream video content onto your television.  Networking interfaces include a 802.11n WiFi adapter. Because there isn‚Äôt an RJ-45 port, you need a USB adapter if you want to access Internet with cable. Bluetooth 4.1 is supported (and very easy to connect to your BT devices).* Cameras: The Click 10 has two cameras, a 2MP one in front (for selfies and Skyping) and a higher resolution 8MP camera in the rear.  At 2.4 pounds (including the keyboard), you likely won‚Äôt use this to replace your digital camera, but it‚Äôs nice to know I can if I want to.* Keyboard: It‚Äôs a bit glitchy for the touch typist.  I have to press hard to get each key to type, and often I won‚Äôt notice a pressed key didn‚Äôt register the keystroke until the password I typed has failed.  Since my husband uses the ‚Äúhunt & peck‚Äù method of typing, this doesn‚Äôt bother him as much as it does me.In General: The Click 10 LX0W-C64 will work well as a general-use laptop for those who need portability.  I do like that this will work as a laptop, as well as a tablet, and when we go on vacation, we will take this instead of my full-size laptop. The Click 10 can run everyday Windows 10 programs (web browser, Office suite or HD content from Internet). Games won‚Äôt work well, there‚Äôs only an integrated graphics for them.  I like the resolution of the monitor. If these things interest you and you don‚Äôt need a heavy-duty computer, the Click 10 should put a smile on your face.

My pit mix, Freddy, is very picky about his treats. While he did willingly eat these dental treats, he didn't go gaga over them. I like that they do clean his teeth. However, I think I will keep looking for a dental treat, that he loves, rather than just tolerates.

I have degenerative disk disease, and the neck pain makes it darn near impossible to sleep at night.  This pillow, when placed atop my regular pillow, gently lifts my neck, allowing the back (or side) of my head to sink down enough so that my cervical spine is more naturally aligned.  This pillow has allowed me to get a decent night's sleep ever since I bought my first one (a bit more than 4 years ago).  The foam beads in my first pillow compressed enough that the pillow wasn't doing its job, so I bought another one.  Ahhhhh.  Blessed relief!  I can now sleep again, thanks to this pillow.  I also bought one for my husband, and he loves his as much as I love mine.

I like this cranbery extract water.  Not only does it keep me hydrated, but it keeps my body clean and purified.  It has a clean and crisp flavor, although it is a bit sweeter than I like my drink (I usually drink water when I'm thirsty).  It's not sweet enough to feel "sticky" in my mouth, just a bit sweeter than I'm used to.  I love that there's no sugar or artificial sweetener -- it's sweetened naturally with Erythritol and Stevia.  I also appreciate that it has no artificial color -- what little color there is comes straight from the cranberries.This drink will fit into the healthier way I've been treating and feeding my body the past four months.  It will help me stick to my diet when I'm in the mood for something a little extra sweet.

I knit lots, and if I don't properly store the wool (and other animal fiber) yarn, atmosphere and bugs cause it to degrade over time.  This bag will help prevent that, as it will keep bugs and humidity out of my yarn.Even the smallest of the three bags is plenty big, as you can see from my Before and After pictures.  I'm using the smallest bag to store 12 skeins of sock yarn (plus a few half-used skeins that I couldn't bear to throw away), and it only took up half the bag.  It was super easy to do...  I placed the yarn into the bottom half of the bag, used the white zipper closing mechanism to seal the bag, used my vacuum hose to suck the air out, then screwed the black cover (shown to the side of the bag in the Before picture) to keep the out from seeping back into the bag. These bags are nice and thick, and they feel like they should last a good long time without allowing any air in.I received these bags in exchange for an unbiased review.  The only problem was the white zipper closer.  There is only one, and it has to be shared between all three bags.  I would have preferred to have a closing mechanism for each bag in case I lose one.

From the outside, it looks quite small, but it fits everything I need, wherever I go.  Even my huge wallet/checkbook fits.  And all the pockets make it easy to keep everything separated, which makes finding it a snap.  I like that it has a flashlight attached to the key ring that snaps into the back zipper pocket, so I can see to insert my key in the door when it's dark out.While the red is a bit lighter than shown in the picture, it's not by much, and it's a beautiful color.

EDIT (10/29/2015): The seller sent a replacement charger, and the replacement worked perfectly.  I'm now satisfied with this charger.I received this charger in exchange for an unbiased review. When plugging this into my car's cigarette lighter, it fits very loosely.  Even worse, my USB cord fits into the port very loosely.  Because of the loose connections (both male and female), whether or not this works is hit or miss.  During the 2-hour trip that I tested this charger, it worked less than half the time.  Because of that, I can't recommend it.

I'm in my mid 50's and my eyes are definitely showing aging, so I was hopeful when offered one box of VIIcode free in exchange for an unbiased review. As the title says, the results are not instant, but by Day 6 they were visible (please see my photos showing the difference).The eye cream definitely does a good job moisturizing my eyes, and I used it above and below them. As you can see, the eye cream didn't do much for the puffiness above my eyes. This leads me to believe that the eye cream needs the pads to work its magic. I took before and after pictures, shown side by side. But comparing the two, I could see the puffiness is definitely reduced by Day 6. I don't see much difference in the tiny crows feet at the outer corner of my eyes. I probably would have with continued usage if this were more affordable.I do love the cooling feeling I that I experienced immediately after applying the pads under my eyes each evening. I also discovered, if I replace the film on the eye pads (the film is what keeps the pads from drying out), I can get one more use out of each pad (even experiencing the same cooling sensation the second night).

I regularly use Joyal Beauty Ultra Hyaluronic Acid Moisturizing Serum, so I was happy when offered the chance to test this Joyal Retinol Serum for free in exchange for an unbiased review.  When used at night, the Retinol Serum makes my facial skin even softer and smoother than using the Hyaluronic Acid Serum alone.  I have added both products to my daily routine, and I will purchase them again.

I've been eating healthier and losing weight.  With the weight loss comes lumpy areas where my fat used to be firm (especially in my thighs, buttocks and upper arms), so I was excited when given the chance to test this in exchange for an honest Amazon review.For the first week and a half, I didn't notice any difference.  It has now been two weeks, and I'm noticing a firming of those dimpled areas.  I've found it works better when used with Anti-Cellulite Cream.This set can also be used for performing lymphatic massage on yourself.

Freddy (a pit mix) is finicky, and I have a hard time getting him to eat natural dog foods.  In fact, after having tried several natural brands, this is the first one he has ever eaten without mixing in treats.  And he eats it with gusto.  This is a hit at our house.

My 10-year old granddaughter loves dolls, and she loves to get silly while she dances.  This dancing Lalaloopsy doll was a big hit with her.  The only complaint she has is the doll tips over, especially when dancing on a carpet.

I've owned three Taylor scales over the years, and they have always been accurate.  This one is no exception.  It reads exactly the same as my doctor's scale.  It easily switches from pounds to kg to stones, so you can accurately know your weight, whatever your country.  I love the beautiful marble photograph on the glass top, and it will fit nicely in the classiest of bathrooms.  I also like that the owner manual has a chart, listing whether your specific weight in relation to your height, is normal, overweight or obese.  It gives me an accurate target of where my weight really should be.

These bio-buds are supposed to be soaked and cooked.  I like them that way,but they're even better straight out of the bag.  They have a delicious sweet, nutty flavor, and they're perfect when I'm in the mood for something crunchy.  I mix them with the ShaSha Organic Sprouted Bio-Bud Adzuki Beans for a great-tasting snack.

These bio-buds are supposed to be soaked and cooked.  I like them that way,but they're even better straight out of the bag.  They have a delicious sweet, nutty flavor, and they're perfect when I'm in the mood for something crunchy.  I mix them with the ShaSha Organic Sprouted Bio-Bud Lentils.  I have these on Subscribe & Save.

I received this bag free in exchange for an unbiased review.  The bag is great for kneading all sorts of dough.  However, no matter how tight I pulled the included ties (even when using both at the same time), I couldn't make the bag watertight, which is what is needed for marinating meats.  As long as I made sure the bag stayed upright, none of the marinade spilled, but if the bag tips over, the marinade drips out.  For marinating, I prefer ZipLoc Freezer bags.The bag is resilient and stretchy, which makes it perfect for kneading.  Because it's silicone, there are no off-putting smells for the dough to absorb, and when I'm done, clean-up is a breeze.

I love white pasta, but I've stopped eating it in an effort to get healthier.  Most brown rice pastas I've tried have a gritty feeling in my mouth.  The addition of quinoa to the brown rice gives this pasta a much better taste and texture.  I love it!

When I first saw these gloves, I was a bit disappointed; they silicone is very thin, so I didn't think it it would do a very good job of protecting my hands.  However, when I agreed to receive these oven gloves at no cost to myself in exchange for an unbiased review, it meant I had to test them.  I heated my oven to 500 F, and after it pre-heated I put inserted a pizza pan.  After 10 minutes, I removed the pan from the oven while wearing the Etekcity silicone gloves, and (much to my surprise) I didn't feel *any* heat through the gloves at all.  These fit my tiny hands as well as it fits my husbands large hands.  I also like the little designs on the outside that make gripping pans easier.

I bought this item at a deep discount in exchange for an unbiased review.  I love peppermint oil for the myriad of uses (nausea, congestion, aches and pains, it wakes me up, etc), plus it just smells great.  At almost $14.00, this oil might seem expensive, but you get 3 times the volume that most other essential oils provide.  This oil smells clean and crisp, indicating its purity.  I love that this peppermint from this oil is grown in the United States (Yakima, Washington, to be specific), and manufactured and packaged in North Carolina.  This oil is steam distilled, meaning it isn't processed with harsh chemicals.Because of the quality, this peppermint oil is STRONG.  If applied to the skin, it must be mixed with a carrier oil to prevent skin irritation (a few drops of essential oil to 1 teaspoon of carrier oil).  If you accidentally get some on your skin, dilute it with carrier oil, not water.

I received a free bottle of Viva Labs Probiotics in exchange for an unbiased Amazon review.  Ever since I reached menopause, I've had problems with Candida, which has caused repeated mouth sores, an entire body rash and yeast infections.  To put it mildly, it has been torture.  Several years ago, I discovered Nutrition Now - PB 8 Pro-Biotic Acidophilus, which keeps my symptoms in check most the time.  I was hoping, since Viva Labs has 25 Billion CFU (as opposed to the Nutrition Now's 14 billion), that Viva Labs would keep my symptoms in check all the time.  Unfortunately, that's not how it turned out.  In order to give Viva Labs a fair trial, I completely stopped taking my normal brand, and that very day I started getting all the Candida symptoms I always get if I skip a dose of my normal brand.  I looked on the ingredients list (something I should have done before starting the Viva Labs brand), and noticed that, while Nutrition Now only has 14 billion live cultures, it has 8 different strains of probiotics (compared to Viva Labs 6 different strains).  I do know different probiotic strain affects a different part of the body, but I don't know which of the strains makes the difference (each brand has probiotic strains not included by the other brand).If you've got a problem helped by the probiotics included in Viva Labs, there are lots of live cultures (25 billion per capsule) in this brand.  I do know I like the other products Viva Labs manufactures.  Unfortunately, the probiotics didn't help me.

This cleaning rod is supposed to work for guns from .22 to a .45 caliber.  It might, but you'll have to buy extra jags if you have anything other than a .45 (which is the only jag in this set).  This means if you really want to use this for anything other than a .45, you'll run into extra expense.  I do like that the mirror like finish prevents this rod from picking up dirt and carrying it into the gun's bore (and that it's resistant to chemicals), but I wish it came with the jags I expected when I ordered this for my husband.One more thing.  Don't expect this to have everything you need, even if your only gun is a .45.  You'll also need a brush, mop, patches, cleaning solvent, and oil.  If you need instructions on cleaning your gun so you can get an idea of everything else you're going to need, you'll find some easy to follow steps here: http://survivalcache_DOT_com/how-to-clean-a-gun/ (Amazon doesn't allow other links in reviews, so replace _DOT_ with .)

The size large gloves fit my husband's hand perfectly.  It is stronger and stretchier than the latex gloves he used to wear, and they are thin enough to provide for the maximum dexterity; he can pick up the tiniest screw while he's wearing these gloves.

I always get bronchitis every year, starting in late September or early October.  I was hoping that Immune Take Care would prevent my yearly autumn illness, so I started taking it early.  Unfortunately, I got bronchitis again, right on schedule (and every bit as severe as it always is).  This supplement didn't cause any negative side effects, but it didn't help either.

I've been eating healthier, and and means no more soda.  While these definitely aren't a substitute for those who are still drinking soda pop, they are a suitable substitute for me.  I like that they come in glass bottles because there's no plastic-y flavor leaching into the beverage.  And I really like the the ingredients are organic.  I do have to admit that I could only taste one predominant flavor in each of the three varieties.  My favorite flavor is the tangerine-lime, which has a predominant lime flavor.  It tastes almost like Sprite (without being overly sweet).  I also like the blackberry-pear flavor, where blackberry dominates.  I expected the raspberry-watermelon to be my favorite because I LOVE watermelon.  Unfortunately, I couldn't taste the watermelon at all.  My husband likes that flavor.  Even though he hates watermelon, he couldn't tell there was any watermelon in there (until I told him).  My husband's favorite flavor is also tangerine-lime.  I wish IZZE Sparkling Water were available in single flavors, specifically the tangerine-lime.

I love these cloths!  I have extremely sensitive skin, and these are soft enough for even my ultra sensitive skin.  They're perfect for babies, but they're also big enough for adults.  These are also extremely easy-care.  I toss them in the washer and dryer, and they come out softer and thicker than they started.  Note: The seller does recommend drying flat or hanging to dry, but I didn't have any problems when machine drying.I received this product free in exchange for an honest review, and I loved them so much that I'm going to buy a few sets for family members that have sensitive skin.

I've been eating healthier and loosing weight.  I was excited when offered the chance to receive this product free in exchange for an unbiased review. because my weight loss has caused lots of fat ripples in my thighs and belly.  It did help with that, and on the first application.This is supposed to smell like lavender, but the smell was more chemical.  I decided to brave the smell and applied it to my problem areas.  It did smooth out the fat ripples; I have to give it credit for that.  However, it also made me itch everywhere I applied it.  The itchiness reduces if I let it completely dry before getting dressed (about 30 minutes), but it still itches a little, even after allowing it to dry on my skin.  If you don't have sensitive skin (and if you're not sensitive to strong aromas), I recommend this because it really does what it's supposed to.

4:16 MinsI have to say this was happy when I got the item , once I opened it up, I can tell the quality is not going to be so great. As I always do I try them out to see how it is and hoping for the best. Their is a few reasons why I'm giving this a 3 star. It's a great set up though.The quality on the vacuum is not so durable as I thought, as the plastic was breaking from me inserting and removing the attachment in the first use. I had to remove the lid and clean filter a few times in the same area. As their was not much to clean up on the carpet, by doing so I made a little hole on the filter. It does a good job on the seats a fabric material, although not on carpet. I had a hard time with it that if you have time to kill then go head. I suction is powerful but until the filter gets clogged up, within a few seconds, then the suction on it goes down.The attachment got hard to put in at times and when putting the attachment on the plastic area started to crack or chip off, very disappointing. I do like the attachment, how thin and long it is. Its a great idea, and came in handy. So if your get this do the vacuuming first then add the attachment so their is no cracking or chipping on your lid.Overall great for seat and fabric material, not for carpets and you need to keep cleaning the filter every few second or every other minute. Great suction then looses it after a while. Be careful when removing the filter as it rips easily. I was able to get this at a discounted price for my honest review and this is solely my own.

0:22 MinsI have to say the mask is cool, very well detailed.I was highly impressed with the great quality and with adjustable straps. It comes with a 7 inch by 2 1/4 inch padding that you can place underneath the mask if the mask is a little big. I place it on my forehead.The mask looks just like the image listed here, great detail, the mask does have some weight to it, not to much. The quality is great is not the cheap plastic kinds, it's made with resin material,  feels like clay. So do be careful with the mask, as it can break if dropped.The mask is sturdy, it has openings for the eyes, nose and mouth. The mask is 6 1/2 inches wide and 7 1/2 inches from top to bottom.The straps can be placed from 11inches to 14 1/2 inches with out being stretched and 1 inch width. The straps are thick and sturdy, with hard black plastic ends. It stays in place and the straps stay closed. It does not make it uncomfortable to wear or put pressure on my head.The mask is a great size for my face as it covers it from top to bottom, and it lines up just great. I am able to see perfectly fine, it does not restrict my vision or breathing. The mouth opening is a great addition as details matter. If you have a big head then this maybe be small for you as this barely fit my brother who has a chubby face. I highly recommend not buying Rocketfish tripods. If you ever need a replacement part (even something simple like the quick release plate, which you would expect would be readily available) you will have a very difficult time obtaining it, if you can get parts at all.I owned the RF-TRP65C which is similar and from the same line -- when the quick release plate was lost by my spouse, I contacted the manufacturer who told me what the part number was for the plate. I ordered it, and it was the wrong part. I contacted them again, and they assured me of the part number -- it was wrong and I got a second wrong part. The third contact, they just said oh it's not available. Add to this that their parts fulfillment happens through yet another company --- and add in the 3 calls to that place --- and I spent about 3-4 hours trying to get a $5 quick release plate, and in the end -- couldn't get one.Add to this that when I contacted the manufacturer, Rocketfish, and felt like the person I was speaking to had no idea what the quick release plate even was, I asked "are you familiar with camera tripods at all?" and he said "no, not really". There's your Rocketfish tripod support in a nutshell.Any other significant tripod manufacturer provides replacement parts -- I highly recommend AVOIDING Rocketfish. The product itself was ok but kind of pricey for what it was. In that price range, reasonable parts support should be assumed. I can understand on a cheapo $30 tripod but the 65C was $150...I can only assume you will have a similar experience on TRP47C as I had on the TRP65C since they are in the same product line.

This has been my favorite Stratocaster bridge because I really like the pop in arm both in terms of convenience and also just arm shape/position. However, it has suddenly doubled in price. You could buy the deluxe/ultra strat bridge prime for around $75-$100 recently...now it's suddenly $140+.Also -- When the heck will fender make this available in Gold?? You can buy the Gold American Standard bridge with the same style saddles but a screw in arm, but not the deluxe model with the pop in arm in a gold finish. Yet they sell the gold pop in arm, and the gold saddles, but not the gold tremolo plate or gold complete tremolo. You can also find a part number  and the complete part for a left handed pop in arm version in gold, but not a right handed version. C'MON MAN!!I recently decided to try some other brands of 2 point tremolos in gold finish since Fender has stubbornly resisted putting this 2 point bridge out in gold. And if I find a suitable similar replacement, I will come back and post it HERE.

PROS* various finish options* priced in the range of other strap locks* flushmount is a nice option if your guitar can accomodateCONS* not easily reversible due to needing to drill a larger hole for the flush mount insert* requires drilling about 1/4" deeper than a standard schaller straplock* maintenance is recommended in the instructions -- cleaning with wd-40 to avoid jamming/sticking* may have difficulty using certain higher quality/thicker leather straps* error in instructions calls for drilling with a 0.400 drill bit (good luck finding one). They actually mean that you should drill with a 3/8 bit, to a depth of .400 - measured the part with calipers before I installed.DETAILSI usually use Fender/Schaller style straplocks on my guitars and have never had an issue with those, other than the nut that holds the top half to the strap can come loose - but when it does it is typically obvious before you would ever have an issue. You tighten it with a socket on one side, and an adjustable wrench holding the other side -- and it will stay tight for a long, long time. The only problem -- on an SG the strap lock is on the back, facing your stomach, and the Schallers stick out about 3/4 of an inch, and poke you in the stomach. (Or possibly worse if you like to hang your guitar more at groin height. Can I get a snare hit?) Dual design Dunlops also stick out too far, really, on the SG. I tried those first but finally came back to the Flush Mounts, and in the end I'm very glad I did. However...I'm confident that both Schaller and Dunlop make good products that work well when properly installed. But the countersunk Dunlops are a little tricky on an SG. Mine is a '61 SG reissue, for reference.  Compared to a "normal" straplock - Schaller or dual purpose Dunlop -, the screws will go about 1/4" deeper. (The actual screw length is similar but they are mounted deeper due to being in the bottom of the flush mount insert.) See photo of 2 screws and consider what is flush with the guitar body and that will make sense to you.The flush mount Dunlop *seemed* genius and like it was the perfect solution. Unfortunately, the screws are so long that they will go slightly through the front of the guitar, although in a location that is covered by a plastic cover. I read on a website that on an SG you will actually hit the truss rod, but mine didn't - I was extremely careful to drill with a tiny pilot drill first, and "feel for it", gradually expanding until I had the right hole.I removed the front plate, felt for the pilot drill, finally put the screw in once I determined that it was no big deal, and filed the tip of the screw so it would be flush with the face of the guitar, then replaced the plastic cover that hides it.If you use a thick leather strap like a Levy's leather strap, you may have difficulty getting these on the strap. I have several Levys straps, and on one there was no way these would ever work. On the others, I was able to actually get it to fit ok.On the bottom edge of the guitar after drilling the 3/8" hole, I discovered Gibson had a 15/64" hole inside with a plastic anchor for the original strap button -- too big for the screw to fasten into obviously. So I had to drill that out further to 1/4", glue in a hardwood dowel, drill a pilot hole in that, and then mount the new assembly.It has worked out fabulously well, but this was more work than any other straplocks I've installed. On my SG, the other style locks sticking out was a real pain, and this is much better -- I'm glad I did it but it took a bit of extra work.

I'm very pleased with this Reverb tank. I bought it to replace an Accoutronics in a Fender Super-Sonic 22 combo, and it worked great. This is probably ok, but I'm not sure why some vitamin manufacturers include such a heavy yellow dye.It basically colors your urine and prevents you from detecting dehydration based on urine color. Normally, if my urine were the color it is when taking this product, I would assume I'm dehydrated and start drinking a lot more water. I think the marketing department may feel that people will believe the product is working if they can see a physical change - however, when I see the change I assume I'm whizzing all the vitamins out in my urine - unabsorbed by my body. Which by the way...is what studies suggest happens to a lot of vitamin supplements.This is probably an OK multivitamin - but I'm dropping it from my routine due to the bright yellow dye, and switching back to my previous multi-vitamin of choice. And yes, probably whizzing that out mostly unabsorbed as well.
seems to be ok

SUMMARYFantastic amp at a decent price. Better if you can work negotiate a discount and avoid tax. Sounds great - Small form factor (size/weight) is ideal for practices with a band, practice at home, or even gigging at smaller clubs or if you mic it, anywhere really. It is probably a bit overpriced at current $950 pricing, but...it is a real amp, not a toy. If you can only have one amp, this might be the one to have, or possibly a DRRI.PROs- Small size and weight- Big sound and great tone- Single channel blackface fenderCONs- Fender always uses cheesy metal feet that scratch the hell out of anything the amp sits on. Replace them with rubber feet for $5.- Lacks a cover (at least mine did).FEATURES THAT MAY BE PRO OR CON DEPENDING ON YOUR SITUATION- It's pretty loud, especially at 7-10 on the volume. Probably louder than you expect.- Removable power cord - I always think I want this but now I have it and I'm not sure it's a good thing.RECOMMENDED IMPROVEMENTS YOU CAN MAKEDisclaimer: I gig. If you don't, some of these might be less important to you, like the cover, eliminating the footswitch, or the tilt back legs- Add rubber feet and throw out the scratchy metal fender feet before you destroy things.  ($5) Best $5 you can spend on this amp.- Add a D2F cover - nice padded covers do a good job of protecting amps. (about $75)- Consider tilt back legs if you gig...eliminates the need for an amp stand. (about $40) available on amazon.- Get an attenuator! Addition of an attenuator can really let you access the best sounds in this amp at manageable volumes for practice. I highly recommend this if you want to get great amp tone while saving your hearing, which is your most important asset as a musician. Attenuators can be had anywhere from $50-$500 or more, and you do for the most part get what you pay for. Finding one used can help reduce the cost if you are patient and get a good one. If you haven't tried attenuators you owe it to yourself to get one and try it out.DETAILSThis is what I always wished my Blues Jr's sounded like, back when I had those. I had BJ's stock, and modified with BillM Mods, as well as loaded with all kinds of different speakers but they always came up lacking no matter what. I did. It's the amp circuit. Loved the form factor (size and weight) but not the sound...now the PRRI costs more but wow what a difference. Sounds great and it's small and light.I also have a Deluxe Reverb, and I've owned Super Reverb (both reissues). This sounds similar to a Deluxe Reverb but is a lot lighter and a little smaller. Remains to be seen how it holds up in the band setting --I've owned about 20 different amplifiers, Fenders, Mesa's, Vox's, Marshalls, Oranges, Crates, Line 6's, Rolands and more. I have to say that if you can buy this on a discount, this might be one of the best amps available for most players. Paired with an attenuator, you have a lot of versatility for practice and bands, in a package that is easy to carry around. There is a lot to be said for that. The DRRI is great but even that gets heavy lugging it around.I bought my PRRI used for $675 in pristine condition, and I love it already. I also have a DRRI I bought brand new at deep discount, which I'm also very satisfied with. I bought the Princeton hoping I could get into the overdrive tones at a lower volume (which I can, a little lower) but even with the PRRI unless you're playing with a band, you'll need a good attenuator to get into the 7-10 range on the volume where the sweet overdrive is, without being really loud. Also hoped to find great tone in a small package, and it DELIVERS on that.My preamp tubes (originally 12AX7A) were replaced with -R suffix instead of -A...might be a warmer tone - not sure. Gotta look into that. I like the sound. Overall, love the form factor (size and weight) of this amp, the single channel which I all I ever used on my deluxe reverb and super reverbs in the past anyway. Easy to carry, plenty loud. I haven't tried it with the band yet as I just got it but I'm impressed overall, and I think it has enough juice and volume to hang in fine with the band. This might end up replacing my DRRI as my primary practice and gigging amp with the band, depending on if it can deliver stage volume with my heavy handed drummer.Overall very pleased -- I haven't had mine long yet but have not experienced any of the rattles, hum etc that I see people grousing about in reviews here. Frankly, my advice on those is to send 'em back on return, or if it's too late for that -- call Fender and demand a repair or replacement under the 5 year warranty. They will usually take care of your issue, although it can try your patience.I'd have to say that while I'm a little concerned about some of the reviews commenting on quality issues -- I still have to recommend this amp highly. If you are concerned about those issues -- buy in a store instead of online -- where you can try the amp before you buy it, and also have the opportunity to haggle on the price and knock 10% to 30% off that price tag.I've had no issues whatsoever on my PRRI, which I bought used and which was shipped from Texas to California...no rattles, no hum etc.  at least so far.I will update my review as my experience grows with this particular amplifier.UPDATE - I have had the amp several months. No issues. Love the amp in stock form. As always the aftermarket D2F cover is useful when transporting to gigs, especially if it rains. Worth every penny. I got caught in a downpour and had to carry gear in the rain - but the amp stayed dry thanks to that cover. I also discovered that unlike my DRRI, if you turn on the reverb and tremolo with the footswitch plugged in, then unplug it, both functions remain on and adjustable. This is also the case after power cycling the amp, and after unplugging the amp. I thought I would need to make a "shorting plug" or "always on" plug to replace the footswitch and keep these functions on all the time -- but no need. On my DRRI, I used a shorting plug in place of the foot switch. Not needed here on the PRRI. Nice practice volume & of course would be great for recording I'm sure.

One of my favorite speakers, and I've tried a bunch. This 12" C12K 8Phm speaker came in my Deluxe Reverb amp stock.I'm a tone chaser so I've tried just about everything else too...Greenbacks, Creambacks, V30's, Jensen P12Q Alnico's, Jensen C12N's, Eminence GB128 Legends, Eminence Patriots, Swampthangs, Eminence Cannibis Rex, and even other sizes from 6" to 15".This is a great and versatile speaker, and a good price point at $95-$100. The biggest difference between this Jensen and most of the others is that it has what Jensen calls a "tight" low end. Most of the others have a looser low end that can be a little farty (P12Q comes to mind.)The only downside I see to this speaker is it is a bit heavy at 9.65lb. That big heavy magnet is the price of the tight low end. The other feature that could be a downside or an upside depending on your specific application is that it is fairly efficient at 99.1 db sensitivity, so it can be a bit louder than some other speakers at the same volume setting.Give it 75-100 hours of good "stage volume" break in, and she'll mellow out and sing for you. Jensens are sometimes a bit harsh until broken in. (As are many other speakers but Jensens in particular.)  Does good with distortion, overdrive, and every effect I've put through it. Overall, this is a great sounding speaker that cuts in the mix, and gives great sounds across a variety of genres and styles of play. I keep trying to find something I like better and I haven't been able to, although I haven't tried those creamback 65's in the deluxe reverb yet so those are TBD still.It's hard to find a more versatile and balanced guitar speaker, in my opinion. Sparkling cleans, chunky low end, and takes distortion and overdrive well.Highly recommend you listen to the sound samples on the Jensen site for tonal differences between speakers. Just be aware that those samples don't demonstrate weight differences, or sensitivity differences -- they normalize the volume in the samples.

SUMMARYPROs- low sensitivity (95 db) means this is not as loud as some other speakers at the same volume setting. (6 on the volume with this is about the same as 4 on the volume with a C12K in my deluxe reverb)- very light weight for a 12" speaker - at 4.1 lbs, it's a full 5 lbs lighter than a C12K (9.65 lbs)- good Jensen "brightness" - would definitiely "cut" in the mix.- 8 mounting slots means this can be a drop in replacement in Deluxe Reverb or other amps with 8 mounting studsCONs- Farty low end when amp is driven into overdrive, or when amp is clean but fairly loud- Fizzly high end when amp is driven into overdrive - this can be EQ'd away by backing off treble about 3 notches.- Seems overpriced for what it is. CDETAILSI picked one of these up and tried it in my Deluxe Reverb, in part because it is a lower efficiency speaker so is a little bit lower volume for the same power input. Also, it's substantially lighter (5 lbs lighter) than the stock C12K. And last I tried it because I loved the sound of my (former) Super Reverb that used four Jensen 10" speakers of similar style and magnet. I also watched some demos of FSR Deluxe Reverbs that use this speaker, and thought the earlier breakup would suit the style of music I am currently performing.However, compared to the Stock Jensen C12K, it turns out I prefer the stock speaker quite a lot.And compared to a 10" Jensen P10R, I like the 10" better than this P12Q.This P12Q is by comparison - almost fizzly sounding if you crank your amp enough to get the overdrive tones, or use an attenuator to get there. (It's not the attenuator, the comment applies without the attenuator as well.) Rolling back the treble helps that fizzly high end. But what I could not EQ successfully was the Farty low end. Jensen describes this as "loose" low end in the product description on the Jensen site. The C12K is described by Jensen as "Tight" low end. I guess a like a tight low end. The sound samples on Jensen's website do give a feel for the differences between the speakers - they play the same riffs through all the speakers so if you have decent computer speakers, you can hear the differences if you turn it up a bit.Speakers are a very subjective thing, and I'll also add that the differences may be more noticable for recording than for live performance in a club atmosphere. And their are tradeoffs. If the weight of hauling your amp around is killing you - this can shave 5 lbs off but sacrifices the low end and might need a little different EQ settings. It can also allow you to get to the tube overdrive at a lower volume than a C12K. But for me the farty low end was a killer.In my opinion, there are cheaper and better alternatives available from Celestion, Eminence, Weber and others. I've bought lots of speakers and tried them (including break in periods)  including Greenbacks, V30's, Creambacks, Legends, Patriots, Jensen Ceramics, Jensen Mods, Jensen Alnicos, Carvins, Mesa's and different sizes as well - 6", 8",10", 12" 15". You might say I'm a tone chaser, a gear junkie, or a mad scientist of guitar gear. This speaker, to me, has less bang for the buck at $139 than almost anything else I've tried. Luckily, I bought mine used for significantly less than that, so I can't complain too much...and I can afford to resell it without taking a bath. Or I might keep it in a 1x12 extension cabinet and see if it mellows with more playing. I can't be certain how much break-in it has seen, which might help the highs, but is unlikely to fix the farty "loose" lows. They sound similar to the Jensen sound samples so...I probably should have started there.I highly recommend using Jensen Speakers audio samples on line to listen carefully to various speaker choices from Jensen.

I bought one of these in 2001 and installed it myself. It lasted about 13.5 years before it started leaking at the veggie sprayer O-ring and at the handle O-rings. I ignored it for 6 months (bad me) then called Delta support in Feb 2015 - they sent me a rebuild kit and a new vegetable sprayer under warranty, no charge. Took about a week to get it.The finish on the faucet still looks like brand new, and with the rebuild, it's working like new too.I like the look of the chrome & brass...even though the style has now changed away from Brass it will come back. My faucet did not use the "quick connect" sprayer hose, but Delta sent me one that did, along with the adapter to update it. That will make future replacement easier as well. (At least in theory, if they don't change the method again.)My only beef is they discontinued the correct sprayer in Chrome & brass -- so had to send me a different one that doesn't quite fit properly. I will call them back and see if they have a hose with a properly fitting base that I can swap.Great support by Delta, just wish they wouldn't always keep switching the finishes.I bought new bathroom faucets & shower set in brushed nickel finish a few years ago -- went to add some additional accessories to match from the same line, and found they have pretty much discontinued brushed nickel finishes now. Seems like it's chrome or the stupid black/bronze finishes. Luckily, Moen still does brushed nickel so spent $$ with Moen on the stuff I needed in a line that was similar looking.

After one use:SUMMARYIf you are trimming with gas, you're a sucker. I'm done with gas and headed toward all battery powered yard tools after using this. The ability to use this early in the morning because it is quiet is really awesome. Low noise protects your ears and expands the working time so you can start early and get the job done while the neighbors are sleeping! This works as well as a gas trimmer in terms of cutting power, it's quieter and requires no futzing with gas and oil, no carburetor replacements, and the weight is lighter. Yes, batteries are expensive but so are carbs and I end up replacing those regularly.  Height was perhaps a little too long -- I'm 5'11" and felt like I had to lift up on the trimmer. I had wrist and back pain after trimming for a full charge - which was 45 min. Overall, I'm impressed, but a little concerned about the ergonomics. An adjustable length handle would have been a design enhancement, and a different trigger system would have been nice too. UPDATE: THE LINE FEED IS NOT VERY GOOD ON THIS UNIT AND I MESS WITH IT ALL THE TIME.PROS-Cutting power is fine - as good as the gas trimmer it replaced.-battery life 45 min is probably long enough and if not can be fixed with another battery purchase-LOVE the lack of noise - means I can trim at 5am if the sun is up without bugging neighbors-worked better than expected in "edger" mode.-Never ran out of line during a full charge - this is good. I hate stopping to mess with line.CONS-Ergonomics seem to be lacking - I had back pain and wrist pain after 45 min with this trimmer, not sure I want to endure that for the life of the tool-Switching to edger mode (rotating the shaft a quarter turn) was a three step process -- loosen a handle, then push in a button, then turn. My old Black and Decker electric did this in one push and turn motion.-Lack of ability to replace pre-wound spools -- but Might be able to buy "replacement heads" and prewind them to avoid mid trimming "rewind".- Seems like a lot of grass gets past the trimmer guard - I was covered half way up my to my knees.- UPDATE: THE LINE FEED STINKS -- for this reason I'd now recommend a different unit -- all I do is mess with the line when trimming. It's a pain.DETAILS, OBSERVATIONS AND CONSIDERATIONSINITIAL IMPRESSIONS - BEFORE FIRST USE After assembly, but before actually trimming with it I had some concerns and observations.1) Not sure the "round" handle is all that stable - might be prone to slipping position. I didn't find this to be true in use.2) The length seemed good for me, I'm just under 6' and I didn't think I'd be hunched over with this thing. I was wrong, it seems a little long and I have some ergo concerns after using it.3) I like the idea of the ability to add attachments, and noticed they also sell reconditioned ones pretty cheap, so might try a reconditioned edger. TBD4) I like the look of the battery charger, and the battery charge indicators that are built into the battery itself.5) After seeing the head, which looks like the same head I had on a homelite gas trimmer (and hated) I was wishing I had ordered something with replacable pre-wound spools. (Black and Decker or Worx, for instance.) All my prior electric B&D tools were pretty awesome, and the trimmer had prewound spools available. I think I'm going to hate hand winding cord onto the one spool, and I'm concerned about how the line will feed in use. Maybe I can buy a couple replacement heads or something so I can prewind them and have them ready to go. Nothing pisses me off more than running out of string and having to stop and hand wind a spool. I bought some Ryobi 0.080 prewound spools but they aren't the right thing for this trimmer, even though the label says it works on 40V Ryobi - no model numbers shown. The concern is that if this is anything like the similar head that was on my homelight gas trimmer -- I spent more time futzing with that than actually trimming (what a POS.) After use, the head worked ok so I'm less concerned. -- UPDATE - the factory wound spool as ok -- once I had to wind my own it's been nothing but trouble. either I'm doing it wrong, or this line feed system stinks! Fairly certain I'm doing it correctly.6) I'm a little concerned that the plastic trimmer guard and the metal connection remind me too much of the last homelight gas trimmer I had -- the metal parts would collect heat as the shaft heated up from use, then eventually the stupid thing melted away and I had to order another. They aren't expensive but I don't want to have to do that. The connection point on this one looks similar so I'm a little concerned. After use - thought this did ok but allowed a lot of grass to fly by and hit my shoes and legs.OBSERVATIONS AFTER FIRST USEI charged the battery fully (plugged in overnight), and took it out back for some Heavy trimming in high weeds on my multilevel backyard. I'm on a .25 Acre lot, with a several hundred linear feet of flowerbeds and retaining walls to trim around. The grass was badly overgrown as the yard is "mid renovation" so had been let go during the winter season and just got its first mow.1) I LOVE that I could go out at 6 in the morning without any concerns about the noise of a gas trimmer waking neighbors. This is when I have time for yard work!2) I didn't notice the trimmer being much lighter than my gas trimmer in use, but it probably is a little bit lighter.3) The "balance" seemed a little less than optimal. I felt like I was lifting the head up, as opposed to holding the head out and letting it "hang". So I noticed a bit of lower back tension using this trimmer.4) I found the trigger system a little cumbersome wearing gloves. The gloves seemed to get caught a little under the triggers at times. Minor regripping solved it but...do I want to mess with that for the life of the tool? Not sure.5) The battery lasted about 40-45 min on a full charge in very heavy trimming. Not bad, but only got me about half way through the task at hand. In normal conditions, probably would be enough to do my backyard but might need another battery...not sure there is another unit with much longer life so it's a function of the Amp-Henries of storage on the battery...easily solved for $125 for another battery.6) My biggest concern is that after the trimmer my right wrist was really sore....so ergonomically, this trimmer is putting a weird load on my wrist. This may be enough to convince me to take it back and try a black and decker or something else.7) Cutting power was as good as all my prior electric and gas trimmers or better.8) The auto feed head worked great, alleviating some concerns, although I wonder once I have to wind it myself if it will feed the same.OBSERVATIONS AFTER SEVERAL USESI really like the trimmer except the line feed is terrible.
