If I had it to do over, I'd have bought a different trimmer because of this. I should have known but I'm into this one for two batteries, the trimmer and an edging attachment (which is awful) so for now it stays. Still...a good battery trimmer is as good as gas...just costs more up front on batteries.

Great little overdrive pedal at a nice price. I always like the form factor, size, and simplicity of controls on Electro-Harmonix pedals like this. They use the "standard" 9V power supply and put the jack where it belongs on the back. Also with the quick peeling off of the rubber feet, you are one piece of velcro from sticking this on a pedal board without weird topography on the bottom of the pedal -- it's just flat, with recessed screws -- perfect.I bought this just for the hell of it because it's inexpensive - and I really like it so far. Have only used it on a small amp that needed just a hint more overdrive and it worked great. This could be used for clean boost, or as an overdrive pedal. Or buy two and have BOTH. Gotta put this in front of a couple more amps and crank it up in a real band setting -- and once I do I'll provide more feedback.What's not to like?

Just got these, thought I was buying the same as some prior sheets we got online but wow...these are cheapo. Thin and easily wrinkled, haven't put them on the bed, and might just give 'em away...they feel cheap. It's so hit and miss buying bed sheets online. Next time I think I'll go to a department store. I've bought about 5 sets on amazon and only like 1 of those.

These are ok but kind of feel cheap and flimsy. To me, they don't have that "great cotton feel" when you crawl into a freshly made bed. They are ok but I like the 800 thread count striped sets sold from the "Egyption Cotton Linen Store" better, at about the same price.We have 2 sets of these but I'm probably going to donate them to goodwill and buy something I like better.In retrospect, I think these are way overpriced for what they are.Not really a fan but they are "ok"

We bought these in late 2011, it's early 2015 and these are my favorite sheets of several sets we have.The only ones I ever liked better were VERY VERY expensive, while these were not.They are thick enough to have some substance, all cotton and feel great when you climb into a fresh made bed.We have several other sets bought on amazon that were disappointing.

Bought the iPhone 6, 4.7 inch Space Gray, Edge to edge Ballistic Glass 1 pack.SUMMARYReally like the product but mine had a small flaw right in the center. For $20 for a small sheet of plastic, I don't think that should happen so I contacted their support. Took 5 days and multiple emails to resolve, then will take up to 10 days but probably less for me to get a replacement. They did agree to send replacement though, which is the right thing to do. Fit is good but they might consider making it about 1mm wider all around, not sure. Overall I do really like how the product installs and how it seems to function. Once I get the replacement unit that isn't flawed, I think I'll be happy with the purchase.PROs* Presumably more protection than a flexible plastic skin* Easier to lay down for a clean fit than the flexible plastic skins* Proper preparation did a nice job of eliminating any dust/bubbles* Thicker, stronger than a plastic flexible skin* Issue was, in the end, addressed with the right answer - a replacement. (i.e. Support "did the right thing")CONs* Expensive (for what it is)and if the product has a problem, now you are messing with support or returns. With a multi pack of cheap skins, throw away and try again with another - no support required.* Size - Looks slightly smaller than I expected for "edge to edge" product. It looks to run close to the edge of where the glass rounds over, but looks like it could use 1mm more coverage all the way around. It's not a big deal and I'm sure it provides good protection in a drop/scratch situation.* Support was slow - would have been faster and easier for me to just return and order another unit prime shipped.SUPPORT EXPERIENCE* Support - They included in the package one of those messages saying "Don't return the product, give us a chance to make it right if you aren't happy". I took them up on that. It took 5 days and 5 different people handling their tickets and e-mails, but they did agree to send a replacement. I had to nudge them 4 days into the process and say - hey this is taking too long - what is the resolution. I'm told all replacements ship out of LA by first class USPS mail, so please allow 7-10 days for delivery. I live in Northern California so I expect I'll have it in a day or two. On the one hand, it's great that they responded and are replacing the product. On the other hand, it would have been at least twice as fast and taken less of my time to just return the product and order another. It would have cost me return postage, where in this case they did not ask for a return of the defective unit. Oveall, they did the right thing but need to improve their support communications and streamline their process. Something like this should take, at most - 2 replies, the first asking for any information needed, and the 2nd informing that the issue has been handled and how.My advice if you have an issue - is return the product on day 1 and just order another, especially if you have prime shipping. It will take 2 days instead of 2 weeks. Or just get it at your local "phone" store and have it installed right there - if there are any issues insist on a different unit right then and let them deal with the manufacturer. I think the price was the same in the store (although everything else was a heck of a lot more than I paid online so I bought all the accessories online)

The physical fit to my 30 pin cord wasn't that great. It connected, but didn't click into place and wasn't that stable/firm.It did charge OK, and that is all I bought it for. I have not tried syncing or any media transfer with this adapter, and I doubt I ever will.You can't take any of that for granted with the cheap knockoff parts...for example by comparison to another similar cheap adapter, the other one fit great and clicked into place, but then did not function...at all.Maybe the two companies should merge :)

I had no expectations that this would work for media transfer, but I did expect it to be able to function for basic charging purposes.It doesn't. In fact, when I plugged this into my phone, it actually started draining the battery instead of charging it. The cord I was using it with is fine - I had just successfully charged an old iPod with the cord when this arrived.I returned it immediately as it is useless, and performs no functions at all. It's junk. Don't waste your time.

BACKGROUND/BASELINE INFOI am reviewing the 820H, which is the 8" speaker. Amazon shows all the same reviews for both the 620H and 820H, which I think can  be a little bit misleading. The 6" and the 8" will sound different. I want to be clear that my comments are regarding the 820H 8" version. Also, I've had the speaker mounted for about 3 months now to give it sufficient break in time.SUMMARYI found the speaker to be a quality speaker with a pretty good sound for an 8" speaker, but not nearly as good on the low end as a 10" or 12" speaker. It will tame harshness in a very bright amp as it is mellower on the highs. However, I found it to be overpriced for what it is. Most 8" speakers are $35 range - this is $70. It sounds a bit fuller, but I didn't think the value was there at $70. Also the power rating at 20W RMS is limiting in terms of putting this in a cabinet as a small option. Ok for 10W amps, but I'd start getting nervous trying this with a 15 or 20W amp. If this was rated for 35 or 40 watts, it would be more versatile. I'm currently running this in a standalone 1x8 cabinet with a mesa boogie mini rectifier head in 10W mode as a practice amp. It's ok...but a 1x10 is really better.PROs and Best Uses- Amps 10W and less (due to it's 20W RMS rating)- The Champ it was designed for- Amps that are harsh on treble - this will cut back the treble a bit- Slightly better/tighter/fuller bass response than most 8" speakers- Use in "bedroom" sized amps.- Use in a cabinet with a high quality head as a practice rig - for helping keep volume controlled.CONS- Twice the price of comparable 8" speakers from Jensen, Celestion and others- Power rating at 20W makes it a less practical speaker for use with amps in the 15-25W range.Probably need to stick to 10W amps and below.DETAILSFrom reviews I've read, people seem to really like this in a Fender Champ. And it appears it was designed specifically for that application so that makes sense. More power to them. I don't have a Fender Champ, so can't comment there.There is also a Bugera V5 crowd that seems to like it as well, although I found it to be a downgrade in that particular amplifier. That amp is a bit short on treble and adding this speaker gives it even less. I did not experience a richer low end either - I preferred the stock Bugera branded speaker in the V5, and I wouldn't recommend this speaker in that amp if you are considering it. I had this mounted in a V5 for about a month.I've also run this with a Mesa Mini-Rectifier head in 10W mode as a practice amp. For this purpose, it's not bad. It has a fuller low end than say a Jensen C8R, but also less treble. It still does not have the low end you get from a 10" or 12" but it's not bad. I think a pair of these in a 2x8 cabinet would be interesting and open up the options of running with amps like a princeton reverb, deluxe reverb, or even the Mesa mini rectifier in 25W mode. The 20W power rating is a bit limiting in that respect for one speaker. But at $70 each, that's $140 for a pair -- you could buy a better sounding 10" for less than 2 of these...I own several amps and several speakers including sizes 4", 6", 8", 10", 12", 15" and 18". You could say I've been on a speaker exploration for a few years. I've tried a lot of speaker and amp combinations and bought and sold a lot of speakers (about 20-25 different speakers) in the past few years. I've tried smooth cones, ribbed cones, hemp cones, paper cones, different magnets, different sizes and voices, and most of the major manufacturers.Also combinations of different speakers. It's a subjective thing but I can tell you when you find a speaker or speakers you like with a particular amp, you know it. It's also important to play in both a real band situation, and just playing in your practice space alone.It wasn't that this is a bad speaker or sounded bad, it just didn't sound that much better than other 8" speakers and it cost twice as much. Also the power rating at 20W is limiting. I would really like to see an 8" speaker with this sound and a little higher power rating -- so it could be used as an ultralight, small, portable cabinet with enough power to run  20-25 watt amp head.I have bought lots of eminence speakers new (and used) but I don't get all the hype or the price on this one. I know there are lots of folks who seem to think it's great but I'm not hearing enough benefit to warrant the price tag personally.Overall it's a decent 8" speaker, it just doesn't seem to be a very good VALUE in terms for what you get for the extra $35 - $40 compared to other 8" options.It looks like maybe they have started to lower the slightly price from when I bought this -- so maybe others felt the same - that it was priced too high for what it is. I'd probably give it 4 or maybe 5 stars at the $45 price point.

I originally had an identical case for my iPhone 4. I think I paid $40 for it from Verizon at that time. I never liked the way the belt clip dug into my side, so I ditched the front but kept the back on the phone for 3-4 years. I dropped it a few times on concrete and never broke anything. I also found the pop out stand very handy and used it all the time. The case back did a good job for me, so...Now I just got an iPhone 6, and saw this online for $9.99. What a great deal. Bought it right away, popped this on the phone, and still don't like the way the belt holder digs into my side. So once again, I'll keep the back, toss the "front" with the belt clip, and carry the phone in a leather holster.I was surprised this came with a screen protector and a stylus. But I separately ordered a ballistic glass screen protector so if that fits with the case, I'll be using that. If not, the little thin plastic one that came with this will be handy to have. The stylus...not useful to me as there is no place to clip it into the case. I don't see using that.My -1 star is for the hard plastic belt clip that is very uncomfortable. But even knowing that, I really like the back half of the case for the stand and the grip, and I bought it.

SUMMARYI love the look and the light weight. But it's a nice looking guitar that has been unusable in a band situation due to bad quality. A non-starter at it's price point, compared to fender, epiphone and others. This is really a novelty toy guitar. Buy only if you want the looks, then plan to spend money on different electronics or repairs. This is not a guitar you want to rely on as a primary guitar but if you want a novelty item for a couple songs, it's ok. I really wanted to love it and was considering several other Dano models for my collection, until I played it, then it made me go "meh" when I actually played it, and the quality rendered it virtually useless. It sat on the rack for 9 months and I'm now finally coming back to explore warranty repairs before the warranty expires. Standard warranty 12 months, requires you to ship to LA for repairs.  Danelectro lacks local authorized repair shops. With prompting, they agreed to pay for my local shop to make a repair.PROs- cute cosmetics- sounds decent in the center position with both pickups engaged, when it works.CONs- build quality is lowest possible.- factory setup is fair to poor- electronics failed on first use- I've also noticed a potential issue with the bridge inserts which may render it impossible to setup - so may be looking at further warranty repairs or replacement.- Standard warranty support is bad with no local authorized repair sites - must ship guitar to LA for warranty repairs - expensive and time consuming - or repair it yourself locally - Danelectro will send you parts, you pay any labor or do it yourself. With some prompting they agreed to pay a local shop for my initial issue - a bad 3 way switch.DETAILSI really wanted to love this guitar, but it sucks. I have many other guitars (about 20 at the moment, have owned and sold many others) and this has turned out to be the worst guitar purchase I ever made.I realize others may have better experience but I got a bad unit. A return was also no economically practical for me. I bought a DC59 in Alligator Blue, which cost about $50 more. Because that model was not widely distributed, I had to buy online from an East Coast music store that had it in stock, and I'm in California. Not an issue, except when it had a problem, making a return became an expensive proposition.The quality of the electronics is very low. The first time I played the guitar was in a band practice, and the switch failed after just a few songs. At that point it became noisy any time you touch the switch, and it fails to cut off the bridge pickup in the position where it should do so. I considered a return but due to cost to ship back, stuck it on the shelf thinking I would check into warranty repair, but didn't get around to that for some time.When I contacted Dano about warranty, they offered to fix in LA if I ship to them, or they would send the part. After some prompting they did agree to pay for me to have a local shop do the repair, and they are providing the part. So they are making an effort to improve the service around the warranty, after some discussion.I do appreciate that they took care of the issue - with the switch replaced, it is a lot better. I did some minor adjustment and changed the strings and it's a little better now.When working properly, the guitar sounds pretty weak on either pickup - I would mainly only play it in the center position with both pickups on. Otherwise it sounds very thin. I don't really believe in "good sounds and bad sounds" just different sounds that can be used to create different feels in songs, so those thin pickups could be useful in specific situations. But not for "workhorse" guitar work on most songs. You will typically want to run in the center switch position - both pickups on.The volume and tone pots are concentric stacked, and if you try to adjust either while playing, you will find it takes 2 hands to adjust volume and tone independently -- grab either knob and they both turn together. Limiting on stage, to say the least. There's always ways around that - use a volume pedal...etc.The factory setup isn't great either - but I'm not sure I want to pay the cost of a setup on this guitar. I was excited about it when I bought it but because of the low quality it's never been played at a gig and only in practice once. In my opinion, it's a toy and should be priced accordingly at about $100. I'd be surprised if it cost them $50 to build it. The body is plywood, and mostly hollow. All of the component parts are the cheapest available anywhere. Pull the pickguard off and look for demonstration in "cheap". Yet the guitars cost as much as a Fender Standard or Epiphone. Kind of a ripoff there but ok the brand and looks have some value and history.But without function, it's only good for hanging on a wall and looking at it. Back in the days of the originals, these were known for being very inexpensive. But now you pay a lot for the brand name and the look -- so the value isn't there like it once was on Danelectro/Silvertone etc.Compared to a Fender Mexican Stratocaster or an Epiphone in the same price range, this thing isn't even in the ballpark in terms of sound or build quality, materials, and design. Just isn't. So if you are buying a first guitar and want to get years of use out of it without issues -- don't buy one one of these - get a Fender or Epiphone or spend more for an american made Strat or a Gibson. The ability to properly adjust and setup your guitar on a Fender or Epiphone in the same range makes it infinitely better.For example, the bridge height adjustment is on two screws the are simply screwed into the wood -- by comparison to a Fender or Gibson which uses studs screwed into metal inserts....so the Dano is not really built for a long life of adjustments and fine tuning, but it functions.I tried playing this Dano through the new Digitech 12 string simulator pedal last week, and thought the lipsticks would really give the jangle but it wasn't great for that either. My better guitars with better pickups and better electronics all sounded much better through that pedal.In the end, I think Danelectro really needs to contract with someone like Guitar Center who has a national footprint, to provide basic warranty repairs. The basic quality of parts is subpar in the $400 range so just know that what you are paying for is the look, the shape, the cosmetics, and to a degree the sound. If you are a serious player, you're probably going to want to make modifications to the electronics to install something more durable. Also know that other mechanical design features are the cheapest conceivable...the way the bridge mounts, the way the neck mounts etc. The guitar has a purpose, and it can be playable but know what you are paying for and what to expect. It's a kind of a toy. So I won't say "buyer beware" but I will say "buyer, be aware". There are better built guitars available for half the price, and pretty much everything in the same price range has a far superior build quality.I don't hate it but if only they would use slightly better materials, it could be a lot better. If yours works it can be fun as a novelty item and can offer a little bit different sound, a cool historical look, etc. But you would never want to rely on one of these as a primary guitar at a gig, and because of poor quality, low value relative to the price, I have to rate the product down overall. It's "ok" but novice players buying this guitar should know that in the long run, you would be better with something else for durability and hassle free performance.I was considering several other models but the quality is so low, I can't see buying another one unless I buy it used and substantially cheaper than the new price.That said, now that mine is functioning properly, it's kind of fun and I do still appreciate the two things I originally liked about it -- the light weight and the kinda cool looks...Just be aware if you are buying one that it's built cheap, and consider your intended uses. To me, it's kind of a novelty guitar, not so much one you want to rely on day in and day out.

Good quality, good colors, and tons of pockets and storage mostly in the right places. This is nearly a perfect configuration, other than the contents of the front lower pocket, which really needs rethinking, and the lack of any smaller compartments in the main section.Description Back to Front:- Nicely padded shoulder straps, plenty of length adjustment- Adjustment  straps have plastic finger loops for easy adjustment- On top there are two "handle" type straps. One is well padded and very visible in the product photo. This is the main grab handle. There is also a canvast strap that runs parallel to this handle, but is more on the back surface. I think that is intended for if you need to "hang" the pack. It isn't padded.- Main compartment has a well padded laptop slip in compartment with a velcro strap. I think the velcro strap is quite a bit longer than it needs to be, but I guess that accomodates larger laptops. There is then another padded flap that I think is there with two purposes. You could slip a tablet in the pack between the laptop pouch and this flap, creating another section with padding on both sides. Or if you fold this flap down it fits perfectly in the bottom of the bag and provides a sturdier "bottom" to the bag, with padding. That is probably the main intended purpose, and I think it is a flap so the bag can be "flatter" if desired, and for when they store them and ship them. The main compartment is 7" deep at the bottom, so you can put a lot of stuff in this part of the pack. Books or folders with papers, or jackets, hats etc. I would have preferred to see this about half as deep, with the 2nd compartment splitting that depth. Also would prefer to have some smaller net storage in here to contain for instance a laptop power supply and cord, pens/pencils, etc. It would be nice to access that all from the main compartment.- Side net pockets - for water bottles etc. These are great for coffee cups or water bottles. I wouldn't have a pack without these. Stay hydrated. If you are in college, this is where you carry two extra 40 oz beers you can drink on the way to your most hated class. You know...unless you want to graduate.- 2nd large zippered compartment is not padded but is large enough for documents, or a variety of items you may not want "on display" when you open the main compartment to pull out your lappie. For instance, I have placed medications, or confidential papers, or just things I carry around but don't use and don't want to see the wear and tear of the main pocket. This is also a good place for my Bose Noise Cancelling Headphones in their zippered case.  There is a nylon divider or pocket in this compartment, so you could put papers in the pocket and then a rolled up jacket or baseball cap in the other section outside the pocket.- Front top zippered compartment: This is my favorite -- I put my work badge, a wireless mouse, various USB flash drives, and anything small that I need quick access to. This is just a zippered compartment - it contains no additional pockets or features. But, it is one of the most used pockets on my backpack.-Lower front zippered compartment - this one might be overkill inside, but if you like a lot of separate pockets for distinct items -- this is the place. Inside this chamber these is another horizontally zippered compartment basically the full size of the pocket. Then on top of that there is a net pocket suitable for a phone or calculator, or perhaps something like passport wallet. In the center there is a vertical pouch with a velcro strap on top. Open that and the thing expands and has another velcro top slightly smaller pocket, and on top of that a 3rd small pouch. I'm not sure what I would use those for and I'd have preferred to see pen/pencil compartments across this section. To the right of that is a slightly wider pocket that is just the right size to put a hohner harmonica in it's plastic box. for most people, I'm not sure what this pocket is good for, it's too small for a phone and too big for pens and pencils. The front face of this has 3 layered slots at different heights. Again..usefullness of that is TBD. I really wish this section had individual pen/pencil pockets. That would be perfect for a work bag.- The front face has 4 canvas loops sewn in which I assume are for hanging other items from with carabiners. Maybe I will order some carabiners so I can use these :)PROs* Good Quality of construction and materials* Good design of most pockets* Price wasn't off the chart, although more expensive that some others of similar quality but lesser features* Water bottle pockets and top front zippered pocket are "must haves" for me.CONs*  The first negative I see is that the strap adjustment slides and the 1 carabiner loop on the straps are plastic. If they were metal, this would be the perfect bag. The problem with putting the plastic parts on this or any backpack is that they usually break before the pack is worn out. These are the weak link in the design of most packs. I don't see metal hardware on many if any so...I guess that just is what it is. They don't rust, on the upside.*  The front lower zippered compartment is too busy with too many little compartments that don't seem to be designed for anything I own. I'd prefer to see one section for pens and pencils, one or two net sections for sunglasses/(or glasses or reading glasses) cases, etc.OVERALL SUMMARYHappy with the pack, it's almost perfect and a good replacement to a similarly designed pack I had for several years. Wish it had better compartments in the front lower pocket. Worth it's cost, and looks pretty good too.

This pedal is available in either this 300 watt version or a more modest power rating (I think 100 or 150W).I have the lower power version -- the functionality is the same.See my review of the regular ($229) version for more detail.-1 star for design choice to use the proprietary 15V Wall wart. That's dumb. Just make it 18V so it can be run from most pedal board power supples instead of the custom wall wart. I hate it when pedals require a special power supply becuase it is more gear that has to be carried to a gig and not easily prewired. Not too bad if there is 1, but a real pain if there are several.

Lots to like here. Not everyone needs one of these, but it can be very useful if you have some specialized sounds that you need to get to in one stomp, but that require multiple pedals. For instance, I have one loop that contains an Electro-Harmonix B9 organ machine and a Hammond Leslie pedal -- these two together can get a great Hammond B3 + Leslie speaker sound, and with the looper -- it's on one stomp.I also like having the boost on the pedal. I set this one for a small boost, and I also have another clean boost pedal at the end of my chain, following this pedal. With the two I have 3 levels of clean boost -- "moderate", "pretty loud", and "you just blew the paint off the walls" (both combined).I've used the remote control feature as well. It's ok but what I'd really like better would have been if it had a way to switch in one stomp between the two loops.PROs- size is reasonable- seems transparent enough- tuner input- boost button with adjustable gain boost-two loops, plus passthroughCONs-Weird 15V power supply means I HAVE to use the provided wall wart. That sucks -- just make it 18V so it can run off a pedalboard "brick" type multiple output power supply. -1 star for this bad design choice- The loops, when remote controlled, don't work quite the way I'd like them to in terms of how you go from one loop to another and the configurable options for the TRS input. Hard to explain here.- I have heard you can't insert this looper successfully into your amplifier's effects loop, but I haven't tried that. The amp I'm currently using it with doesn't have a loop, it's a Fender DRRI. Not a big deal for me but I can see how it could be for some folks.SUMMARY- If you need to simplify the pedal board river dance and have  a couple multi-effect sounds, this is a pretty good way to do that without a huge investment in more sophisticated controllers. The slingshot remote control option also opens up some interesting possibilities in terms of putting this in a rack with a drawer full of pedals and then putting the remote pedal in front of you. It's a cool pedal. Maybe priced a bit high for what it is. I bought mine used and still thought it was a little more than it should cost, so new the price is high. Maybe that's why there are so few reviews.Build quality seems very good. I'm happy with it but really wish they had used a 9V or 18V power supply instead of the really weird 15V option.

For me, this is just what the doctor ordered. I'm playing in a blues/blues rock band that needs some organ sounds, but we have not been able to find a keyboard player to provide them (at least so far.) As I took about 5 years of organ lessons as a kid, I was considering buying a portable organ (about $1500) until I saw this pedal. This pedal brings some Hammond sounds into our Allman Brothers and Bluesbreakers tunes, and without my having to buy an organ or carry it around. For my purposes, it's perfect. Good sounds, easy to use, small size, highly portable.PROS+ great organ sounds.+ simple to set up and use+ "standard" 9V power supply and the jack is located on the rear vertical surface where it belongs+ small form factor / doesn't hog space+ eliminates need to carry a keyboard to blues gigs, and helps maintain a simple rig and small footprint+ I did not experience (at least so far) any weird noise from the pedal, so I suspect what some people have reported may in fact be related to their technique, their pedal board setup, or their power supply. I have played at high volume with this pedal on a board once so far. (I've only had it less than a week.)+ Plays well with Hammond Leslie pedal. The two together can really provide that Hammond B3 + Leslie sound including the flexibility of speed up/slow down/braking multi speed Leslie, plus the organ tone coming from this B9. I put those two pedals in a loop so I can step on one button to get my organ tone. Then I manipulate the Leslie pedal buttons as needed. If you don't want to spring for the leslie pedal, you can still get a pretty decent sound from the B9 alone, it just doesn't have a way to adjust the leslie speed while playing and it doesn't sound as good as the leslie pedal. But it's pretty decent alone.CONS- a bit expensive for what it is...seems like this should sell for $150, not $220. Get a coupon or negotiate with your local store and try to get 20%  or 30% off. I didn't have too much trouble getting 20% off at my local store, took about 3 minutes of negotiation, saving just under $50.OBSERVATIONS* The pedal is sensitive to your technique, so like some other effects, you need to learn how to use it. You can't quite just plug in and use it perfectly the first time -- although it is pretty close. It only took me a few minutes of messing with it to "figure it out". Just like you have to learn to play a wah pedal musically, you need to spend a little time understanding what works and doesn't with this pedal. For instance:* Responds best to smooth light consistent picking - it IS sensitive to the level of your attack - if you pick one note hard and another soft, it will play those notes louder or softer. That is a little weird since organs, unlike pianos, are not "touch" sensitive in that way, but if you learn to work that you can make it do good things. As a guitar pedal, I like the dynamics of that but if not used correctly you could get some weird results. Might benefit from putting a compressor in front to smooth out the signal -- I have not tried that yet as my compressor needs a new switch.* Does not respond well to intense string bends or huge barre chords. Playing the notes straight with no vibrato and sticking to 2,3, or 4 note chords or single notes works best.* Sliding into a note across a few frets sounds great, like a keyboard player swiping up or down the keys to a note.* For a grittier sound, kick down to a bridge humbucker with your volume up. To smooth it out, kick up to a single coil neck pickup and/or roll the volume back a little bit. You can also stick a tubescreamer in front of it to dirty it up a little for a grittier tone.* It is VERY sensitive to volume adjustment, and the response is not instant so if you roll from 10 to 5 you are likely to find it doesn't change much on the note you are playing, but when you hit the next note, the adjustment is immediately apparent. So subtle volume adjustment is required, or adjustment over several notes, or through practice, knowing exactly where you want to move that volume knob. Otherwise if you are expecting it to adjust volume instantly on the fly, like a guitar usually does -- it's a little weird. Again a few minutes of playing with and you will figure out how to use your volume control effectively with this pedal.STILL TO DETERMINE* I've read it doesn't take a battery, but haven't pulled the back off to look or bothered to look in the manual. I pretty much plugged it in and went to town.* Have run only with provided power supply so far, not with my pedal board w/ mounted power supplySUMMARYThis is a really cool pedal if you are a guitar player in need of organ sounds. I'm a fan. The small form factor and standard power supply are both a big plus, and the ease of operation is nice too. It makes some great organ sounds and has a variety of settings. I like the #1 setting with most of the knobs at about 1/4 to 1/3 (or combined with Leslie pedal, I turn the mod knob all the way down.) If you just need some organ chording or some simple organ notes to fill in selected parts in songs, this seems like a great way to get that. It's not a keyboard player in a box, but it's about as close as you can get and it does it for a heck of a lot less money than buying an organ. It's also a small addtion to the pedal board instead of lugging a keyboard and stand around. This helps you keep a small footprint on stage as well. Two thumbs up for the B9 !! Very cool.
It is exactly what it is supposed to be, and it works. There isn't a lot more to say on this product.

It's a guitar. Not a great one, and it's not supposed to be. These have a plywood body, and cheap parts.And still, it sold new for around $449 new, without a case.  They must be selling out or sold out because now I see 2 sellers on Amazon selling these at > $1000.00 (or trying.)For me, this guitar sounds best when running both pickups. I find the bridge alone to be thin and weak, and the neck alone to be a little boomy. But together...pretty nice. The highs are maintained and the lows are in perpective at this point. Put some reverb and chorus on that and you have a nice tone for Pretenders clean tones. Kind of sparkly but full enough.I'm really not crazy about the tone and volume stacked concentric rings. For starters, I can never remember what is what. And for finishers, they two rings move together when you try to turn one or the other. Very awkward. But if you manage to dial in a tone and volume you like, then I guess it's ok. The switch is definitely cheap...the hardware is cheap, and the tuners are crappy. This has a metal nut as well.So what's to love about it? Well, it has a cool look, a little different tone, and who doesn't love a blue alligator. You might not want to buy it as a primary guitar, but as a specialty piece in your collection, it's interesting.While loading gear for a practice today, I noticed and appreciated how light this guitar is.I think this might be one of those guitars that is just interesting to pull out from time to time and play with. A bit of a novelty.Also, mine will be up for sale as soon as those prices reach $1500 :)

I love this pedal. I bought it on a "stupid deal of the day" for about $40 and it's what I've needed all along for stepping forward at solo time.Its got a "standard" 9V power supply, and that is placed where it belongs on the rear vertical surface. That's a big thing with me on pedals -- I hate it when they have weird power supplies that require special adapters or cords.Form factor is the right size for pedals. Not too big, not too small.Controls are simple, build quality seems high.Heck, I even like the color as well as the lack of any over top weird graphics.Just a great pedal that does what it is supposed to without breaking the bank.

I bought one of these used but in "almost like new" condition for about $350 with a transparent blue top. By "almost like new" I mean the body and finish had no marks or dings, and the frets had no visible wear. The electronics however, were starting to wear. There's a lot I like, but a few things I have to downgrade my rating for.PROs- attractive finish and top- dual HB tele with coil splitting- decent fit and finishCONs- cheap, non-standard tuners harder to upgrade cleanly (different 2-pins location than typical 2-pin fender/schaller modern tuners)- cheap import electronics don't last, and sound somewhat muddy- lacks a case at the $700 price point, on an Indochina(current)/Korea(older model)guitarDETAILS AND COMMENTS ON UPGRADESOn the upside, the top of mine looks really nice in the flame maple trans blue stain. I like the set neck and the feel at the heel is ALMOST as good for reach as my american deluxe strat with a tapered heel. This isn't tapered, but the shape is less boxy because it is a set neck. The neck is narrow both in width and thickness, so players with smaller fingers can get a bit better reach. Some people don't like the Jumbo frets but I don't mind them at all. The weight of the guitar is really light - which is nice if you play or practice long sets. The body cutaway on the back is also a big plus for comfort.Most notable, the tuners are not great, and if you try to upgrade them to a normal 2-pin drop in replacement tuner for strats and tele's you will find they do not fit. This guitar does use a 2-pin tuner, but the pins are about 1 pin thickness closer to the center post of the tuning peg so that a "normal" fender/shaller tuner will not fit. And worse, it's designed so that if you try to drill it, it will be very difficult to do even with a tuner pin jig, because you are basically trying to drill on the side of the holes. Minus 1.5 stars for this...I normally replace all my fenders with locking tuners but I only do drop in replacements for a clean look. I don't like to drill additional holes or leave exposed pin holes, because then it looks like a hacked job. There are plenty of tuners that I'm sure CAN go on, but I now have to hunt for one that is going to fit and cover properly. (Update: locking Sperzel tuners will cover the two pin holes, but require drilling a single, centered pin hole. I have a pin jig for this, but...the black Sperzels have a silver center peg?! so from the front, you lose the "blackout" look. I ordered planet waves locking tuners, and installed them. They just cover the 2 pin holes of the original tuners, but do require the drilling of a small hole for the anti-rotation screw these tuners use. I measured the bore of the tuner holes in the headstock and it is 25/64". This is the same bore Gretsch used for the Sperzels, and the Planet Waves auto-trim lockers fit this nicely as well. I'm overall very pleased with the Planet Waves, they provide a clean install, good function, and full blackout on the front. Also, they are not as expensive - $52 vs the Sperzels at $70.On my model, it used Fender Pickups instead of the Seymour Duncans. They are ok but not great. Perhaps a bit muddy. I expect to replace them before long. A few years ago they switched this model to SD's, but I'm not sure they are the ones I would pick to put in here. No downgrade in rating, just an observation. After all, someone else might love these pups.The electronics (switches & pots) on mine are "import grade", and I can feel it, hear it...and in fact, they are shot. Now I bought this used but it has pretty clearly seen limited use so for the electronics to be crapping out this early in life...is indicative of the cheap import parts. So I'll be replacing those, hopefully with American parts assuming they will fit properly. I am downgrading half a star on that because frankly, there is no reason to use the cheap crap on a $700 guitar. Fender has such huge purchasing power that they could easily standardize on the same high quality electronics for everything, and from a cost perspective (cost not price) it would save them money. A little searching on the Fender site produced the factory wiring diagram, but changing the pups will change all the wire colors anyway. So...more to come on that as well. I will most like put Pearly Gates in both neck and bridge. (Not the "Plus" found on current models, and not the '59 neck RP pup.) Again, I will update this review when that is done. I'm exploring if I need to get an RP (reverse polarity) neck pickup similar to what was done by Fender. I like the push pull pot being on the tone knob for the coil splitting.Last, lack of a case. This model sells for $700 without a case...that's a lot for what it is. This is made in Indochina...(mine was made in Korea). So they really could include a case at this price and still make a good profit. At least throw in a decent gig bag, Fender!All in all it's an interesting Telecaster for the dual humbuckers and flame top, but if you are used to player american fenders or even current MIM fenders, there are some features of this that fall short as shipped. I'm not saying don't buy it, I'm just saying be aware of the differences it has compared to a MIM or American product. I think buying used then scrapping the import parts and upgrading may produce a better guitar for the same, or less money. (That's my hope, anyway.)

PROs* Reasonable price at $79 for the full kit, shipped prime.* Pop in tremolo arm is a time saver, and convenient* Shape of tremolo arm is preferred to traditional arm - doesn't angle "up" as far.* Flat saddles work better for palm muting that traditional saddles (at least for me.)CONs* Lack of other finishes like Gold, Black, or Nickel* Unavailable on Amazon for some time now...how about some stock guys?SUMMARYThis is my favorite bridge for Stratocasters.  I put this on all my 2-point strat bodies, and I no longer buy bodies or guitars drilled for a 6-point tremolo because I like this 2 point bridge so much more. I originally got this factory installed on my American Deluxe, and since then I added it to a couple of American Standards and a special run MIM with 2 point setup. My only real complaint is the lack of other finishes. I've seen it left handed in Gold, but never right handed except on a factory special edition, and never in black or nickel. I can't downgrade this item based on that...but it is another example of why I have a love hate relationship with Fender. They do some great stuff...but they also do some really annoying things that are designed to make sure you can't upgrade certain guitars.

Pros------It's cheapIf you want something relatively low power, this could be a good fit.Would work great for amplification of a podium mike -- people speaking.Cons------Lacks 1/4" outputs - requires speakon to 1/4 adapter if you want to run 1/4" TS cables.Audio is not that clean...sounds muddy by comparison to better amps.Power ratings are misleading - they are peak ratings, not RMSI bought some old Behringer monitors used and ran them on a friends QSC power amp...and they sounded really clear and good. I was frankly surprised how good they sounded. So I decided to add this Behringer power amp for use in my studio with the same monitors. However, with this amp, they sounded muddy and not that great.It's not terrible...it works, but it's not the crisp clear sound I got from the QSC amp. Gotta say, not really a fan, but if you need an amp for something like people speaking at a podium, this could work well. For music...I'd recommend something clearer if you want really good sound. It works, and of course you have to be realistic at the price point which is pretty low...you can use it for music but it's no match for a better quality amp in terms of the sound quality.Wanted to like it but just put it up for sale on craigslist. Should have returned it but I'm a little too late for that.3 stars = "It's ok".

This is great flooring for a gym floor.This particular tile is 3/8" thick and the description says "black" but the photo shows a speckle pattern, so I'm not exactly sure what this is.I have the zip tile in 8mm or 5/16" thick 28.5" x 28.5" tile and it is really heavy duty, and both costs a little less, and is less expensive to ship than the 3/8 tiles. The 8mm weighs 9.6 pounds per tile and the 3/8 is closer to 11.6.Check other online retailers -- search "zip tile rubber floor".  I have the 17% Cocoa/Eggshell on black and it looks great in a room with beige paint. I buy mine for about $27 per tile out the door at a local retailer, and found it online shipped for about that same price, buying 10 tiles.However, as of late this product has been hard to obtain -- my local store is sold out and can't tell me when they can get it, and the online retailers are showing 20-30 days until it ships. Too bad...I wanted to expand my area but now I'm thinking about just buying a different product altogether.

I like Chuck's playing...a lot.I just got this and have been sampling it...have not gone through the whole thing but already it has exceeded my expectations.For the people saying there is no instruction...I think they are saying it isn't a Mel-bay/Hal Leonard 1-2-3 book.But there is a lot of instruction if you listen to what he is saying, and watch what he is playing. I bought this to get a nice clear view of Jessica, even though I am more guitar player than piano player. But I find there are good useful instructional elements that go beyond piano technique. Things like how to think about what you are playing...notions of warming up, how to approach studio work, etc. This stuff may sound boring but I have a seen a lot of players who need to hear this stuff! Beyond that...it includes 8 PDF files of notation, and the keyboard is visible from an overview view when he is playing. Presumably, as a musician most of you also have ears...so use 'em. :)Personally, I think this video not only can help you be a better piano player, but a better musician on any instrument you play.And...I just love the stuff he is playing on this video. Thanks Chuck for a great video!!

Disclaimer: I purchased "Jessica" digitally, rather than this whole book, but the version I downloaded was from this specific book.I am using that to evaluate the quality of the book, based one (very famous) song from the book.SummaryThis is in the Piano/Vocal/Guitar format -- which means it includes guitar chords, but not guitar tab. It is intended more for a piano player and includes a treble clef and bass clef standard notation, and guitar chord charts. For songs with words the vocals are also included. If you are a piano player and want to play the chords and/or something similar to what The Allman Brothers Band recorded, then this is ok. However, if you are playing with a band and seeking the actual piano solos, they aren't here. For me that was a disappointment because that is really what I wanted.Pros- Good collection of ABB songs- For a piano player, a good starting point on the songs- for a beginner guitarist, provides chords for songs, so you can strum-relatively inexpensive at about $15Cons- For Piano player specifically -- lacks the note for note transcriptions of solos and instead has "ad lib solo here". That is fairly useless since if I wanted to ad lib the solo, I wouldn't have bought the sheet music!- Not really for guitar players, it is just chords. Guitarist should seek out the guitar tab versions of the songs. They are available in similar collection books, or digitally online from hal leonard's joint venture called sheet music direct US.

I bought this for the case, but the one I received is not what is shown in the product photo.However, it works for me as it matches another hohner case I have.I got the same case shown here:http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001GF9AS6/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1It is a black case, with zipper around the side, no flap.The harps look like toys...I plan to give them to a local kids charity.It's ok for $18...as long as you mainly want the case and not the harps.UPDATED REVIEW:These never made it out of the house as a donation, they were still sitting in their case, fully packaged when I decided to try the Bb harp since my Marine Band Bb developed a bad reed. So now that I tried the actual harmonicas, I have to downgrade my rating to 1 star. The volume of these harps is about half that of a "real" harmonica. They feel very cheap when you play them. And on the one I tried, the 3 blow hole makes no sound at all.The volume difference between draws and blows is significant, and the volume differences from hole to hole are also noticeable. This harmonica is not suitable as a musical instrument. These not only look like toys, they ARE toys, plastic made in china. Literally non-playable junk when brand new. Don't buy these unless you plan to throw the harmonicas in the garbage and just want the case.And unfortunately, I see these are now $24 instead of $18, and at that price, it's a ripoff. You can buy a much nicer case for around $30 that holds more and has a hardshell and a handle. I even got a nice hardshell 12 harp case free with a microphone purchase so you might consider that too. The harps are total junk and NOT RECOMMENDED.If you want to play harmonica, start with 1 good quality harp in the key of C.A Marine Band, Blues Harp, or Golden Melody are good choices.

This is a great lateral filing cabinet. I recommend it to others. It's solidly built, and the folder hanging rods inside each drawer are adjustable to the two main sizes for hanging folders. The exterior metal has a quality feel to it instead of some of the cheaper metal filing cabinets you see. The paint isn't exceptionally durable, though, so be careful if you put anything heavy and with pointed edges on the top.

These are great corner braces. They are just as pictured. They are just under 1.2" inches x 1.2" inches for those not using the metric system. I used mine to secure a non-load-bearing shelf on a piece of furniture, and I'm happy with the result. I recommend these to others.

This are great cufflinks. I recommend them to others. They look great and are just as pictured.Note that they aren't traditional cufflinks that have a straight rod between the "T" part of the cufflink and the square part. Instead, the square part is at an angle from the rod. You can see that in the product picture: the square part is tilted back from the camera. The result is that, when you wear these, it forms a sort of "C" shape hooking through your french cuff shirt holes. This isn't a bad thing, but I didn't notice it from the product image.The C-shape isn't harmful,and these are still great cufflinks. I recommend them to others. If mine break early or otherwise have an issue, I'll come back and update this review.

I wanted to love this skimmer. Protein skimmers are a simple idea, but they can cost a ton. I thought this option might be the solution. For my set-up, it just wasn't at all.The problem I had with this skimmer is that it just doesn't stay together. It's super-thin plastic that is not snapped together, adhered together, or even firmly connected by size or pressure. It just gently rests together at four or five different places. Unless, of course, you touch it, in which case it falls apart in four or five different places.For example, my sump is a bit crowded. I couldn't even get this in the sump without it falling apart a half-dozen different ways. Once I did, moving it made it fall apart again. And going into that compartment to do anything, again, makes it fall apart.If you can (a) get this together, and (b) keep it together, it might be great for you. But I couldn't get it to do either. So, instead of wrestling with it, I upgraded to something more sturdy.

This is a great sampler kit. I recommend it to others.I do acrylic work as a hobby, and I wanted to diversify the applicators I already had. This was the perfect way to do that affordably. I have had no problems using the applicators I received.I recommend these to others.

These are great gloves. I recommend them to others as long as you're using the right gloves for the right task.These are not heavy-duty gloves. They look fairly flimsy, and they are. If you're doing a lot of pulling or heavy lifting, you're going to rip these. For lunchroom use and other light tasks, these would be great. The material on these reminds me of really thin, office-style trash bags (not the stretchy kind but the plain, clear plastic kind).I use mine in a reef tank aquarium on top of smaller neoprene gloves. It keeps my arms dry when I'm reaching down into the tank, and I have the neoprene gloves too in case I accidentally grab something sharp. They work well for that task. I've used a dozen or so and have not had any leaks. However, I wouldn't try to move live rocks in my tank with these‚Äîthey'd probably rip for that. But, the benefit of not having heavier-duty gloves is that you don't lose much precision or feeling because these gloves aren't really thick, so I can still tell which part of the coral (stone base or soft polyp, etc.) I'm picking up.For lighter tasks, these are great glove that I recommend to others.

This is a great way to organize your office, garage, kitchen, etc. It's a sturdy plastic wall file that was easy to mount on my garage wall. I use it to hold schematics for projects. It's much better than leaving them in a pile on the workbench. I plan to buy a few more for the kitchen to sort mail. Otherwise, the product is just as described. I recommend it to others.

This is great acrylic. It is just as described. The color is a standard black acrylic, and the dimensions were as advertised. There's really not much else to say. I recommend this acrylic sheet to others.

These are decent spinners, except they don't really spin if your planters weigh much.  Our hanging baskets are pretty heavy, and these spinners don't spin really at all. Instead, they seize up and only twist slightly right or left. That is enough for us, and so these met our needs. But be warned that unless you have pretty light hanging baskets, these are probably not actually going to spin much.

This is a great little lantern, especially for camping. I recommend it to others.TaoTronics sent this lantern to me to review, like they do for lots of people. Here are the pros and cons:Pros:1) plenty of light for walking on a path, in a small tent, or around a house in a power outage2) easy to find at night because there's a small flashing green light on the front (always on)3) very sturdy4) the light adjusts from low to high to flashing5) it has a place to hang it either upside down (like from a tent pole) or normally (for carrying it)6) it is surprisingly lightweight even though it is a tough little lanternCons:1) the positive/negative terminals of the battery chamber aren't marked2) the green light that flashes cannot be turned off, so it will slowly drain batteries if you leave batteries in it3) there's not much difference between low and high light settingsOverall, this is easily a five-star lantern, especially given the price. It's rugged, provides plenty of light, and is easy to hang or hold. It is great for camping and would be pretty good for use in a power outage. The only real drawbacks to each are that you would want to face the flashing green light on the front away from your face if sleeping, but that's not a big deal because it isn't a bright, annoying light or anything‚Äîit's subtle.For power outage use, it's a bit less ideal. You shouldn't store it with batteries in it because the flashing green light will drain them over weeks and months, and since the battery chamber doesn't have positive/negative markings, it is a little annoying figuring out how to put the batteries in when you need the lantern. Still, these aren't a big deal because you can tell how the batteries go in by looking at the spring/metal parts in the battery chamber. But terminal markings, especially large ones you could feel in the dark, would be better.But, for the price, these are small things. Still, I recommend this lantern more for camping than power outages. And of course, as of writing this review, the name of the item is "camping light," so that makes sense. Overall, this is a great, rugged lantern. I recommend it.

This is a great package of items. I recommend it to others.I've been using this kit, along with other tools I bought previously, to bond acrylic together for saltwater fish tanks. It's important to have fairly fresh solvent, so I needed more Weld-on 4 and this kit was a bargain since I also needed more Weld-on 16. If you're working with a big tank (or bonding a big piece of acrylic for any reason), having a second bottle applicator handy and full of Weld-on is essential in case your main bottle runs out in the middle of gluing a long piece together. So though I didn't really need more applicators, they were a great bonus.Plus, if you've never tried putting down Weld-on 4 with larger vs. small applicators, you are depriving yourself of a handy set of options. This kit came with a few different size needles, which is a nice addition to the other sizes I already had.Overall, this is a good assembly of items for the price. I recommend it to others.

Although I loved this syringe for acrylic bonding projects at first, it went bad quickly. I can't recommend it to others.This is seemed like a great syringe, but it lost three stars for me because after about a half dozen uses in the course of two weeks, the rubber plunger inside now frequently pulls off the sliding piece when you backdraw it. That's pretty annoying.I was using it for Weld-on 4 application, which is what the title of the item said it was for when I bought it (in case it changed now). So it's not like I was using it for an unadvertised purpose.Because this went bad in a very short timeframe but was great before that, it's a solid two stars in my book. I can't recommend it to others for use as an acrylic bonding solvent applicator.

These are great battery-operated lights. I recommend these to others.I received four of these as a holiday gift and fell in love. I later bought four more myself. They have a great soft glow when it is dark and there is no motion, and they light up a nice-sized area of the floor well enough to see when walking. They make my trips down the stairs at nice much safer when I don't want to turn on the big oversized light and blind myself (and others).They also aren't battery hogs. I put in rechargeable AA batteries (using C-size spacers) and only have to replace them every few months. I do recommend you get rechargeable batteries, though, because these would be costly over time if you used disposables.Otherwise, these are easy to install and have held up well over time. I had one go bad right away, but Amazon replaced it with no problems and the other eight have been perfect. They look nice and do their job well.Overall, I recommend these to others.

This is great foam tape. I recommend it to others.I was using this tape to make boards that could help level acrylic while bonding large pieces together. Acrylic naturally warps, but if you set it on boards with strips of camper tape, the acrylic naturally sinks at the warps and makes a flat surface. A flat surface is essential to bonding two pieces of acrylic together securely. This camper tape fit the bill perfectly for that task.It would work well for other tasks, too. It attached securely to MDF board and has held that position. When I removed the acrylic tank, the camper foam didn't stick to the acrylic on the non-sticky side of the foam (aside from a little bit from pressure). It came off quickly and did not peel away from the MDF board at all‚Äîit had a firm grip on the MDF board. I've used it for a few weeks now and it shows no sign of wear despite living in my very hot and humid garage.Overall, I recommend this foam to others. You probably aren't using it for what I was doing, but it's still a great, durable foam with a strong adhesive grip on one side, which will be well-suited to many other uses.

This is an okay item, but it didn't do all the reviews said and did not work for my purposes.I was using this item as a temporary refugium to house macro algae in a saltwater tank. I was counting on the feature that it would cling to/stay on the side of the tank, as some reviews described. Unfortunately, that didn't happen for my tank and I have a guess why‚Äîmany saltwater reef tanks have more flow than non-reef tanks. The flow in my tank, even when not aimed at this breeder chamber, pushed it off the wall regularly and send it floating around and into corals. You can rig something up to keep it in place, but that wasn't an option in my particular set-up.Otherwise, this is a fine isolation chamber. I plan to put it in my sump in between a few baffles as a way to keep macroalgae where I want it (and give copepods a place to live). I think it will be great for that. It is well-made and I otherwise like this item.If you need something that will stick to the side of your tank and you have much flow in your tank, this isn't it. Otherwise, this is a good isolation chamber for the price.

I recommend these motion-detecting lights to others.Full disclosure: I was provided these lights for review purposes. That has not affected my review, however, because I only write reviews I believe in.These are great lights. In testing, they were at the bottom of three flights of stairs with the goal of lighting the bottom of the steps during evening, night, and early morning hours when lighting at the bottom of the stairs was inadequate.  The lights properly and timely activated when the steps were approached, and they remained on a short period of time after leaving the area.  The lights were bright enough to illuminate the area in the vicinity of the step. They don't make it daytime or anything, but they easily get the job done of putting convenient light where you need it and without having to think about it.There's not a lot more to say about these lights. It can be just a bit tricky opening the back compartment at first, but it's easy once you get the knack. Adding markings to the back of the device would be helpful.  However, it's otherwise easy to use them. I suggest using rechargeable batteries for these so you save in the long run.Overall, these are good lights that get the job done. If I run into any problems using them in the future, I'll update this review.

These are solid earbuds. I recommend them to others.First up, I was given these earbuds to provide a review of them. My review is not based on that, though, as these are solid earbuds.As others have noted, these are pretty standard earbuds. The easily paired with my S4. They fit comfortably in my ears, which is rare for most of these (most other devices I have to wrestle with). It came with a few other covers that you could swap in if the default piece didn't fit well for you, but I didn't need to do that.I have listened to a variety of styles of music on these and the sound quality is very solid. They reproduce mids, highs, and even bass cleanly, which is a nice change from many other units in this range/size that can't handle hip hop, dubstep, and other bass-heavy genres. Sometimes I wish the highs were just a little more crisp, but it's hardly noticeable when I'm not actually thinking about it.These also seem pretty durable. I didn't have any trouble when using them. If I run into any issues while using these in the future, I'll update this review.One quick tip on use: The "next track"/"previous track" buttons, like most earbuds, double as +/- volume buttons. But unlike some others I have used where pushing + increases or decreases volume, here you have to hold the + button to increase volume. Pushing it once will just skip ahead to the next track. That's no problem, but it's the opposite of what I expected.Overall, these are great ear pieces. They perform well and are durable. I recommend them to others.

This is a great humidifier. I recommend it to others.Perhaps because I bought so many TaoTronics products over the years, I was sent this product for review. Except for one or two items, I've been a TaoTronics fan. This humidifier is no exception.First off, this things looks really sleek. The ocean blue color of the reservoir tank is great, and the white has a high-tech look that reminds me of many Apple products. I love the nightlight that illuminates inside the tank, and the display is a fairly nice LED instead of the all-too-common cheap LED screens I usually see on tech products in this level.The unit works well. In my testing, it detected the humidity within a few points of what my wall AC panel displayed. The mister has an auto-shutoff feature that stops producing mist when it detects the humidity in the room matches or exceeds the humidity you set the unit to produce. When I tried it, the unit accurately detected the mist. Note, though, that it didn't detect it for me until I changed it from the factory default. If you want to keep yours at 40% humidity but yours doesn't detect humidity and shutoff, try cycling up to 45% and then back to the factory default 40%.The unit also has a timer and says it has an auto-shutoff feature for if the water gets too low, though I didn't test that to avoid damaging the unit. It's easy to change the humidity setting‚Äîjust push and hold the button and then cycle through 5% intervals with further button pushes. I didn't see a way to be more precise than 5% intervals, but I don't think most people will care about a 53% humidity setting vs. a 55% or 50% setting. It's equally easy to cycle through the three mist output settings (low, medium, high) by pushing the mist button. The buttons are clearly labeled so there's no guesswork here.A few quick tips in using the device. First, don't fill the reservoir through the top/output. Flip over the reservoir, remove the filter (it unscrews), and fill it there. When you pop the filter back on it won't leak or something when you flip it over as long as you hold it by the provided handle. Do be careful when filling it that you don't get water in the dimple that will be where the light goes. Although the light might be water-resistant, there's no reason to add water to where electricity will almost be.Overall, this is a solid humidifier that, as a bonus, looks great. I recommend it to others.

This is a fairly sturdy selfie stick that, like the other TaoTronics products I own, I would recommend to others.First off, I should note that I was sent this product for review. Although selfie sticks aren't really my thing, I was surprised at how fun this was to use. I've done the awkward "take a picture of me and someone else" arm-twist at theme parks and special events too many times. The photos, even when you use a front-facing camera so you can see the screen, are usually a little odd, a little too close, or both. A selfie stick solves that problem.But a selfie stick is no use if you won't actually take it with you. The collapsible arm on this unit makes this a stick that is both versatile and has a great reach when fully extended (about 30 inches). Because it collapses, it's easy to store in a large pants pocket, cargo shorts, a backpack, or a medium-size purse (it wouldn't fit in a really small purse).This unit feels pretty sturdy because the arm is made of a fairly thick metal. It feels kind of like those extendable antenna on remote control cars. This makes for a pretty firm pull required to extend the arm fully, but it's very manageable. The weight balance shifts from the handle towards the camera when in use because the weight in the handle comes from the collapsed arm. That's not a problem, though, because the handle is ridged and easy to hold.Finally, the other features of the selfie stick work just as they should. The tension hand grips the phone well and easily fit and held onto my S4. That's critical so you don't end up dropping your phone when trying to take a photo, especially if using it in a crowd at a party, bar, club, concert, theme park, etc. The bluetooth button is large and easy to push and has virtually no lag time to trigger the camera.Overall, this is a well-designed, rugged selfie stick. If selfies are your thing, I recommend this to you.

These are great rechargeable batteries. I highly recommend them to others.About a year and a half ago, I put a number of battery-operated devices in my home recently (hallway lights, outside lights, etc.) and I didn't want them to cost me a fortune in battery costs. I switched to rechargeable batteries to try to save money. I'll never go back to disposables‚Äîthese batteries are great.First, they last just as long as the disposables I had at the time. I put the last of my disposables in at the same time I put rechargeables in other, identical devices, and they lasted a similar duration. Recharging is easy (I use an Eneloop/Sanyo charger), though you have to charge two batteries at a time which is a bit annoying for me (my hall lights, for example, generally use three batteries each).The best thing is that you don't need a fleet of C batteries, Ds, and AAs. You can just get AAs and AAAs (if you need AAAs) and use spacers so the AAs fit in C and D-size devices. Note, though, that AA batteries have a much lower capacity and will not last as long as C or D batteries would. That works fine for me, though, because my devices are generally low-draw (LED lights, etc.). I've recharged mine maybe a half-dozen times and they're still going strong.Do be aware that this manufacturer, like many others, regularly releases new versions of batteries. The newer versions generally can be recharged more times and might have a slightly different capacity. You might want to double-check that you're buying the newest generation of product.One last warning‚Äîif you're going to use these in devices that go outside, either make sure the device is truly waterproof or consider switching to disposables. Rechargeable batteries save money over time, but not if they get waterlogged and die before you get your money's worth. For some of my devices, I still use disposables outside in case water gets in. I'd rather a cheaper disposable battery be ruined by water than a more expensive rechargeable.Overall, these are great batteries. They save money over time and are easy to use. I highly recommend them to others.

I recommend this light to others.This is a great light. It has a number of different color variations, and it produces a pretty clean "cool white" as well (not all LED variable-color lights do). The response from the remote was quick and, though you do really have to point it right at the light, I didn't have any trouble with changing the setting on mine. The light is also well-built.My one complaint is that the 10W version is just not that much light. But that's not the light's fault, it's my fault‚ÄîI should have bought a brighter one.Overall, this is a great light. I recommend it to others.

This product works as described, and I recommend it to others.I was having a phosphates problem for a while in my salt water tank at work because some of my macro algae had broken down in a spot I couldn't reach and was decaying there. I also, unbeknownst to me for a while, had an reverse osmosis/de-ionization filter system that wasn't pulling all the phosphates out of my top-off water. Bottom line, I was able to get the problem in better control using PhosGuard. That's good because the excess phosphates were really feeding some hair algae that had sprung up in my tank.The one thing that you have to note about this product is that it really needs to be in a place where it gets good water circulation over the media. I haven't had much luck in applications where there isn't much flow going directly over the PhosGuard.Additionally, depending on the prices at the time of purchase, you may be able to save money by buying a bag for the PhosGuard and buying the larger quantities of PhosGuard. Once when I did the math, it was about the same price to just keep buying these 100 mL bags, but the next time I needed some it was cheaper to buy the bag and the larger bottle of PhosGuard. Apparently the price of these fluctuate a bit.Other than that, I recommend this to others trying to keep phosphates under control.

I recommend this printer to others.This is a great printer. It's fast, it has a variety of settings, and inexpensive ink is readily available. The quality of printed items is excellent, but we mainly print boring documents and I haven't tried fancy photo prints or anything like that. It also makes great copies and scans things quickly and effectively.Okay, so time for the nit-picking details. First, this printer is huge. It's like a tank. I was a bit surprised to see how huge this thing is for a modern printer. It also doesn't exactly feel modern. The noises it makes (button pushes, operating sounds, etc.) are something I'd expect to hear from a 1980s fax machine, and the buttons themselves are huge and kind of clunky. However, some users might find the oversized buttons helpful (for the same reason some people prefer larger-button cell phones, etc.). Still, those drawbacks are quite small and the printer is still very fast and works well.Overall, I recommend this printer to others. It does what it does well and the price is great.

I enjoyed my Jawbone UP 24 for about four months but then it started to work less effectively. The lights on the band stopped coming on and the rubber-like cover started to slip over both ends. However, I was able to return mine for a replacement with no issues. I didn't keep the replacement, though, because I wanted to switch to a smart watch instead.Otherwise, however, i was a great product. I especially liked how easy it was to switch to sleep mode (just push and hold the button on the band) or to start recording an activity (same idea with an extra push). I loved that it had a thirty-minute or so idle alarm: anytime I was sitting around at work for too long, it would buzz and I'd stretch or go for a walk (if I had time at that moment). It was really great. That same buzz helped remind me to walk around more often. I'd say this was one of the main selling points that set the UP 24 apart from other fitness bands.Overall, I recommend this product to others. However, as other reviewers have noted, the quality isn't perfect.

I recommend Zyrtec to others battling allergies.I adopted a shelter dog and two shelter cats and discovered, to my surprise, that I am allergic to this kind of dog. Everytime she licked me, I'd get skin irritation there and when I woke up in the morning I was all congested if she had been on the bed. We didn't want to kick her out of the bedroom (and certainly didn't want to return her!), so I tried a few different allergy products. Even though Zyrtec had not had great impact on environmental allergies I had, it worked wonders for the pet dander. I am now a few years into having the same animals and have minimal allergy problems as long as I take Zyrtec.I'll note that I also tried taking a generic brand of Zyrtec (to save money) and it did not work for me as well as Zyrtec did. I tried the other brand for a month and have tried alternating from the generic to Zyrtec, and Zyrtec always works better. It seems like the generic version wears off sooner. That's possible I suppose because, although the product mights be chemically identical in terms of active ingredient, Zyrtec might have a patented (or just better) delivery system that causes the generic brand to last less than 24 hours. Anyway, that was my experience with the generic brand in case that helps you.I recommend this product to others battling allergies, especially pet allergies.

This product works as described, and I recommend it to others.I was having a phosphates problem for a while in my salt water tank at work because some of my macro algae had broken down in a spot I couldn't reach and was decaying there. I also, unbeknownst to me for a while, had an reverse osmosis/de-ionization filter system that wasn't pulling all the phosphates out of my top-off water. Bottom line, I was able to get the problem in better control using PhosGuard. That's good because the excess phosphates were really feeding some hair algae that had sprung up in my tank.The one thing that you have to note about this product is that it really needs to be in a place where it gets good water circulation over the media. I haven't had much luck in applications where there isn't much flow going directly over the PhosGuard.Other than that, I recommend this to others trying to keep phosphates under control.

This is a great automatic-top-off unit.I use it in a twenty gallon tank and it does its job well. The basic idea is simple: the floating water sensor is held in place by two powerful magnets (don't get your fingers or anything else between them when moving them near each other‚Äîthey snap together pretty strongly). When the water level drops, the Tunze pumps water into the tank for about 1.5 minutes. Then the pump shuts off.The one thing that you want to watch out for with this ATO is that it will pump different amounts of water depending on how high your tank is compared to the pump and water reservoir. The ATO instructions explain those numbers, though, so you don't have to guess. In the end, it won't matter much because if the unit doesn't pump enough water in when the float drops too low, it will just pump more in when the float gets low again.Overall, this is a great, cost-effective ATO. I recommend it to others.

These are great batteries. There isn't a lot more to say about them‚Äîthey were shipped quickly, they had what seemed to be a full charge, and they are working in the devices we put them in as they should (home automation devices). The prices on Amazon was better than our local stores, so this was an easy choice.Overall, I recommend these batteries to others.

I recommend this card holder to others. I looked at a number of business card holders and this was the best one by far, especially for the price.This is a great, simple card holder. It swivels open easily and has space for over a dozen cards (and my cards are a bit thick). The holder is surprisingly weighty and feels solid and well-made.
