Due to a fortuitous circumstance, Wyatt and his friends are invited to the star-studded opening of Monsterland. In a theme park full of real vampires, werewolves and zombies, what could possibly go wrong?My Review: Imagine a place, where zombies roam, werewolves howl all night, and vampires are heavy metal musicians? Only in Monsterland will you see it all. And in a place full of monsters, what could possibly go wrong?Wyatt wants nothing more than to be noticed by the most popular girl in school, but it seems she is only into the athletic type. And when he finally gets the chance to actually speak to the girl, his dear brother ruins it with a simple slap on the back.Melvin is as dorky as one dork can be. His life his so full of everything from aliens to scary movies that he just doesn't have time for anything else.Howard is totally oblivious when a girl likes him or not, he just can‚Äôt keep up with it all. But one thing he does know is there is one girl he wants to be his and he isn‚Äôt to scared to make tat known. So when these three kids along with a few friends and Wyatt‚Äôs bratty brother get a once in a life time chance to go to the notorious Monsterland, they are ecstatic. But things aren‚Äôt all they seem at that theme park, for there is great evil at work.Monsterland is a wonderful book full of blood, gore, and monsters. I really enjoyed this book and found it to be a great read. If you are looking for something to frighten you, look no further. This book will give a real good scare.**NOTE** For Foul Language**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from the author.

About the Book:Bailey Wilde is one of the best new ranchers in the West. She's been living disguised as a man for a while, but when Gage Coulter comes to drive her off her homestead, he quickly realizes he's dealing with a woman--a very tough, very intriguing woman at that.Gage is an honest man, but he didn't make his fortune being weak. He won't break the law, but he'll push as hard as he can within it. Five thousand acres of his best range land is lost to him because Bailey's homestead is located right across the only suitable entrance to a canyon full of lush grass. Gage has to regain access to his land--and he's got to go through Bailey to do it.Spending a winter alone has a way of making a person crave some human contact. In a moment of weakness, Bailey agrees to a wild plan Gage concocts. Can these two independent, life-toughened homesteaders loosen up enough to earn each other's respect--and maybe find love inthe process?My Review:Bailey Wilde doesn‚Äôt plan to ever marry or have the help of a man. Her plans only involve running her ranch by herself with absolutely no one bothering her. But with Gage Coulter as a neighbor, you are definitely going to be bothered. He breaks into her home hopping to disarm Bailey, who of which he believed to be a fiery young man, but oh did he found out that was totally wrong.  Bailey isn‚Äôt too happy for Gage to know of her being a woman, after all she work so hard to keep the whole town from knowing her true identity.After a long lonely winter, Bailey is surprised when she finds Gage on her doorstep. He is equally surprised to find her actually wearing a dress and having long hair like a normal girl. He spouts off and outrageous plan and after a few swings, Bailey believes he isn‚Äôt crazy after all.When something bad happens, Bailey and Gage must work together to find the culprit. But no one knew finding the perpetrator would hit so close to home.Fire & Ice is book three in the Wild at Heart series. If you have read any of Mary Connealy‚Äôs books, you know this author knows how to write. If not, you are missing out big time. You can have a gun fight at one moment and loving embrace in another. She knows how to keep you on our toes and on the edge of your seat. I loved this book so much I add the whole thing read in a matter of hours. I can‚Äôt wait till I get to read what she has next.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from Bethany House.

About the Book:Grant and Audrey are adding grandchildren to their family left and right, but middle daughte, Danae, and her husband, Dallas Brooks, have been trying for years with no baby in sight.Though Danae is ready to consider adoption, Dallas will not even discuss it. Despairing of ever having a family of her own, Danae decides to pour her passion and energies into volunteer work with a newly opened women‚Äôs shelter in town. Looking for a good cause to fill her lonely days, she never expects to give her heart to the hurting women she meets there. She‚Äôs finally learning to live her life with gratitude, but then heart-wrenching events on Thanksgiving weekend threaten to pull the entire Whitman clan into turmoil‚Äîand leave them all forever changed.My Review: Danae Brooks wants nothing more than to have a child. But each visit to the fertility doctor proves to be futile, she once again is told she is not pregnant. Her husband, Dallas tries to understand, but truth be told he wants the craziness to end, he wants her to act normal once more. When she learns of her sister once again being pregnant, this time on accident, Dallas believes this is the last straw for Danae. It‚Äôs time for a break.Danae decides to devote herself to volunteering at the local women‚Äôs shelter. But never did she expect to find a woman there that she finds to be a good friend. Her life suddenly begins to start looking up for once. And maybe just maybe Dallas will begin to look into adopting a child. But something unsettling happens leaving them all in shock, something that will change there lives forever.Another Way Home is book three in the Chicory Inn series. This book was a wonderful addition to this series. I found it to be a very interesting and exciting read. I love this authors books and I can‚Äôt wait to see what she writes next.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from Litfuse.

About the Book:Shining coat flashing in the sun. Silky mane rippling in the wind. A toss of the head and the stamp of a hoof.Few of God‚Äôs creatures are as noble and soul-stirring as the horse. Even those of us who aren‚Äôt lucky enough to have horses of our own seem to have an innate desire to connect with these beautiful, regal beasts. As children we read stories about them, collected models of them, and tacked posters of them up on our walls. Throughout history they have carried us and calmed us, pulled our loads and pulled at our heartstrings. They give us a taste of wildness and yet make us feel at home.In this inspiring collection, you‚Äôll meet horses who show up at the right time, who help their humans learn important truths, and who rescue the very people who rescued them. These true stories of horses and the people who love them are sometimes touching, sometimes humorous, and sometimes miraculous. Always they are inspiring, like the horses themselves. They will touch your heart, renew your spirit, and show you that surely God had us in mind when he created these magnificent creatures.My Review: I‚Äôve always had an odd infatuation with horses. I‚Äôve always wanted one even though we of course have neither the money nor time that it takes to have a horse. Instead I drowned myself in books and movies about them. So when I had the chance to read The Horse of My Heart, I of course was ecstatic.The Horse of My Heart is a wonderful book full of stories about different people‚Äôs various experiences with horses. Each story has an important truth that was taught to the owner at one time or another by their horse. I really enjoyed how each story was wonderfully wrote. Being the horse lover, I am I‚Äôd say this book was beautifully put together with each story complementing the others perfectly.The Horse of My Heart is just one of Callie Smith Grant‚Äôs many books. This book was a wonderful read and can‚Äôt wait see what this editor has in store for us next.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from Revell.
Yes this product did work on my hubby's sander. I was a little worried but as soon as he put it on it fit right away. We are very pleased!

About the Book:Naomi s Gift by Amy ClipstonNaomi has started to think that she isn t meant to find love, but she might receive more than she ever hoped for this Christmas.Twenty-four-year-old Naomi King, who has been burned twice by love, has all but given up on marriage and children. As Christmas approaches a time of family, faith, and hope for many others Naomi is more certain than ever her life will be spent as an old maid, helping with the family s quilting business and taking care of her eight siblings. Then she meets Caleb, a young widower with a 7-year-old daughter, and her world is once again turned upside-down.An Unexpected Joy by Ruth ReidAbigail has driven other suitors away, but can Micah find a way to show her he cares?Abigail Kemp has managed to frighten off every bu who s ever driven her home from a singing. Sure she will live to be an old maid, Abigail starts saving her money to buy a horse so she can at least have some independence.Micah Zook is looking for a caregiver for his grandmother, and Abigail needs a new job. He never expected that Abigail would talk so much . . . or that his grandmother would keep finding ways to set the two of them up.Despite Abigail s constant chatter, she and Micah become friends until Micah makes a decision that leaves Abigail feeling betrayed. With Christmas in their midst, can Micah find a way to reconcile with Abigail and to reveal what s on his heart?A Christmas Visitor by Kelly IrvinFrannie Mast returns to Bee County for Christmas, but her heart stays back in Missouri with an Englisch farm boy.Frannie knows her parents have the best of intentions when they send her back to Bee County, Texas, to live with her aunt Abigail and her husband Mordecai. After all, she knows nothing can come of a relationship with Rocky, the handsome but Englisch farmer boy back in Missouri. It s best to put those feelings aside, no matter how hard it is. But all bets are off when Rocky follows Frannie to Texas to plead his case. Could he be the Christmas gift to end all gifts?"My Review: Just as the holidays are beginning to approach, this is the time when I start thinking about all things related. So My family and I have already started our pumpkin muffins and hot chocolate tradition because that's how we roll. Christmas is the best time for family and An Amish Christmas Gift is the novella to accompany us on this "sweet" tradition.Naomi s Gift by Amy Clipston Amy Clipston can really give you a good story to sink your teeth into. She does it rather well and we see that in Naomi's Gift. A story about a twenty something girl that feels there is no hope left for someone like her to find true love. But as the story goes, you find love when you least expect it. And so it goes for this young lady when she meets a young widower that instantly melts her heart.An Unexpected Joy by Ruth Reid Abigail is just fine with being an old maid. Every guy that has even looked her way she manages to scare off. She seems not to be troubled by this, but deep down I feel for her. And I think it just plain old hurts when a guy won't stick it out to get to know her a whole lot better. Soon Abigail receives what she may of needed all along in the way of Micah Zook.A Christmas Visitor by Kelly Irvin A sweet Christmas story to enjoy. I liked this one the best because of the cozy feel. The author made it feel like home and I think it resonated more with me than the other two. But each story was equally brilliant. Frannie receives a welcome surprise this Christmas but will she feel it's so welcoming when Rocky shows up at her Aunts home to plead his case? Each story is perfect for a cozy read under a blanket accompanied with some warm coffee cake and a cup of hot chocolate by the fire. To welcome in the holiday season, An Amish Christmas Gift is the book for you!**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from Book Look.

About the Book:Selah may have escaped the Mountain, but the real danger has only begunIt's been two days since Selah Rishon Chavez escaped the Mountain with her father and dozens of other Landers who had been held captive there. Now it's time to move on to safety. But no one can agree on a safe route or even the final destination.Selah's real problem, however, lies deep within. Ever since her first interaction with a Lander, she has been changing, and the changes go far beyond the mark just below her collarbone. As a novarium, she is destined to be the key to solving a 150-year-old mystery--making her Public Enemy Number One not just to the Company but to other Landers.My Review:Two Days after escaping the Mountain, Selah learns that they must move on to safety. But with her father, Glade and Bodhi fighting over the safer routes, she know something must happen and fast. Soon Glade introduces a guide/bodyguard for the trip someone of whom he trusts greatly, but Bodhi on the other hand believes the guide has ulterior motives.Selah finds herself under scrutiny by fellow Landers, who seem to want nothing more than her head. With so much to face, how will they ever find some where safe?Aftershock is a Stone Braide Chronicles Story. This ebook was an epic read with equally epic action. I love how even though it was only forty-one pages long, it still had action and adventure all through it. I definitely can't wait to see what happens next in this series.**Disclosure** This was a purchased book. All opinions are my own.

My Review: Selah Rishon found her father and believed she could live a happy normal life once more, but all is not what it seems. Her father, Glade has a few secrets he‚Äôs been hiding and now wishes to involve the ever so handsome Bodhi. The only problem is Glade despises Bodhi, and Bodhi has begun to loose his powers, do to the fact he begun Selah‚Äôs transition.With Selah trying desperately to find her mom and younger brother, she finds herself with the question of what to do. Her dear friend and her brother plan to travel to the Mountain to unveil whats going on. They wish for her to go along, but what would Bodhi and Glade have to say. But then again they had just left for the Mountain themselves earlier that morning.Soon both Selah and Bodhi along with friends, find danger in the craziest of ways. With some much going on around them, how will they ever save the people Selah holds most dear? And will it cost them everything even Selah‚Äôs life?Lightening is book two in the Stone Braide Chronicles. This book was an amazing sequel to Thunder (book one). I have to say this series is one of my favorites. I love the action and adventure. This book shows what it truly means to have girl power. And boy do I have to say Selah sure has it. I want to see what happens, next cause I don‚Äôt know about you but I want to see what happens to Selah and Bodhi.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from CFBA.

About the Book:Every story whispers his name ‚Ä¶One person is at the heart of every story found in the Bible. One man is the center of God‚Äôs entire redemption plan. This trade adaptation of Sally Lloyd-Jones‚Äô bestselling Jesus Storybook Bible explores the connections and wonders of how one giant love for humanity pointed to one small baby who would grow up to be the one perfect person who would make things right again for everyone.The Story of God‚Äôs Love for You features a new, never-before-seen image from award-winning illustrator Jago, as well as a two-color interior that is ideal for any age ready to encounter an amazing, Never Stopping, Never Giving Up, Unbreaking, Always and Forever Love.My Review: A book of stories, real true to life stories that were sent to help us understand the unimaginable sacrifice that has been made on our behalf. God sent to us His infallible word. A book of stories, a book of promises, a book of truths to set His people free. He need we would need it in this life and He knew we would need so much more, His son. The author has taken this adaptation of a recently published work and made it exclusively for older hearts and minds to embark on the same journey our younger children may have experienced when reading the earlier books from the same author. This beautiful book is full of the hope and promise that God's very word gives. The author has written it beautifully and it is very encouraging and full of hope.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review through my participation on the Z Blog Squad.

About the Book:All life on earth is about to be terminated by an entity as old as the galaxy itself. To make matters worse, Simon has broken everything already.In a future world that is run by computer systems and that is without want, how can a man find his role? Then, if the very computers he works on to try to make them more human suddenly try to kill him, revealing a secret so vast that it affects every living soul on the planet, can that man be a hero?These are the questions that face the stumbling, comic, and certainly flawed Simon Bank. His job is to work with the System‚Äôs artificial intelligence, making it fit more perfectly into human society so that it can keep the country running smoothly. But when the System threatens the peaceful world he knows, Simon suddenly must rush to save his own life, as well as the life of everyone on earth. Forced to reassess everything that he thought he knew, he is caught within circumstances way beyond his control.Simon‚Äôs only hope is to rely on intellect and instincts he didn‚Äôt know he had, and on new friends, not all of them human, to change himself and all humanity. And he doesn‚Äôt have much time.My Review:The world is now run by computers and one man who is very skilled at working computers finds himself in an awkward situation. Simon Bank has a wife and five kids, and going to work each day seemed to be pretty simple. But one day that all changes. With a few codes copied and few things changed, the whole system is being to shut down with Simon as the culprit.He soon runs into a guy named Capt. Charles Cramer; who believes that Simon knows more than he‚Äôs willing to spill. As they go deep into the system, they discover someone else has been tampering with the computers. But who?Systems are threatening to shut down, which could end life as they know it. With a handful of names and Control on their way, Simon and Cramer must act fast.The Path is an epic novel with a wonderful Sci-fi effect. I loved the futuristic feel. The Path is an amazing book. I really enjoyed it and must say this is definitely a real page tuner. I can‚Äôt wait to see what this author has in store for us next.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from the author.

About the Book:Readers of Jan Karon‚Äôs Mitford series and Patrick Taylor‚Äôs Irish Country series will fall in love with Jeff High‚Äôs funny, heartfelt Watervalley series.The pastoral charm of small-town Watervalley, Tennessee, can be deceptive, as young Dr. Luke Bradford discovers when he‚Äôs caught in the fallout of a decades-old conflict‚Ä¶After a rocky start as Watervalley‚Äôs only doctor, Luke Bradford has decided to stay in town, honoring the three-year commitment he made to pay off his medical school debts. But even as his friendships with the quirky townsfolk deepen, and he pursues a romance with lovely schoolteacher Christine Chambers, several military veterans‚Äô emotional wounds trigger anger and unrest in Watervalley.At the center of the clash is the curmudgeonly publisher of the local newspaper, Luther Whitmore. Luther grew up in Watervalley, but he returned from combat in Vietnam a changed man. He fenced in beautiful Moon Lake, posting ‚ÄúKeep Out‚Äù notices at the beloved spot, and provokes the townspeople with his incendiary newspaper.As Luke struggles to understand Luther‚Äôs past, and restore harmony in Watervalley, an unforeseen crisis shatters a relationship he values dearly. Suddenly Luke must answer life‚Äôs toughest questions about service, courage, love, and sacrifice.CONVERSATION GUIDE INCLUDEDMy Review: Doctor Luke Bradford‚Äôs start in the small town of Watervalley was anything but easy. Now after deciding to stay in town for three years, in order to pay off his school debts, he finds himself actually enjoying being there. The only things is he‚Äôs going to have to get use to the small town life, where everyone knows everybody and everything about everyone.Luke finds comfort in the very pretty Christine Chambers. Christine is a school teacher, who seems to have the same feelings for him, he has for her. Where Luke is concerned, she has this small town life down pat and feels pretty comfortable in it.When Luke meets an angry veteran by the name Luther Whitmore, he finds that he must learn what he can to find out what bothers this old man. But with a subtle visit to the local Mennonite town, he learns something is up. And apparently it‚Äôs an age old dispute.The Splendor of Ordinary Days is book three in the Watervalley series. This book was a wonderful read. I‚Äôd have to say one of my favorite parts is when he visit‚Äôs the Mennonite town. I really enjoyed this book and I expect many more great reads from this author.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from Litfuse Publicity.

About the Book:‚ÄúThe Grail is a story, a myth! It didn‚Äôt exist on your world! It can‚Äôt exist here!‚ÄùThe city-state of Varuz is failing. Duke Aurelian is the last of his line, his capital is crumbling, and the armies of his enemy, Duke Conrad, are poised beyond the mountains to invade. Aurelian is preparing to gamble everything on one last battle. So when a holy man, the Doctor, comes to Varuz from beyond the mountains, Aurelian asks for his blessing in the war.But all is not what it seems in Varuz. The city-guard have lasers for swords, and the halls are lit by electric candlelight. Aurelian‚Äôs beloved wife, Guena, and his most trusted knight, Bernhardt, seem to be plotting to overthrow their Duke, and Clara finds herself drawn into their intrigue...Will the Doctor stop Aurelian from going to war? Will Clara‚Äôs involvement in the plot against the Duke be discovered? Why is Conrad‚Äôs ambassador so nervous? And who are the ancient and weary knights who arrive in Varuz claiming to be on a quest for the Holy Grail‚Ä¶?My Review: City-state Varuz is slowly crumbling, with the enemy surrounding them on all sides. Duke Aurelian feels like a failure, believing the only possible answer is to go to war. So when a holy man, The Doctor, arrives he asks for his blessing on his plans, but what the Doctor says blows him away.Clara finds herself in an awkward situation in the Varuz kingdom. The duchess and the dukes trusted knight wish for her to speak with the coming ambassador, secretly behind the dukes back. Clara believes the duke will have her head, but the Doctor agrees with the duchess plans. What choice does she really have?With knights claiming to be looking for the Holy Grail and the enemies ambassador shaking in his boots, what is really going on?Royal Blood is an epic novel in the Doctor Who series. I love both the history of knights and the Doctor Who series, so this book was perfect for me. This book was an amazing read and perfect for any Whovian. I can‚Äôt wait to see what happens next in this series.**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review from Blogging for Books.

About the Book:Based on the bestselling The Beginner's Bible brand, The Beginner's Bible: Kid-Sized Devotions is perfect for children 6 and under. The simple connections to scripture make the content relevant and understandable for young readers, while the colorful illustrations are sure to be a delight. Each of the 365 devotions has a theme to which the Scripture, story, and art relate. It s the perfect starting point for children as they develop a stronger relationship with God, to cuddle-up with parents or enjoy at church or daycare."My Review: Even our 4-8 children need devotional time and what better way to get them interested than to find a devotional that is clearly up their alley. The Beginner's Bible brand knows all too well how to appeal to children so this book is a slam dunk for them. Included in Kid-Sized Devotions is enough for 365 days of great learning. In simple to understand sentences and with illustrated pages your children can learn easily and quickly each day about God and His creation. Based entirely on scripture, each devotion has a short and sweet lesson each day consisting of just a few sentences and a Bible verse. So even your young children can benefit from this book without feeling like its to hard o understand or takes up too much of their time. A perfect gift for Christmas!**Disclosure** This book was sent to me free of charge for my honest review through my participation on the Z Blog Squad.

This is very good matcha - not gritty, clean flavor, no bitterness, not too grassy. I would say it is one of the better matchas I have tried and is an excellent compliment to plain green tea, which I drink far more regularly (easier to make and cheaper).Thank you, Midori Spring!

This book is a most excellent way of learning how to find, communicate, and use information. If you need these skills and you don't have time to read a pile of textbooks, this is a good place to start.Data analysis is taught anywhere, but data synthesis is a much rarer skill. With Signal we have a resource that covers both of these angles, is easy to use, and comprehensive in coverage. This is an excellent standalone guide but would also be a great overview to the subject prior to deeper studies.

Babadook is the heart-warming story of a woman, her seriously annoying son, and the children's book that nearly tore them apart.The son is basically the type of person you'd wish someone would lock in a car on a hot summer's day, but his mother puts up with him, bless her heart. Until one day, a children's book arrives mysteriously, and has lots of spoooooooky pictures and cryptic poetics about some guy in a trench coat. The mom starts to lose it, and the more she loses it, the more the trench coat guy pokes at her. But as she loses it, the son becomes less annoying, so pretty soon you're hoping he will "accidentally" push her down the stairs. But he puts up with her, bless him. Soon they join forces and turn the trench coat guy into a house pet. The end.It's not a bad premise really, I always thought children's books were the perfect medium for seriously twisted stuff, so that's a cool feature. If the Babadook was really a book and not a movie, people would seriously freak out, and it would be legend. But instead, we have this film. Alas.

Best movie ever? Quite possibly. This is ridiculous to an extreme. It's more absurd than anything, but that absurdity translates into all sorts of things - romance and mutilation, comedy and dismemberment music videos... If you take your cinema seriously then you're in trouble. Highest possible recommendation.

This book lives at the nexus between a corporate finance textbook and a popular management book. It condenses a lot of information that seems like the stuff you'd learn in the first year of business school, but yet is very instructional for anyone just learning organizational capitalism and all that it entails. I imagine this would be an excellent refresher for highly motivated executives as well, although I'm not sure there are many of those around.I took the advice of another reader who recommended pairing this with the McKinsey Valuation Workbook, but I had to do a lot of side research to fill in some technical gaps. I might have been better served with the more advanced and regularly updated Valuation, but I appreciated the brevity and condensing of valuable topics into a fairly short read.I would definitely recommend this book, if you have sufficient motivation to really READ it.

Louie, I get that I'm not supposed to watch this show and like you. You're going for the opposite effect here. We're supposed to all believe you're a bumbling moron with no sense of humor, terrible parenting skills, blatant hypocrisy regarding recreational drug use, and worse raping skills than a 13 year old. We get it, that's just who you are, and the show is about you. You suck as a person, and that is what makes the show funny. But you can suck better than this. You sucking as a person is supposed to be funny. That was why you got this show. Now please, do something productive with it.

I have owned this book for six years and have done my best to do the exercises daily. I have found it to be far more potent than any other system of internal training I have tried, and the instructions in the book are much better than the instructions I have received in personal training. I do not own the DVD, but I watched several segments of it and found Tim's examples to be very close to my own movements. The trick is the movements you cannot see, of course, but this book gets into that as well.Basically the meat of this book (for me) is the 17 exercise system of xingyi neigong. Each exercise is explained three ways - one is a translation of the original Chinese teaching, one is an English-native explanation (from Tim), and one is a "traditional" explanation (very poetic, but points out more esoteric features not covered in the other explanations). Read all three carefully to get all the points. It will take a while, and you may want to check your work with a martial arts instructor or (in my case) a TCM practitioner.Very highly recommended. Too bad it's out of print.

A retired pilot guy lives in South Dakota. He stumbles across a NASA base where a scientist has discovered a hole in some Jupiter moon. The hole leads to some other galaxy with a bunch of planets. The scientist convinces the pilot to fly through the hole and find out what happened to a bunch of other people who went in and never came out. The pilot goes in, and finds the most boring planets ever. Knowing that he should have stayed home, the pilot tries to kill himself by flying into a black hole. Come to find out, that black hole is actually a portal to his daughter's bookshelf, which makes him super upset. But he gets over it, then programs a wrist watch so it will communicate the black hole's physics to his daughter so she can build a spacecraft and save all of humanity.Twists and turns abound... We learn that the scientist thought that flying into the other galaxy was a waste of time but he didn't bother telling anyone. But it turns out that it wasn't a waste of time because the aliens who built the hole to the other galaxy weren't actually trying to get us to live on the planets there. They were trying to get us to fly into the black hole, but we wouldn't have known that if the planets weren't so deadly boring that they drove the pilot to try to kill himself. So they must have made the planets boring on purpose, so anyone who went to them would instantly choose death and try to use the black hole to commit suicide. And it turns out that they aren't aliens at all, they are us! We built a space-time manipulation computer inside a black hole inside a galaxy inside the hole inside a moon inside our solar system! It was all a ploy by future humans to save the past humans by tricking them into trying to commit suicide. Brilliant!But that's not all... Nolan actually designed this film to be so boring that YOU will want to kill yourself, thereby taking the meta-plot and making it a meta-meta-META-plot. You will suffer the same horrifying boredom that the pilot endures in the film, and you will want to travel back in time to your own bookcase to warn yourself not to watch it. The level of brilliance is now, officially, through the roof.

This book is all you need to make information graphics in reports, business documents, presentations, and publications in general. There is a lot of theory in many other books on the topic but not every researcher, analyst, student, executive, etc has the time or inclination for that. If you learn nothing more than what this book teaches, you will be able to present your data cleanly and effectively. This alone puts you ahead of 90% of everyone else.

This is one of the better side-opening autos out there for the money. The design is simple, ergonomics are clean, the size is decent enough for hard use and the weight is manageable for regular carry. Legalities aside, this is an excellent choice for a folding knife that requires rapid one-handed deployment.One thing to note is that the X1 version of this knife has the fish-scale milling, but only the "M" version has the safety switch. The price difference is about $20-30, so is the switch worth it? Personally I think so - I would rather have it and not use it than not have it at all. But it does get used - I find I am much less apprehensive about hard use when I know the button cannot be depressed to unlock the blade. I don't see how the switch would be useful in the closed position, since the button is flush with the surface, the blade is tip-up (facing the outer pants seam instead of the crotch), and deployment is greatly compromised when you have to remember (under severe stress) to flip the switch.In all this is a fine knife that holds its own against pricier competitors without compromising build quality or reliable use.

Not that this book needs another five star review, but I have a reason for chiming in. I was reading Ron's books starting around 2005 or so, and while I loved the way they made me think about everything. After writing five books that I know of, Ron produced this work, which summarizes everything from previous books and offers a hands-on approach to his value pricing model.Now, Ron is an accountant. This means you have to be able to think about what he is saying in your own context. He cannot give you your context, only his own. This doesn't make what he says any less useful in any professional service. The idea of value creation as a measure of company plus customer profit, and how to apply this concept to define price, is applicable to anyone who uses their brain to make money. And there are many ways to think of a fabrication company as a professional service provider, so no one is entirely excluded.Another selling point for this book is that this is where the nuts-and-bolts of value pricing ended up after all revisions of The Professional's Guide to Value Pricing went out of print. So if you missed that one entirely, if you're new to Ron's work, or if you're a professional looking to radically rethink how you and your company create value, get this book.

I love these shoes. They work great indoors and out, on tile, dirt, grass, concrete, wood, and that padded crap in dojos. Wear resistance will vary, depending on the abrasion level of the ground you're training on, and how much or how hard you train. They fit well and don't cause any problems, no markings on the floor or pinching/rubbing on my feet. Nice.Measure your foot while standing (as your foot will splay out a bit) and if you buy the right size you'll be fine - but they are a little narrow. I prefer these to the low tops for training and I prefer the low tops for exercise. So get a pair of both, then double up on the one you use most. If you're dedicated enough to training that you are reading this, then you're going to need spares.

This is it, Spyderco's definitive gentleman's no-nonsense utility folder. While they took the gentleman's wharncliffe folder to new levels of style with the Air and the Des Horn, the Kiwi 4 strips away all but the bare essentials of functionality. Here are some important design points:1. The design is 100% ambidextrous, you get full opening, using, and closing functionality with either hand, and it carries on either side with a simple swap of the clip.2. The blade is full flat ground, providing unprecedented cutting geometry for slicing tasks, which is pretty much all this knife is designed for.3. The Kiwi 4 was designed by Spyderco founder Sal Glesser as both a size and utility upgrade from previous Kiwi models.4. The Kiwi 4 is actually lighter than the Kiwi 3 by a few grams, despite being larger overall with a longer blade.Criticisms I have heard include the price, the use of pins instead of screws, the design differences from previous Kiwi models, and a stiff pivot. Here are my thoughts on these.The price isn't much different from other Moki-produced Spyderco lockbacks, and for the use value and production quality you're still getting a lot for your money.You could never make the knife this compact with screws, so the design would have been chunkier and defeated its own purpose.I don't see how simply enlarging the previous Kiwi profile would make this a better knife. Clearly Sal didn't either.If the pivot is stiff when you get it, add a drop of oil. Problem solved.All things considered, I feel this is one of Spyderco's better products in general and it has largely taken the place of my Dragonfly 2 and Caly 3, which have many similar attributes. Once the novelty is worn off I might find myself alternating it more often, but if I could only have one, this would definitely be it. Good job, Sal.

This is a difficult book to review without having completed every training protocol outlined by the author. The first training set (basic physical conditioning) is prescribed after only ten pages of introductory content, and the reader is instructed to do these exercises for three months before you continue reading the book. Most people simply do not have the focus and self discipline to do this, and moreover it is difficult to be motivated when you are still on the fence about jin or qi in general.There is another complication: the martial applications are systemic (taichi or xingyi, for instance) and thus not included in this book. The author claims this is a future project, but for now you are on your own. And if you study something non-Chinese in origin, you'll be on your own even if the author makes a follow-up book. So be prepared to find or modify your own path once you're done with this book.So what do I think? I think this book required a leap of faith, both in internal martial arts and in the author's ability to instruct you via a book. I also think it is worth it. Even if you have your doubts, you will feel profound changes in your body by doing exactly as the author describes.With this book, you spend a lot of training time developing strength in parts of your body that may seem irrelevant to martial arts, but are actually the key to mastery. Anyone who has trained with a credible instructor can attest to some inexplicable things - the inability to move them, the shock and pain delivered by casual looking strikes. The instructor seems to expend no effort yet can throw people twice their size. Few books out there really explain how this works, and nearly every instructor or student I have trained with believed these abilities came with endless repetition of forms.That is why you need this book. You will learn, firsthand, why this power (jin) is so hard to explain, but you will learn through your own practice and honing of form and movement. There is an undeniable logic present here, even if is is intrinsically tied to mysterious invisible energy channels. And if you think this latter item is a complete myth, try suspending your disbelief and follow the instructions as written. You will learn for yourself what you are really capable of, regardless of your opinion on the theoretical underpinnings.In all this is an excellent resource worthy of diligent study and use. There is much more use than study, however, so you'd better be willing to make time in your schedule, or else you're better off not getting this book in the first place.

This is the only planner I will use anymore. The most useful feature is the weekly spread, with a week of daily schedule slots on one side and a full sheet of lined paper on the other, I can set weekly goals and take notes without being stuck inside the tiny margins provided in most planners. The back pocket is also highly useful for storing anything from shopping lists to records without worrying about them falling out whenever I use it. Definitely the best planner on the market and I will continue using them as long as Rhodia makes them.

This book is not a bad introduction to real options for people who have some corporate finance background and who work in project management specifically. I do think it is one of the better introductory texts to real options for those who have to actually use it, but I am also highly spoiled.Before I read this, I was fortunate enough to get Shockley's Real Options Valuation book, which has a heavy emphasis on applications. It contains a mind-blowing number of examples and practice questions that will get you fully up to speed on how and when to use real options valuation methods in lieu of static-NPV based methods that do not account for optionality over multiple time periods. This is something Project Valuation Using Real Options briefly covers but not to the level of practical detail that I think project managers will truly appreciate and heavily use.In sum I want to say if you are not sure what real options are or how they are used, and you need a brief corporate finance refresher to help you pick it up, then this is a good choice. If you want heavily theoretical literature, go for Real Options by Trigeorgis and dig in to your heart's content. But if you want advanced practical applications, get the Shockley book. None of them are necessarily good or bad, but are relative to what you're trying to accomplish.

I'm no athlete, but I know a good idea when I see one. I have trouble finding time in the day to eat the right things, and eating big meals a few times per day leaves me alternating between hunger and over-filled bloatedness and lethargy. One option is to snack on whatever is available, but that often becomes handfuls of nuts, granola bars, and other foods that are bland or overprocessed.So what is the solution? How about portable mini-meals that can be made quickly in batches and individually wrapped for portability and portion control? Brilliant. And this is the book that got me there. Now I don't even need to worry about meals when I'm on the go, and I don't feel like I have to give in to the all-too-easy temptation of junk and fast foods. And the real kicker is how easy this stuff is to make and to modify to fit my individual needs and tastes. Brilliance, once again.Besides the wide range of recipes presented, this book provides a fair amount of nutritional information as well. Although geared specifically toward athletes (and professional athletes at that), it works great for busy people who want alternatives to premade foods that never provide the satisfaction of real, home-cooked food.For those looking to go beyond recipes and get into the science of nutrition without going totally overboard, I recommend Teri Tom's Martial Arts Nutrition. That book plus this one make a great team, and now I have Biju and Allen's previous book on order so I can learn even more, feel even better, and make more incredible foods that satisfy both the body and the palate.

Imagine, if you dare, a world in which our accelerating use of technology allows us to never do anything useful. We become our social network and earn capital by liking cat videos and posting photos of every single breakfast. We don't have to wash our own clothes, but no one is employed so we will have to exchange online product reviews for laundry detergent.This is the horror imagined by Rifkin. If we are not cautious, we will become so vapid that all of humanity will vanish up its own butt, never to be seen again. This ominous tome explains how we are well on our way. May the gods help us all.

This is one of the better sunblocks I've tried. It is very dry, making it hard to spread over wide areas but great for faces and other areas you don't want to look or feel greasy. It smells weird - my wife says it smells like "plants," but I think it smells like a room that hasn't been dusted in years. There isn't much else to add, just don't use it for large areas like your chest, back, or legs because it absorbs fast and dry and you'll likely end up using more than is economical.In summary, I tend to use one very dry sunblock for my face and neck and another wetter kind for larger areas. This one fits right into the type I use for my face, and it a bit more robust than what I'd use day to day. I think this would make an excellent sport sunblock or one for long periods in the sun with water and sweat exposure. Definitely worth buying.

It's hard for me to believe I never reviewed this book before. I have to say that when I first got it, I wasn't sure what to think of it. The layout is insane, with photos and drawings and clever use of white space and text size. Paul was an ad man, so this makes complete sense.As for the information, well, Paul seems to harvest his ideas from the farthest corner of the left field. The main point of the book is that you can only get something insanely audacious if you immediately try to grab hold of it. This forces you to curb fear of rejection and possible lack of credentials and simply act as if what you want is already yours.Of course, doing this will lead to spectacular failures. But reaching for something high requires a few bad falls, and the only alternative is to live on an even keel. And if that's what you want, then why are you here?I'm not sure what I would have done with the last ten years of my life if I hadn't read this book, but I'm sure it would have been much duller. I was certainly more inclined to do something risky (write and publish a book, defy an old boss who fired me as a result, etc) and for every fall I ended up gaining something bigger and different than I could have ever predicted. And every time I think of Paul and his books.I understand that there isn't a lot to read here, but there are a lot of behavioral pointers that will have powerful consequences in your life. If you made only one piece of Paul's advice a part of your life, you would be a different person. Go on, see for yourself.

A beautiful spoon with a nice deep ladle cup, good for spooning out soups or stews. It is a lightweight wood but seems to be sturdy and comes with a leather tie to hang it. I think this may be my new favorite spoon. I really like the ladle design and it is great for at the table, well balanced. It is a nice addition to my wooden kitchen spoon collection that will see a lot of use.I received this product free or at a reduced price for my honest opinion.

It is decent toilet paper and has always been considered to be the best but not any more. The rolls are getting smaller not only in width but also in size and sheet count. Charmin isn't squeezing any more they are pinching and making us pay more. I have been a long time user of charmin but have since started to use another TP simply because they are making the value so poor.That being said the TP is soft and is strong, it gets the job done.

The product feels creamy and spread easily. It does seem to make my eye area look a little better. I felt no burning or irritation from it. I can't get past the strong perfume scent it has though. This product also pills which I find unacceptable in any type of skin cream.Some people seem to love it but I don't. This is my personal experience, yours might be different.

wow it is the brightest solar light I have seen so far. We tried this and it just doesn't shave close enough unless you remove the guard and then the blade itself is exposed. I tried shaving a few hairs off my legs just to try it and I have to go over it multiple times just to get a few hairs. My son tried it and the only way it actually shaved well was to remove the guard. It really isn't very good and didn't give the results we wanted. My son is very disappointed in this. It would not give a close shave on any hair and trimming hairs with the guards didn't work well, most of the hair didn't even cut.

The ingredients seem to be OK, there are some I am not sure about like turkey tails? what is that? It does seem to be healthy and gives good protein and digestive ingredients too. I would be pleased with the product if it weren't for the taste. I think it tastes terrible. To me the chocolate tastes fake or it is not a good chocolate. I do like that it has stevia in it instead of some fake sugars. I have had things with stevia and as long there isn't too much in it, it tastes fine. I think they put a little much in this since the flavor is off and it is too sweet. It is better with milk but still not good enough. So while the ingredients seem to be good the taste is enough to keep me away. For being an inexpensive and small unit this works surprisingly well. I like the collar because I can adjust it and it stays so I just need to buckle it. The only reason it loses one star is because of a few minor things that could be improved. I would like to see 3 buttons one for each the tone, the vibrate and the shock. The way it is now you have to cycle through the options to get to what you want. There is no on/off button, it goes into standby but a couple times we had to push a button a couple of time to wake it. The range isn't as far as the more expensive ones but for in the yard it works well. We have an older german shorthair and she mostly just needs a reminder to listen and we don't have to use the shock most of the time, just the vibrate or tone but when we do need the shock we need it immediately not after cycling through all the options.If you need a trainer this would be great for most dogs and the collar is adjustable, I know there is a lot of adjustment left for my dog. I don't think it would go real small though but you could put another collar on this I would think just so it is wide enough. My dog sometimes wants to take out after a deer or a cat and that is when we need the shock to stop her and bring her back.I received this product free or at a reduced price for my honest review.

It works great with apple but we tried 2 different models of android (BLU, Alcatel) and neither of them would work even with the camera 360 app. If you have an apple product go for it, it is lightweight, extends and contracts easily, super easy to use and is also easy to stick into a pocket or purse. Headsets are everywhere these days and I suspect many of them share the same guts.  Fit and comfort are a place where these differ.  I have a giant head - my bike helmet is called a "Kinghead," my proper circumference is 62cm - and these expand to fit adequately without dragging my ears down or pressing on the tender point right under the ear.  The earpieces are not super cushiony; they're soft, roomy, fit easily and well.Sound quality is average for headphones these days, which is to say very good indeed; that crystalline sparkle of the $250+ Sennheiser is missing, but these are neither Sennheisers nor anywhere near as expensive, in fact, you could outfit your whole guild with these for that price.  The mic seems OK; no one had any trouble understanding me and it was easy to position, and the foam windguard cuts down on breath noise.You can use it with nearly anything that takes a 3-lead 3.5mm jack, including an Xbox, a PS4, a Mac, an iPhone 6, my gaming PC's front headphone/mic jack, and probably a lot of other things that I didn't try; I don't have an Xbox, but I tried it on everything else listed above and it worked perfectly, no muss, no fuss.  Packaging and instructions were adequate; I don't care much about those things and they did what they needed to do.I like the way these phones look; the electric green color is kind of sassy and I enjoy it.  So I'd say if the price looks right and you don't mind a wire tether - I don't, wireless headphones are a huge hassle - then pull the trigger on these cans and get shooting!

I'm pretty passionate about knives.  I love cooking - enthusiastic amateur - and as far as I am concerned, good knife work is the first step in getting the best flavors out of meats, vegetables, and fresh herbs.  And you can't do good knife work with a bad knife.My mainstay for comparison is a Global 8" chef's knife, G-2, and I simply adore it for its weight, balance, and edge retention; so I'll be using it as my benchmark in this review.  (I've also had a variety of Henckels kitchen knives including both their middle-of-the-road and top lines; Buck, Marbles, and handmade hunting knives; and an old Solingen carbon-steel knife from the 1950's.)  I found myself using the Sabatier a lot over the last month as I compared them side by side.  The Sabatier is as light as the Global - the only other Chef's knife I've used that's as light.  The blade is actually smaller, both shorter and less tall, and I didn't like that as well; it is thin enough that it almost feels like it might flex, which is really undesirable in a knife.  It has a full tang but the handle is very light.  I have gotten used to the Global integral handle, which is hollow textured steel that has captive sand in it so the handle weight shifts depending on how you're holding the knife; this knife doesn't do that, but the handle is light enough that it only feels a touch handle heavy by comparison; I can chop and dice just as fast as anything, the knife never slows me down.The factory edge was great but not quite surgical; and though it is Cromova, edge retention was nowhere near as good as the Global alloy.  I mostly cut vegetables on plastic for the month I used it, and at the end of the month it was dulled worse than the Global, which I last sharpened more than a year ago.  Don't mistake this for a complaint; this knife comes in second of all the knives I've ever had for edge retention; I had to sharpen my top-end Henckels twice a week, and the middle-of-the-road Henckels simply wouldn't get sharp enough to satisfy.  The Sabatier is also super easy to sharpen; I dread sharpening the Global, it takes most of an afternoon to get it right without wrecking my Arkansas oilstone in the process.  Sharpening the Sabatier back to better-than-factory took less than 5 minutes and it felt good - it was easy to know where you were with the edge.I love the mother-of-pearloid handle.  (In Fender guitars, this plastic is affectionately called MOTO - mother-of-toilet-seat.)  It's beautiful; it feels nice; and it's super easy to clean, indeed it's hard to dirty it.  The edge of the blade is something I use a lot to carry diced stuff around; it's not too sticky and most of the back is straight, but the short height of the blade means there's less area to use as a scoop, and I found myself swearing as I had to go back for second and third swipes between board and pan.  The aggressive taper of the tip doesn't help this either; in fact, it's not good for much of anything and I wish they'd put a bit more curve on the bottom of the tip and left a little more metal at the top.Details.  This knife is great.  It's not good enough to switch me from Global, but for someone who wants an attractive, easy to clean, easy to sharpen, absolute top of the line 8" chef's knife that's super light, this has got to be top of your Christmas list!

This is a plug and play bridge.  My house's setup is one Airport Extreme upstairs, one Airport Express downstairs, and a few wireless speakers; and there are a few dead spots; the AE is halfway between the kitchen and the garage and neither is fully covered when it comes to streaming music.I moved the AE closer to the kitchen, plugged this in in the laundry where it shares a wall with the garage, and went through the 2 minute setup.  Done.  Full coverage.100% recommended for extending an Apple network!

It'd been a long time since I'd done regular workouts with a bag - I got my black belt a full 25 years ago, quit working out a few years after that.  I ended up buying a Ringside heavy bag to work out with and these fill the bill nicely, keeping my knuckles looking pretty on Monday morning.  They fit well, they're easy on and off, and there's enough room inside for thick tape if you are wanting to go that route - I don't, the padding of the glove is enough for me.  The force of the impact distributes nicely and there's no sideways forces to knock your knuckles out of line.  They're quick to put on and the thick velcro is quick to cinch up and highly adjustable.  I can go a full half hour with these on, which is about as much bag work as I need to do.  And I'd forgotten what a great workout it is - and how much fun!

Cuisinart is a name I associate with best-in-class food processors.  But I can't imagine this pizza server is best in class.  It's two pieces of sheet metal, stamped, folded, and then welded together - and then the weld filed down.  Edges aren't sharp, and the shape of the thing is right.  But the cheap, sticky black rubber that surrounds the handle belies the Cuisinart name it's stamped with.  It's not nice to touch and it smells funny.  The hook fell right out as I opened the package; it's just a bent piece of wire that can fit into the hole at the end of the handle.I am sure that if what you need is a tool to lift a pizza slice - or a small trowel - this will fit the bill nicely.  Mine ended up in the garage, it'll be just the thing next time I have to lay down a cement patch.

This is a deep plastic tub designed to go under a normal sized washing machine to catch water leaks.  It comes with a fittable hose-bib so that leak water could be redirected via hose wherever you wanted it to go.  It could also underlay a hot water heater, I think.  But I have been using it to sit under a portable window-A/C unit that sometimes overflows water on humid days; it catches that and keeps it off my hardwood floor.Another use for this tub is washing large, flat things, like small rugs and car floor mats.  It's deep enough that you can submerge a carpeted mat and get a good lather going.Highly recommended!

These gloves are large, but they are not particularly large-sized.  Usually an L fits my 7.5 size hand but these L's felt more like M's to me, the fingers were about a half-inch too short.Because the glove material is thick, it is a bit less stretchy than the usual nitrile exam glove, compounding the sizing problem.  But the thick nitrile is super tough; I can't imagine anything piercing it in normal use.  Nitrile is non-reactive and resistant to a variety of oils, solvents, and alcohols, and these gloves are totally water-tight as well.  The cuff covers my wrist, but not much of my 'lower forearm', whatever that is.Bottom line: great single-use wrist gloves for heavy duty; order a size up.

Very standard, thin, single-use nitrile glove.  The "L" size is a good fit for my size 7.5 hands, the fingers are the right length, a touch baggy in the palm.  The fingertips are textured for better grip when handling tools, but in general these are quite thin gloves, they'd be appropriate, for example, in a breast exam if you needed to be able to feel small lumps.  They're not particularly stretchy and are prone to tearing if you over-stretch them.They're nitrile so they are resistant to a variety of alcohols, solvents and oils as well as 100% watertight.  Light blue color is what it is.  Downside is they're not very durable.  If you're doing anything with edges, corners or abrasion, these gloves will last 10 minutes tops before you get a rip in them.  But for their intended use they are just what the doctor ordered.

These thick black nitrile gloves are a true M in size.  They are stretchier than some nitrile gloves and have a good tack to them so they are form fitting on my size 7.5 hands, but the fingers are not long enough; I think they'd be a perfect fit for a 6.5 and a good fit on a 7.  They are not slippery and make it easy to pick things up; they are totally watertight, so if you use them on a hot day, soon your hands will be swimming in sweat.  They're also resistant to a variety of solvents, oils and alcohols that I work with; I didn't find anything that dissolved them or that went through the material.  And they're tough, quite resistant to rips and tears in a way that usual exam gloves are not.The black color is what it is; if you are working with dirty things, it makes it very difficult to tell whether your hands are too dirty to touch something that you'd like to keep clean.  On the other hand, if your shop's workers are seen by the public, these gloves don't show dirt.

This is a small bag made of stiff canvas/duck fabric, with prints of different kinds of bread around the inside top.  I usually have a loaf of bread lying around and a bread-box strikes me as old fashioned and overly formal.  This bag can be tossed in the corner of the counter.I usually get sliced rounds and they fit in with no trouble.  A long loaf of bread won't fit inside, but can lean against the stiff edge and poke out the top.  It looks cute and if it gets kitcheny, it appears it'll be easy to clean in the washing machine.

I've been writing coffeemaker reviews on Amazon for nearly 15 years.  Consumer-grade grind-n-brew?  Yeah, been there, done that.  I recall one prior Cuisinart that I slammed for "near-total absence of venting and valving;" that one let steam into the grinder each brew cycle, requiring two paper towels to clean it per session.  Another, a Krups, seemed to get the valving right with a rotary disc; but its blade grinder ground too coarsely and it broke a lot: after six months it had spent more time in repair (two trips!) than actually on my counter making coffee.  And in addition, it leaked onto the countertop.I'm pretty happy with this Cuisinart, after using it daily for three months, and I'm going to write a little bit about what they got right.First of all.  I don't usually drink 12 cups of coffee.  4 cups is my daily dose and I needed a machine that could brew that, hot and on time, and deliver it with the same quality found in the occasional 12-cup batch brewed for guests.  This ruled out the plastic insulated carafe models.  4 cups of coffee into a 12 cup carafe - well, by the time the carafe warms up, your small volume of coffee is now lukewarm.  It'll stay lukewarm - the carafe is insulated, right?  But it'll never be hot.  Yuck.  This model, the 700BC, has a glass carafe that rests on a very conventional electric heating element.  The coffee drips into a hot carafe and is kept hot; it gets sour after about 90 minutes and I think there's auto shutoff at the 3 hour mark.  The carafe itself is nice to hold, nice to put together, holds tight through a dishwasher cycle (don't add extra heat, you'll melt the plastic top).  My favorite of all: you can pour quickly, even past vertical, and the spout will not splash coffee everywhere.  It is an anti-spill top and it makes it easy for me to direct coffee just where I want it, even before my first cup when I am not quite awake yet.  I have yet to have a spill and am considering getting rid of the plastic tray that my last 10 years of coffee pots have needed to sit on!Now let's talk daily operation.  Time is easy to set; program time is just as easy to set.  The dials and lights are easily viewed from adult height.  You get the choice to program a start time for grind-n-brew operation, or if you want to pre-load grounds the night before you can set it for 'grind off', that is, brew-only operation.  Or if you want it to go immediately, you just press the button and you are off to the races.  The grinder is a little bit loud; I can't hear it upstairs, but it definitely alerts my backyard bluejays that it's time to come and get their morning cashew.  It's not painfully loud nor is it an unpleasant sound; it sounds like a coffee grinder.Grinding has a few settings: you set it for number of cups and mild, medium or strong.  I have mine set on 4 cups and strong and it gives me a very consistent, predictable dose.  The burr grinder is light-years ahead of the cheap blade grinders in other units; yet, inferior to a real pro burr grinder like my la Pavoni.  On the grind chute:  there's all kinds of people talking about cleaning the chute being a pain.  Pro tip: don't bother.  I think I've cleaned the chute twice.  It's not necessary to clean the chute if you make coffee every day; you may get just a tiny bit of day-old grounds in your coffee.  It doesn't plug up, at least not if your beans are fresh and dry.Assembly is easy.  The grounds assembly is two parts: a normal basket filter holder (I use Melitta Basket Coffee Filters, Natural Brown) and a tight-fitting lid that has a spinny disc on it.  After putting it together, you have to line up the disc properly with the housing when you close the door on the assembled filter holder.  Now this disc has three holes, which are lined with a stretchy synthetic-rubber valve seal: one is for grinding, one is for dripping hot water, one is for sealing the aroma in.  Works like a charm, no muss, no fuss, no moisture in the clear plastic bean hopper, ever.  Easy to clean under a running sink; you'll know when it's clean because just the pressure of the water will spin the disc in either direction.  And you can load the filter in wet and let it sit overnight, it'll work just as well as if you bothered to dry it.  Cleanup takes 15 seconds; reloading is another 15 seconds; I usually let the grounds assembly drip dry in between.  They can go in the dishwasher, but I don't bother.  This is the first coffee maker where I've ever actually been pleased with the convenience and ease of this step.The hopper holds about a half-pound of beans.  Its lock mechanism is a little fiddly but once you figure it out, no big deal.  I like that the top is crystal clear so I can see my beautiful, oily beans; and yet it is moisture sealed, an excellent place to store beans.  The clear plastic looks like it ought to scratch, but it hasn't yet.  The brushed-steel and gloss black plastic surfaces are handsome and wipe down easily with a paper towel when necessary.  Controls are firm, decisive, feel nice to use.  The plug is a bit flimsy, my Breville appliances have spoiled me, but it is an adequate length.This is the part of the review where I talk about what I don't like.  I had to stop and think; there isn't much.  I am very happy with this machine.  The door in the back where you pour the water in is a little narrow.  You have to have good aim or you will miss.  I have splashed a bit of water behind the coffee maker, maybe every day.  No big deal.  The machine is tall; I have standard height cabinets over a standard height counter and I have to pull the machine all the way to the front because there is not enough room to get the carafe in above the machine, yet below the cabinets.  Again, no big deal; I can push it back again when the water is loaded in.  I don't bother with the included charcoal filter because I have RO water.Durability is the last word.  It's been working perfectly for about 90 days.  If it breaks, I'll update this review.Until then, this coffee maker has my 100% recommendation; with no reservations.  It is far and away the best daily coffee pot I have ever used, it beats the competition by a country mile.  If mine went out of commission for some reason I'd buy another one tomorrow and I have recommended it to all my friends!

This Canon was a pleasant surprise for me.  The last time I used an inkjet printer, they were just cheap, flimsy plastic housings for expensive inkjet cartridges.  But this device is much more than that.Setup was easy; it was nice to be transferred from a no-words giant poster, that had substeps 1,2,3 and 4 for step 1, then went on to step 2 - confused yet?  I sure was - to the touchscreen, which provided a nice animated way of explaining what you were supposed to do.  There is a lot of tape to peel off and plastic fiddly bits to throw away; it helps to know that all the discarded stuff is orange.  It took about 15 minutes to get it all set up: install all 5 cartridges (I got black on my thumb, but I am a klutz;) print out the calibration page and scan it; and then hook up to my password protected WiFi network.  I use an Apple Airport, so I couldn't use WPS; that was under 'advanced options'.  Software install was easy, I went to their webpage; and as a bonus, my Macbook Pro noticed I had a Canon printer, immediately went online the next day and downloaded a driver update and the Canon software.  I like that the printer doesn't have to sit near a computer; it's happy where it is.I immediately started by trying to print a high-res, very saturated photo (Nikon, even) of a sunset that I had tweaked in post until it showed every color of the rainbow.  Performance was surprisingly good, but not perfect; the vibrant purples turned into a sort of washed-out mauve, the reds turned into oranges, and the deep aquamarine, one of my favorite colors, turned into cyan.  On more restrained images - faces, a Christmas tree - color performance and resolution was acceptable.  And this was on regular paper; I'm now motivated to get some glossy paper and print out some snaps.  The included software also helps you print out other things, like Christmas cards, and I'm interested in getting that to happen too. But I wouldn't use it for volume; a quick online search suggests that 100 4x6 glossies would cost about $80 in supplies, so I think if you had 100 identical cards to print out, you'd do better with an online service.I don't have much need to scan or copy but those features work, in color or B&W, and it's nice to have this around for the occasional quickie scan.  And the interface and menu is typical Canon quality, lightyears ahead of the 10 years old LaserJet multifunction beast that this replaced.I'd recommend this to anyone who is in the market for an inkjet photo printer - it surpassed all my expectations.  If Amazon doesn't barf on my review this time I'll try to add pics: of the original sunset photo, and then a photo of the printer's attempt to reproduce it, tweaked in post to match what my eye sees (turns out digital cameras see things differently than the eye does; the photograph of the print looked identical to the original, not washed out at all.)  EDIT:  Couldn't figure out how to do it.  Check the product photos.

A large hook for attaching to matte tiles.  Fine.Doesn't use adhesive or friction.  OK, now you got my attention.A clear square plastic sheet, sticky on one side, 3x3", sticks to the tile.  It's pretty clear - you can't see it in normal light.  A suction cup, except no suction, locks into the back of the hook.  Oh wait, whoever installed the plastic into the back of the steel hook got it upside down, it doesn't lock this way.  2 screws later, it's right.  The flat plastic "cup" sticks to the slick square.  Great.Put it up.  Hang a bathrobe on it.  Put some towels down so when it falls off it doesn't take a chip out of my nice tub - this hook is heavy steel.Come back 15 minutes.  It's fallen down.  Good thing I put some towels down, it would have chipped my tub.Now it's in the wastebasket where it belongs.  I want the 10 minutes of my life back that I spent opening the package and fixing the backwards hook!

I am a physician who has been in practice many years.  My Littman Cardiology III has saved lives.  Supposedly carotid auscultation is neither sensitive nor specific - OK, fine, but my Cardio III has picked up a few high-grade stenosis, one double stenosis on a 79 year old with recurrent syncope.  That man was about to die; a week and two operations later he was right as rain.I've also picked up pericardial tamponades, VSDs, all sorts of valvular abnormalities, succussion splashes, and even the occasional bruit from an AVM or vertebral artery abnormality.  And I can hear all of the Korotkoff sounds on those occasions where I choose to take a manual brachial BP.This 'scope is no good if you don't know what you're listening for, don't care to hear it, or haven't been trained.  It won't train you.  The tunable diaphragm is a neat feature - I use it every day because I'm accustomed to it.  That takes time.I knew a cardiac surgeon towards the end of his career who was going deaf - he took around a Fisher-Price scope.  You could hear murmurs through it but it was like listening through a fuzzy curtain.  But in his case, and for the rest of you wangs who didn't train in physical diagnosis, a nod is as good as a wink - to a deaf bat.  Buy a status symbol.But if you want comfort and quality sound amplification, this scope is the one.  Buy it, use it everyday, and, then, you will have the luxury afforded by any good tool - you can forget about it and get to work.  I'm buying another because I want an extra scope for my doctor's hospital bag; I still have my original, and it's been through some pretty rough use - looks brand new.One downside: people steal these all the damn time.  There's a reason they made the name tag big, ugly and hard to remove, and this is it.  Use the tag - or lose your scope.

I have been running one of these for about a year.  I bought the bulb as sort of a foray into LED lighting, and interestingly, the price has not gone down one bit - so much for those promises.The bulb consists of a finned housing that contains some ultraviolet LEDs, and a big yellow plastic thingie, donut shaped, that the LEDs sit upon.  UV light makes this yellow plastic donut glow, and it glows bright white.I was one of those guys who liked soft-pink incandescents - the very mildly tinted GE brand - to illuminate his room, and I'm totally left behind by the low-energy revolution.  Billionaires need fossil fuels for their wars; they can't afford to leave any drop of oil behind for their serfs.  So by their imperious mandate, I am left with harshly lit rooms at home and at work.I was hoping that a glowing yellow plastic donut might provide a softer light.  I put this into an upright torchiere with a plastic translucent shade, and there it has remained.  I have a normal white incandescent, same lux, on the opposite side of the sofa and compared to that soft orange wash this throws a harsh blue light.  But there is no flicker, no green tone, and the tone is warmer than the average 'warm white led'; so it's been the best I could find.I guess I got lucky; other had noisy bulbs, or early failure.  I am pretty sure I am coming up on 10000 hours on this bulb and I have never had any such issues.  There is a slight delay, this bulb takes about 1/5 sec. to power-up.  And, though it is dimmable, the torchiere I have it in has a 3 way rotary switch.  The bulb does *not* work with the three-way switch; it turns 'off' in the 'off' and '50W' setting, turns 'on' in the 100W and 150W settings.  So there is an extra click to turn the bulb on.  I should probably switch it over to the better torchiere with a potentiometer and a tan cloth shade over on the other side of the couch, see how that works out for me.EDIT:  So yeah, I tried this bulb on a torchiere with a continuous dimmer knob instead of an on-off switch.  For a moment I thought a swarm of bees had landed in my lamp - it was that loud.  Put it back over to the on-off lamp - no buzzing at all.  So if you dim this 'dimmable' bulb, get ready for a lot of noise!

This very light oil melts in the hand, has a very light and pleasant coconut odor, and skin just soaks it up, leaving very little mess.  It's pleasantly slick, not sticky, and it doesn't stain cloth, plastic, wood or stone surfaces.  It's particularly nice to use while sunbathing.  I've used most of it up already!

Perfectly serviceable cable.  I am using it to get photos off a digital camera.  It has a regular USB jack on one side and a typical Micro USB jack on the other.  Works fine.  True 3 FT length.  Color is brighter than in the photo - it's a really bright vibrant purple, looks like a child's toy.

Battery died after 6 weeks.I will probably at some point be able to get a replacement under warranty, but it took an hour to find the toll-free number to call (it's 1-800-682-7664), and I chose a wrong time to call that number, and I know what this means; more and more hours trying to have a working ultrasonic toothbrush, when the current state of affairs is that I'm out six bills and have no working toothbrush.Since what I wanted was a working toothbrush, not a non-working toothbrush and an obligation to fight repeatedly with customer service specialists on the phone for a few hours, I regret the purchase.  I will update this review with news on how the fight went, but it'd take an act of FedEx to make me change the star count.The toothbrush is almost as good at cleaning my teeth as the 8 year old Sonicare Elite - still working, by the way - that it replaced; and it's easier to keep clean owing to the sealed design.  If it actually worked it'd be somewhere between 3 and 4 stars.EDIT:  Once I finally got through, during working hours, it took 32 minutes to get the guy on the other end to agree that the battery was defective.  To his credit he promptly shipped a replacement battery, which has been working fine for a month; they made me ship the old one back, on my own dime, which is against the law where I live, but whatever.  Add a Hamilton to whatever you thought this thing cost.It works fine.  I usually spend about half as long as the device thinks I should, twice a day; and I floss once a day.  The compact DiamondClean bristle tip I chose works very well, cleans everything, even the little spaces between the gum and tooth junction; when I had to go on a trip for a few days and bring a normal toothbrush because this one was out of commission, I missed having clean teeth.I still have all the teeth I was born with, intact; and I plan on maintaining that state of affairs for another 40 years.  This device makes it much easier to carry out my plan.

You always see palm trees in the desert and other dry areas.  So when I bought a home with a couple queen palms out front it didn't occur to me that they need special treatment.  But they do; they need lots of water and they prefer special food.  This formula greened up my palms - no, that brownish-yellow color isn't necessary, they can turn bright green, has to do with potassium and trace minerals - and, along with copious watering, got them to grow a foot taller just in one summer.  I use it every 8 weeks along with a regular saturation-watering schedule and I couldn't be happier.I even sent this jug to my mom.  It pops open and the top has a special scattering system so she doesn't have to bend over to scatter the granules; she is older and has some joint troubles and I didn't want her to have to bend over or crawl around!  She was very pleased with that.PRO TIP:  If you like the shake and feed jug as much as I do: When it comes time to refill, save the empty jug and buy the 8 lb refill of granules.  Pour them into the old jug.  As of August 2015, you save 30% that way.

I bought this to replace an old one which had yellowed and gone opaque.  It is good to know, maybe, that this sink saddle is slightly fluorescent; in daylight there is a definite blue glow to it, and it will not match anything white or clear that is in your kitchen, unless you are wearing a highly fluorescent diamond ring - it's that same color.  At night this goes away.  No big deal but sort of weird.It's sturdy, has square edges that hold their shape.
