You can rest a very heavy pot on it no problem; it totally protects the underlying sink divider, which in my kitchen is porcelain and needs the protection.  Yet the flower pattern has enough holes in it that water evaporates away before annoying slimes and molds can accumulate there.  My old sink saddle would melt if anything hot touched it, even for a moment by accident; I've had a few touches with hot pans and rotisseries on this one and it failed to melt, though I'm sure it's not intended for hi-temp use.I guess I'll be buying another one in a few years.  If I did, I'd be delighted if this one were still available; I'd buy it again.

This is the best kitchen faucet available on the market today.  Amazon often has open-box returns and I took advantage of that to purchase one that was in new condition, had never even been unpacked but the seal on the box was open.  You can get a significant discount that way so I do recommend checking the Warehouse Deals on this product.Ladylux 3 is a Grohe model, it means you get the one-handle design that controls both flow rate and temperature.  The moving parts are ceramic and are warranted for a lifetime of use. During installation, the handle can be positioned to the right, left or center in case you wish to accommodate lefties or little ones in your house; but it's easy to use in any position.  (I find that, though I have the faucet head installed on my right side, I am often holding something, like a heavy pot, with my right hand when I turn it on, and my left hand operates it naturally without any trouble.) The spray head easily detaches and if installed properly has a nice spring action that is light but easily auto-retracts.I bought this faucet in RealSteel, which is solid steel construction.  If you choose to verify this with a magnet, as I did, here are two things to know:  1)  Steel becomes less magnetic where it is bent.  The graceful bend at the top of this faucet is one such place.  2)  A metal magnet, or indeed anything harder than steel, will scratch the beautiful brushed-steel finish of this faucet.  Use a tissue or a thin cloth.  I have, however, been using this faucet for a month and nothing else has scratched it; I think it's safe to say that this faucet will be the hardest thing in most kitchens.  (My chromium-molybdenum-vanadium steel Global chef's knives, for instance, won't scratch it; it would scratch them if I scrubbed them against it, which I do not.)I bought this because I had just switched to soft water; hard water had pretty much spoiled my previous faucet, a Grohe white plastic number that is no longer made.  (The soft rubbery water outlet does make it pretty easy to get rid of limescale, but it'll build up eventually.)  A plumber took about an hour to take out the old one and put in the new; I did request that he remove the flow restrictors and given other reviews I am pleased I did, the flow of this faucet is not particularly powerful.  That's nice because it doesn't splash out of the sink even in the shallow side (8") of my double sink.  Yet when the spray button is pressed the flow is strong enough to wash off baked-on food.  It's just right.The faucet is 15.25 inches high from my granite countertop vertically to the highest part of the arch.  The water impacts in a radius 8.5 inches from the center of its mounting hole when the spray head is pointing down.  You can make the spray head point out instead of down by rotating it 180 degrees; the water impact point stays in my 31 x 20" sink when this is done, though I have still not found any reason why this would be useful.  The width from the center of the mounting hole to the widest point of the faucet lever is 4.5 inches.  I rounded all these measurements up to the nearest quarter-inch.The finish, RealSteel, is gorgeous.  It is simply solid brushed steel, grey with a matte shine and just the tiniest hint of blue, as steel does have.  (This faucet is not blue; I am talking about a tiny hint of color, usual for steel, that, at the age of 42, as a guy who loves colors and material science, I can barely see any more with my old eyes.  My iPhone 6 camera can see it!)  Grohe makes this faucet in three finishes.  Mine is RealSteel, which as far as I can tell is solid steel through-and-through with just a wire-brushed finish on it.  The others are Starlight Chrome and Brushed Nickel, which I only know from photos.  Both of those are brass with a coating of either chrome or nickel.  As far as I can tell these are some of the highest-quality coatings on the market and are warrantied to match; I like the RealSteel and expect it to last decades.The upgoing and arch parts of the faucet are very thick steel pipe stock; the spray head and spray button are a much thinner steel, so lightweight I initially thought they might be plastic.  They're not; they're very strong, tough steel.  The rotating part of the faucet I think might actually be plastic; it's replaceable and has a little rubbery seal where it mates to the stem of the faucet.  The lever feels substantial, moves smoothly, stays put.It's surprising how much a person uses their kitchen faucet.  If you're like me and like to have the very best, stop looking - this is your faucet.  And if you're upgrading, don't forget a matching dishwasher vent cover - I got this one: KOHLER K-9111-VS Air Gap Cover with Collar, Vibrant Stainless - and I found it to be an excellent finish-match.
Perfect fit for the oil filter housing cap on my BMW N54 engine (2008 3-series.)  Snaps right onto the square head of my ratchet wrench handle.  Made of coated or painted metal, seems pretty sturdy.

I've been using this for years.  It used to be colored yellow and come in a clear bottle.  It's not something you'd want to eat - it's a bunch of substituted quat-ammonium surfactants - but it's safe for food prep surfaces, not poisonous, and it wipes off clean without residue.  Rinse and wipe down the surfaces after use and you're good to go.It's particularly good at getting baked-on oils off of appliance surfaces like oven or dishwasher doors; it is excellent at cleaning and re-whitening the matte plastic door of my fridge, where hand grime accumulates; and while I don't really like using it on my granite countertop, porcelain sink or my wood cabinets, it doesn't harm those if overspray gets on those surfaces.A bonus: I'm pretty touchy about foul scents and perfumes added to a lot of products.  This cleaner has a very mild lemony scent that doesn't even cover up the smell of the active ingredient - and which doesn't trigger my migraines.  So that's a major plus.When this bottle is empty I'll be buying another.  Keep it out of reach of young hands - and always have a bottle around!

This little quad is not the cheap junk that was flooding the market a few years ago.  It's sturdy, well built and easy to get up and flying for this beginner.  Comes with everything you need - a two-handed remote, a battery that charges via USB (you have to provide a powered USB port), and a little card for video and still pics.  The pics were a little tricky to start taking but once I got the hang of it they were surprisingly high quality.The Kodo flies for about 6 minutes on a charge, less if you're recording video.  Crashes are a part of RC flight but if you install the included prop guards like I did, it's pretty hard to damage the little beast - haven't managed to do so yet.  (That install requires a bit of fine dexterity and a bit of strength - it's a press fit, props have to come off, then you place flexible plastic hub around a metal axle; it's not a task for little hands.)The Kodo's amazingly fun and a tiny little marvel of technology and design.  I bet it ends up in a lot of Christmas stockings!

An excellent car shampoo.  I used it with a foam gun.  It's better at removing stuck-on insects than the California Gold that's my go-to shampoo.  Gentle on the hands and smells nice.  Easy pouring from the bottle, too, unlike some shampoos that are almost a guaranteed spill.

This is a great Armor-All type product that works on both vinyl and rubber.  It is low shine and is equally as good at cleaning interior vinyl as it is at protecting tires.  I found it good for restoring new life to the black vinyl inside my convertible, which gets dusty and beat up.

Unpacking this valet stand, my heart sank as 1,000,000 fragments of cheap styrofoam flew everywhere.  You already know what you're in for, don't you?You'll need 2 philips head screwdrivers, a large and a small, to assemble this valet stand - if you buy it, which I don't recommend."Wood" is very cheap, very thin mahogany veneer - I think - over MDF.  As I pulled out the hanger part, I thought there was some white paint on its edge, so I went to scrape it away with my fingernail.  The white area expanded instead; apparently I was scratching off finish, which had started when the wood rubbed against styrofoam in the package.  What's white about wood, I'm not sure; if you thought you were buying a wooden product, you're mistaken.  I banged the piece against a white molding carrying it into my bedroom; didn't dent, it was just a touch, but it left a big purple streak like a crayon.  I rubbed that out with a Magic Eraser, so you may want one of those if you're buying this too.  (And def have a vacuum nearby; there'll be a little pile of sawdust and styrofoam bits.)The parts list wasn't complete; there were two tiny little wood screws that weren't on it.  Don't mistake them for the single, short metal screw (parts list calls it a wood screw), which is used in step 1.  If you use a long metal screw (called a wood screw on the parts list) instead of the short metal screw, you'll break the veneer over the little valet tray from below.The instructions are poor; they instructed me to leave out a wooden peg, and at the end I realized I'd just made a mistake.  They also don't tell you what to do with the tiny wood screws; they're to hold the hanger onto the frame, although one of the holes for them wasn't drilled, just touched with a drill to break the finish.The piece is small and rests on 6, not 4, rubberized feet; it'll never sit level on any surface.  It's about 15 inches wide - it looks a lot wider - and tall enough that a light touch is enough to knock it over.  Did I mention it marks purple whatever it lightly touches?  So that's great.  I'm kind of afraid to put nice clothes onto it, and I don't really need this kind of stand for play clothes.I went back and looked at what I paid for this, thinking, heck, what do you expect for an Andrew Jackson, from China these days.  But China is actually putting out some top quality stuff.  (This ain't it.)  And this thing cost an army of Jacksons; after tax those Jacksons were knocking on Mr Franklin's door.  That's ridiculous.I think this is probably going to collect dust for a few weeks before I throw it out.  And that's the kind of thing I'd like to know about something before I bought it.  So I hope you found this review helpful.

To its credit, this thing has lasted 8 years.  But it's leaked for most of that time, right at the inlet/bib where the connector hose attaches, and it gets worse and worse every week.  Oh, did I mention the connector hose?  I'm on my third - doesn't last, kinks really easily.But the nice, hand-towable design?  I'm normal height, normal arm and leg length; it bangs against my leg under tow, and bounces everywhere, because it's not designed right for towing.  (It's not designed right for staying in place, either; a pull on the hose is just as likely to tip the whole thing over as it is to unwind more hose!)Unlike other reviewers, I still have smooth, excellent crank rewinding of a heavy 5'8" hose after 8 years.  But like the other reviewers, thinking about this hose bib makes me positively cranky!One star!

I've been using D'addarios in this gauge for many years on a Fender P-bass.  Great feel, don't chew my fingers up, they last a long time without corroding or getting muddy, and they don't break.  I like the slightly heavier bottom for the thump that gets the rhythm going and then if I am doing a melodic line I can actually do a couple runs on the G string.Recommended, no reservations.

If you have a pastry bag and like piping decorative icing, these will increase your possibilities.  I use them with typical buttercream frosting - not the best at holding its shape but it tastes good.  Works fine.  You need to buy some bags with them - you'll find that you're doing more piping because it's fun and easy.  Cleanup is a breeze too, just throw these in the dishwasher silverware bucket, or run 'em under hot water - they're stainless, no muss no fuss.

Hostess got a lot of free publicity when it declared bankruptcy and voided its obligations to pay its retired employees pensions' and healthcare obligations.  Of course the 'assets' - the factory and recipes - were quickly sold to venture capital; and employees who didn't care to be out of work along with their suddenly-evaporated non-pensions were rehired, so pretty much business as usual in the USA.This free publicity reminded me of Hostess Cup Cakes, my favorite in the 80's.  They used to come in packs of 2, so when I saw that this was a box of 8, I thought it was a box of 8 packs of two.  Nope, it's a box of 8 single cupcakes, each one individually wrapped.They're also about half the size they were in the 80s - if that - and they are not packaged in plastic cups any more, just sitting on a cardstock board, so they are sort of squashy and get molded roughly into a cube shape on their journey to your house.They tasted just like I remember 'em; moist cake, rich chocolate flavor, creamy icing, and of course that white foam, reminiscent of Chantilly cream, in the middle.  They arrived a few days before their sell-by date and freshness was not in question; they tasted fine.I am not sure I am really on board with a buck fifty apiece for such tiny morsels - I can get larger, fresher, less technologically engineered cupcakes at that price at the local bakery - but otherwise, these cakes deliver as expected.

Bottom line, moved to the top for clarity:  a designed-infused coffeemaker that is beautifully designed and makes lukewarm coffee.Bodum is a company famous for design, and particularly design parsimony.  Their vacuum powered coffee makers - one piece of glass, a handle, boiling water, coffee, no moving parts - are famous as design tour de forces and are still preferred by a lot of coffee snobs today.  But this is their take on a 10-cup drip coffee pot, with some innovative design features.I get why design aficionados might want this coffee pot.  Pee-Wee Herman would love it - it's his favorite color, a sort of slightly pinkish bright red - and it won't match any other red appliances you have in your kitchen.  Kids would love it too because you can see all stages of the brewing process.  Heck, I like that too.It's lightweight, but covered in no-slip nubbles so you won't drop it - and it's transparent in the back, so you can see that the interior is held to the same design standards as the outside.  Drip coffeemakers are simple - steam water with electric heat, use steam pressure to pump water over grounds - and you get a good look at this process with the Bodum.This shipped in a cardboard box.  Inside the cardboard box there is another cardboard box.  Inside this cardboard box there is another cardboard box, this one with glossy printing on it; and a two page too-long-didn't-read summary of the neat features of the coffeemaker.  (For instance, the steam tube is tempered glass so no plastic odor gets in the water.)  Inside the third cardboard box, there is a bunch of cardboard eggcrate material; a thick instruction book which I didn't touch; and the coffeemaker itself, each part wrapped in styrofoam and bubblewrap.  If this sounds like it was overpacked to you, it was, which is odd for a coffeepot trying to position itself as environmental.It's easy to set up and use.  The grounds holder is made of a very, very fine herringbone titanium weave.  It is incredibly fine mesh.  If I liked metal mesh groundsholders, which I do not, this would be the best one I had ever seen.  Only the very finest bits of grind get through into the coffee; which in my opinion is only somewhat inferior to no grounds getting in the coffee at all.  However, the book chastises paper filter users for 'loss of aroma', so I didn't use any paper in my trials.Ergonomically this thing is great.  The filter holder has a nice rubbery handle about the size and color of a clown nose; makes it easy to take it out, empty it, clean it.  Cleaning the metal mesh filter will spray grounds all over your white porcelain sink, of course, another reason I prefer paper, as after a few months of this your porcelain is now brown.  I like the clear water reservoir; it's easy to remove and replace, easy to fill, and gradated in every sort of volume measurement system known to Man - cups, SI units, Imperial units.The carafe is almost worth the price of admission.  It's beautiful red ABS plastic, double-walled (so they say) steel interior, has a little thumb-lock so it won't pour until you want it to, cuts off the flow immediately when you let go of the trigger, and doesn't drip.  It also has a spring-loaded top so you can steal the first cup brewed without spills before brewing is done, if you want; all the caffeine comes out in the first 15 seconds of brewing so you can really shaft your co-workers or family members if you choose to use this feature.  I really like this carafe.  I don't get why the bottom of it unscrews; there's a glob of adhesive under there and when I saw that I regretted unscrewing it.The silicone showerhead is supposed to catch all chalk deposits and evenly distribute water over the grounds.  It definitely showers the grounds evenly.  Extraction and flavor was perfect - they really got that right.  I didn't use this long enough for chalk to build up; I can see that the silicone rubber (polysiloxanes) is easy to remove and would be easy to clean and replace.  It amuses me that there is plastic in the steam path, right after the tempered glass pipe that is advertised as being plastic-free, and right before the silicone showerhead.  All the plastic appears to me to be ABS, which is totally nonreactive at coffeemaker temperatures, so it's fine with me, but for the price of this coffeemaker they ought to hire someone to verify the marketing claims.I don't agree that this looks or feels cheap.  It looks goofy because it is explicitly designed and has a bunch of built-in design cues.  There is a difference.There are two things wrong with this coffeemaker, and one is a real deal-breaker.  There is no carafe warmer.  The coffee comes out of the filter holder into the carafe, and it will never gain warmth again.  It hits the cold carafe, and loses heat as it warms up the carafe.  You then pour coffee into your cup, and it loses heat there too.  By the time the coffee hits my lips it is barely, barely hot enough to drink, and 30 seconds later as it loses heat to the cup and the air, it is lukewarm.  I experimented, and found that this is less of a problem if you brew 10 cups at a time, but I don't; I usually brew 4.  It is also less of a problem if you heat your cup, either by microwaving a cup of water or running hot water into the cup - but who wants to do that?I don't want lukewarm coffee, ever, and so this was frustrating.  The carafe is great - it holds the coffee at temperature perfectly for hours - but that temperature is not hot enough.The other problem is that this coffeemaker is huge.  I have a pretty big kitchen, but counter space is always at a premium; and coffeemakers require a lot of space because you need somewhere to put the beans, grinder, cup when you're pouring, etc.  This thing takes up like 3 times the space of my Zojirushi Zutto and 4 times the space of my little Braun cheapie.So yeah, at this price it's good but not great, and I think that people who love (hot) coffee more than they love showing off their innovative Euro Design collection would be advised to look elsewhere.

Not a soap connoisseur here. Just a guy who has some skin trouble, is tired of every synthetic thing under the sun, wanted to try something tried and true.This soap smells great, feels great, lathers well, and the giant block lasts a long time. It is a touch drying, but despite that my skin loves it. I was not expecting this soap to be anywhere near as good as it is. Ingredients are 72% olive oil and some coconut oil, saponified with vegetable-ash lye; sea salt; and water. I don't know why it smells so good - none of the things I mentioned seem like they ought to have this light, soapy fragrance - but it really does.I will buy another block in a few months, when this one is finally done.EDIT: I am updating this review to reflect my increasing pleasure and joy in using this soap. I already gave the product 5 stars; I wish I could give it 6. I had originally just been using it as a kitchen hand soap, but I took it into the shower a few days ago, though I worried it might dry my skin out. Nope - it works perfectly well as a body soap, conditioner, and shampoo. It is gentle on all the exposed mucous membranes of the body - it does sting if you get it in your eyes. However, it rinses off easily and quickly and leaves hair and skin supple and soft, not stripped of natural oils. I have occasionally used olive oil as a skin moisturizer and this soap leaves my skin feeling the same way.Another reviewer endorsed this soap because she didn't want to be applying "someone's chemistry experiment" to her skin. I have come along to feeling the same way. I didn't even know about this soap; I wouldn't know about it, except that I visited central Spain a few months ago, and that area is famous for Castile soap, which as a physician, I know is one of the few things safe for use as an enema. So I was interested in learning about Castile soap, and that Wikipedia article led me to Marseille soap, and that led me here.You ever get the feeling that we're off track as a civilization, inventing ever newer and fancier ways to screw ourselves up, when the old tried and true standbys languish, available but abandoned on the march to ever more relentless consumer capitalism? No? OK, just me then. Get some of this soap anyway. It's totally excellent.EDIT 2:  I've learned that Marseille soap made by Marius Fabre comes in two recipes.  One is 72% olive oil, like this one; a light green color; beautiful fragrance; and says "72% Extra Pur" stamped into the block of soap.  The other kind has palm oil (sodium palmate is the ingredient on the label), does not say 72% extra pur, is tan colored, and smells different, not as nice.  The palm oil soap is also more drying on the skin and I can't use it - Fabre themselves recommend it as a laundry soap.  As far as I can tell, in France the palm oil stuff is cheaper.I've gotten the palm oil soap at least once when what I ordered was the olive oil soap; so, buyer beware!

I am a Vine guy, but I bought this set of pans with my own money.  I like the Emeril name and I already had an Emeril 'chef's pan' that I bought at Bed, Bath and Beyond a few years ago; I've always enjoyed using that pan, which is vaguely wok-like, and I thought I'd see if I liked this set as much.  I love to cook and have been doing so regularly for 20 years; I've used cast iron, QVC stainless steel, 80's style Corning Visions glass cookware, 60's style Club brand pure thick aluminum pots, crummy aluminum lightweight backcountry camping cookware, Le Creuset and Staub enamelware, cheap Teflon nonstick, middle-of-the-road nonstick, and the very best Anolon Advanced nonstick.  I've fondled a lot of All-Clad - never cooked with any - and  I've even used pure bright-copper pots and skillets, though goodness knows a set costs more than a car these days.I like to write a long review and I've been using these pans exclusively for about 2 months as I thought about what folks might want to know about this set.  I like this set pretty well for what it's good at; I feel the same way about a lot of different kinds of cookware and so I will talk about appearance, quality, ease of use/ergonomics, cooking performance, cleanup, and how different parts of the set stack up to other things I like to use.First off: appearance.  The first week out of the box I had every piece out on my rangetop and counter.  It's gorgeous.  This is good chrome steel with a nice mirror finish on the outside and a nice satin finish on the inside.  I expect it to develop a nice patina - indeed some of the pans are already headed that way - and if you like a nice looking set of cookware you won't go wrong here.  The lids are glass - I like to see through my lids, that's just me - and the long handles are shiny and nicely bulbous, no edges.  (The small handles that are made of bent bar stock are dull-finished and have edges, which makes them not very nice to hold while they are hot, one of many ways this set falls short of the All-Clad name it bears.)  Handles are riveted in with small rivets but the joints are solid enough that they conduct heat readily.The stockpot is smaller than I thought it'd be from the Amazon photo.  It's 10 quarts.  Works great - eating chicken soup from it today - but not big enough to, say, brew the wort for a 5 gallon batch of beer.  I complained to my mother about this, which was a mistake, maybe, because she went into her garage and got me a 14 quart Anolon clad steel stockpot she has had stored away for 20 years, still in the original box.  Mom's awesome.  She was once a professional chef and probably has enough cookware in the garage to stock 10 homes; most of the stuff I've cooked on was hers.Quality:  No aluminum is visible.  The sides of these pots, skillets and pans are very thin walled, maybe 2 mm, where an All-clad pot is closer to 6mm.  The bases of these pots are thicker, maybe 4 mm.  The two pieces of steel make a 'sandwich' where the inside third layer is aluminum - at least I assume so.  They certainly spread and conduct heat lightning quick, much faster than steel usually would.  These are the lightest-weight (apart the camping gear) and quickest and most evenly heating pans I've ever used, more on that later.  I feel like they're light enough that I might dent them with a hammer, or if I ran my kitchen like one of Emeril's rowdy restaurant kitchens, but I can't see that happening in my quiet little house.The volume gradations on the inside of the pots is a neat idea and actually was a motivator for me to get these pots.  I am sorry to report they are printed on, the same way Henckels and Global knives print on their knife blades; I expect they'll last a year, no longer.  I was hoping - kind of thought - they would be stamped in and actually permanent.  Nope.Ease of use: there is this new techology that's available, lots of reviewers haven't heard of it yet.  It's called potholders.  You're going to need a few to use these pots - no option - because there has been no effort made to stop any handle from getting hot.  The handles get very hot.  They will burn you badly if you do not use a potholder.  You must have a potholder.  Some of the handles get as hot as the cooking surface, which I regard as questionable design.  I love that the pots are light, which makes them much less likely to slip out of my glove / potholder; I can swish or flip food with a flick of my wrist, like you see big thick-armed Mario Batali types do on Iron Chef.  I can't do that with cast iron, though I'm pretty sure Mario has no problem with it.  (I've been to 3 of Emeril's restaurants, one with an open kitchen; looks to me like all his chefs use cast iron pans and steel pots, not these.)  I like the way the long handles fit my hand, which is 7.5 size; I do not like the lid handles or the stockpot handles, they feel sharp-edged - not knife-sharp, but unpleasant to bear weight on the fingers - and I feel like my fingers are a little too fat for the narrow space those handles leave for them.  Since I'm usually using a potholder it's not a real problem.Cooking performance:  For simmering and medium temperature saucing and soupmaking, these are ideal.  Heat transfer is swift, immediate, and super efficient - these pots probably save natural gas, all the heat goes to the food; and they're light enough to easily move around the kitchen with no fear of droppy/burny accidents.  (Cork mats, friend - put one everywhere a pot might want to be.)  However, these are the easiest tasks and most pots perform well at them.  These pots clean up OK afterwards, much better than copper or cast iron, nowhere near as easily as nonstick (although I hate simmering things in plastic, it just doesn't sit well with me.)Now let's talk about higher heat.  Say, like sauteing, or stir fry, or even a sear.  These pans *transfer* heat super evenly and super efficiently.  But they are light and have no way to *retain* heat.  They are a poor *reservoir* of heat energy.  What that means is they heat up lightning quick - often way, way hotter than you wanted them to; and then when you put the food in, or your deglaze, they suddenly drop 300-500 degrees and suddenly now you're not sauteing or deglazing, even though just 3 seconds ago your pot was hot enough to melt Tina Turner's vinyl miniskirt.  Sitting there trying to re-warm a pot full of soggy pork bits and boozy cognac is a sorry excuse for a deglaze and it never really tasted quite right yet; I don't think i'm going to be able to get it right.  The other problem, though, is that when you do get the pan that hot - especially if you're trying to, say, sear a hangar steak or something - your steel's not stainless any more.  The first time I used a sauteed-kale recipe that I'd been doing in a thicker clad stainless pan for years - lightly brown diced garlic in olive oil; add chopped kale and a touch of salt and red pepper; saute lightly 2 minutes, then wilt, covered, for 5 minutes more - the pan discolored as soon as the kale hit it; and then the kale wouldn't saute; I had to heat it up another minute to get it warm again.  Then when I covered it it heated up to insane temperatures on the lowest heat my range would do.  It ended up soggier than usual and the pan surface was permanently stained - even after an SOS pad.  (I don't like using Barkeeper's Friend or SOS, but you'll need something like them if you don't want the skillet pans getting downright ugly inside.)What about very low heat, like omelet?  Forget about it; you simply cannot get precise enough due to the high temp fluctuations of these pans.  Your omelet will be scorched and runny.  (The best omelet pans I've found are nonstick, the only thing I like using nonstick for; the thicker the base, and the lower the heat, the better.)  You could maybe scramble an egg tough without burning it in these pans, but forget about over easy.  (The whole world already has forgotten over easy, the most challenging egg; I haven't gotten real over easy in a diner for more than a decade.  So I *have* to be able to make it myself.)Cleanup:  These are totally OK in the dishwasher, although if you let the mirror surface rub, it'll scratch and develop patina.  I use the dishwasher and I am hoping eventually to acquire a good old 18/10 style sweet glowy patina, but the inside of these pans is starting to show permanent black and brown stains, like the crappy 18/0 Oneida flatware I bought last year thinking it was the same as my old 18/8 flatware.  (It wasn't; it looks worse now than the 15 year old stuff it was supposed to replace.)This set is better to clean than cast iron by a long shot, better than anodized - much tougher; simply, however, not in the same league as even cheap nonstick.  Food will stick and stains may need abrasive scrub and some stains won't scrub out.  It used to be that use of metal utensils distinguished steel as superior to nonstick in cooking or cleaning; nowadays the best nonstick can take a fork poke without scratching, so steel lost that advantage.Summary: I honestly think this set is designed to look like All-clad, but it costs less than a single piece of All-Clad cookware would.  The pots are fine; it might make sense to buy this set just for them and then get one decent All-Clad skillet for higher-temperature work.  Another option, which I didn't realize until after I bought, is that the Emeril chef pan I liked, the one with a 5mm thick chunk of copper clad into the base, is a Bed, Bath and Beyond exclusive.  That pan *does* retain heat in its base and doesn't cause the problem I talked about above.  But you can't buy those pans anywhere but BBBY - believe me, I looked; I'd forgotten that I got that pan at BBBY many years ago.  Lately I learned they still carry that Emeril line; and that line's set, while I think with one fewer pot and one fewer lid, is price-competitive with this set.  I might have bought that set instead if I'd realized that it was still being made.  However for value, looks, and light weight I don't think this set can be beat!

The time: the future, somewhen or other.  The place: A faraway planet, Iaxo, that could have been a paradise, but now it's a battleground.The tech: WW1, plus a bunch of far-future FTL stuff that was only used to drop the 'least necessary force' - aforesaid WW1 technology, and a cast of about 30 - planetside.The setting:  War.If you play video games, you know there's a debate.  War never changes.  Or has it changed?Sheehan's war is fought on behalf of corporations by private military contractors, and it is an illegal war; but we learn, from the mouth of one of his tough old soldiers, that war is fought, always, "in the mud."  And that's where we start - in the middle of things - and, ultimately, that's where it ends.A riveting read - I couldn't put it down, a real page turner - and I'll be awaiting his next novel eagerly.  If you liked Starship Troopers, A Fire Upon the Deep, The Mote in God's Eye, Dune, or the Lensmen series, I'll put my money down that you'll like "A Private Little War" as well.

This is a Krups combination espresso and regular coffee maker.I wouldn't recommend anyone buy it, but I wrote most of the review before I tried to pull a shot of espresso, so read on if you want the full review.The espresso pot holds two long shots.  The coffee pot is what is called a 10-cup and takes a #4 cone filter (book says #3, but Amazon doesn't sell unbleached #3's, only 2's and 4's; I actually used #2s for this review); no filter is included.  There is a steam wand for frothing milk, but no milk pitcher is included (a steel pitcher is recommended to get the best froth.)  This machine has no grinder and includes a clock and a program setting which will activate the coffee-side of the machine once at a specified time not more than 24 hours in the future.  There is no cup warmer and a measuring scoop with a flattened bottom does double duty as a tamper, though you are told not to tamp grounds tight.I am comparing it to my current setup, which is a very basic Braun 4-cup coffee maker and a 1988 Krups Espresso Novo.  Whole beans, highest quality and drenched in oils; and RO water are used; I grind at brew time with Braun blade and La Pavoni burr grinders.  I probably drank 5 times my usual daily intake while writing this review, so if I go overboard, please blame the caffeine.Unboxing was easy, not too much waste, and it would be easy to repack the unit.  On inspection, it's a handsome piece of equipment, all black plastic, except the drip plate under the espresso portafilter, which is gray plastic.  I liked the manual cord winder beneath the unit so you don't have extra cord all over your counter.  Water is loaded into the espresso boiler from the top; inspection reveals some sharp edges in the cast aluminum boiler.  The portafilter is narrower and deeper than usual, suggesting to me that pressures and extractions might be on the dicey side.  The steam wand swings out to the user's left, requiring left-handed frothing and at least a good 6-8 inches of free space on the left of the unit.On the coffee side, the filter holder swings out, requiring about 6-8 inches free space on the right of the unit.  The filter holder is ridged black plastic, nothing unusual here.  The carafe is glass and a very odd shape: its fat base narrows down considerably to fit onto the 4-inch-wide heating element.  (My Braun and Zojirushi 4-cups each have a 5-inch-wide element; the Krups carafe is 6 inches wide just above this weird base.)Java, first cup:  the coffee brewed quickly, quietly and, sadly, with little aroma.  I had music playing and my usual sonic cue that the coffee was done was not audible.  A red light indicating brewing comes on, then goes off; a green light comes on indicating ready; I am 5'10" and had to back 8 feet off to be able to see either of these lights in my bright kitchen because they are recessed too far into the panel.  About 25% of the water was lost in the brewing process, same as my little cheapie.  The carafe poured easily and did not spill everywhere when I wanted to pour swiftly, a major problem with some carafes.  Flavor was bright, bitter and clear and the coffee was much hotter than I am used to: altogether a superior extraction.  I like to use coffee machines for years and hand-clean them; this was, of course, missing that flavor, but the oily bitterness of a nice complete extraction more than made up for it.  Cleanup was swift and easy.Espresso:  This thing doesn't make espresso.  I compared it side by side, identical conditions, to my 25 year old Krups Espresso Novo.  Now a purist would scoff at that machine, but after looking at the price tags on La Pavoni Europiccolas for the last decade, I've never managed to pull the trigger and buy one, so I think it'll probably be my home-espresso standard for the immediate future.  My standards are at least 8mm of crema; a nutty, buttery, just-baked-bread aroma, sweet caramel flavor notes, and a super oily texture on a ristretto; tongue-burning hotness in a prewarmed demi-tasse; total destruction of that fishy smell that is common and appropriate to true freshly-roasted full-city beans; and no burnt/sour/bitter after-coat on the tongue. I shot one just before trying the machine under review and it was as usual - better than usual, actually, because I bought some really nice beans for this review.First I tried filling up the boiler on this machine.  (Meanwhile I set down the filled portafilter, which promptly tipped over and spilled.)  I pressed the button, thinking it would heat and build up a head of steam - my old machine took 124 seconds to be ready.  This machine did nothing for 15 minutes.  I then read the manual and found out that you have to pre-load the boiler with the exact amount of water you want in the carafe, and then just let it go through at its own pace.  Since the options are two demi-tasses and four demi-tasses, you can't shoot straight into your prewarmed cup - you must use the carafe.Already I was skeptical - espresso is made by swiftly forcing a cylinder of overpressure steam through a tamped grounds cake with no headspace - but I did what the manual suggested.  In about 2 minutes I had a carafe full to the '2' mark.  There were 2 mm of listless crema which did not come through in the pour from the carafe into my demi-tasse.  The coffee was about 110 degrees at that point.  The taste was ashes, bitter cinchona bark, fresh-beans fishiness, and a tongue-coating burnt bitterness that lingered foully.  The difference between this and my old machine was night and day and I spat this machine's product into the sink.Inspection of the portafilter was revealing.  Larger bits of grind had clearly FLOATED in the headspace.  There was no disturbance of the surface of the cake by jets of steam, something I like to look for in an espresso maker.  The cake was tamped tight, suggesting that some overpressure had taken place, and when I knocked it in the trash it came out in one piece.  The plastic filter-lock also popped off its hinges, though, so the filter and filter lock also fell into the trash, and the side of my index finger that was holding the filter lock on, slid up the handle to the metal filter holder and got burned - second degree, too, nice blister.  (I swear that's not why I'm giving this machine 1 star, though - could've happened to anyone on any machine on any given day.)After this, I actually took the time to fire up the steam wand.  Surprisingly, perhaps, it was almost as good as the old machine.  The wand wouldn't reach the bottom of my standard issue Krups 20 oz. steel pitcher.  Really getting stiff foam with a home machine like this takes some practice - it's nothing like using a commercial 6 atm machine - and this was complicated by the fact that my practice has all been done using my dominant right hand.  I used my right hand for this, too, but it was the wrong side of the machine - lefties should love this wand - and it was awkward.  Foam was decent, not super, certainly didn't form peaks or serve as a surface for mocha art.  There was also an extra step; after I was done foaming, I shut the steam off and then the manual instructs me that I have to let all the steam out into a vessel of cold water.  That took like another 30 seconds.Seriously, Krups?  I don't shoot espresso into a carafe.  The left side of this machine is a small drip coffeemaker.  Don't try to sell it to me as an espresso machine.  As part of this review I went to BB&B (needed a steel pitcher, couldn't find mine) and noticed a few Breville machines - one with a built in grinder - and actually one Krups machine as well - that look like they'd build up 15 bar and do it more or less right.  All of these were metal, had super thick groupheads and portafilters - yeah, I am the kind of guy who uses the word grouphead, live with it - and were priced about three times as much as this model.Summary:  Right side works just as well as a lot of $30 coffee makers with clock on the market - and better than some, though I prefer my Zojirushi Zutto.  Left side is worthless unless you want to make hot chocolate.  Therefore, one star.  Consider moving up into the higher pricepoints; getting a dedicated 15 bar espresso-only unit; or buying a used Espresso Novo #964 in the usual places (if you do, make sure its steam wand has a black rubber tip with a steel snorkel, and that the snorkel has the little black plastic doohickey on its top end.)

Just got done installing this lamp.  It is and it isn't what I expected; I'll summarize.The dimensions here on the Amazon website are accurate, and the colors are too, I think, with the exception of the base, which looks brass here in the picture.  It's not brass; it is indeed the 'antique bronze' as advertised, although it is one or two shades lighter than all the other oil-rubbed bronze fixtures that I have nearby.It is super light, which made it nice to install; I easily did it by myself in about 15 minutes on a stepladder without even straining my arms, and I'm no muscleman.  It came on and stayed on the first try, so I guess I would call it 'easy' to install correctly.The flip side of that is that it is super flimsy.  It feels cheap.  The glass is so thin that at first I thought it was plastic; it's not, it's just thin glass.  I have it installed with a dimmer switch; I've owned other, better art glass - QVC, go figure - and that thick, heavy glass oozed saturated color as the light washed through it, casting a beautiful glow.  This fixture doesn't do that; it looks like plastic.  In addition, this particular style depends on straight, even lead-lines to make the rows and grid of the pattern.  To call this shade hand-made as another reviewer did is strictly charitable; it looks like it came out of the workshop of a retarded monkey.To add insult to this injury, the glass shade came coated in a really repulsive smelling oil.  A few scrubs with a dish sponge and lemon Joy in a sink, followed by drying with paper towels, took much of this off; not all of it, but enough to stop it spreading the smell through the whole room.The other lamp I was looking at cost five hundred and fifty dollars; it is a Restoration Hardware flushmount.  I figured this would be prettier and less expensive; now I regret the purchase because it looks like a twenty dollar plastic lamp.  And I wish I'd known that before I bought it; which is why I wrote this review for you.

I reviewed this lamp along with its partner, the 10W 36 degree 3000K "Vivid" indoor lamp.  Apart from slightly more robust heat sinks, the two lamps were pretty much indistinguishable.  I don't have a 12V rail outdoors so I pointed my hanging lamp fixture out the door to check out back-patio performance. Foliage and the lawn were rendered vividly and the light was very attractive on some Cornish hens that just came off the grill; the lighting was bright and vivid without being stark or washed out.I'm thinking about putting a 12V system in my back deck now to replace the current LED strand lighting I have on the pergola.  If I do, this is the bulb I'll use!

This LED makes a nice replacement for halogen on your 12V rail system.  It says 3000K, but that is a color temperature associated with incandescent and fluorescent lamps; this lamp delivers a full spectrum that I felt was slightly colder than a usual halogen but still quite warm and very pleasing and easy to the eye - I preferred it to the halogen it replaced. Power consumption is low and although the bulb is rated for warm environments it didn't heat up anywhere near as much as the halogen it replaced.

I run a small business that has been growing exponentially since it was founded.  I'm the President, CEO and bookkeeper; and I use a very good accountant; but, in the last year I have felt that the numbers were 'getting away from me.'  I've never had any formal business training!People like me are really whom this book is for.  Of course it's for students taking a class - but the principles in it, of how to get a handle on numbers in a way that can be used to make decisions - are incredibly useful.  I am a leader - I know my goals - and I am a bookkeeper - I know how to make the numbers reconcile at the end of the month.  Everything that goes between those two roles is in this book.I enjoyed the humorous style as well.  It's hard to make a topic like this interesting but the author manages it.  I have this book on my desk and will be paging through it frequently in the next year, I think; and I 'd recommend it for others in my situation.

I'm a huge fan of OXO. Most of their stuff has been well made and well functioning... and this wine stopper/pourer is no exception!It's easy to wash, insert and stop.  There's a round ball-type mechanism that covers the spout underneath to seal in the liquid.  It also looks good, not cheap...got a nice weight to it.I don't use it daily so I have not had the fail-issue as others have mentioned. Wonder if there was a bad batch? So far mine has held up well.Overall, very happy with it and would highly recommend it.

This travel pillow was very underwhelming for me.  I mean, you're not really asking it to do much, right? Fit easily for travel and be semi-comfortable that it's worth toting around.Unfortunately, it's not comfortable (too flat)nor is it easily squishable so it'll take up less room.Mine had that stinky fish smell for the first 48 hrs or so then went away.  But when I removed the cover to wash it, I noticed the foam was holey like swiss cheese.  But since encased in sewn material I couldn't see what was up. Overall, I wouldn't recommend it.Btw, the pillow cover is blue like hospital-issue scrubs.

The strip is a very thin yellow line but it's in front and back and frankly, as a first-time mom, I LOVE having it.  My son has super sensitive skin so I like changing the diaper as soon as it's soiled, even if it's a light pee.Because of my son's sensitive skin, we have tried every brand out there (even the really obscure ones).  This has by far been the best and now that the size 3 has a wetness strip, I love them even more.Comparing these to Pampers Swaddlers Sensitive Size 3 Diapers, 156 Count (Packaging May Vary), Seventh Generation Free and Clear Baby Diapers, Stage 3, 35 Count (Pack of 4), Earth's Best TenderCare Chlorine Free Diapers, Size 3 (16-28 Pounds), 140 Count, Tushies Diapers, Medium (12-24 Pounds), 30 Count (Pack of 4), Fisher-Price Happy Days & Happy Nights Baby Diapers Value Pack, Size 3, 96 CountNurtured by Nature Environmentally-Sensitive Diapers, Medium Size 3, 16-28 Pounds (124 Count)... these are the softest and least irritating to my 4month old.The only drawback to these diapers is the price:( But frankly, seeing a perfectly unblemished baby bottom makes every cent worthwhile!
Very happy with the texture, feel and fit of this case. Nice touch that it comes with a screen protector (although I don't use it).Solid fit without being too bulky.  Looks attractive on the phone.
Very happy with the texture, feel and fit of this case. Nice touch that it comes with a screen protector (although I don't use it).Solid fit without being too bulky.  Looks attractive on the phone.

I liked the look of this baby gate because of the dark wood/metal instead of plastic.  When it arrived, I was fairly happy with the black/wood (no silver despite the title description)combination. It would have been nicer to have it be one color. Unfortunately, it will only fit staircases up to 40.5" width.  Mine is slightly wider so it doesn't fit:(

We just got the diagnosis for our 3mo old that he has eczema...the splotchy, itchy, red and bumpy clumps all over his body and face that everyone (including a pediatrician) told us was "normal baby acne."The diagnosing doctor educated me about the importance of keeping the skin moisturized.  I used this cream along with a small dab of OTC 1% hydrocortizone cream immediately after the baby's bath (pat dry then apply hc cream then this cream all within 3 minutes, according to the National Eczema Foundation pamphlet from the dr's office).I did this and it made a HUGE difference in my baby's skin.  Being new to the eczema world, I didn't realize how his eczema affected so much else, like sleep!Usually, the baby wakes up early and as soon as he's unswaddled, he digs his sharp little nails into his face, body and scalp.The last couple of nights, we've been leaving him unswaddled and I was surprised that he slept from 8PM to 10AM (quick diaper changes and feedings within that time).  When I woke him up he did not dig into his scalp. I think having this thick cream on made a really big difference in moisturizing his poor skin.I'm positive the hydrocortizone took the redness and inflammation down but I also credit this cream for making his skin so much softer and taking away the peeling, dryness.Unlike another reviewer who complained about the smell, I don't think this cream has any smell at all.It goes on thick and greasy but the greasiness goes away.  I did not see any damage to the baby's clothes even tho I dressed him as soon as I lubed him up.The consistency also makes it easy for me to use it on his mostly bald head to control the dryness and cradle cap.This 1lb (16oz) tub is sold with or without the pump.  If it's your first order, I would highly recommend getting the pump because it makes it so much easier when dealing with a squirmy little baby.Lastly, for other newbie parents finding out about eczema, I was told to keep my son in light cotton long-sleeves and pants even during the summer to help control the flare-ups.
I've been using Avery address labels for more than 10 years now.  This newer easy peel is great.  Very happy with the ease of use and quality!

Set up was fairly easy...plug in and insert disc.  But I changed my user name and password from the one that came on the router and could not connect.  Took 25 min call to cs to finally get it to work.  Guess what worked in the end? Yep, unplug, then plug back in.  I wish he would've told me that at the beginning of the call.  Otoh, my call got a live person fairly quickly and it wasn't to overseas.Performance -- very happy with it overall.  I was mostly interested in this because of some  of the deadspots in my home and this dual band router does a good job of solving that issue.I also use my wi-fi for my iphone when I'm at home and notice that it is faster.I think it's slightly pricey but I have not tried watching movies on it, which it might be worth the price if you're a heavy Netflix user.

My Medela Freestyle Breast Pumpcame with the soft fit and it leaks horribly when you go to remove it.I bought these just as a spare and have found these fit better, leak less and are less painful!  Now I only use these.

I found these to be a better option to comparable snacks...For the GOOD:*quite yummy...reminded me of Teddy Grahams Graham Snacks - Honey, 8 oz*Ingredient list is completely understandable...no super multi-syllabic preservatives or flavoring agents or hygrogenated oils.*sodium level is pretty good -- 95mg per serving (about half that of traditional graham crackers).Now the not so good:*figs -- it's really more fig bits.  It's great that real fruit is used but I doubt I could've ever figured out what it is based on the tiny bits.*The second ingredient is sugar:( and contains palm oil:(The thin cripsy cookies/crackers are about 2" in diameter (actually slightly smaller than the picture on the package).  And three of them (30g) = 140 calories...about the same as traditional graham crackers.Overall, I would choose these over the traditional graham crackers or the Teddy Grahams.

I ordered this 5-pk thinking that my newborn would like it because he seems to favor the Soothies the best. I chose this one because of all the great reviews but unfortunately, my baby must fall into the small group who doesn't really care for it.  The nipple is slightly smaller than a Soothie (which he still spits out, that's why I tried this one).  Overall, seems like a good pacifier if your little one is willing to take it... but be forewarned, not all babies will love it.

I received the smaller, portable one as a gift and so far, it's been a life saver!I'm a big fan on The Happiest Baby on the Block: The New Way to Calm Crying and Help Your Newborn Baby Sleep Longer and subscribe to the 5S theory because it's worked for us as first-time parents.I love this sleep sheep because the sound options are all great and soothing.  I attach it to the bassinet handle at night and during the day, it's small enough to either take with me to the baby's swing or inside the baby's stroller.The only reason I'm leaving off a star is because the longest you can leave it on is for 45 minutes.  I wish there was a longer time option because I notice my baby tends to start moving around and making noises when the machine turns off.  I'm sure this helps conserve battery power if you accidentally left it on but I would love to leave it on through the night, as every parent knows, the longer sleep sessions would be greatly appreciated!I would highly recommend this... would be a perfect shower gift because it's cute and useful!

I know, you may be wondering what moron needs this, right?I take super hot showers and don't even realize they're hot.  I only know they're hot because I turn bright red afterwards and if my husband's jumping in after me, he screams.So before our baby was born 7 weeks ago, I ordered this to finish off my baby registry (no one bought it for us probably thinking this was a needless gadget.)But they were sooooo wrong!This is an awesome baby bathtime invention!!!  What I really love is that the whole gadget is automatic.  I don't have to turn anything on or off.  I don't have to push buttons or calibrate anything.  All you do is put it into the tub and listen for the beeps or read the temperature.HOW IT WORKS:It automatically turns on when it hits the water... and automatically turns off when you take it out of the water (GENIUS!!)It beeps the first time to let you know it's on.After that, it beeps if the water falls outside the range of 90-100 degrees.My only complaint is that it's slightly bigger than I thought.  I'm using it in the Fisher-Price Whale of a Playtub and it fits into the bottom bigger portion without any problems (even with the baby in the tub).Besides using it to fill the tub initially, I also use it when I'm getting ready to rinse off the baby.  I put it in the bigger part of the whale tub and before I pour the water on him, I know it's a perfect temp.  This set also includes a cute little cup that slowly sprinkles just the right amount of water to either rinse off baby or keep him warm during the bath.Even though the baby books and websites tell you to test the water temp on the inside of your arm, it's tough to know if it's too cold or too hot for baby.  The reason I like having the exact temp is because I figure baby is 98.6... so if I make the water close to that temp, I know it will be perfect.  The first time I bathed the baby, I didn't use this because I was already overwhelmed with the baby and I think he was cold.  But I now rely on this gadget and he's been a happy bather ever since.

I bought this set to finish off my baby registry thinking all the components will "grow with baby."Since my baby is only 7 weeks old, I've only actually used the finger tip brush.  I would give this a big thumbs down because it's sooo BIG.  I can barely fit it into my infant's mouth and as soon as I put just a portion in, he started screaming madly.  I'm not sure he wouldn't have screamed with anything else but this brush really isn't practical.  And by the way, I have a small hand/fingers and the brush barely fit over my pointing finger.  I know, I want a smaller brush but am complaining about it being too small right?  As a new mom, I would think they could make a smaller one for say the pinky finger... or have the brush part sort of strap onto the finger so you don't end up bulking up the finger.  Sort of like a finger-tip brush ring.While I haven't used the other brushes yet, I really do like the little stand that holds the brushes upright.  Overall, I think it's a good value but pass on it if you're specifically looking for something to use on a newborn/infant.Lastly, the pouch that comes with it is a super cheap plastic thing.  I almost accidentally threw it away because it was folded up in the back of the box.  Not sure why they even include it because it really wouldn't be useful for anything other than maybe packing away 1 brush ?

It's very sweet and carbonated... sort of reminded me of an Izzy juice. I can taste the strawberry but the banana was nowhere to be found.I like that all the ingredients are understandable with apple juice being the first on the list.As for caffeine, an 8.4 oz can has slightly less than a Starbucks tall mocha (80 vs 95).If energy drinks are your thing, I would opt for this natural version...if you don't mind the slight off flavor.

I ordered this for my Cameleon and like everything else in life, there are pros and cons.PROS:  fits the Bugaboo well. The velcro sides can be pulled very tightly but unfortunately, it's a little extra long so you have leftover. Not a big deal.  I like that the outer pocket (there are 3, 2 small and 1 medium) fits my iphone perfectly in the medium slot.  I also like the zipped center to carry a few granola bars on my walks.  It's also nice having a double drink slot...which btw, have a mesh bottom so if you spill, you won't get a yucky pool of liquid.CONS:  Ugh, wish it didn't have the brand name on the middle zippered pocket so prominently.  It also won't install in a way where the drink holder is level...so it's ideal for carrying only bottled items.  This means a travel coffee mug or Starbucks cup won't fit well:(  Even if it's only half full, you'll get spillage.  In fairness, the instructions say not to use it for any hot beverages.  Lastly, you won't be able to flip your handle over (so the stroller faces the other way) without having to redo the whole thing.Overall, it's a good buy and I would recommend it as one of the better options for the Bugaboo (unless you want to pay $25 just for the cupholder {eye roll}.

I got this to try from the Amazon Vine program and thought it would be handy for small needs around the house.  But after trying it out, I have mixed feelings.First, the package states the fasteners will stick on plastic well.  But the drawback to this is that the sticky side is packaged on a plastic sheet, making it tough to peel off (sometimes, the gluey part of the back would not peel off smoothly).The dots are about the size of your thumbnail.  I tried to use it to fasten a baby toy to the car seat handle but that didn't work too well because the toy is a fabric.  So it won't work well on fabric.  But to be fair, the package doesn't claim to.I also used it to attach my garage door opener to a baby stroller handle.  The opener is plastic and the handle is aluminum and both stuck great.I do like that it peels off without leaving the glue behind.

This cream is amazing.  I wouldn't have believed it if it weren't for what my son & I just went through.My 5 week old infant developed a horrible red rash all over his face.  The rash oozed and started drying over in a thick, yellow crust. I'm not sure which was worse, the crustiness and redness all over his (mostly bald) head or his face and ears!  It was extremely distressing to see this.  The pediatrician said the red bumps were "normal" but it continued to spread and get worse day by day.  I bought this cream as a last ditch effort.The package does not make outlandish promises.  But what got my attention was a small phrase stating this was good for ezcema (I didn't even know what that was) and "mystery rashes."  I thought I had little to lose by trying it.I saw a difference within hours!!!  The cream seemed to have calmed the angry red rash on his face.Then I used it as part of a three-prong approach to his horrible cradle cap.First I used a gauze and baby oil to massage and rub the crusty bits on his scalp.  The baby must enjoy having his head massaged because he was content during this whole process.Then I washed his hair with Mustela Foam Shampoo for Newborns - 5.07 oz..  Then I brushed out any remaining flakes with a soft-bristled baby brush... finishing it up by applying this Calendula cream all over his head.RESULTS:For his face, I saw results within hours but within 24 hours was a remarkable healing!  I'm guessing he has ezcema and must be allergic to baby lotion (I had used Aveeno Baby Daily Moisture Lotion, 18-Fluid Ounces Bottles (Pack of 3) and Johnson's Head-to-toe Baby Lotion, 27-Ounce (Pack of 2)).  This cream got rid of the redness, crustiness, oozing and the bumps.  Now 48 hours later, his ears are almost back to normal and his cheeks are showing small bits of flaky dry skin...which I'm assuming is the dead skin peeling off for the renewed skin underneath.  I applied this cream with clean hands -- every time I nursed him.  I only used small amounts on which ever side was facing me.  It has a subtle spa-like scent and absorbs easily...not greasy at all.The results on his head are just as remarkable.  The crusty cradle cap is virtually all gone!!!! So are the tiny red bumps on his head.  Now, he has a bit flaking which I take to be a positive sign that the skin is healing.  I have never been so grateful for a product but after my experience, I'm a huge fan of the California Baby Calendula Cream.

Without any baby experience, I stocked up on 3 different types of NB diapers.  A fourth type was given to us by the hospital.The Huggies Little Snugglers were the brand used by our hospital and we were given a package of 40 when we left the hospital.I had stocked up on Pampers Swaddlers, Pampers Dry Max and Seventh Generation.HUGGIES -- This was my favorite overall.  This one has a good cutout for the umbilical cord.  My husband & I also really like the stripe on the outside that changes color when the diaper is soiled.  As first-time parents we really liked having this because even though we change our baby at every 3-hour feedings, we like to change him in between if he needs it.  Since we don't really know what a soiled diaper should feel like, this little detail made it very easy for us.  The only caveat is that this is the only brand that would leave little "crystal"-like substances in the diaper.  At first I was alarmed thinking these were from the baby's urine but after a quick google, it seems some diapers can create these.  Out of the 4 types we used, only the Huggies left this.  The Huggies also held in the poops well.  The size seems like it grows with the baby for the first month without any problems.Seventh Generation Seventh Generation Chlorine Free Baby Diapers, Newborn (Up to 10 Lbs), 40 Count (Pack of 4)-- This was my 2nd favorite.  Again, there are pros and cons.  The pros, besides the fact they are chlorine-free, is they held in the watery poops well.  But I don't like that it's difficult to tell when the diaper has been peed in.  You can't feel wetness so you kind of have to look at the heaviness in the front.  This is a slight pain especially if you're a first timer and aren't sure what a wet diaper feels like.  I know this sounds stupid but if a newborn is only outputting one ounce and you want to change the diaper, it's tough to tell.  I do like the minor detail that it doesn't have silly characters or designs on the diaper.  This fit our long but lean son well for the first month.  This does not have an umbilical cord cutout but it didn't ride up high like the Pampers.Pampers Swaddlers Pampers Swaddlers Dry Max Diapers, Size N, 84 Count-- Despite the claim that it has an umbilical cord cutout, I couldn't tell.  I still had to sort of fold over the top so it wouldn't rub against it.  It has no wetness indicator as I guess like a previous version.  It did hold in the poops well.  My 3rd favorite.Pampers Baby Dry Pampers Baby Dry Diapers, Newborn, 124 Count-- I didn't like these at all.  The fit was much more snug even though my son is slim. This was also the only brand that leaked out poop.  When it didn't leak, you can see the yellow through the diaper.  This was also the "stiffest" diaper of all the ones we used.  This didn't have an umbilical cord cutout either.  I also didn't care for the Sesame Street characters on the diaper even though this obviously does not affect the performance of the diapers.For any other expecting first time parents, I had stocked up on NB size diapers (more than 400 when you son was born at 8lbs+.  We also went through multiple diapers at each diaper changing session because as we would go to close the diaper, the baby would either pee or poo so we would start all over again.  This would happen as many as 4 or 5 times.  Yes, that means going through 5 or 6 new diapers at one session because small amounts would soil the diaper.  If I had it to do again, I would order one case at a time since the Amazon Mom/Prime shipping gets the diapers to your door in 2 days.  You might also save money by buying a smaller package at a brick and mortar store as your baby grows out of a size instead of having a huge case of leftovers.

Mark your calendar for 11 August for the release of Julia Heaberlin‚Äôs newest psychological suspense novel, Black-Eyed Susans, which is not to be missed.  Heaberlin has crafted a brilliantly executed psychological thriller that this reader was unable to set down.  When Tessa Cartwright was sixteen, she was found barely alive, being the only known survivor of a serial killer whose victims were dubbed the Black-Eyed Susans; it is Tessa‚Äôs testimony that places the serial killer on death row.  Two decades later Tessa discovers Black-Eyed Susans outside her bedroom window and fears the worst, is it possible she placed the wrong man is on death row and the serial killer is on the loose, who could be leaving her these clues and what do they mean, if anything.  Meanwhile forensics are still working on identifying the bones found with Tessa as lawyers work frantically to exonerate the man her testimony put on death row, hoping Tessa will be willing to undergo hypnosis in a desperate attempt to retrieve her lost memories.  A killer may or may not be on the loose, an innocent man may be facing the death penalty, Lydia her childhood friend disappeared without a trace, and the only known living witness has built a fortress of secrets to protect herself and her teenaged daughter.  Heaberlin is a gifted storyteller and has crafted a complex, multilayered story alternating between the past and present continually keeping the reader guessing and questioning what is real and what is imagined.  The characters are richly developed, the story lines are atmospheric and suspenseful, and Heaberlin leaves the reader questioning memory, truth, and closure.  I highly recommend The Back-Eyed Susans to all fans of psychological suspense thrillers.

Freedom‚Äôs Child by Jax Miller is a very difficult book to review without getting into too many spoilers. Miller has created a very multi-layered story with an exceptionally unique cast of characters, for better or worse, which make the story work.  Freedom Oliver is a very complex character, she is working at a biker bar, she is loud, brash, and usually drunk, she is also not really Freedom Oliver, she is in witness protection, and in her past she made a deal with the Feds, she put her two children up for adoption, and she was arrested for murdering her husband twenty years ago.  Freedom learns her daughter, whom was adopted years ago is missing and she chooses to leave witness protection to find her daughter.  As Freedom heads back to Kentucky her past begins to catch up with her.  Miller has created a very intense, fast-paced thriller, filled with complex and mainly unlikeable characters with very unique backstories which intertwine and somehow through Miller‚Äôs talented writing work.  Freedom‚Äôs Child is indeed a thriller, however, it is also about a woman haunted by a past she cannot forget and the desire to right many of the wrongs that have been done.  Miller‚Äôs writing is definitely distinctive and I would have rated the book higher had there not been so many scenes of intense violence.

I was rather excited to read The Fixer by Joseph Finder as I have heard rather good things about Finder‚Äôs suspense novels and it is a genre I immensely enjoy, unfortunately I did not enjoy this book as much as I had hoped, however, Finder has written numerous books and I will definitely give him another chance.  The Fixer centers around Rick Hoffman, a former investigative journalist who loses everything and moves into his father‚Äôs vacant home. Rick‚Äôs father, attorney Leonard Hoffman suffered a stroke almost two decades ago and has been in a nursing facility ever since.  Rick decides to renovate the neglected house with the help of his neighbor Jeff when he stumbles across over three million dollars hidden in the walls.  The money brings more problems into Rick‚Äôs life as his easy gain suddenly turns to paranoia, fear, and the need to figure out just who his father was prior to his stroke.  Finder has crafted some intriguing storylines, with Rick being a rather unlikeable man for the majority of the book and his father a rather intriguing man without the ability to speak, yet possibly not quite as helpless as one might think.  I found the father son dynamics to be of some interest, yet not enough to make me not want to set the book down now and again.  The Fixer is truly an interesting premise and it is quite possible the book would not unfold as well if Rick was not so obnoxious, the reader would be unable to see his transformation, and while I do not need to enjoy the protagonist to enjoy a well written book, I just did not care about Rick, yet I was fascinated by his father‚Äôs life, which is what kept me reading this book.  Overall, I would recommend The Fixer to fans of well-written mystery and suspense novels.

DII 100% Cotton, Machine Washable, Cleaning, Drying, Utility Bar Mop Multi Use Dishtowel set of four are 16‚Äù x 19‚Äù, the bright bold colors stayed bright and bold after use and machine washing and drying.  The price for the four towels is quite reasonable and frankly I was not expecting them to do well, be thick or last.  The towels are not very thick, however they are very absorbent, dry dishes exceedingly well, and are machine washable and dryable, making these a wonderful addition to the kitchen.  As the title of the towels state, they can be used for many purposes, for this review, I have only used them at home and I am quite content with my experience with these towels.

And Sometimes I Wonder About You by Walter Mosley is the fifth Leonid McGill novel in the series and one I was unable to put down, just as I was unable to put down his previous four books in the series.  Mosley‚Äôs characters are fully developed, multidimensional, and utterly fascinating, Leonid McGill is one of my all time favorite Private Investigators.  Leonid‚Äôs personal life is still in chaos, much as it was in the previous book, All I Did Was Shoot My Man, his father is still missing and his wife‚Äôs slow recovery in the sanitarium is making things rather difficult for him and Aura.  To further complicate matters Twill is busy working is own case helping Fortune and spending time with his girlfriend Liza.  When Leonid is approached by Hiram Stent to locate his cousin Celia, who is about to inherit millions, he decline the case that is until his office is broken into and Hiram is found dead.  McGill masterfully crafts a multi-storied PI mystery where Leonid finds himself in the seedy underbelly of Celia‚Äôs family, helping Twill, locating his father, attempting reconciliation with his wife and his girlfriend, and in his spare time, attending Gordo‚Äôs wedding.  While this brief synopsis may sound chaotic and like spoilers, Mosley‚Äôs gift of storytelling makes sense of what appears chaotic and thankfully his writing allows me to give this much information without spoilers.  Mosley‚Äôs writing is pure genius and reminds me of Mickey Spillane‚Äôs books, my first foray into PI stories.  I highly recommend this book and Mosley‚Äôs previous books in this series to anyone who enjoys exceedingly well written, multi-directional storylines with complex characters and the feel of ‚Äúold fashioned‚Äù PI stories.

The Theft of Memory: Losing My Father One Day At A Time by Jonathan Kozol is an extraordinary memoir, heart-felt, intellectual, factual, and personal account of Alzheimer‚Äôs disease.  Kozol writes about his father, Dr. Harry L. Kozol, who helped establish the fields of forensic psychiatry and neuropsychiatry and was a well known neurologist and clinician. Dr. Kozol‚Äôs expertise led him to treat famous artists and intellectuals such as Eugene O'Neill as well as infamous criminals such as Albert DeSalvo, the Boston Strangler and Patty Hearst and finally to diagnosing himself with Alzheimer‚Äôs disease.  The Theft of Memory is a moving a loving tribute to the life of Kozol‚Äôs father, a detailed look into the decline of one‚Äôs life as Alzheimer‚Äôs disease takes over, and above all, the relationship between father and son and how the relationship shifts and changes throughout life.  Kozol has written a beautiful memoir of love and loss and I would not hesitate to recommend this book to all readers and discussion groups.

The Life and Death of Sophie Stark by Anna North is one of the most thought-provoking and uniquely written novels I have read in recent memory, narrated by those who knew Sophie best.  Sophie‚Äôs career as a filmmaker is on a rapid slope upward, leaving her with little left for those that are close to her.  In her career‚Äôs rise to critical acclaim, she stops at nothing to feed her artistic creativity, which at times puts her at odds with those she loves.  While the true-to-life films that she creates reveal her passions and talent for filmmaking, Sophie learns, perhaps too late, that there is a price to pay for her obsession with her career.  This is my first experience reading North, and her writing in The Life and Death of Sophie Stark has left me wanting to read the other works by this talented author.  I would highly recommend The Life and Death of Sophie Start to all who enjoy literary fiction and to group discussion groups.

The Ambassador‚Äôs Wife by Jennifer Steil is the story of Miranda, wife of a British Ambassador, who faces challenges beyond her worst nightmares when she is abducted by terrorists.  Her life in the Middle East, while enviable to many, had its drawbacks:  surrounded by staff and bodyguards wherever she ventured, her autonomy was sacrificed, challenging her very sense of being.  In a twist of irony, the life that she so longed to lead was swept away by kidnappers who would stop at nothing to fulfill their agenda.  Steil, through her carefully crafted and atmospheric writing, effortlessly draws readers into this suspenseful story about relationships and the ultimate challenges faced by one woman. Steil further solidifies her place in the genre with this thought provoking, high-tension, and, at times, heartrending novel.  The Ambassador‚Äôs Wife is an excellent choice for those who enjoy well written, thought provoking suspense novels and it would make an excellent book discussion group pick.

Lovers on All Saints‚Äô Day by Juan Gabriel V√°squez is a collection of seven short stories all of which take place in Europe, where the only connection between the stories is the emotional tone of deep longing.  As I have come to expect, V√°squez‚Äôs prose is beautiful, however this collection of stories is deep, intense, and dark.  The collection of stories are neither uplifting nor necessarily redemptive, however, they show humanity as it is, V√°squez does not hold back, and while the stories are short they are intense, emotionally packed, and convey the life of the characters in a rather short space of time.  Each story is brilliantly written, filled with love affairs, betrayals, revenge and troubled pasts.  Lovers on All Saints‚Äô Day is a beautiful collection of short stories, each of which is a small example of society, yet these stories are often intense and dark, V√°squez is able to show the reader a more keen understanding of the human experience and the complexities of relationships and love.

Due to be released 30 June 2015, The Mask by Taylor Stevens is the fifth book in her Vanessa Michael Munroe series and I think this may be my favorite of the series thus far.  As I have stated in my reviews of the previous four books, they can be read independently, however, I think the reader will be missing a lot of back story as the characters are quite complex and ever evolving and Vanessa Michael Monroe is truly a fascinating character with a rather unique past.  In The Mask readers will be happy to see Munroe reunited with Bradford and unlike previous novels, this one deals with industrial espionage.  Miles Bradford accepts a job as a security consultant in Japan and after what happened to Munroe in the previous novel, no spoilers for those who have not read The Catch, Munroe needs a well deserved rest, however when Bradford is arrested for murder, Monroe‚Äôs predator instincts and loyalties are tested as they have never been tested before; how far will Munroe go to save someone who by all appearances has betrayed her.
