Air flow is pretty good, for its size.This fan can be set on a flat surface and they provide a metal mounting bracket for the wall. When folded "closed," it is designed so that there is room for the air to get into the back of the fan, unobstructed. This allows it to be a floor fan, pointing straight up. The various positions the fan can "unfold" are in a 90 degree range. They securely click into one of 5 positions. You can move it with your hand; no buttons to push.In the previous version of my review, I wrote that I was disappointed the wall mount ability was designed so that the fan "unfolded" so that it pointed only downward in varying degrees, and I wanted to wall mount it so that it "unfolded" upward. Well, taking a closer look, I discovered that the base of the fan actually rotates 360 degrees, clicking in place at 12 evenly spaced stops, which, then, does allow me to use the wall mount and be able to position the fan pointing upwards. This ability is not mentioned in the instructions I got in the box. It also means you can point the fan left or right, or at a 45 degree angle, or just about anywhere you want.So, I can now see that between the fan angling ability and the sliding fan speed ability, this is a very flexible fan than can serve a lot of purposes and be able to direct air from, perhaps, odd locations.I only have 1 issue which may or may not be important to you. Since it uses an ac adapter plug, you have the adapter part at the end that plugs into the outlet. Some are designed to fit neatly into an strip outlet, with the adapter part extending away from the outlet strip. This one, however, is designed so that it covers an outlet or two next to the one you plug in. Hate that.I am sure I will give this fan a lot of use in the summer, in my office, and in the winter, in my house distributing heat. Seems pretty well made.

I tested this on my drums and compared it to a Shure SM57. It's not a direct match with the ATM650 because the ATM650 is hypercardioid and the SM57 is cardioid. When I tested recording sound walking 360 degrees around, the ATM650 is noticeably better at not picking up the sounds from the rear and sides. I tested recording with the mic over my drums and the differences there are also quite noticeable. The SM57 delivers a much more even and realistic sound. The ATM650 picks up the high end much stronger. The cymbals and snare seem much louder and in your face. I'm not saying this is bad. It may be a matter of preference. This could be something modified with mixing, if needed. However, I prefer the much more natural sound the SM57 delivers.Other than that, this is a very solidly built and nice looking microphone, at a good price.

I like the rounded, smooth design, but I they were lighter than I hoped. I like a heavier feel in the hand, but these are noticeably lighter than my existing set. They don't seem to be consistent, though. The large spoons' handle thickness is what I like, but you can see it is thicker than the small spoons' handle. But, the large and small forks are the same thickness. The fork tines are sharper than my last set, but not a problem. The width of the knife is a bit thinner than I'd like, but the serrated edge cuts better than most butter knifes. They are balanced and the thumb rests nicely on the handle. As a side note, the packaging or product gives no indication of where they were made.Overall, I like the set, especially since I got it on a deal of day sale, and it does match fairly close with my older, depleted set, I just wish they were heavier.

Creamy, smooth, delicious. Really lubricates things up when I kiss my wife! Probably one of the better balanced cocoa blends I have tried. Long lasting, too. Tin is a little hard to open at first, but you get used to it.

While we don't have a PlayStation, I thought these might be better for gaming. My son reports that the fit is tight and because the ear pads do not go around the ear, they press on the ear, it leaves his ears bashed down in his head after wearing them a while. But, the mic works good and the sound is decent. Not his favorites. He also has a pair of Sony MDR-7506s. I took some time to test and compare them. I used the audio tools on my desktop and 7.1 sound tests on YouTube to compare. The Sony's deliver much better top and middle sounds; sharp, crisp and clear. While the PlayStations sound muddled on the high end, definitely lacking crispness. The 7.1 tests I did delivered pretty much the same spatial effects replicating the 7.1 speaker sounds and positions. The Sonys feel lighter and are a true over ear design, not pressing on your ears. This also allows them to noticeably better keep outside sound out. The Sony cord is coiled and thicker while the PlayStation is thinner, straight and not as long. The Sonys also look and feel much higher quality. I definitely prefer the Sonys, and so does my son.  However, the Sony's cost twice as much as the PlayStations, but they also sound almost twice as good.

This is the 4th Grind-and-Brew model I have bought over the last 14 years. The last model was the sloped back front style Cuisinart DGB-550BK, bought close to 5 years ago. It didn't stop working, but after years of daily use it started to show its age, and I started hearing funny noises when grinding. This model has the exact same guts as the sloped back model. Same pot, too. While they still sell the Cuisinart DGB-550BK, I guess I was just looking for a change.I've been using it a while and I'm glad I switched to this style. One difference I have noticed is that it is quieter. The difference with this design versus the sloped back design is that there is a more room in the grinder department inside. This makes it quieter because the sound sort of "gets trapped" inside the larger compartment, making it sound muffled. Also, it seems to not grind as long. So, I am happy that it is less noisy and still brews the same great cup of coffee. I do not, however, think the design is nicer looking, but I will gladly accept that for less noise.I always thought the grind noise was too loud and long, and it might wake people up. I have my clock set to go off a bit earlier, so I always hear it. But, I had visitors recently who got up earlier than me and used the grinder, and I slept right through it. So, maybe the noise isn't an issue for some, anyway.In general I highly recommend the Grind-And-Brew line for nice, fresh coffee in the morning. If noise is an issue, this model is a bit quieter. Otherwise, the sloped back design works just as well.

The first thing you think when you see this thing is, Wow! Compared to the typical shower head products you find in stores, this thing is truly a FIXTURE. Heavy, solid, apparently really well built, and built to last, you have to approach it like you are building a new shower and this is the main thing everything is built around. In fact, it is probably best to wait until you remodel and have it custom installed professionally then. I didn't quite know what I was getting into. The instructions do not really make it clear, but I figured it; you still need to have an existing on/off mechanism. The bottom part that attaches to the wall is a dummy base; no water goes in there, only at the top and none of the Grohe valve positions are for on/off. You need a way to turn on/off the water. This means either the existing on/off valve needs to be used or you need to get some plumbing done to accommodate it. If you have one of this bath tubs where the shower is turned on from a lever on the bath tub faucet, that is best. My existing Moen on/off lever, however, was right in line with the what would be the middle of the Gohe fixture, and it isn't flat enough against the wall to fit behind it. Also, make sure you note the measurements of this thing and how much room it needs. It looks huge in my shower! Short story is, had to pay a plumber to move around some pipes to make it fit.Once installed, I am happy with it. The water flow is good and the spray options numerous enough. I'm not a big fan of the rainfall option, but my family likes it. Still, know what you are getting into first.

My daughter has Boo, so I thought this would be a nice companion gift. The construction, itself, is of typical Gund high quality. The main way Buddy is designed to be Boo's counter part is that Boo is all face and Buddy is all body. They sort of balance each other out. This makes Buddy, with a body of fluffy long fur and a bigger tail, a better plush toy for hugging.The only thing I knocked a star off for was the packaging. **The way I got it may be because of the Vine program.** I'm not sure. Maybe the manufacturer will clarify somewhere, but Buddy came in an Amazon box, wrapped in a suffocation warning-labeled plastic bag and nothing but a 2" x 2.5" tag attached to its ear. Not exactly excitement inducing packaging if given as a gift. If that's the way it is shipped to everyone, though, be prepared to re-wrap it if you want a better gift presentation.So, Buddy is nice as a companion gift for someone who already has a Boo. However, if you got Buddy for someone who doesn't have a Boo, you are probably setting yourself up for a future Boo purchase (marketing plan working!)

My wife had been using a Magic Bullet NutriBullet (NB), but it had become unusable, so when this came up on the Vine program, it fit our needs perfectly. My review compares the 2 products.Pros:1) Smaller size, more powerful than NB. The power rating is a bit higher, but, to her, seems even higher. Since she tends to cut up a lot of different fruits and vegetables, this is a nice upgrade. Having the motor unit smaller helps, too, since we tend to keep it out on the counter top and it takes up less space than the NB2) The NB  did not have a handled, large size cutting container, which she says she will use primarily over the drinking glass size containers. The handled container has a nice rubber footing that helps keep it from moving. Overall, nice assortment of tools and containers3) Easier to clean than NB. One difference is that the Ninja containers are designed so that the rubber seal ring is on the outside of the lid versus on the inside for the NB. This makes it easier to remove so that all food particles can get cleaned out4)  In general, all of the components have a sturdier, more heavy duty feel to them. My wife says she was a bit scared sometimes using the NB, which seemed, to her, a bit more unstable. She has more confidence using the NinjaCons:1) No cover for the motor unit (the NB comes with one). While it may be hard to turn on with your hands, a cover helps keep the motor unit clean and looks better when sitting on the counter2) This design may have the same issue as the NB: on the motor units, you need to push down (or also up with the Ninja) with the mixing container in order to get the blades to turn. The NB requires the containers to be upside down over the motor unit, while the Ninja 2-in-1 works 2 ways, with the some mixing containers on top or bottom. With frequent use of the NB, one way or the other, food or liquid dripped onto the push buttons on the motor unit. With the NB, the pulverized food got stuck in the button cracks making it hard to clean. But the real problem was the food that got inside dried up and froze some of the buttons in place. My wife had to use a screw driver to un-stick them, and just before we got the Ninja, the NB unit pretty much froze in place, making it inoperable. My wife is concerned the same thing may happen with the Ninja, however, she plans on using the handled container most of the time and, since the motor unit goes on the top, there would be no opportunity for food to drip down onto it.Other than that, my wife would like the ability to have a button to turn the unit on rather than having it automatically start once it is in place.

This product solves a big issue I have had. I was using a programmable thermostat for many years, however, one thing I hated was when the unit would turn on, when we were out of home, when I didn't want it to. I even left for vacation once forgetting to turn the unit off, and wasted electricity cooling the house with no one there. I really wished I had a way to turn it off, or on, remotely. Now I do. After set up, I tested the smartphone app and it works as advertised. I really like the ability to control my heat pump remotely.One big piece of advice for those setting this up: take a clear picture of your current wiring first. Even though I thought I was sure I had the wires identified and labeled correctly, I could not get the new controls to turn on the heat and I couldn't remember which wires went where on the old thermostat so I could check my work. This led to a lot of internet research to learn what the wire colors mean and how they are wired a little differently for some brands. I did call tech support, and I did get through to them quickly, and they were knowledgeable. Still I had to a lot of research and experimenting before I discovered one wire was either not previously connected, or it came loose when I removed the old thermostat from the wall. It took me a couple of hours before i got it all figured out and working.I do like the ability to keep the back light on. This provides a night light for my hallway. I wish it had cooler looking graphics, but for the price, it looks good. I also like the humidity gauge option.So, despite some issues with my particular situation with the wiring, it appears to work as advertised and solves one problem I have been looking foe a solution to.Update 12/26/14: I have been using this a while and I find it regulates better than my previous programmable thermostat. This one appears to detect temperature changes faster and my heat pump now turns on and off more often, whereas my previous thermostat tended to stay on constantly, seemingly never reaching my set temperature. I did notice that this one does not turn off very quickly when it reaches the set temperature. I didn't wait around to see how long it took; I simply set my intended target heat temperature one degree lower.One wish I have for the manufacturer: since this thing is online, I wish I could save data that I can later analyze. I think I could get a better idea of what temperature is ideal if I knew how often and long it is working each day. Maybe I'm a data junkie, but I really wish I could have the data to plot out and see if there is something I could be doing to be more efficient. At minimum, it's a shame to be wasting all the data it collects. If I had the option to send it to one of my cloud accounts, that would be great.Update 09/01/15: About 2 months ago, it malfunctioned. Over a course of several weeks I patiently tried every possible wire combination, researched everything I could online and spent hours on the phone with tech support before I gave up and called in an expert to evaluate it. Sure enough, they found one of the wire terminals stopped connecting for some reason. I was able to get it replaced easily and the replacement did, indeed, work. Their customer service is great for this product, but it took forever to eliminate all other possibilities.

Apparently, I got a bad copy and it did not work properly. I set it up according to the quick instructions and used the Genie app for any configurations. From the git-go, it had many issues. One computer is connected directly to the router while I use powerline adapters for 2 other computers. The same pattern occurred on all: it started out connecting to the internet at top speeds, but with each click of the mouse it progressively deteriorated in speed until unusable. Then I had to reset, re-pair and turn on/off one thing or the other, or all of them, then the same pattern would repeat. I was also never able to connect directly to the wi-fi channels, even though the signal strength indicators showed 5 bars. Somehow, though, I was able to get some connectivity, with the same speed deteriorating issues, when connected via my Amped signal extender.I tried my best to get it to work for 5 days. I called tech support, but they told me the product was already registered to someone else and they couldn't help me (my belief is the product they sent me was a returned product that they did not erase the original registration for). Tech support had no clue what the Vine program was and was completely at a loss what to tell me. After expressing considerable frustration, they provided me with the e-mail address for the development team (I believe). They were helpful but the only way they could help me was to have me go through a significant amount of manual tinkering, which I had no time to do. They also pointed me to some new software version they claimed would help, but by that time the router had completely stopped working and I couldn't even download it to try it. I couldn't take it anymore and removed their product and re-installed my previous router. Now, all is working again. They are sending me a pre-paid shipping label so they can examine the unit.I read another reviewer's bad review and they said it may have had something to do with the Dynamic QoS they were using. But when I checked the Advanced settings through the URL control panel (which you do not see via the Genie app I was using), I found the Dynamic QoS was not turned on (I tried it turned on and it didn't change the behavior). In general, though, I think this product may have been rushed to market. The software versions are still in the 1.0.0 level and it appears to me the development team is currently working a lot on this product.Other people appear to have had good experiences. My only advice if you buy this, make sure you install it on a slow week in case you run into trouble. Also, before you call tech support, register the product or they will refuse to help (protocol, you know).

You need to understand this product's capabilities and limitations before you buy it, but it may be the perfect solution for your needs. I have had a lot of opportunity to review security cameras through the Vine program, but this one is different. For me, though, it fits a need I have perfectly.Before I begin, you must understand that when this product says "wireless," it is not over your wireless network. The only way this product works wirelessly is between the cameras and the viewing device that comes with it. You cannot see it on your computer or smartphone.Pros:1) Works right out of the box. I was quite surprised to see a video image on the screen as soon as I plugged in the camera. I didn't have to do anything with the settings. It just worked2) Probably one of the better motion sensing software features I have seen yet. By default, it records any time it senses movement. I did not touch any settings and I found recordings that fairly accurately showed when cars and people entered the cameras' viewing area. Night viewing is a little more difficult; I found it came on when bugs or birds flew in front of the camera. You can test different camera sensitivity levels to improve that, but I don't think you can eliminate false starts completely. I have owned several security cameras and I always ended up turning the motion sensing feature off because either it was too sensitive or missed too much. So far, I am impressed with this one's accuracy3) Easy set up. I will not give it bad marks because it may take a few trial and errors before you figure everything out. There is not an overabundance of settings and the ones included are fairly intuitive or can eventually be figured out. Most of the other cameras I have tried said they were easy, but under a thin veneer of user friendliness was a dashboard of settings only a security professional could love, and understand. This one is not designed for professionals and the settings that are included are probably the only ones the average person needs4) Good wireless reach (for me). The directions prominently warn you that if you live in a brick walled house or there are steel structures around, the signal could be significantly shortened. My house is constructed of masonry blocks and steel beams, so I was expecting the worst. I am using this mainly from my office behind my garage. The furthest camera is about 60 feet and the closest is about 25 feet, but on the same side of the house my office is on (signal doesn't have to travel through the house, but it does through the garage). The signal strength, to my surprise, is strong. No problem getting images for me5) The ability to keep a separate video monitor running constantly. Unlike network cameras that require you to view through your computer monitor, the separate viewing monitor for this product can be set up on your desk and provide a quick and easy way to keep an eye on things6) Good night vision. I originally judged it to be poor or at least on par with other so-called night vision cameras, but over the last few nights of recordings, I have come to conclusion that this camera does provide a decent night vision view. You can make things out pretty good, in the entire field of view, which goes as far as day vision. Some cameras' night vision I have seen either have good vision only for 5' to 10' or only show the brightest objects, and ghostly, at that. This won't give you detail, but I am impressed with the overall night view qualityCons1) Poor battery life on the portable viewer. You basically need to keep it plugged in when you use it. When it is plugged in and being used, the most I have seen the battery bars go up to is 3 out of 4 bars. When unplugged and being used, after 4 hours the battery bars disappear (I haven't run it until it dies). This gives it little usefulness2) Poor audio. The sound only comes through when, on screen, you are viewing a single camera, and it's pretty poor. In addition to a tinny sounding speaker, there is a constant buzzing on the further camera3) Incident record time settings not flexible enough. When the cameras detect motion, they start recording from the first motion detection only for the amount of time you set. However, the only options are 30 seconds, 1 minute, 5 minutes and 10 minutes. I wish they either included more minute options between 1 and 5, allowed a customized setting time, or recorded for all the time motion is detected. For example, 1 minute was too little to catch an entire package delivery between when the camera detects motion until they leave. Yes, it starts recording a new file again after the first time out because motion is still going on, but 35 seconds were lost in the transition. I'd like a 2 minute option, at least.4) Day image quality. It will do the job as far as monitoring what's going on and making out what you see, but it is not high definition (to be fair, they are not making any claims the image is high quality). When you view one camera taking up the full 7" monitor screen, you can detect pixelation. Colors are decent, but the only camera controls available are for brightness. I have seen some cameras marketed as high definition provide much better day images, with better colors, but for the purpose of surveillance cameras, I think the quality this product provides is par for the course5) Be advised that the only place it records is on the monitor device, while it is on. I did not take stars off for this because that is how it was designed to work. But for those looking for a higher security application, this one does not record to a separate recorder locked away in another room, or to the cloud. Again, if that is your need, don't buy this6) Mounting bracket does not allow it to be hung from a ceiling or overhang. This seems odd since security cameras are often mounted from a ceilingThis product is not going to be right for someone who wants to monitor a home or business from a distant location on their phone or computer, so if that's what you need, don't get this one. But, if, like me, you've been looking for a basic solution that allows you to keep constant tabs on a couple of locations around your immediate vicinity, this product is perfect for that, and that is the context in which I rated it.

This isn't so much a chair as it is a cushion holder. I was really hoping to be able to say it looks better in person than in the photo, but I can't. I believe the comfort of this chair is going to depend on your height. I'm 5' 6" and, for me, the chair is not a good fit. I will say that the cushion itself is extremely soft and comfortable, but I don't think it works well as a chair.Pros:1) Very soft and comfortable cushion2) Easy to assemble3) High quality materialsCons:1) The proportions of chair do not look well designed. The back of the chair is unnecessarily tall and wide. You look at it and wonder why it flares out like it does: there's no rhyme or reason for it. I live in a mid-century modern home, where form follows function. The chair's over-sized back does not serve a function. I thought this would look good in my home, but it doesn't. Ikea makes better looking modern design chairs. This one does not look like it was designed by a high end design firm. Again, it looks like a cushion holder, related more to a futon couch frame than a piece of furniture2) It's too high off the ground. If you want a comfortable chair, you need to fall into it and be able to lean back. Again, this might be different for people of different height, but for me, sitting on it like you normally would a chair is not comfortable. My feet cannot lay flat on the ground, my legs are pinched inward between the 2 front arms, and I am sitting in an upright position. The only way to feel comfortable is to straddle your legs between one of the front arms and dangle your legs over. My kids are small enough for them to curl up inside it (my dog may end up getting this chair as his bed) and they like that waySolutions:At this point, I doubt I will leave it in my living room. It may end up in our bedroom (lots of cushion space to throw clothes over!). My daughter now takes the cushion off the chair and lays it on the floor, propped up against the couch. I think this is how it started out; as a big floor cushion. That may end up how we use it.Here is what I have done, or thought about doing, so far trying to make it useful:1) I reversed the cushion position. It is supposed to have the huge part on top and smaller part as the seat. However, by reversing it, to me, it is more comfortable. The back is lower and actually looks like a properly proportioned chair back. With the bottom longer, it supports my legs better and I feel like I am sunk back into it, in a laid back position. It is more comfortable, BUT, it doesn't look like a well designed chair this way, either2) I am thinking about cutting through the top, back cushion pockets that the rear arms slide into to let the cushion slide down lower, so the back doesn't look so freakishly large and it sits lower to the ground. However, I suspect this will not work. I may end up with my butt resting on the frame below it and the frame may not be able to stretch wide enough if I slide them down further3) When you think about, this chair is just an interpretation of a butterfly chair. I happened to have an old, folding butterfly chair in my closet, so I took the cover off of it and put it on the Puff chair. It fit and it looks good. The only problem is that my butt just touches the frame underneath. I'm trying to see if I can find a smaller butterfly chair cover that may lift me up a couple of inches. If I can find one that works, then I will keep the chair in my living room with a butterfly cover and use the cushion as a floor cushion. With a butterfly chair cover on it, It actually looks like a modern chair (it really does look good). I'm hoping to make that workAgain, everything I discovered may be a function of your body size. Taller or shorter people may not have the same issues with it as I do. I really wished I could say I like the chair, but it just doesn't work for me.

Sometimes I like to just have a way to mark the places on the table when everyone is going to eat. These serve that purpose nicely. What they are not is an absorbent place mat, which is something people need sometimes. The material is heavy enough and woven in such a way that it has substance when placed on the table. It's flexible, lies flat and won't blow away easily. They are big enough to mark your "spot" and protect the table from possible scratches from plates and utensils. If you spill something on it, the liquid does soak through slowly, but the material and weave are such that a lot of liquid also remains on top, so if you were to spill something, at least not all of it soaks through.It's got a nice geometric, shiny pattern that can be reversed and look the same. Easy to clean off. When my kids were younger and more prone to spilling and splattering food, I'd probably want something more absorbent, but now they are older and all we really need is to add a little formality to the table, and these work well for that.

This thing has become sort of a favorite around our house, I even use it on my old skin. It's a simple idea, a spinning brush, but it does the job. You can believe it cleans far more effectively than hand washing (10 times more, though?). The spinning brush on your face makes a pin-like feeling, I assume because of the "sonic pulses." Must be the effect of a micro jolt that makes fairly soft bristles feel like they are standing up, digging down a little bit into your skin to loosen up oil and dirt. There are 2 brushes: one regular, with all bristles the same, and the other has a strip in the middle with what I assume are stiffer bristles. To be honest, I don't notice much of a difference, though.The device has 3, 20 second cycles so you can focus on 3 zones on your face. I find this amount of time to be about right. One thing I was concerned about was if the brush would retain enough soap by the time I got to the 3rd zone. It does. The soapiness doesn't go away. I think the density of the brush head holds the soap effectively.The only knock I may mention is the fact it needs to be placed in a charging stand (though not often). I am concerned placing it anywhere near the sink, so I keep it in another location and charge it as needed, away from the sink.So, nice little tool to have. Quick, easy, makes you face feel clean. Everyone likes using it.

Good sized, stylish fryer. Electronic controls are accurate and easy to read. The top covers the entire machine, giving it a clean look, and the lid can be easily washed in the dishwasher. The cord is just a bit longer than other fryers I've had, and that is appreciated. I don't really get the "dual zone" feature; seems like a marketing stunt to me. I didn't see any difference in the frying performance. While the top does have a nice sized filter, steam still escaped from around the lid when you first put food in. The odor was controlled just fine, but I have had other fryers that performed as well.The main benefits I see from this product is the food capacity and heating strength. I was using a T-fal FR7008002, which I truly liked for the convenience of being able to simply filter and drain the oil into a self contained storage bin beneath the unit. However, this was accommodated by reducing the food capacity. While I do not like having to store a separate oil container, I think I like the DeLonghi's food capacity enough to put up with it. The other appreciated thing I noticed is that this machine recovered from a drop in temperature when first adding food a lot quicker than the T-fal. The only knock I can give it is that the top handle is so close to where the steam comes through the filter that you do feel the heat on your knuckles. The lid is also rather large, so you need to find a big spot to set it when you take food in and out.Overall, the food I cooked cooked faster and more evenly. I like the food capacity and the speed which it comes back up to temperature. It is a stylish design, but it may take up a bit more space. The odor control is on par with most other modern fryers and the electronic controls are clear and accurate. Most parts can be machine washed. A good choice for a fryer.

This is a nice addition to my amateur video making efforts. I happen to have a large tile floor area to roll around on, and that adds the ability to make videos that have that flowing action to them you normally see from professional work. The product seems well constructed and the wheels are a nice quality. The tripod anchor points adjust to fit your tripod and the tripod feet locks work well. I like the locking wheel feature: it's a cool effect to lock one wheel and then you can pivot around your subject for a 180 degree continuous shot.Not great on bumpy surfaces and the wheel sound does get into your camera mic if you move fast or on a bumpy surface (not an issue if you are dubbing a separate audio track in). Having this low priced version makes me want to get a high end, expensive one, but really don't need to do that for my purposes. It's just fun to use for some pro effects that makes your video look more interesting. Even if you don't use it for flowing videos, the rolling base is useful just for moving your camera around to where you want it; you can lock all wheels to create a stationary base.

This does not replace duct tape, but it does compliment it. The problem with duct tape is the resin it leaves behind. This tape isn't as strong as duct tape, but for temporary situations (like taping over an extension cord used for a party), it is better because it removes cleanly.

(I should point out, this is for the metal version) Just what I was looking for. Solid construction, crisp graphics. Make sure you understand the size you are getting, because it is rather large, but I had the right spot for it. Just hope people get the point and turn away. I wish it had an extra line of text: This means you!

Soothing and relaxing sounds help after a long day. The clock showing through the cloth seems a little weird, though, and it really only is visible in the dark. My problem is my room has a lot of light coming in, so the lights that wake you up really don't have that effect on me. It looks like a lot of thought went into it, but that also made it difficult to figure out. Had to keep the instructions nearby for a while, even now. One issue was it seemed to keep reverting to military time, but I think it stopped.Overall, an interesting, creative clock that has an interesting array of sounds and lights for those who don't ordinarily like alarm clocks.

Not sure if it is necessary, but the fragrance definitely sticks around and my dogs fur is smoother. I use this in conjunction with Fresh 'n Clean prewash, so my dog's getting a pretty thorough cleaning.

I've been using this mainly in my office, mostly for the charging stand feature. The plug can be configured to hold a USB or any Apple plug, so it is versatile. One little annoyance, though, is that the connector leans back too far and I have to wiggle and wedge the bottom of my SIII before it slides in, but otherwise, it holds the phone securely.The radio reception seems weak from the times I tried using it. The antenna doesn't help much. I think it's effectiveness is going to depend on your location. The box has all the usual radio features (no bass and treble, though), and it also functions as kind of an all-in-one device port via bluetooth, which is used for the telephone feature and music playing. The phone mic/speaker feature works fine; people said I sound clear. The music sounds pretty balanced for such a small speaker.The only other knock I have is that in the back, where you can wrap the power cord and phone connection cord, it is too close to where the phone charger cord comes out and if you have to use a long cord (they don't supply an Apple cord), it gets blocked.Overall, a nice little device to have as a do-all, little, versatile desktop audio workhorse.

I didn't quite catch why these were available on the Vine program, but then I realized the eneloop brand is now made by Panasonic, rather than Sanyo. These have been my preferred brand of rechargeables for years, and they have never let me down. The Panasonic version appears to be identical, so that's good news.If you are thinking of making the switch to a rechargeable battery household, get these whenever they are on sale. They are the gold standard.

Nice, solid piece of hardware. I had no issues installing it. Looks good in the right spot. Hooks arms might be a tad shorter than you'd like for thick things, likes towels (to be fair, they do specify robes). The "hooks" are also not so "hooky" and clothes may fall off easier than you'd like if you try to hang from the collar. However, it looks like it was designed to hang clothes from a loop on the clothes, and for that it works fine.So, if you need an exclusive robe hook and your robes have loops to hang from, this is a very well built and stylish piece of hardware.

My kids got a kick out of the seemingly endless list of things it says it can do on the container, but it appears to be pretty much true. These towels are for when you need an extra agent to clean a tougher mess. I have been using them in my kitchen, mostly to clean our granite tops. The trick to these things working, and removing some pretty tough stains or dried on goop, is to give them some time. If you work over the area you want to clean long enough, the chemicals in the towels will eventually loosen up or remove pretty much everything they say they will. Just need to let the fluids soak in enough. I was surprised I was able to remove pen ink and even sharpie marks.The towel size is handy, but I could work with something smaller for my needs. The material is more plastic-like than soft cloth. It isn't designed so much to soak things up, but to deliver a cleaning agent. So, for example, they doesn't pick up crumbs very effectively. Still, as a way of cleaning off a build up of tough stuff on your counter top, they work very nicely.

My corgi sheds a lot. I try to wash him as often as possible, but often that may mean a month or more between washes. So when I had the chance to try this product, I was definitely interested. I've used it twice and I believe it makes a difference. I think it is getting more fur off him during the wash because I do not see as much loose fur coming off him afterwards. It definitely leaves a nice smell that does appear to last at least 2 weeks, like it says. His fur seems softer, too.So, if you have a dog that sheds heavily, and you're like me, you will want to try anything to get more fur off each time you wash. I believe this does help. It's not a miracle potion, but it does seem to get the loose fur out better than just by shampooing. And it makes your dog smell nice, too.

This is the 4th Network AV receiver I've used the last 4 years. This is also the highest specs/most featured one. Previously I was using a Denon AVR-X100, before that an Onkyo TX-NR515 and before that a Harman Kardon AVR 2600.Pros:1) 7.2 ability - I believe my Harman Kardon had 7.1, but I didn't have the speakers for it. Now I do and I love 7.2 sound. My set up uses 2 high and wide speakers up front. For movies and shows created to use 7.1, the effect is epic. I wasn't sure if it would make a difference, but it did and it's nice to have. The ".2" means you can add 2 subwoofers, which I'm beginning to really get curious about......2) Easy set up and network connectivity - This is something that has been improving with each new receiver. Lately it seems like I just have to connect to the network and everything just shows up. I think DNLA enabled devices are the easiest to use. It just seems like everything that can be used is easily found with no extra tinkering. Wireless and bluetooth work fine, too3) Good internet streaming source list - Good list and includes Slacker, my favorite. The Denon had the fewest choices4) Auto speaker set up software - This is something my last 2 receivers had and I really like it. You use an included microphone to get the best sound adjustments. This model of Onkyo uses their own version of software but it is unclear if it is a version of Audyessy. While I like it, read on in the Cons about it5) Lots of connectivity options - I think this is what you get the more you pay. This one has plenty of HDMI in and 2 out. I know my Denon did not have an input for our Wii, which used RCA connectors, but this one does.6) Zone 2 - This would be an important feature for me because I also have outdoor speakers I use as Zone 2, but I am now using my old Onkyo as a dedicated outdoor amp. This Onkyo has a powered Zone 2 feature (important if you don't have a separate outdoor amp). I haven't tried Zone 2 on this amp, but the previous Onkyo remote had a Zone 2 controls I never did get down. There does appear to be some changes to this Onkyo's remote, so maybe they made Zone controls easier (maybe other reviewers can touch on this)7) Good sound - I am not an audiophile, so I can't go into the technical aspects of this receiver. All I know is that the thing is powerful and it sounds great. It helps to have a bunch of good speakers, though. I think if you just need a really competent AV receiver, this level of specs/features has just about everything you need. They claim it is future proof because it supports 4K video, 21:9 display format, HDCP 2.2 and a bunch of other stuff I'm not really up on. But, I guess if I get them in the future, I'm ready8) Workable smartphone app - I actually prefer using it to the remote sometimes. It also impresses your friends at parties the first time they see you use it9) UPDATED 1/6/15 - Watched a few movies with Dolby Atmos and it sounds awesome!Cons:1) Auto sound settings software - In my review of the Denon, I praised the ability of the Audyssey MultiEQ XT. Onkyo has been a client of Audyessy for a while, but now they are using either a completely new software of their own or a modified version of an Audyessy product, AccuEQ (the fact they use "EQ" in the name hints it might be an Audyessy product). I do like the AccuEQ, but not nearly as much as the MultiEQ XT. It lacks the "3D" effect of sound seemingly coming out of nowhere, filling the entire space from all directions. I miss that. AccuEQ is good, especially handling 7.2 speakers, but it just doesn't have the same sonic effect on my ears. I will continue to tinker with it, but it is a let down (of course, if you never used Audyessy before, this will still seem like a big improvement) UPDATE - 1/6/15 - Dolby Atmos provides an awesome "3D" effect, but not all movies have Atmos, yet.2) Lack of ability to display anything but music from network sources - This is an odd inability. It took me forever to confirm it wasn't built to do it. My last 3 AV receivers could do it. I expect a network AV receiver to display images (though none display video from network sources, which also seems odd for an Audio Video receiver). To add to the confusion, when searching network sources, it lists audio, images and video categories, and search results will show (and take time to download in the list) image and video files, but if you click on one, it doesn't work. I really think this stinks, especially for the level of model it is. I can still get images, but not video, to display, but I have to go to a connected device (Roku, in my case) to do it. I really can't believe this inability from this receiver3) Poor user interface - This is really an industry wide issue. I have yet to see a truly easy to use and understand user interface. It's take a long time to figure out where everything is, how to get there, what it does and how to use it. In addition, there is inconsistency in the graphic design. Why can't any AV receiver manufacturer create a user interface that is easy to use and looks cool?4) An issue with the volume button - Perhaps it has something to do with the mix of components I'm using, but if I don't turn on the TV, DirecTV box and receiver in a certain order, the volume button doesn't work right. It "flickers" between mute and volume. I figured out that I need to turn on the receiver, then TV then DirecTV box in order for it to work. I can remember it, but it's hard for others in the house to do itBottom line is, if you are set to upgrade your system and spend some money on a good network AV receiver and want it to last a long time, being compatible with new technology as you add it in the future, this is a very good receiver to buy.

I have been using an Eneloop charger for years and I can tell this one is faster (haven't timed it, but it is noticeable). It also gets hotter, but I assume is because of the faster charging. I don't necessarily need an audible beep, so, to me, this is not a big feature. This kit included 4 batteries, but they were 1400 mAh, which are relatively weak. I don't know if they were just being cheap about it, or they wanted to make the charger look faster when you charged these, but it would have been nice if they included some stronger batteries (standard Eneloops are 1800 mAh), especially at its price.I want to mention I was fooled at first by the lights. It starts off red, and the first couple of times I tried my Eneloops in the charger, I thought it was telling me they weren't compatible. I figured it out. They are compatible.

Does it soak up water? Yes. Is it convenient to use? No.Pros:1) Soaks up waterCons:1) You have to keep it damp or it dries up hard as a rock2) You are supposed to keep it rolled up, moist, and stored in a plastic box3) If you try opening a dry, folded towel before it gets moist enough to "unstick" from itself, you can actually tear the outer layer off (this is constructed with 2 outer layers and an inside of cloth mesh)4) Hard to wipe anything with because it is "sticky" on surfacesIf you regularly have a situation where you need to soak up water, perhaps this is worth the requirements to keep it functional, but for me, it's too much to deal with.

After getting an electric corn popper for Christmas, we've been trying to find the right type of ingredients to make really good popcorn (why does it seem like microwave popcorn is still better?). Most of the retail popping corn we've tried from the local supermarket seem to have a moist or stale feel to them. This brand, however, comes pretty close to the kind of fluffy, crunchy texture we are looking for. Worth trying if you are on a quest for the best ingredients.

I have been using a Hoover Spin Sweep for years (on my second one) so when this came up, I thought it would be a good product to review. My review is going to mainly be as a comparison with the Hoover model.Karcher better than Hoover1) Cleaner pick up. The Karcher uses a single round broom in the back to scoop up debris and deposit it in the bin. It does a much better job of cleaning up what you roll over. The Hoover relies on the front 2 brushes to sweep debris into the bin and tends to leave a small line of debris from where the 2 brushes come together2) Better front spinning brushes. The secret of the Karcher front brushes is they are geared to spin slower than the Hoover's. This results in a gentler sweeping action that does not fling debris to the left and right like the Hoover does, especially the faster you walk. The bristles are softer and do a good job a simply moving debris under the sweeper to be swept up by the back brush3) Dust bin easier to empty. It just sits in place and you do not need to push a button to get it out or press down to click it back in place. The problem with the Hoover over the years is the bin lock can break because you are pushing down in the same spot to lock it back in placeHoover better than Karcher:1) Easier to push. The Karcher seems to have a lot of gears to turn and it is noticeably harder to push than the Hoover, which feels featherweight in comparison2) Better with large debris. The Karcher has a "twig catcher" in the form of plastic fins that are supposed to keep large objects out of the bin, but it tends to get clogged up. Since I have a lot of little twigs to sweep up, this has been something I have to avoid with the Karcher. The Hoover seems to be able to swallow everything.3) Brush bumpers. The Hoover has bumpers with wheels on the outer part of the machine that do an excellent job of guiding the sweeper around walls and corners so the brushes keep spinning. The Karcher's brushes are unprotected and you can easily jam them to a stop against walls4) Steering. The Hoover steers easily and goes in a straight line. The Karcher seems to have a mind of its own and you are constantly adjusting it to stay in a straight line5) Reach. The Hoover uses the front brushes in a single step to sweep debris up at the front of the sweeper, so you can usually get anything the brushes touch into the box, but the Karcher uses a 2 step approach and you have to travel the length of the sweeper before the debris get lifted into the bin. Imagine trying to clean up under a table. The Hoover would get everything as far as you can push, but the Karcher would need more room to travel to get the same debris.6) Containment. This is something perhaps particular to my situation. I have to move the sweeper up a step to cover the area I sweep. Picking the Hoover up with the handles angles the front up as I move it. It also angles the Karcher the same way. But when you tilt the Karcher backwards, some of the debris in the bin falls back out, onto the rear brush and gets stuck in there and ends up being redistributed all over the ground as you move it, You have do extra sweeping to get it all up. The Hoover bin stays contained and even helps, because as the bin gets almost full, it can start coming out the front. The Hoover has a bigger bin, too. Another annoying issue with the Karcher is if you roll it backwards, it actually can pull debris out if the bin is full enough for the back brush to catch it.At first I thought the Karcher was much worse than the Hoover, but as I used it more, I've come to realize it may be better for some jobs than others. It does a better job on driveway debris, for example. I really wanted to give it 3.5 stars.In the end, I would say use the Karcher if you have a lot of flat area with a lack of big twigs to pick up and you want a clean sweep (a garage floor would be good). But if you want an easier to push and guide sweeper that can pick up bigger and more debris, but not do it as cleanly, the Hoover might be better. I'm lucky to have both, so I can switch between the two depending on the job.

I have a 7.1 system and have been using these as my front 2. I am really impressed with the bass response and the separation of highs, mids and lows (ok, I'm not an audiophile). This is the third set of speakers I've had in the front position. My original Klipsch Synergy B-20s did a fine job (they are now my "height" speakers in the 7.1 configuration), then my Polk TSx220Bs did a better job (though not a huge jump) and now the JBLs are doing the best job.The thing about the Klipschs and Polks was they didn't have the "oomp" for the bass I would have wanted (lack of rear port hole on the Polks might have been part of it). The JBLs do, but it doesn't compete with the mid and high range notes. The thing that really caught my ear was when I was listening to music using just stereo, i.e., the JBLs only, and I could have swore the sub woofer was on. It wasn't. The JBLs were producing a sub woofer effect all by themselves, yet it wasn't blending with the other sounds, muddling the sound. I couldn't believe it.I can clearly hear low, mids and highs. They do a confident job filling in the front position in a 7.1 configuration and perform even more admirably alone.The only negative I have is I am not wild about using a piano black finish because of the dust, but I'm not complaining.I wasn't sure I would hear a difference but I guess once you get up in price it does start making a difference.

I've actually owned 2 of these before and they didn't last more than 2 seasons. Still, the idea of being able to get a wireless read of your pool temperature is enough of a benefit to make it worth trying.Pros:1) Temperature reading is the same as the liquid tube type thermometer I have in the pool. Not sure if either is absolutely accurate, but you get used to the relative readings to know how warm the water is2) Floats around harmlessly in the pool, rarely getting stuck in one spot3) Nice to be able to read the pool temperature from inside your houseCons:1) Stops working or loses signal occasionally. Sometimes it's just hidden from a direct line view. Other times I've had to open the floating part and check the batteries (which were fine, but started working afterwards). It sometimes loses signal but starts working again on its own. My experience has been this is the way it is2) Incredibly hard to open the floating part. It is necessarily a tight fit to create a waterproof seal, however, there is nothing to grip onto to turn it. You can hold the blue top ok (but it is wide), but the bottom is tapered and smooth and you need a significant amount of force to open the thing. I have had to resort to placing mine in a vice (gouging the bottom part) and using an oil filter clamp to turn it. Maybe it's just mine? Also, the direction the arrows indicate to turn are not clear and you could easily find yourself turning it the wrong wayI don't really care about the inside temperature readings or the 24 hour high or lows, so I haven't spent time testing if they are accurate.The bottom line is, there are not a lot of options to get a wireless pool temperature reading and having that ability is useful. So, it is worth a shot to get one of these and hope for the best.

I have no idea why this book is so entrancing, but it is. Animals count juggling balls up to ten. The text is very simple, and is a great reader for kids in K and first grade. The pics are bright, with soft pastels complementing them. I like how the numbers are shown in blue circus type, and then highlighted in blue when presented in the small rhymes in their word form (e.g."six"). I love the fact that on one page you can see a pic of a cat named "Gi-Gi" on a wall in a donkey's dwelling, and that Oliver the octopus wears a shirt proclaiming him as the world champion of juggling. All numbers are shown together on the last page. I loved this book when I was small, and read it to my kid constantly when she was small. She loved it. She is now twelve and knows how to count. Copyright 1970.

A book that gets overlooked, despite the fact that Trina Schart Hyman illustrated it. Owen is some kind of Christian warrior. I am pretty sure that Hyman was a Jewish one. Tells the story of a grapefruit's journey, from infant to oldster. And, hey, once you're picked and sold, that's it, baby. Owen wrote this book so that kids would appreciate the wonder of nature and hard work, either seen from a follower of God's point of view, or a follower of Pan's if you skip page fifteen. So, yes- you will find the word "God" on that page, and her message at the end of the book clearly shows her devotion to God. Hyman illustrated it beautifully. I love her touches of detail that complement her homey visions of life. In the grocery store, she displayed many brand names of her own creation, including a cigarette ad! I get a kick out of that. (I am mentioning that fact for sensitive types.) She added a countryside train, which appeals to kids of either sex and all ages. Kids will enjoy the pics, but not the prose. A grapefruit's life is boring. Copyright 1962, United Church Press.

I was not lucky enough to have this book as a kid, but my kid was! Perfect for K'ers and first graders. Terrific for kids struggling with reading. Print is medium-sized and easy to read. You can practice counting as well, and kids enjoy the competitive antics between the animals that ends in a big crash. Sixty-three pages of fun. Written by Dr. Seuss when he wasn't drawing racist cartoons. Buy used so you don't support his descendants.

I am so embarrassed that I just discovered these bombs via an eleven-year-old kid. Anyway, this is my fave. Nettle comes flyin' out, along with seaweed and salt that you can discern working it's magic. Smells of sea, air, clouds, and of calmness that will create waves if you enter any packed room after use. This one makes you butter and better. Lush me up anytime.

One of their bestsellers. Water starts of pink, then morphs to eventually purple. Mica brings the stellar stuff on. I do not remember what floral additives were floating around, but I do remember the scent. It is to die for. Very calming yet heady. You will smell heavenly. Wish it was edible.

For old-fashioned gals. Rose is what you get with this bomb, and rosy skin to boot. You will smell like a Victorian, and be as soft as a chinchilla after use. Smaller than the other bombs, and the price here is very high. Yes, it does leave rose petals and various leaves in your tub after the bomb disintegrates. I just forced all the debris to one end of the tub, picked up what I could with a rag, and then I picked up the remains by hand. It is easy. I am used to cleaning up after everyone. Get this one if you want to smell vintage.

Just like decades ago, this stuff still delivers. I have never seen this style of Dubble Bubble sold to the public in this way- if you wanted this type, you had to insert a quarter in a machine to get six to seven pieces of chewy manna. Now, you can get this gum from dollar stores in bags. So glad that they did not change the recipe. Here's to the late seventies!

When my husband showed me these gumballs yesterday, it took me back to being six-years-old, staring with hesitation at these gumballs in the machine in the lobby of the supermarket. I remember finally trying one, only to be disappointed by a strong artificial taste. Well, I am glad to report that after thirty-six years, they have improved. Delicious. They are big, so even some adults might want to chop these in half before consuming. (When you do cut them, they are totally manageable.) Dubble Bubble was created in Philly and so was I.  I am devoted to this brand that I grew up with (in Jersey) because it is the fuel of kids with knee boo-boos and of adults clinging to bygone days.Note: Can get at dollar stores.

You got your sparkles. You got your pink. You got your soft scent inspired from preteens in the late eighties. Reminds me of Mr. Bubble. Perfect for kids, preteens, and teens. Not my style, but someone else's. Under eighteen.

Very odd, yet seductive. I do smell the plum...but commingled with Coppertone! O.K., there is brown sugar, vanilla...this one is true! I can smell all the advertised scents in this stuff. Yeah, I still smell Coppertone, but that's at first sniff. Who's up for tanning with an artisan dessert right now?! Or a sunburn with a Hostess pie? My pale stomach is growling.

How this brings me back...this is from the "Era of No Microwaves". The fact that you cannot see the popcorn kernels themselves, but the foil chamber filling to an almost-explosion just adds to the anticipation. There are special instructions to make this stuff on a gas range or camp stove. The butter component was not false, but I was not too jazzed by it either, as I wanted my experience with this stuff to be as close to my memory of it as possible. Yeah- sans butter; just salt because we had no microwaves to melt butter, and we were just trashy enough to avoid doing it on the stove. Here is some more info:-Do not pop on glass top, ceramic range, over charcoal grill, or an open fire.-Follow directions exactly, or it will burn. Get two.-Contains milk.Sometimes being older is being retro.*This is a take on their slogan.

Obscure eos that we missed in the stores. Ours was fresh, although the box had been opened for some strange reason (I did report that). They do smell like watermelon and passion fruit- well, whatever that smells like...smells good. Definitely makes lips softer and kiss-ready. All natural, which we love. We have never had the mold problem that some people complain about. (I am planning on looking into that one day.) Perfect set for gift giving. Or for yourself!

I'm with Simone. Worst one we have ever owned, and we bought ours in a hurry, too- from a dollar store. Swing-tops do limit the amount of trash you can put in. You have to constantly push down trash to accomodate for the swing-top's movement within the can. I forgot about this. However, our problem was that bags- no matter what brand- would not fit the width of this can. The bags were constantly falling within the can. Very messy to deal with. We didn't even mess with the lid. It was a joke, as Simone said. Try to get a trashcan with an upward sliding door. Not this one.

This book is adorable. Just like everyone else stated, this book shows the reader how kids from across the globe get to school. All kinds of transportation- even a Skidoo-, horse and buggy, skis, and a radio, too! (I did not mean to rhyme there, but that is how the book is written.) The kids going to school have names, except for a few. I love that California has a skater! There is the map at the back, like someone else stated. Nice touch, and easy to use and to teach kids about our world. This book is suited well for K'ers and first graders- second graders will look, but the rhymes are so over for them at that stage in life. I love the fact that Philadelphia and Lancaster are featured parts of the world in this book (Baer lives or lived in Teaneck, NJ). Well, I am done, and I am glad that I do not have to get to school anymore.

Has a double wick. At first I thought that it had very little scent. For some odd reason, when this candle was placed in a bigger room, I could smell it in the hallway. I then realized that I do not even know what an actual blackberry smells like. Because I know it's not this! This smells like a teen designed it. Almost like candy, with some vague, sweet fruit backing it up. Pretty presentation, but pass-on-by scent.

Nobody in my home eats cornbread but me. Instead of buying a bag of cornmeal, I decided to try this stuff. Big mistake. I can't even explain it; it was just not good tastewise. I will say that it baked well. I used to make cornbread from scratch, even vegan-style, and a simple recipe never failed. This one did.Note: I have had other Krusteaz products before; this is the first time I had a terrible one.

Strangest sunblock I have ever used. While it does prevent sunburn, you can never fully rub it in. Even after trying your best to do so and then sweating, you will have patches of this stuff left on your face. Oddly enough, it makes you "sweat" somehow- I accused my husband of rubbing his sweaty arm on me, but it was my own sweat I was experiencing! Today my forehead was dry, but my chin was wet. Very weird. It's more like condensation as opposed to sweat. Plus, it gives you zits...it's non-non-comdogenic. I'm going to deal with it, but not on my face!Tips:-Sunscreens in the high numbers are shams. They just make us feel better. Anything like 30 is fine, but research this first so you do not blame me if you get radiated.-You do not have to put it on twenty minutes beforehand. Put it on as soon as you get to "Sunnyville".-You towel off, start over. Meaning, put it on again!-Try to be a vampire. Sunscreens do contain chemicals. Stay away from the sprays.

I loved this book, too, as a kid in the mid-seventies. How can you go wrong with an ass, a dog named "Hector", and even blood droplets released in the name of vanity?! The deal- Donkey-donkey wants to change the position of his ears after he compares his with Pat's. He tries; with disastrous  results. (The page with Donkey-donkey crying in the stable has stayed with me till this day.) The lesson- he finally realizes that he is hot when he gets a lecture from a bird on being himself and when a human girl declares him so. I love this book that has light humor. It affected me because at the time of me constantly perusing it, I was insecure about my pigeon-toed left foot, which is still turning in to this day. I have accepted my foot as part as me, and I think that it adds charm to my person. I am now married, so someone thought I was hot enough to keep. I owe it all to a man who left France for Gladstone, NJ. Thanks, Roger!"...and this story is finished."- Roger DuvoisonNote on illustrations: 1940; they have a vintage appeal with soft colors that are natural and farmy. Think: "fresh milk". Hope that helps.

So charming. I love the dayglo colors contrasted with the black and white spreads. Great as an easy reader, and the capitals teach emphasis (sometimes my kid screams words presented in capitals; she learned about emphasis in first grade). Plot is simple and sweet. Pics are as well. Vintage animals go straight to your eyes and heart. I almost put this book in storage for my kids' kids, then realized how wonderful this book is. Timeless classic that will be my daughter's reading homework tonight.

Best lemon cookie I have had. Not too soft, and not too hard. They are very simple and natural. There is even a recipe on the box for pie crust made with these cookies. They contain wheat and soy, and are made in a bakery that uses peanuts and tree nuts. You can get these cookies in South Jersey (U.S.) if you live in that area. I used to eat Ivin's ginger snaps, and they are great as well. Cookie perfection.

We just got Nancy from a thrift store. I had never heard of this brand of dolls, but was pleasantly surprised by her her high quality after inspection. Here's her stats:-Layered, golden hair with almost rose-gold and white blonde highlights.-About 16.5" tall.-Face and hands are made of soft rubber.The above pic shows you the rest of her glory. Perfect doll that does not cost a fortune.

Ah, what happened to the days when you could pretend that your pretzel stick was a cigarette? They are now toast. (Pun intentional.) These pretzels are not as I remember- fresh and baked. This time around, they were the exact opposite. Specifically, I think the light baking made them seem stale, even though they were within their expiration date. Darnit, all this moping has made me depressed and I now need a cigarette. Candy aisle, here I come!

I love trying new bizarre fabric softeners that my mom pays for. I was surprised to dicover that this stuff adds scent, but not softness. Fabric softener does eventually degrade fabric, so that is a plus if you do not want softness. It is very strong- so strong that it gave my daughter a rash and made the laundry room caustic with its astringent scent. It is the strongest scent I have ever experienced. I added some to a load of towels, and while they came out of the washer strongly scented, the scent had dissipated when the towels were removed form the dryer. For some reason, I can smell it on clothing...said air-dryed clothing did get a higher dose, but I do find it strange that the aforementioned towels had no scent whatsoever. No boost here.Update on 8/11/15: O.K., so I did other batch of towels with the same amount of "Fireworks", and this time they did smell good a few days later. (That whole "fresh for weeks" thing I will report on later.) However, I was picking up not only a hint of must, but also another scent that I can only describe as smelling of vomit. By total coincidence, I was reading reviews a few weeks ago on the "new" detergent, "Persil". Some people were reporting these same scents on their clothes after using Percil, so I am wondering if Fireworks contains some of the same ingredients as Percil, despite the fact that is not a detergent. The Fireworks bottle gives few clues; same for my quick Wikipedia search. Scent still very strong in air when in use, and does travel to adjacent rooms if laundry room door is left open.

Horrific with tiny pieces of bone here and there. Scares the hell out of me, for who wants to guess which bite could be their last? Just threw out practically my whole sandwich (minus three bites). Waste of bread, time, money, and sanity. May the mermaid hosting this terror tuna go to Davy Jones' Locker.

Was so excited to experience blue cake. I am sorry that I did. Not moist in any way whatsoever. Taste was very subdued- more like vanilla with a hint of blue raspberry, and had a strange staleness to it. No idea how; I am just reporting my experience. (The mix itself is not stale- this is an actual nuance I am detecting.) No one in my house will eat it, so it is going to our feathered friends. My wish to be seven again has been dashed.

Nothing like a simple, solid book that brings out the fanatics. Those type are my favorite! I mean the books. Kidding aside for a moment, it is shocking to me that anyone could have a beef with it. This book is a guide on how to handle death with honesty, gentleness, and learning that life is a cycle. My dog just died, and I read this book to my kid to let her know that she is not alone in her pain. It is everyday life with a cat funeral, cookies, bedside talks, gardening, and love. It's told in the first person from a young boy, and that combined with small details of a home make small listeners feel connected. Simple pen illustrations by Erik Blegvad add to the straighforwardness of this book. The afterlife conversation is quick and to the point, so I am not sure what the fuss is about. The dad in this book tells the neighbor kid, Annie, that we, as collective humans, are not sure if heaven exists after she refutes the fact that Barney is in the ground. Should he have lied in front of his son and agreed with her to placate her? Would the narrator have had a nervous breakdown, wondering how reality was bent so that Barney was not in the ground even though he witnessed the whole deal? We all know that burying the dead and the later decomposition is a proven process. Heaven, on the other hand, is not. Messin' around with untruths and kids is a future catastrophe played out in a comfy chair with this book on a coffee table in a therapist's office. This book deals with life and death. Why can't we?I hope the narrator invites Annie over to watch "Pet Sematary" while munching on pretzel sticks.Copyright 1971.*Includes statements and review title, more or less.

Gets out knots and tangles created by kids who endorse freedom of expression- namely, as street urchins or debauchers. This brush works for both. It does work gently. I am guessing that it is no different from the brushes that are from the small grooming lines. Kids can use with ease. Always does the job.

Best lotion I have ever used. We can only afford it when it goes on sale at "Whole Foods" after somene drops it and breaks the pump, but I can enjoy the high life for a while, can't I?! All natural, no scent, absorbs quickly, and hydrates forever. Does not "wear off". I have extremely dry skin, and this has helped greatly with regular use. My husband is extremely sensitive and it has helped him as well. He is allergic to tons of stuff, and putting this lotion on affected areas on his hands has somehow alleviated instead of aggravating discomfort. Put on and request caresses.

O.K., sometimes I purchase items despite their cons- the great looking but brainless husband, the fluffy yet ugly towels on sale, and this book. I love the fact that the font is huge and that makes it easier for beginning readers and their moms who hate fetching their glasses, but the rest is passable. Nothing grabs you- neither text nor the illustrations. It is akin to a preteen's effort. Basically, some animals want to change their looks, and decide to travel to gain different colors to effect that change. They use natural color sources to do so. A colorful parrot helps them see the light with a few uninspired words, they clean up, and they go home. That's the plot. Dragged out and enlightened by a creature related to prehistoric lizards. Three-year-olds will love it, but anyone older will be bored. I can't figure out how this book became part of the "Weekly Reader Children's Book Club", a club from the late seventies that I could not get into, or why big font impresses me so much that I throw caution to the wind. I will try to air out the thrift shop mildew scent and then send it on a trip to find a different owner. Copyright 1979.

I agree- what a sweet book. Encourages shy kids to reach out- or at least say "Hello!". Vanessa's mom tells her to take a risk and to try to make friends by just saying two syllables to her fellow critters. We got a kick out of Vanessa's first whispered attempt at a greeting, then her shouted, aggressive attempt that results in a fleeing toad. Those moments make for great out loud reading that make people laugh. I like the fact that a variety of animals are presented, not just one kind. Has pen and ink pics in shades of gray (excuse me- not fifty) as the one seen on the cover. Written by the chick who penned the "Nate the Great" series, and illustrated by Lillian Hoban, who brought us Frances the badger. Copyright 1979.

I just picked up this book of seasonal poems yesterday from a thrift shop. Perfect as a reader for brainy second graders and regular third graders. K and up will love listening to the rhythm of some poems, and the beautiful imagery in others.Some authors:Gwendolyn BrooksLee Bennett HopkinsDavid IgnatowEve MerriamMaurice SendakCharlotte Zolotow...and many more at the amazing price of .25 to $16,95 depending on where you can obtain it!O.K., O.K....Has colorful linocuts by Dirk Zimmer, famed for two of my faves- "In a Dark, Dark, Room and Other Scary Stories" and "Bony-Legs". Also has an index and acknowledges sources of the poems. Copyright 1983. Can't go wrong with this one.

Despite a good amount of prior reviews, I figured I would chime in. While these readers are not "Dick and Jane"- it's that famous repitition that made great readers - I liked the fact that my slow-to-blossom reader was not overwhelmed with many sentences/paragraphs on one page. This made her reading sessions more enjoyable. There are some odd words here and there, but not enough to give up. Let's face it- some words cannot be sounded out, but have to be memorized. Constant exposure to those difficult words will hopefully help, so constant reading is where it's at. The bright, cheery pics help, too. Affordable price doesn't hurt. I compared these readers to "Bob Books", and, as you can see, went with this set.Here are some extra tips:-Wait a long time if you have to for the kid to read a word. I learned this from a speech therapist with a Ph.D.-Use the strategies that teachers provide- "chunking", looking at pics, coming back later.-Some kids' brains do not "awaken" at the end of K like most kid's brains do. My kid woke up just now (end of first grade).-If you are worried, tell the teacher. My kid is still reversing some letters, and is using caps and lowercase letters in strange places, or together in one word (e.g."aPpLe"). She is also still reading aloud "no" as "on". I plan on telling her second-grade teacher these facts, even though she was already tested for reading problems and found not to have any.(They did discover that she needed a speech therapist, so it can't hurt to request testing. Reversals can happen up to second grade, but after that it is something that should be looked into.)Examples from the books:Longer sentences: "At the playground, I get around!", "I have a hat that is tall."Obscure-to-kids words: Donuts, pasta, crawls, grilled, gull, acorn, half-circle.Words that can be figured out from pics: ribbon, stickers, scissors.

When I saw my husband reaching for these cookies, I instantly thought of boring, standard grandmothers. Well, guess what? They taste like those types of grandmothers. I am being generous here- technically they have no taste, but symbolically...yes, deceased, female elders. Hey, not all grandmothers are boring. Rejoice if you have or had spicy ones with cookies that had that extra somethin'.

She got to travel to the big city and wear a dress that tied at the back after pneumonia, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, and acute renal failure. C. diff just added to the learning experience, plus she now has a dark spot under her eye that gives her that certain emo look. Three extra visits to the local ED made her privy to the world of phlebotomy. She even gets to use deodorant like her big sis, possibly because of ingesting antibiotics a couple shades lighter than Melanie's shirt. Her sister, vaccinated since birth, has yet to get to eat ice cream while hooked up to machines that monitor your body's functions. Her grandfather got to do the same stuff in 1956 with rheumatic fever that still affects him today at age sixty-nine- a keepsake from an Austrian refugee center.This installment in the series is dedicated to Steph "Dark" Messenger, who is overjoyed that a vaccination for strep throat does not exist.Amy Steele lives in Sticksville, North Carolina, United States, and devotes her life to making her older child even more autistic with future vaccinations in order that she can facilitate employment for said child in the "Silicon Valley" and relocate to Polynesia. She has the support of many secondhand books and havoc-minded relatives.

I have been washing clothes for twenty-eight years. I've tried 'em all. My husband bought this the other day half-priced at our local supermarket. I was expecting nothing. Well, after using this stuff I almost fainted. It smells so good! It is strong, so if you are sensitive be careful. However, be prepared to have your socks knocked off...(or cleaned, if you will)...For years now, I have been wanting to do the detergent challenge. So, I did, for my sanity and yours. I do not think that the seconds that elapsed between coatings of chile sauce are a biggie. I tried to move as fast as possible, and as fair as possible. The chile sauce is "My Sweet Hottie"- either our husbands or Tom Selleck, your choice depending on your day.I tested: this Fab, my homemade stain remover, Purex, the cheaper Tide- ("Simply Clean and Fresh") that you can get at dollar stores, and Shout stain remover.  I tried to upload photos, but failed. If you want to see them, I can try again, so just ask.The results amazed me. Fab did the best. My homemade stuff is usually the bomb. If you want the recipe, just ask. It does contain the usual Tide, so that is shocking.All I can say is: Fab is fabulous!
Delicious, and great for people on diets. Plastic is BPA-free. Just one squirt is all you need, and you get twenty-four in each bottle. You can adjust if you want to. Kids love it, and I do, too.

Our vet gave us this clay "disc" with May's print already on it. To be frank, she had already passed on when they got the print, so I am guessing that the task was easy. Just keep that in mind. We followed the instructions exactly, and the clay baked perfectly. The instructions call for the clay disc to be baked for a certain amount of time if it is 3/8 of an inch, and ours was already that thickness. We do not have an oven thermometer, so we were not sure of the exact temp, but it turned out fine. Our oven is about two and a half years old, and we did it for the maximum twenty minutes. If your clay is thinner or thicker than 3/8 of an inch, then you might have to adjust baking time, so measuring it first is a good idea. You can decorate it beforehand or after baking. I loved the fact that a few of May's hairs were baked right into the clay. It just adds to the holiness of it and makes the memento that much sweeter.
