Stellan Skarsgaard is the older guy who hears her story, with compassion and genuine concern, a scholar with issues of his own.The version I watched has Part I at 2 hours and Part II at 2 hours, 4 minutes. I understand a longer version is coming available, but, in my experience, there is not a wasted moment. It's riveting at all times. It's episodic, and each episode makes its mark with profundity and plot, edited in a way that kept things flowing quickly. I wasn't bored for a minute, unlike the previous two films, though Gainsbourg shines in all three.Von Trier has a definite feel for the subject matter, sympathetic without sugar-coating the more "honest" flow of events. There are courageous performances from all, eschewing any preconceived personae: Shia LeBoeuf, Christian Slater, Uma Thurman and Jamie Bell, as well as powerful appearances from Willem Dafoe and Udo Kier.  Much admiration for Stacy Martin as Joe's younger self, setting the scene for a scenario that will blow you away. I have no end of admiration for Von Trier's film. He's not a happy man, but, instead of being depressed all the time, he's put his life on film, often in ways that baffle and confuse and create fear, but it's who he is.Other directors do this in an artsy-fartsy way that challenges the viewer to guess what's going on. Von Trier's done that a few times. But "Nymphomaniac" is a straight-forward narrative that had me intrigued at every moment.The sex scenes were performed mostly by porn actors, and in the long run, it's not so much about the sex act as it is about how it's overcome our attitude toward love, trust and understanding.Despite all the bad press, etc., there are a few others who saw the film in a positive light. Von Trier finished his trilogy and shoved it in your face. I wish him well.

I was worried that my old reliable fave, Mr. Koontz, was in a rut. I have every book available that he's written, and he's had his winners (Shadowfires, Dark Rivers of the Heart) and his clunkers (Cold Fire, Dragon Tears). Well, I couldn't be more pleased than to announce that my go-to guy is back on track with a true winner, Innocence. Rarely has he written a character with so much humanity, compassion and dignity as Addison, who, like Odd Thomas, reluctantly finds himself in a joint effort to save the world. The difference is that Addison, due to unfortunate circumstances, has been somewhat of a hermit for most of his 26 years, and facing the world at large is daunting. He knows only too well that evil exists, and has spent his life avoiding it. Along comes the seemingly carefree (and very independent) Gwyneth, who has her own demons to cope with, and a bond is formed.Koontz often goes off on philosophical tangents that neither add to nor enhance the goings-on, but he keeps that at a minimum here, and has created a compelling and fast read. I'm a very sporadic reader (usually a chapter a night before I sleep), but I had trouble putting the book down.  Good guys are very good, and bad guys are very bad, but there are a few characters that keep you guessing on which side they fall. All in all, it's the best book by Dean Koontz in many years.

Gregg Araki is always interesting, and most of the time I didn't know where he was going with "Kaboom". At times I thought he was writing it as he went, but then I'd notice references to previous stuff and before I knew it, I was totally engrossed in the goings-on. I won't deny that there are certain continuity issues, but nothing major enough to keep me from liking the loveable character of Smith (Dekker), and the journey he's destined to take. Smith's character is written so well, slowly coming to terms with the events of his life, and relying so much on the support of his friends (and those, on him). It's a tight circle, and there are twists and turns and frustrations, culminating in the only logical ending.I enjoyed "Kaboom" on many levels. I was never bored for a minute. I knew Araki would involve me in his roller coaster ride, and I wasn't disappointed. As weird as it got, the straight-forward enthusiasm of the fine cast never let up, and I was pleased with the film as a whole. I haven't had so much fun in a long time. Lighten up, nay-sayers; it's only a movie...and a fun one, too.

James McAvoy has finally gotten away from the good-guy stereotype to which he'd been subjected. This is a courageous, complete performance, worthy of awards. The film itself is unsettling, making light of corruption in the police force, and how much a guy in power can get away with.I admire this film on many levels, and it made me angry, sad and enervated as it progressed. Quite humorous regarding some of the quips and comments, but I wouldn't label it a comedy.There are lots of rotten cops in the world. This is only one, brought to magnificent life by McAvoy, whom I've always admired, and now think he's world-class. Bravo!

I think that, after the brilliant "LOTR" trilogy, the novelty has worn off. I also think that turning the small book into a 9 hour trilogy may be excessive. Still, the fantasy lives on in this "LOTR" prequel trilogy, and episode 1 is quite entertaining without being redundant. Peter Jackson has proven he has a penchant for humor ("The Frighteners") while sustaining intrigue.I have absolutely no problem with this film. The technical achievements alone are worth a look, and Martin Freeman is an excellent Bilbo. I'm glad to own the Blu.

I saw the film because of it's award recognition, but I can't say I enjoyed it. The claim that "art is subjective" certainly applies here, as it does in other films that I absolutely adored (Alain Resnais' "Last Year at Marienbad", John Frankenheimer's "Seconds" and others). I was younger then, and was less subjective about what entertained me.I think the hallucinogenic approach to the goings-on left me quite flat, though Amy Seimetz' unflinching performance was nothing short of brilliant.The Blu-Ray I watched offered no extras or commentary that may have shed light on Shane Carruth's vision or purpose. That was disappointing. Maybe I'm jaded in my old age (65), but I had no end of enjoyment and admiration for "Cloud Atlas".Without being cruel, someone tell me what I missed. Maybe, at my age, I have a lower threshold regarding futility and hopelessness.

I, too, was given a free copy in exchange for an honest review. I told Mr. Dalton outright that I wasn't a sci-fi fan, but he talked me into reading it. I did. I also decided to read the other reviews, and agree with some, not others.Some of the advanced terminology left me empty and a bit lost. Some of the forced humor sounded "cutesy", especially some of Ranyk's outbursts (nonetheless, enjoyable). Why couldn't he just keep his big mouth shut!?It's a popular ploy of authors to build up a bunch of suspense, and then end a book with no resolve, so that others will buy the next one in the series. Of course I wanted to know what happened to the characters, and I guess I'll just have to wait.One thing that was annoying was that the 3 main aliens (Ranyk, Sckiik, Dr Perinath) weren't described very well, so it was difficult to envision them in my mind. Exoskeleton? Were they insects? I could only envision Dr Perinath as some incarnation of Maleficent with spikes and scales. Those characters are important, but I had trouble 'seeing' them.Dr Perinath came off as manipulative and evil, and then I started seeing good, solid qualities about her that made me genuinely care.No one else mentioned Sean, who I thought was a terrific character and quite likeable. I think my favorite character was the misunderstood, abused and much-maligned Gill. Why did Sckiik and Ranyk hate him so much? At the end of "Houses of Common", he came off to me as being a hero. He was so bullied, and it made me like him even more.To Mr Dalton's credit, I was given a scenario of great suspense and intrigue, and after 370 pages of "set-up", I'm ready for more. As complicated as it is, I didn't have too much trouble following the basic narrative, and I thank Mr Dalton for that. Good job. An exciting ride.

The wonderful and terribly underrated Linda Fiorentino finally has another chance to shine in this thoughtful revelation from Kevin Smith. You have Affleck and Damon as fallen angels, Jay and silent Bob, Salma Hayek, and Alan Rickman (in all of his magnificence) in a very unorthodox, unsettling (to some, maybe) display of a potential Rapture.I'm sure most of the devout will be offended, but it promotes a thought that I've had for many years, in that the separation among religions will never make sense until we all realize there is one God, and He might get pissed off of we all try to separate ourselves from each other. The dialogues among the angels involved make so much sense, in that respect.I'm endlessly in awe of Smith for this effort. I wish his further endeavors would've been better, after showing how original and profound he can truly be.

A magnificent new world is, once again, created by magician Wes Anderson. This film had me from the start, with Anderson's usual display of controlled insanity, and this MUST be his best achievement. Anderson has his own regular crew of stock performers (Murray, Balaban, Schwartzman, Swinton, Keitel, etc). Add to this the lead character, Gustav, impeccably and totally portrayed by the masterful Ralph Fiennes. I haven't been as impressed in many years.Special mention should go to Tony Revolori, perhaps the best straight-man, while holding his own.Anderson's manic narrative is never slow, and some of his stock characteristics are ever-present. I haven't had such a good ride in years, not to mention the downhill sled-ride.Brilliantly written, edited and executed, not to mention excellent tongue-in-cheek performances from all of the supporting characters, this is my favorite film of the last few years.Unfortunately, it was released too early in the year to be given serious Oscar contention, but, awards aside, I can't recommend this film highly enough. Fiennes should be nominated, as should Anderson and Best Picture.UPDATE: Lots of Oscar noms and wins. Deserved more. My fave film of 2014.

This is a review about the achievement of Steven Soderbergh and excellent acting from the ensemble cast.Liberace was a narcissistic and manipulative celebrity who used (and paid) everyone around him to satisfy his own extreme indulgences. Scott Thorson was as much to blame for his own selfish indulgences, though he may be forgiven due to Liberace's promises of success and grandeur.Who's to blame, here?BEHIND THE CANDELABRA is based on Thorson's own account of the events, a somewhat sugar-coated narrative of a poor guy trying to find a level of success in a world of deception.Sexuality aside, this is a story about a relationship founded on manipulation and promises...many promises. Liberace wanted Scott to look like him, convincing him to have plastic surgery. This alone makes me think Thorson was more involved in the relationship than may be thought.There aren't many things about Thorson that are pretty (besides him) and his big-money foray into drugs is well explored.Were the drugs the reason why Liberace dumped him? Was Liberace tired of him, looking for "fresh meat"?All of these events are well portrayed in BEHIND THE CANDELABRA, as realized by screenwriter Richard LaGravanese, and very well presented by Steven Soderbergh. It's pretty much of a no-holds-barred expose, with two unflinching performances from Michael Douglas and, especially, Matt Damon. Douglas handles the role well, free of too-much caricature but with most of the flamboyance that WAS Liberace. Damon was the best, with a lot more change of attitude and character as the film progressed. Douglas won all the acting awards, but Damon had a tougher (and bigger) role.There's no nudity, and a lot of reference to gay sex preferences, but at the end, it's the story about a serious relationship that wasn't meant to be. Whose fault? Decide for yourself.Excellent support from Scott Bakula, Dan Aykroyd, Rob Lowe and (unrecognizable) Debbie Reynolds added to the sincerity of the narrative being presented, and the sets and costumes were all you would expect from a film about the excessive Liberace.Not for the prudish, I would recommend this film to anyone who thinks they might make it in Hollywood, unscathed.

Sid Caesar didn't make many films, but he will always be remembered as one of the great originals from television's Golden Age, along with Milton Berle and Ernie Kovacs. I enjoy this film on many levels and, though dated, still offers loads of entertainment and fun. Barry Gordon, one of the most popular young stars of the 60's (A Thousand Clowns) is always fun, and scream queen Vera Miles (Psycho) is on board, too, offering reliable support. The entire supporting cast is loaded with character actors of the era, all totally enjoyable, including John McGiver, Mary Wickes, Jesse White, Jay C Flippen, and a host of others.Kick back and relax. You'll have a good time.

I've seen all of the National Parks, and Olympic is in the Top 10, a gorgeous place with three separate eco-systems. I'd set aside 3 days to see the park, but could've stayed longer. This DVD by Holiday Films is as complete as it needs to be, whether to tempt you to go, or to reminisce with after you've gone. I enjoyed it a lot, with great photography and clear narration. The extras are very good; I especially liked the Olympic Music Video segment, as well as the brief sojourns to nearby Mt St Helens, Mount Rainier and North Cascades. Also great info about the In-Park lodges.This is definitely worth a watch, and I'm glad to have it in my Nat'l Park DVD collection.To fans of the "Twilight" series: Forks, WA, is a real place and you have to go through it to cover all of the park's glory. A nice town, with lots of shopping opportunities.

Superman and Superman II (Christopher Reeve) are the only ones of that franchise that are any good, and they're excellent.Superman Returns (Brandon Routh) offers a very handsome new guy in the role, as well as an extremely villainous Lex Luthor in the hands of Kevin Spacey. I'm very happy with this collection, and it looks terrific on Blu.
This is good, but only covers 6 years. Good to have it, but waiting for an update.

Excellent suspense, thanks to Andy Muschietti, a disciple of del Toro. It's a great first directorial effort. Jessica Chastain is the hero, almost unrecognizable in her black wig, but as full of vim and vinegar as ever. Nicolai Coster-Waldau is beautiful as ever in a dual role. The little kids are terrific and the terror level is on high at all times. Very creepy and loads of fun. The Blu effect adds a bit of creepiness. Recommended.The cabin in the woods is particularly creepy.
Totally silly and fun. A classic example of buddy comedy. Cult classic status, glad to have it. Blu looks great.

This TV film is loads of fun, and constantly has you guessing what's going on. Nothing is as it seems. It's a little tacky, and silly, like every Stephen King adaptation. I had no problem enjoying it. Nancy Travis makes a change in character that may happen too quickly; Matt Keeslar handles the heroics well, as does the entire cast.It's fun. Check it out.

Ship of Fools was the reason I bought this; the Oscar-nommed cinematography (black & white) is stunning on Blu. It's a great film,with terrific acting and great direction by the master, Stanley Kramer. Nommed for Best Picture and many others.Vivien Leigh's last great role.Lilith was OK, an early performance from a young Warren Beatty and Jean Seberg. Not very interesting or exciting; Robert Rossen directed, but missed something essential to make it as riveting as it might be. Beatty tries, but is miscast. Seberg is an intriguing actress, but her career didn't flourish to her satisfaction and she eventually committed suicide. Pity.It's an interesting combination, but the films have nothing in common.

A great film, on any level. I bought the Blu because it seemed to be the thing to do, for a film freak like me.I'm not disappointed, though my DVD was every bit as good; some greener greens and some pinker pinks, otherwise, it's the lovely film it's always been.

I visited Barrow, Alaska, last year, and then bought this film on Blu because I heard it was filmed there. I liked the film a lot, but the Arctic Ocean doesn't freeze until about October, and it's already dark there. Also, no alcohol is allowed in Barrow. Ever.I liked the film a lot for it's message, Photography is great, and the participation of native Alaskans is commendable.Decent acting, and a terrific story about saving the whales. Unfortunately, many scenes filmed inside Pepe's restaurant are archival because it burned down in 2013. A great restaurant, a sad loss.I liked the film on many levels.

This was entertaining, but it's basically about mean or ignorant people. The song "Let It Go" didn't knock my socks off, and if it wasn't for Olaf, I could've turned it off earlier. I like animated features, but thought "The Croods" was more fun, Oscar-wise.My favorite Disney film is "101 Dalmatians", but after it came out (and the re-makes), dalmatians were so over-bred that they are now considered dangerous around kids.Let's hope snowmen don't become inbred.

I really wanted to like this film, because I'm a fan of Damon, Foster & Copley. There was something wrong, maybe with the script, or direction, but I simply wasn't riveted; I wanted to be blown away, but it didn't happen. Great premise, good attention to tech effects, but the characters were entirely uninteresting. The actors did what they could, but without a coherent script or any sense of forward movement, how can they make this into entertainment? Maybe I didn't "get it", but I watched the whole thing and wondering "Why?".

The horrific murders of 500K Indonesian citizens is well examined in this very upsetting doc, which uses interviews with the murderers. The only reason these people aren't in front of war trials, is because those murderers won in the takeover of the government. They were given free reign over the developments, and the depiction is outrageous, cruel and unsettling.These moments must be exposed, and hopefully cruelty and the complete absence of humanity will be brought to surface.Indonesia is a very Islamic country. None of the murders were due to religious reasons. The power given the militants was simply out of control. Not for the weak.

I don't know if BluRay adds to the simplicity of the profound film achievement, but I'm so glad to have it in my collection.Brilliant acting, superb editing, carrying the multi-plot devices that Altman is known for, and a somewhat improvised screenplay by Joan Tewkesbury, all add up to one of my absolute favorite films. If I had to pick favorite actors, they would be Keenan Wynn and Barbara Harris. It's also notable that Keith Carradine's Oscar-winning song, "I'm Easy", plays an integral part of the drama. Most Oscar songs are simply "thrown in", or played over credits. Carradine's song has a tension and power that most don't realize.The beauty and poetry of Altman's direction is how he can find dozens of characters and, somehow, make all their lives interact. He brought this idea to perfection in the brilliant "Short Cuts".I LOVE this film, and the great Altman.

Very enjoyable, with good lessons for kids, laced with the current rebellious sensibilities of kids as they may relate, suggesting it's an age-old phenomenon. Voice performances from Nicholas Cage, Emma Stone, Ryan Reynolds, Catherine Keener, Cloris Leachman and all provide a narrative of strength, intelligence and survival.Great animation, good story and endearing characters. Dialogue is especially sweet, especially from Cage's befuddled father. He's wonderful.BOTTOM LINE FOR KIDS: Parents are cool. If you don't think so now, wait a few years.

Upon the demise of the wonderful Robin Williams, I realized I have very few of his films. Of course, I have "Garp", but it's a horribly edited version of the original, which I saw in the theater; there's no "real" version of it on DVD. I ordered this Blu, and am completely happy with it. The insanity of it all looks terrific on Blu, and I'm amazed it didn't get an Oscar nom for Visual Effects.Kirsten Dunst was fresh off her auspicious debut in "Interview with a Vampire", and is a natural. All of the kid actors are good. Jonathan Hyde is also impressive, playing a dual role (a psychological subtext).I always thought director Joe Johnston was under-rated. He handles the very complicated material in a way clear enough to be easily understood. I recommend this film, to show how Williams brilliantly combined manic and serious in a most enjoyable entertainment.

This is a remarkable film from Kenneth Branagh (star and director). He was married to Emma Thompson at the time, and the chemistry was terrific. I bought it because I remembered the (unbilled) performance of the late, great Robin Williams. Excellent support also from Andy Garcia and Derek Jacobi.It's one of the most complicated, intricate plots I can recall, and all is handled beautifully thanks to fine direction and excellent editing.There are red herrings, plot switches, flashbacks, and gender-bending, all kept together by Branagh, creating an exciting and riveting narrative. It's also the first (as I recall) serious dramatic performance from Robin Williams, perhaps channeling inner demons, and it's a knock-out performance, unbilled when released.

I'm a huge fan of 50's schlock horror. In the 60's the schlock was a little over the top, and by 1970, that schlock I loved so much really went down the toilet. The Drive-Ins were hurting, and some last ditch efforts to revive them didn't help with films like "Carnival of Blood", one of those sad trashy exploitation films that signaled the end of an era. The whole idea isn't new, and has been done so much better. The photography is tacky, and the acting is more laughable than anything from the 50's. A slight moment of inspiration comes from Earl Edgerton, in a flashback scene. Memorable is the performance of Bert Young, an Oscar nominee for "Rocky" in '76, after he changed his name from John Harris, probably to remove himself from any connection to this overly dismal attempt at entertainment. No surprise that director Leonard Kirtman never made it; Ed Wood had a lot more style.The reason I bought the collection is for "The Undertaker and his Pals", a silly, campy film I remember seeing at the drive-in. It's tacky, yet somewhat clever, and lots of fun. Director T.L.P. Swicegood seemed to have more sense of direction regarding the flow of events. It's apparent that all involved were having nothing but fun. The DVD transfer was also far superior to that of "Carnival" (though, if I did drugs, "Carnival" might've looked "cool"). The bottom line is that "Carnival" was boring, and "Undertaker" held my interest.The price is right, and I'm glad to have "Undertaker" in my collection.

I wasn't sure what to expect, but I was amazed at how important this film really is. Body-image seems to be so prevalent today, and plastic surgeons are cleaning up. Patrick Moote has laid it all out, courageously, to discover the answer to the age-old question, "Does Size Matter?". There's no clear answer, though any thinking human would know that substance of a person is most important.The subject is one that, I'm sure, is of interest to many men, to beware of quick-fixes, pills, and witch doctors...as well as implants. This info is equally important to women. It's a $5-billion industry preying on innocent, good people. Patrick Moote compares his penis to a female with an A-cup. He goes all-out to find out how he can correct this, and travels the world to get opinions. Some of it's amusing, other parts are actually frightening.The DVD is wonderful, and the extras are great, especially an interview with Dr. Dunas, and an extended interview with Dan Savage.Anyone with a body-image problem should see this film. It's straight-forward, honest and to the point. Little is left to speculation, with no nudity. A few graphic scenes, but most are blurred out. The film is presented with honesty, sincerity and great information about being who you are, and not whom you think you might be. Just be yourself, and be the best person you can with what you have.Mr. Moote is endearing, and quite adorable.

I'm not a huge fan of science fiction, but Mark Henrikson's "Origins" is so original and well-written, that I couldn't put it down. As outrageous as the plot may seem, Henrikson creates believable characters doing unbelievable things. What if aliens built the pyramids? And how did they do it? With that age-old premise, Henrikson runs with it. His interpretation of the plagues of Egypt and the role Moses played are also explored in a very entertaining, non-Biblical way. This is the first of a series, and tied up just enough loose ends to leave the reader craving more. I plan to check out the whole series.

I'm a fan of Friedkin's groundbreaking film "Cruising", and was satisfied with the way the film was presented, as a good murder mystery. Apparently, the ever-adventurous Franco and Mathews thought that the 40 missing minutes would be of interest for those looking for sensationalistic gratification, and thought, even more, that anyone would really care.  What the producers attempted to do is quite lost in its resolution. Those 40 minutes may have been segments, bits and pieces, that Friedkin left out to secure an "R" ratings.Franco and Mathews decided it was all porn stuff, and created a documentary about, well, porn.The leather bar scenes in Friedkin's film were as complete as they needed to be. This film was a boring attempt to recreate something that may or may not have happened. I give it one more star than it deserves, for the dedication of the actors involved, some of whom are straight.

This is a ground-breaking, multi-Oscared film that is fun and innovative. Robert Zemeckis (Forrest Gump) somewhat perfected the art of animation mixed with live action, though "Mary Poppins" did it as well (20+ years earlier). Having seen it's initial release, I thought I should have this in my collection. Certainly, it's clever and cute and fun, and Bob Hoskins' performance is outstanding, but if it was a live action film, it would only be mildly amusing. There are some clever lines, and Kathleen Turner's Jessica Rabbit is spot-on, but it didn't blow me away.I know I'm in a minority in my opinion. So shoot me.

One of the greatest cult classics of all time, the studios didn't know what to do with it. Small early releases resulted in an amazing rash of critical acclaim, and a wider release and an unusual money maker for the studio. What does that tell you? It tells me that the studios don't really know what the hell the public wants. I like this film a lot, and nerds like myself aren't afraid to laugh at ourselves.It's a sweet film, hilarious and sensitive at the same time. The Blu transfer doesn't really make a huge difference, but it's still a film I will watch again, often, for the feel-good sensation. Great cast, dedicated to the premise that nothing is more fun than little guys beating up the hierarchy (in this case, the jocks). We all know people like this. Let's even the plane.

OK, it got bad reviews, but I found it entertaining with lots of action and fun stuff. I especially like Rihanna in her butch, tough-as-nails role. It may not be as artsy as "Pacific Rim", but there were fewer dull moments. I enjoyed it a lot, and with lots of popcorn and beverages of choice, you might, too. What I liked best is that it didn't take itself so seriously, and the entire cast looked like they were having nothing but fun.Lighten up, folks. Kick back and enjoy.

So many documentaries are serious and give feelings of dread and angst, and then there's this uplifting story about undiscovered wonderfulness.  I was immediately taken by the pace and presentation, wondering what would happen next. I didn't have to wait too long. The presentation, led by interviews with family, created an enigma right to the actual introduction to the wonderful Rodriguez.Is America the land of opportunity? According to Rodriguez, it is. He was led to all kinds of promises, only to be let down by the powers that be. He was never fazed by it, rather used his talents to create a life of peace and happiness.What the big-shots didn't count on, was the overseas market, and Rodriguez was an idol in South Africa (long thought deceased). Imagine HIS surpriseThe rest is history. A wonderful and terrific story about an American hero, after the fact.This is, quite simply, one of the great feel-good movies I've seen in a while. Knowing it all happened only heightens that, and knowing Rodriguez, as the very humble and unassuming person he is, lets the viewer know that life, as it is, ain't so bad.

This is one reason I stopped watching NBC, when the execs kept pulling shows like ED and CROSSING JORDAN.ED is and always will be one of my favorite shows. Tom Cavanaugh was adorable and sincere in the role, and the entire supporting cast matched his sincerity in creating a lovely and complete scenario of regular people like you and me.I crave this show on DVD, and you'd think the studio would like to cash in, regarding the hundreds of positive reviews here on Amazon. NBC has been digging its own grave for years, and the execs are simply not paying attention.

I was given a preview copy to review, so I'll not mention the spelling and grammatical errors; hopefully, this was corrected in subsequent editions. Mr. Garza has a writing style that is quite attractive and committed, with descriptions that were clear and exciting. It's apparent that he was writing with purpose, and loved his material.The book is only 200 pages, and a quick read, broken down into 3 sections. The first (and longest) section sets the scene and introduces us to John, Angela and little Alex.  I was hoping for a little more background as to why John loved Angela so much, as she came off (to me) as an unstable and totally unpleasant harpee, with no redeeming qualities whatsoever. At the same time, John came off as an insecure, subservient (read: whipped) wimp who didn't seem to have an original thought of his own. Those first 100 pages got a little tired after a while, and John was annoying me quite a bit.The second section suddenly has John stuck in the city, trying to get back home. Suddenly, he's Rambo, showing clever heroics and meeting some almost cool characters (though there was no real development for these characters). I was hoping he would become someone to admire, but, unfortunately, he went back home and succumbed to the domineering Angela (the third section).As I said, Mr Garza's writing style is intense and interesting, and the plot was a little more original than most zombie stories, but it was hard for me to care about any of our lead characters. By the end, I really didn't care what happened to them, though the twist ending was interesting.I will read more by Mr Garza. I'm sorry to say that this effort was lacking in character continuity.

I'm not a huge baseball fan, but this coming-of-age tale about a boy and his dreams is so loaded with passion and drive (and a little pathos), that I can't imagine anyone emerging from this experience unmoved. Seen through the eyes of a little Hispanic kid, he confronts issues like racism, bullying, rivalry, the importance of family, and, most of all, a kid's natural curiosity revolving around his hero and idol, who happens to live across the street. Our kid's no slouch, and he's smart enough to let the ugly attitudes of the privileged roll off his back, as he focuses on his one passion: baseball. Mr. Hazelgrove well examines the resiliency of kids, and the necessity to focus on what's important, as Ricky learns his life lessons. Excellent characters throughout, from his feisty and independent mom to his baseball idol, now a grizzled and cranky old man. I won't give any more away than that, but I recommend this book highly. It's an easy and fast read, loaded with humanity and an innate joy of life. Another great achievement from the talented Mr. Hazelgrove.

Mr McNally had a good thing going, from the first page. Interesting (and very original) turns of events made my think that I'd be introduced to a "new" neo-folklore, as the first readers of Frankenstein or Dracula were introduced to. The folklore is what I craved and was quite riveted by the turns of events...and then Mr McNally copped out. Aliens and military conspiracies? Really? Aw c'mon...After a satisfying build-up, I was so very disappointed that McNally took the "easy way out". The evil spirits were in place, the oddities were groundwork for all kinds of ancient curses (or whatever)and McNally had a wealth of options to keep this tale in the realm of a new folklore. Instead, he took the easy way out, and opted for a tidy, albeit trite, solution. It might've even been a good old-fashioned ghost story.I also got this book in the mail for free, seeking a positive review, and that's why I'm giving it one more star than it deserves. I liked the characters, and wasn't upset when major characters were killed off early on (as others were), thinking it would all resolve as interesting as everything that went before. Descriptions of the bleak surroundings were well conveyed, there were likeable characters and the book had just about everything going for it, til the last few chapters.The chapters were short, making it a fast read for a sporadic reader like myself. I finished it in record time (for me). Mr McNally has it in him to create ghostly worlds, and his grasp of the supernatural seemed so natural and so very original. After so much good stuff, I was sorely disappointed that he didn't show more originality at the end that was so prevalent at the outset.McNally is a good writer, and I will watch for his next endeavor.

The premise sounded interesting, and after I started reading, it was difficult to put down. Certainly, this book may be guilty of TOO much plot, but Mr Krisch methodically and carefully laced together all the seemingly loose ends to create a cohesive whole. I admit I had trouble remembering the many characters, and trying to keep them straight (mostly the random townspeople) but the good guys were well portrayed (I would've liked more of Greta).Without giving too much away, the juxtaposition of the Underground Railway and the Great Depression showed many parallels, a history lesson of sorts, about man's inhumanity toward man. I enjoy the supernatural elements a lot, and it was enhanced by the profound displays of good vs evil. The unpleasantness of it all was also well explored, which got a bit disconcerting at times, especially when innocents met their demise.Mr Krisch has a style that is straight-forward and not the least bit pretentious. Other reviewers complained that it was too brutal, but I thought of it more as being realistic; nothing was sugar-coated. Those were cruel and desperate times, and Mr Krisch had a terrific handle on the subject matter being presented, not to mention the very original central plot regarding the underground. I was riveted from beginning to end. I will definitely be reading more by Glen Krisch.

This is a fun film; Sven is lovable, and you want to cheer for him. He didn't win that one (NO spoiler there), but his grit and determination is well explored.I've met Sven at his terrific Hostel in Fairbanks, and in winter, he's in Bettles giving sled tours with his dogs. He's a true outdoorsman and is excited about just about everything, especially his dogs. Worth a look.

Mario van Peebles is to be commended for making this tribute to his father, Melvin, a pioneer who tried to get away from the Balxploitation trend of the 70's. I never saw the film in question, but Mario did a fine job of exploring the obstacles of producing an Indie film with a new idea. Melvin attempted to give the Black man dignity, after all the craziness of the period, and the Sweetback film was difficult to get out there. This film is fun and frustrating and funny...Mario did a great job. Melvin's film is a cult classic.

I must admit, Heneke likes to create confusing scenarios that keep the viewer watching, and then he doesn't deliver. Thank God, it wasn't longer than it was. It's a lovely relationship, but doesn't really show the power of their love, which, after all, is right there in the title. Emmanuelle Riva won awards for her performance, probably because she's old, has a fairly good body of film performances, was nude at 86 and puked on herself. Jean-Louis Trintignant has even a more impressive film resume (at least in the US), and carried the entire film. Everything was from his viewpoint. He was wonderful, but not recognized by any critics' groups, even a nomination!You would think a film about old piano teachers would have some music, but there was none besides some lovely Schubert moments. Isabelle Huppert, the gorgeous sex siren of yore (Death Becomes Her) is very fine as the concerned daughter.Certainly, the husband's descent into madness, as Haneke interprets, wasn't as complete as it might've been. His final decision didn't make a lot of sense. He had love all around him, from family and friends. That's the Haneke question...what pushes someone over the edge?

I've seen lots of films about the Jewish Holocaust, and am always in awe regarding the profound display of man's inhumanity toward man. I just now watched James Moll's 1998 Oscar Winner, and was quite taken by the individual witnesses' accounts of their own personal tragedies. This is one of the best, quite personal and riveting. It centers on the plight of Hungarian Jews, which hasn't been focused in previous docs.I read a few 1-star reviews by those who deny the Holocaust, and I'm saddened by the fact that, with all the physical evidence, such an idea could perpetuate itself. "The Last Days" is definitely worth a look. A fine documentary film achievement.

I wasn't sure what to expect, but Adam Scott carries this film to unexplored heights. I haven't seen a display of devastated love so completely realized. I've been there. Mr Scott is one of those guys who annoys mercilessly, worse than a mosquito, yet has levels of intensity that settle into mild comfort and, eventually, genuine normalness, becoming loveable. The script is so well layered that you don't know whether to laugh, cry or cringe. There are only really 4 characters, and all are good; Brittany Snow, Alex Frost are wonderful, and J.K. Simmons is outstanding as the father, endearing, with issues of his own.It isn't hard to get into this film, as it's so well written, acted and edited. The somewhat generous DVD extras will entertain. Check it out. A bittersweet love story, that has no answers...just like life.

This VERY low budget Indie by Sean Baker won the prestigious Altman Award for 2012. I was compelled to find out what the fuss was about.Imagine my surprise; a well-written, well-crafted, simple story about integrity, good intentions and issues of the elderly. I won't give away some of the more sensational plot-points, but the plentiful DVD extras explain that first impressions should not make one judgmental regarding the true make up of a person. The talented Mr Baker lets you know these people before adding an interesting element that may shock some (I found it mildly amusing).Dree Hemingway is remarkable as Jane, a girl new to the San Fernando Valley, staying with friends while she establishes herself. She buys a thermos from a cranky old lady at a yard sale (the magnificent Besedka Johnson), later to find out there's $10K inside. This makes Jane uncomfortable, and she attempts to find out if the old lady might really need that money, a guilt-complex that results in an adventure of stalking, friendship, fondness, understanding and genuine love.At age 85, it was Johnson's first film role, and she handles it like a pro. It's Jane's integrity and perseverance to know this old woman that is the gist of the film, a sweetness that can't help but move the viewer. It's a beautifully controlled relationship starting with suspicion, mutual interests, leading to genuine caring. I was totally taken in. The film still resonates with me, though I saw it over a week ago.I won't give away the other plot points, but there are terrific supporting players; Stella Maeve as Jane's stoner best friend, Melissa, and James Ransone, great as Melissa's manic, stoner boyfriend.It is to Mr Baker's credit that he let you know the sweetness of Jane before he drops the "bomb", about one-third into the film. A great lesson to not judge people before you know how good they can be.It's "Not Rated", so be prepared for some surprises. A delightful film, in many ways, and a landmark film in pacing and development.I admire "Starlet" very much.

If only being duped by The American Dream was this amusing! Our hero, Dale Hammer, is an Everyman, knocking himself out to create a better life for his family. His musings on the simplest things are genuine and from the heart.There's really not a plot; rather, Dale's first person narrative explains how he got into the mess he's in, and hasn't a clue how to get out of it. Nothing is sugar-coated, though his spot-on metaphors are quite amusing. He has to figure his outcome by himself; his father has been a poor role model, his brother is an over-reactive liberal, his wife is tired of his ambivalence, and he's surrounded by impossibly clueless suburbanites, with few exceptions.I don't want to give away the story, but I'm a slow reader and finished this one in record time. I was taken in completely, and enjoyed the ride. Recommended.

Mr Herzog admits at the beginning that he's against the death penalty. Many people are. This is probably the only time he's given a personal societal opinion in all of his excellent documentaries. Even in "Grizzly Man" he never said the protagonist was the ignorant idealist that he was."Into the Abyss" is well made and well presented, and I was riveted at all times at the careful procedure that Herzog used to present the grisly subject. Guilt is not the question; rather the events leading up to it allow the viewer to make his own decision. The film ultimately is about the death penalty, though Herzog allows a lot of room for speculation.It's a good film and an important one, and we need people like Mr Herzog to show us the unpleasantness of life, in his honest attempt to show life as it is (or as it might be).Herzog had 2 fine films in 2012, the other being "Cave of Forgotten Dreams", quite fine. I admit "Grizzly Man" annoyed me for its subject, but I beg anyone to say "Encounters at the End of the World" wasn't intriguing.Herzog is good at what he does, and I will look forward to his next endeavor.

I love movies that show the kids to be smarter than the adults. I love most everything by Wes Anderson, who always seems to find a scenario that delights and make one think. How he comes up with these ideas is a wonder, and he never fails to amuse. (The Oscar nom for screenplay attests to that.)The use of color, and that little element of fantasy is something I always look forward to in a Wes Anderson film. The BluRay does not disappoint. Glad to have it to watch after a disappointing day. A true upper for the senses.

I was looking forward to getting an aquarium DVD to play at work, as a novelty. This is about as good as it gets, crisp and clear. Wonderful music, etc.I wanted to get a "looper", that would play, non-stop. This was not really what I wanted, but it's as good as you can get.Beautiful.

How refreshing that this film comes from a land rife with strife. The jokes are at the expense of the academic hypocrisy and the situation is amusing. No reference to political situations are brought to light, which was gratifying to me. What's here is the eternal nonsense of the academic effort to achieve honor over reputation. This is universal, and I'm happy to have seen this film.What I found special was the devotion of the son to his ignored father, and the dilemma is well explored. I enjoyed it a lot; deserving of the Oscar nom.

I'm so glad I was put in touch with The Three Doors. From the first page, I was drawn in to a world of intrigue that wouldn't let up.I am a slow, sporadic reader, but I found myself enthralled by what might happen next, and finished it in record time (for me). At 500+ pages, I must admit that there were very few slow moments. Mr Holland has created a world, well thought out, with multiple characters adding their own very individual motives. In a nutshell, it's a story about good vs evil, and there's little question about who's what. Both sides get a working over, and I was convinced that the good guys' plan wasn't well established, but when time is of the essence, our crew did what they had to do. On many occasions, just when I thought everything might work out, there was another glitch and further excitement was in store.Another reviewer suggested that this was a "Christian" book, though that might be a misnomer. Though there's an effort made by Christian people to combat evil, it's really an effort of a bunch of good people doing what they have to do, more of a moral dilemma than a religious one.Our gifted hero, Jared, is quite endearing. One would think he's got it made, but he's very aware of his vulnerability. Indeed, the power of true evil has him a bit shaken throughout, but he's a young man of conviction and purpose. Most impressive. I liked the way all of the many characters were given their own, solid identity. Albi was especially good, though I would like to know more about Iris, and what made her so profoundly desirable. She almost seemed vapid at first, but eventually proved to be a good catalyst to Jared's motivation.For such a big book, I'm amazed at how quickly I got through it. A solid beginning, an eventful middle, and an ending that left few questions, make me think The Three Doors is one of the most enjoyable rides I've taken in a long time. I repeat, never a dull moment. Highly recommended.I will make an effort to read more by the talented Brian D Holland.

The Nazis will never come to Holland, right? Wrong. This astonishing film by Ben Sombogaart depicts how powerful is the work of evil. Twin sisters, separated at birth, are convinced that they will be together again, though the ultimate get-together doesn't seem to happen. There are secrets, deceptions, heartbreaks and everything imaginable to bring this wonderful film to an unnerving climax.This is not your usual Holocaust film, a surprise Oscar nominee. It's a film about hope. Ugliness abounds, and the hopeless feelings of shame and helplessness are so perfectly portrayed, that I found myself liking most of these characters, very well written.Acting is exceptional from all, and Sombogaart draws us in slowly and perfectly, creating a canvas that isn't pretty, but perfectly compelling.Highly recommended.

I admire director Marc Forster a lot, especially after the brilliant "Finding Neverland". He seems to long for the appreciation of misunderstood persons, and is usually successful. His James Bond effort left me a little baffled, but "Machine Gun Preacher", despite its crazy title, just didn't work for me. I'm thinking the main problem was Gerard Butler, who was either hot or sweet, and there wasn't much grey area. Michelle Monaghan and Michael Shannon were reliable in their respective roles, but our protagonist was never really convincing as a good person.The plight of the poor kids was the most interesting element, but everything else about the film left me wanting more. Mr Childers may be a fine man, but standing beside a church doesn't make you a Christian any more than standing in a field makes you a farmer. Childers' transformation was superficial, at best, and needed more explanation to make this viable to a thinking person.I saw a film about a confused, misdirected guy who was looking for his next rush. He didn't seem to know how to be his own man.

I bought the new version of this dress in Indigo. I love it! The color is a deep purple/blue. The color matches what I saw on my monitor. The fit of this seasons Coco dress is a tad larger than last seasons (I have the teal one with stripes across the front). The sleeves are a couple inches longer and there is a bit more room in the arms and through the hips. I bought my normal prAna size L. This style makes me feel younger than my 57 yrs! Great for those times when you don't want to wear a fitted or semi-fitted dress. The tag says to wash on cold and lay flat to dry. Such a cute dress!

This dress looks amazing on my hourglass figure. I love the flared skirt of the dress. Also, the embroidery in the back is lovely! It fits like my normal size Large from Prana, maybe a bit more room in the hips. The blue color is beautiful and the fabric is soft and flows nicely. Awesome dress!

I bought the green top in a a size L. The fabric is soft and flowy, it does CYA, I am 5'8", size 12. I find the fit somewhere between the photo of the model wearing the green top and the over-sized blue one. I normally wear a L or a M, depending on how roomy it is. A medium would have been too small for me in this one. It looks great with leggings! The color did bleed some when washed, so wash alone the first time. Awesome cotton top.

I bought the Cinder color in a size L. I love this top! I am 5'8" and the sleeves are super long as is the length. It's longer than I thought it would be, and that's a plus, it's as long as some of my summer dresses. It looks great with leggings. The fabric is super soft. This is a light weight fabric. Love the hood too. I just ordered the blue one. I could live in these tops!

This is the first item I have tried on that has a blend of acrylic and nylon. I found the fabric to be scratchy. I have a prAna dress that is a cotton/acrylic and that is soft. The 'purple tart' sweater colors were lovely though. I found the fit to be boxy and short, not quite like in the photo where it appears to be a slimmer fit and a longer length. I bought the size L. I am 5'8" so maybe it would work better for someone shorter. It is a well made sweater, just not for me.

I am very disappointed that the shirts still bleed the colors after 10 washings. It would not have cost much extra to have used a chemical to set the dye. I need to separate these shirts out of the normal load and wash them separately. Too much trouble. I won't be buying these again. They are going to the garage to be worn for car repairs. The colors and the fit are great, too bad they keep bleeding out the color in the laundry.

I bought the pink version and it's super cute, what a fabulous summer dress. The bottom is twirly :) The fabric is very soft, the pattern is awesome and the dress just flows over your curves and the bottom swirls and flows with you when you walk. The pink is a purple/blue based pink I wear either a medium or a large depending on the brand (always a L in prAna). I bought the L. It fits great in the bust and a little big in the waist area, but that's the style of the dress. I am a 36C, 5'8" tall, 170 lbs or so. I was worried it would be a bit short on me but not at all. This dress is a winner!

The seam goes across the bust instead of underneath, so it just isn't made for me. I usually wear a medium in Columbia and the dress fits like their mediums. It was soft and the length was great for me at 5'8". If the seam landed under the bust it would have been a winner. I had to send it back.

This was a gift and the recipient said that the shirt runs about 2 sizes smaller than it should be. I thought I was safe ordering the 2X (they wear a 2X in Champion or Russell brands etc), but they said it fits like an XL. Maybe the shirt was tagged wrong. The fabric is soft and the design is great. It just didn't fit them.

This was a gift and the recipient said that the shirt runs about 2 sizes smaller than it should be. I thought I was safe ordering the 2X (they wear a 2X in Champion or Russell brands etc), but they said it fits like an XL. Maybe the shirt was tagged wrong. The fabric is soft and the design is great. It just didn't fit them.

This is a large tote. I love the yellow pattern and design, very cheery! It holds about 2 loads of laundry. The long handles make it so easy to put on your shoulder to carry. Very well made and should last for years. Love it!

This is a great laundry tote. It's extremely well made and should last years. The large braided rope handles are awesome. It's bigger than I thought which is a nice surprise. It holds about 2 wash loads. I like to fold the clothes after they come out of they dryer and this tote is great for hauling them upstairs.

This is the 5th pepper mill I have bought and it's the best I have used. I do find it is a little hard to turn the top when grinding which is why I am giving it 4 stars. It actually grinds fine to coarse! The other ones I bought wouldn't do that. The OXO was one of the worst ones I bought. I found chunks of the ceramic grinder in my pepper! The Unicorn is easy to fill and with a twist of the knob underneath the mill, you can easily change the grind from fine to coarse.

The dress is poorly made as another reviewer commented. The seam under the bust also came apart - before I even tried it on. The colors are more muted than what are shown here, more dusty grey purple. The fabric is soft. The length of the dress hit just above my knees, I am 5'8". There was too much fabric under the arm area, and where the empire seam is, so the size I ordered was too big. Depending on the brand I wear a medium or a large. After seeing the dress with the seem apart at the same place as the other reviewer mentioned she had in her dress, I cannot recommend this dress, even for the sale price I paid on amazon prime day of $22. This was my first Aventura purchase and I was disappointed.

I wear a size medium in this brand (size 10/12). The red/pink color is bright and fun for summer. The medium fits as expected, maybe a tad large in the body but that's the style of the dress. It is fitted in the bodice and flows out from there. The fabric is soft and airy. I wanted a dress that wasn't fitted as most of my dress are. This is a nice addition. I am 5'8" and the "hi" part of the dress hits just above my knees and the "low" part is at the top of my calves. I would say this dress is not figure flattering but is comfortable and cute.

This is a great red dress. The red looks to have a pink base to it and the stripes are a maroon color, very pretty! The fabric is super soft and the criss cross back is very cute. The cotton and modal are top quality, has a great hand feel. I could sleep in this it's so soft. I bought my usual prAna size L and I found that this dress runs a half size smaller than their normal size L dresses. After being worn for a couple hours the dress did stretch out nicely to a more flowy fit. The length is great, hits about 3" above my knees, I am 5'8". I wasn't sure if the dress style was too young for me (at 57) but wth, I love it, it makes me happy and that's what counts.  I enjoy wearing this dress so much that I might buy it another color!

I bought a size L and it fits like a prAna L. In other brands I can wear a medium. This is my first Merrell dress and I think it is very cute and well made. The back is awesome. The pink color is a lovely blue/purple based pink. The waist of the dress is more of an empire waist, and I am short waisted so it would be even more of an empire for a longer waisted person. I am 5'8" and the dress is 3" above my knees (in the L size). A fabulous spring/summer dress grabbed at an awesome sale price, thanks Amazon!

At first I was skeptical, but this really works for me. Don't expect it to work like a Dremel tool. If your callouses are thick, the Amope Pedi will seem like it isn't working, as it takes a small layer off at a time. I would use a really coarse emery board (100 grit) and do it by hand first. Then use the Amope Pedi once a day to keep the callouses down. I really like this. My husband likes to use it once in a while, but mostly he uses the Dremel. And sometimes I can hear him cuss when the Dremel works too well. I will stick to using the Amope Pedi, much more delicate and less likely to injure yourself. I needed to replace the batteries that came with the unit after about 3 weeks of almost daily use. The original roller is still good. I bought another package of two rollers and put them on my subscribe and save to arrive every other month.

UPDATED~I changed my review from 3 stars to 4 stars. I did re-order in the size L. It fits great and it arrived with no holes in the fabric, and I paid $27 so it was a much better deal than my original purchase that arrived with a hole in the top.***************I love Mod O Doc tops. I usually wear a medium in this brand, but the medium in this top was too tight, and there was a small hole in the back. I found the color was nice (cinder), and the fabric was soft. If there was no hole and it fit I don't think it was worth the price I paid, $42.00. I did not reorder in a bigger size. I have not bought anything from 6pm, LLC (fulfilled by Amazon) before, but I probably won't again because of the hole in the top.

I bought the blue and white top. The blue is really pretty, true to what I saw on my monitor. I bought the medium and had to return it for a large. I have 3 other tops in this brand that are a medium, but in this shirt the medium was super tight. The large is still fitted. The fabric is soft, the rouching is cute and the length of the sleeves are good for me at 5'8".  I bought this on sale for $22, awesome deal Amazon.

This jacket is great for my NW weather. I love this jacket! I bought the dark raspberry color, it's beautiful and super soft, better than I expected. I also bought a size larger so I could wear layers if needed. I have the shorter version of this jacket and I love the omni-heat and knew to buy an xl. My usual size is L, I am 5'8"/165 lbs size 10/12, and the sleeve length is plenty long.  It is a very light weight jacket that is perfect for packing in a suitcase. It provides plenty of warmth. I wore it in 24 degree weather with a light shirt and mid weight sweater underneath the jacket and was plenty warm enough. I still had plenty of room for more layers if needed. Sometimes a two way zipper is tricky to use, but not this one (I have a Columbia trench coat that is). This is an awesome jacket!

This is my favorite workout video (I do it 3x week). When I first started, the warm-up was enough intensity. After a week I was able to add a few minutes of the low impact. Every week I could add a few minutes more. Now I can do the warm-up, low-impact and hi-lo sections back to back. I like the cardio blast section too - I am working up to doing the whole section still. I have done the step section and it's a great workout, but my knee doesn't like it so much. I do modify a couple of the exercises. Cathe is a great motivator. The choreography is spot on, the music is good and there is an option for vocals only which I use so I can listen to my own playlists. I appreciate that there is no idle chit chat with the workout crew, this is a serious workout with many options to suit your individual tastes or needs. I also really like her core max video, which I do a 20 minute section 3x a week, her slide n glide and Afterburn video.

Wow! What a great upgrade from the old style crank or squeeze handle sifters I have. This is so much faster! I just hated sifting ingredients before and now I look forward to it. I read that some chefs use a wire whisk to stir the ingredients while using this sifter and it makes it super fast, no shaking the unit. I store it on top of my kitchenaid bowl. I have not used it for fruit, only dry ingredients. Love it!

The Saucony Hurricane 16 fit true to size for me. I have been wearing Saucony shoes since the 80's and this is another great fitting shoe. My foot is on the wide side and these shoes are plenty wide in the normal width. Saucony's are known for a wide toe box. I always buy a 9 in athletic shoes (heels I wear between an 8-8.5, and a European size 38 in sandals and 39 in closed shoes). The size 9 in this shoe fits like my Hurricane 14 and 15 Saucony running shoes. This shoe has plenty of cushion. My calves and balls of my feet love the 8mm heal to toe drop so much better than the 12mm.Sometimes I have slight heel slippage and I fixed that with proper lacing for heel slippage (see below).IF YOUR HEEL SLIDES UP AND DOWN.(Create a more secure fit around the ankle without tightening the entire shoe).Technique:Lace as normal until one eyelet remains on each side. Draw the lace straight up on the outside of the shoe and bring it through the last eyelet. This will create a loop. Repeat on the other side. Cross each lace over the tongue, thread it through the opposite loop, and tie. The loops help to cinch in the material around your ankle to prevent your heel from slipping without making the rest of your shoe any tighter.IF YOUR TOES FEEL CRAMPED.(Reduce forefoot constriction by using four shoelaces instead of two).Technique:Remove the laces and measure them. Buy two sets (four laces) half that length. On both shoes, use one lace for the bottom three eyelets and a second lace for the upper three eyelets. The end result will be two bows on each shoe, allowing you to tie the bottom laces looser to accommodate your wider forefoot.YOUR SHOE IS TOO TIGHT ALONG THE TOP OF YOUR FOOT.(Use parallel lacing to secure your foot without putting pressure on the top).Technique:Lace the first two eyelets on the big-toe side of the tongue (not the first eyelet on either side of the tongue like you normally would). Bring the lace from the first eyelet straight across to the first eyelet on the other side of the tongue and push it through. Pull it straight up the side, skipping one eyelet, and thread it through the third eyelet. Pull it straight across the tongue, and push it through the third eyelet on the opposite side. Repeat until all eyelets are laced and tied.YOUR SHOE RUBS ONE SPOT ON THE TOP OF YOUR FOOT.(Eliminate pressure on a "hot spot" by lacing around it, not directly over it).Technique:Place a lipstick smear on your hot spot. Slide your bare foot into your shoe and take it out. The mark on the underside of the tongue tells you which set(s) of eyelets to skip. Lace your shoe until you reach the eyelet before the spot. Take the lace back under and pull it up through the next eyelet on the same side. Take the lace across and continue to lace. Repeat this on the other side. You'll have an empty spot on the tongue where no laces cross it, which should eliminate your pressure point.

About 30% less power in this new Kitchenaid than my older version I bought around 2003. I used it almost everyday and I think using it in hot soup was detrimental to the unit, so now I cool the hot pot of soup in a bigger pot of cold water before I blend it. I like the attachment blade for batter, it makes really fluffy pancakes! We use the S shape blade for soups and smoothies. The chopper unit works really good for nuts, but I generally don't reach for it and just use a knife for chopping vegies etc.Overall I am happy with the immersion blender but wish it was as powerful as my old one.

Moving Comforts new Chic Hoodie is just as soft as their two styles from last year (the Mock Turtleneck and Gotta Love It Tunic). According to the Moving Comfort size chart I am a medium, but the L in last years styles are very fitted (which I love). This new Chic Hoodie run a half size larger than last years. So, if you are in between sizes you could easily size down if you want a fitted tunic. This tunic has more fabric in the back shoulder area and down through the waist. The hip area is semi-fitted. I am 5'8", 162. The sleeves are plenty long and the thumb holes are extremely comfortable. The length of this tunic is long, maybe a bit longer than last years styles. The cowl/hood is fabulous, I love that. I bought the purple color and it's a deep rich color, very beautiful. Keeps me warm on cool morning walks, I add another layer if the temp is below 50. This is an awesome top!

The bands I received have NO writing on them at all, so either I need to memorize the color strengths or go by the feel of the thickness (the thicker the band the more resistance it has). They were not individually wrapped but arrived all together (with some powder to keep them from sticking to each other) in a small box that looked a bit banged up. The label on the box had the color and resistance for each band.It would be more helpful if it was written on the bands like in the photo/description here.These bands seem thick/strong enough that they won't break anytime soon. Even though they are 3" wide, they can still fold/scrunch up like the 2" ones. Mostly I use one (blue) going around both knees when I do dumbbell squats for more stability in my knees. I have to spend at least 20-30 seconds fiddling with them to get them to lay flat going all the way around. If it takes longer than that I use them scrunchy which hurts just like the 2" bands. So far they work for what I bought them for. I was using a long 6" band that was not looped but I knotted together to make one long piece. I was nervous that was going to come apart on me so I bought these. I also did a few hamstring curls with the bands and they had enough stretch and resistance for that exercise.Overall, I am satisfied with the bands after using them a few times this week. I will update my review if I encounter any issues with them.

I have used the Olay 'normal' facial cloths for years and tried the combination/oily last month. I don't like them! The cloth is too scratchy, it feels a bit like rubbing sandpaper on my face. Plus, I didn't care for the fragrance of these, much too strong. I have re-ordered the 'normal' Olay facial cloths which I love. They are soft, and mildly fragrant, they are perfect!

UPDATE:  The metal edge of the curler that pushes your eyelashes against the rubber pad is super sharp and has created a cut all the way across the pad. Luckily I saw this before it was too late and it cut my eyelashes off. I threw out the curler. I only saw this because I had on my reading glasses, I am sure that my eyelashes would have been cut off soon, the cut was deep.I have been using Shiseido's eyelash curler. This is an amazing curler. It costs around $20 at the department store. Spend a few dollars more and get a high end curler.***************The curler feels sturdier than my old Revlon curler. I really like the padded handles, it's much nicer on your fingers when squeezing and holding the curler for 10-30 seconds. The curve of the devise is perfect for my eyes, all my lashes fit into the curler. It did not pinch, I can get really close to the base of my eyelashes. My eyelashes are more curled with the Bella curler than my old one (my eyelashes are not hard to curl). The curl lasted most of the day without using mascara. On a day I apply mascara, (Lancome Difincils-my absolute favorite!) my eyelashes are less curled after the mascara is applied, so after it dries I will use the curler again and that sets the curl for the rest of the day. My eyelashes actually touch my skin under my brow they are so long and curled. I don't know it's this is the best curler made, but it's the best I have used. I've been using drugstore curlers for 40 years.I would have like an extra pad for the curler. The company says the pad will last the lifetime of your curler if taken properly care of. But what if it falls out into the toilet or you lose it? It's not like you can buy a replacement pad at the store or even from Bella. I would like to see Bella make available extra pads to purchase or at least include an extra pad with your purchase.You will get two follow up emails from Bella after your purchase, the first one is thanking you. Then another email asking if you received the curler and how to properly use it. And, if you love your curler would you please leave feedback. Also, you will be offered a discount on any other product they have, which at this time looks to be one other product.Bottom line, I love this curler. It is a five star curler for me!  But minus one star for not offering replacement pads to purchase or at least give you an extra one at the time of purchase.

One of my disks had a bubble under the fabric which was really annoying when I put my foot down on it, it made popping noises. So, I stuck it with a a pin and pushed the air out, now it's great. They are made in Taiwan. Also, there is a warning on the box that says "This product contains one or more chemicals known to the state of California to cause cancer, birth defects and other reproductive harm". So, good thing I don't live in California :)The gliding discs work perfectly on my cheapo carpeting and linoleum flooring. You will scratch your flooring if you have dirt/grit on the floor while using discs though. This presents an added bonus of burning a few more calories as you can use it as a warm up and clean your floor first, or just use it on your carpet!  These disks are smaller than the big name brand one in which you have to buy 1 set for your floor and another set for carpet ($40 for each set!). My gym has these and I find that the Gold's Gym sliders and just as good. Yes they are smaller, but you only place the balls of your feet on the sliders so your heels can be used for stability and braking.The dvd was an added bonus. There are a few exercises that are safe for newbie exercisers or people new to the gliders. A few of the routines are for more advanced in-shape people who have used the sliders for a while. I have used sliders in my gym class 2x a week for 10 months now and there are exercises on this video that I can't do yet, and a few that I won't do because I know I will hurt something. At 56 years old injuries take longer to heal than when I was 40, so I try to be careful. I also lift weights 3x week, and do a couple other cardio things.The gliders are great for cross training. I have gained a lot of core strength using gliders. My legs are so much stronger too, I can feel and see the muscles now. I have also gained strength in my back/shoulders and arms from using gliders with different plank exercises.These are awesome gliders on my carpet and flooring, I highly recommend them (unless you have expensive Berber type carpet, other reviewers said they don't work on that).

I love this top. I bought the blue glass in a size L. Sometimes I wear a medium or a large. The L is very fitted. The sleeves could be a bit longer, I am 5'8". The fabric is super soft and not as sheer as I thought it would be (a plus). I don't need to wear another layer under the blue glass pattern. It does cover your bum or you could bunch it up at the hips, it looks really cute because of the shirring at the hips. Great top that runs a half size small. If you are in between sizes definitely size up or if you don't want the top fitted but more semi-fitted, size up too.

I bought this in the plum color, size L. I usually wear a L in prAna (a medium once in a while) and I find this top to be very tight in the upper arms. I am 5'8" and the sleeves are barely long enough (just at my wrists). I wish they were as long as shown on the models, that would be 'cozy'. The fabric is not as soft as I was expecting. Overall it is a cute top though, on the thin side but I was expecting that. My black/gray tattoos show under the fabric. I returned the sweater and did not order in a larger size, as the chest, waist and hips fit nicely.

I bought this in the red and in my usual prAna size L. It was too big, the inner bra had no support and it was a bit loose fitting in the waist. I exchanged it for a M and it is much better, the inner bra is lightly supportive. The colors and pattern are beautiful. Not useful for exercise, but I bought it for everyday wear. I am a 36C, 5'8" tall and 162 lbs. Lovely top!

I usually wear a medium (if I wanted it more fitted) or a large. I decided to go with the medium because this looked like it ran large,  I made the right choice with the medium. I still find it a bit large and wish it was more fitted in the waist. The fabric is super soft. I am 5'8", 162, 36C. The sleeves are long enough (yay) and the length was too. I found that I like to cinch the ties up more than the photo shows, but either way it is totally cute! I bought both the green and the eggplant colors, and found they were true to what I saw on my monitor. These are a great addition to my wardrobe, and 3 season tops for me.

I needed a new one for a small office. It makes HOT coffee and it's fast. Super easy to use. When you pour the coffee out it does not dribble down the carfe, only into your cup. The red color is an added bonus. My coffeemaker looks like the maker in the second photo, one button (on and off switch), no  clock or programmable buttons. Great coffeemaker!

It runs large. I usually wear a L and bought this in a M and I still have some extra room. I am 5'8" 162 lbs. It hangs nicely (covers my bottom), and the style is very cute. The fabric is not quite as soft as I expected it to be. It did not shrink after washing and drying. The black color is not really black, but a charcoal grey. The pockets in the front are nice, they have no zippers, which would add unnecessary bulk. The top might make you look a little pregnant if you have a tummy. My husband liked this top on me so it's a keeper!

I bought both the brown and the cream sweater coats. They are a mid to heavy weight and will be great for wearing for 3 seasons for me. I love the style of this sweater, stylish and fun. A reviewer said that it is a slim fit, so I bought the L/XL instead of the M/L. The cream color is a perfect fit and the brown one is about 1/2 size bigger - maybe it will shrink a bit after being washed since it is cotton. The sleeves are long enough for me at 5'8" 162 lbs, so I think if I bought a size down, the sleeves might have been a bit short. The length is great and there is plenty of room for layers underneath.

The fabric is soft and hangs nicely. I am 5'8" and the sleeves are the perfect length, it hits about top of mid thigh area. I think that it runs a bit large for the size L, but then that leaves room for other layers underneath when the weather gets colder. The buttons are large but that adds pizzazz to the jacket. It is a mid-weight fabric, not a summer weight so I can pretty much wear this for 3 seasons. It looks great with my black fedora. When the weather changes I know it will look great with ankle boots and tall boots. If you are in between sizes I would order down a size.

I bought the cloud color tunic and it fits great. I bought a size L, I wear a dress size 10, 5'8", 160 lbs. The fabric is super soft and flows nicely. I could wear this to bed it's so soft! It's plenty long, hits top of mid thighs. I can wear my normal bra with this and it doesn't show in the back, I did have to pull the strings a little tighter together so it wouldn't show, but if it shows - I don't really care! The back is so cute and an added touch of fun.This is not a frumpy top, it does goes in at the waist, unlike some other tops that fall straight and look boxy. This is an awesome summer top that I will wear a lot, even in the winter.

I bought the purple tunic and it fits great. I bought a size L, I wear a dress size 10, 5'8", 160lbs. The fabric is soft and flows nicely. The color is true to what I saw on my monitor. It is as see through as the photo shows, you will need a tube top or a sports bra underneath if you don't want to flash people. This is an awesome summer top that I will wear a lot, even in the winter at home. The back and the braided straps are cute and an added touch of fun. I might buy another it's so cute!

I bought the red top and love the color (does bleed so wash separate the first time) and the fabric is really soft. I think I might have to take it in a bit, it doesn't feel tight enough. I am a 36C, wear a medium or size 10 in dresses.

I own about six of these now. I love the fabric, it is extremely soft. I normally would buy a L but I tried them on in the store and I wear a M in this. I wanted a fitted shirt to go with my summer shorts and skirts. I don't use them to workout in, if I did then I would have bought the L. They are not as long as they show on the models, mine hit at mid to high hip, except for the orange top, that one for some reason is 3" longer than the other colors. I wish it came in more vibrant colors, I would buy them. They wash and dry nicely. I love the cotton/poly tri blend.

This is my first Prana dress and I love this style. I have bought 2 of them so far, the Fuchsia Mayan and the Dragonfly Mayan. The fabric is super soft and flows beautifully over my curves. The inner bra is not tight, feels about right, I have worn it all day and it still feels great. The colors and patterns are vibrant and fun. I normally wear a 8/10 or medium, but I read that Prana runs smaller so I bought a L and it's a perfect fit. I am 5'8" and the dresses are plenty long enough, 162 lbs/36C. Might be too long if you are short. This dress is about 39" long in the L and 37" long in the Small size. I love this dress.

Awesome red summer hat. Since it's for men and I am a woman, I bought the size small/medium and it fits great. I wear a size 7.  It it well made and it is a vibrant red, perfect for my black polk a dot dress! The straw is stiff enough so that it is not a slouchy hat but is still soft. I would buy this brand again, fab hat!

This is the 'almost' perfect cross body purse for traveling, walking around cities or river bike paths when you don't want to carry something bigger/heavier. It holds just enough, inside there are several credit card slots, room for bills, lipstick, and small eyeglasses. I put my android in the outside pocket and there is plenty of room left if I want to slide my eyeglasses in there too. There is another small pocket on the other side that I keep hairbands/panty liners in. The only minor complaint I have is that the strap could be softer for when I wear summer dresses or tanks, it feels a little scratchy. All in all, this is a fab little purse. I love Baggallini products.

I bought the Water Lily and the Malaysian Blue (Blue Glass). I am 5'8" and it is a tad short but it is for summer so it's fine (even at 56 yrs young)! I love the fabric, it is so soft and flowy. The pattern on both dresses is fun and colorful. I wear an 8/10 or medium and this fits true to size for me. I wear a L in Prana. The inner bra is very comfortable and not tight (I am a 36C and 162lbs). I knew what size to buy because I tried on the L and M on in the local store and the medium fit better, and of course I bought it for less on Amazon! Yay Amazon!

I bought the black glass and the blue glass. The pattern is retro fun and cool. It is plenty long enough for me at 5`8", the skirt in size large is 19" long. The side tie is super cute. The waist is not bulky and the fabric flows nicely over your hips. I usually wear a L in this skirt and a medium in the Soybu Tahiti dress. Awesome skirts.

Saucony makes my favorite singlets and tanks. They are true to size, I am a size 10 and bought a large. These tops are super lightweight and extremely moisture wicking. The top is semi-fitted. As with any burnout fabric, your skin may show a bit through the fabric. I like the racer back for more freedom of movement.
