You really don't notice these things when the gnome is in a garden, as intended.The gnome itself is just under a pound in weight  and about 8" in height and 3.2" from shoulder to shoulder in width. I was worried it would be too light ti withstand winds and weather but it really is very sturdy and stable. It should be placed on a flat surface though, as it seems unstable on loose soil. If you intend on putting in the ground with plants make sure to bury the feet a little for stability. Because this is so lightweight it would make a great traveling mascot (just a thought.) In all, we're happy with the buy and I'm sure my mother will love displaying this sassy gnome in her garden.

When I asked my stepfather for any ideas as to what to get my mother for her birthday this year his response was,"I don't know, she really seems to like unique earrings."  One would think this would open a whole world of possibilities but my mother has several allergies to various metals and an only tolerate surgical steel and genuine solid gold. Any of my buying options in the surgical steel range were quite cheap and just didn't have the feel of a quality gift one would give their mother. Once I committed to genuine, solid, gold posts I browsed nearly every design I could find on Amazon (as Prime shipping was a crucial factor in my time frame) within the $40-$100 range.As I came across these I was instantly drawn to them. They looked 'unique' by every definition without being too gaudy or loud. Fun and trendy without being inappropriate. My mother isn't the sort to wear flowers and hearts so finding a feminine touch that would garner her compliments was high on my checklist. Once I decided on these I anguished over 'mm' size and whether to go with these Lavender or the Margarita pair. While the Margarita (green) listing seemed equally beautiful I had high hopes that these would offer more depth in the range of colors.I'll admit, I've never paid $63 for any piece of jewelry before, so this was a big deal to me and that first glimpse was a true hit or miss moment. These arrived in a pretty cheap silver jewelry box (not like the clam-shell, velvet lined, one I have placed them in to gift to my mother,) and there was no way to know they were solid gold other than a sticker on the outside of the bag the box came in. All that aside, I was very pleased with the actual earrings. The way these caught the light from every angle, one couldn't help but stare and inspect them from every side and lighting. They are even more beautiful than my photos (and I think I did a great job capturing their glow and facets!)The 6mm ended up being the right choice for me- They are not too small, but not too big to look cheap or overwhelming. The gold posts are extremely dainty and hold up to basic genuine gold testing. The backings seem to fit snug, and the stones seem well mounted, though only time will tell how they will hold up. I wish, for the money, these had been presented in a nicer jewelry box- but I really am very happy with this buy. I was nervous about spending this kind of money on such a unique pair of earrings, sight unseen, and online but I couldn't have been happier with the speed of delivery and their captivating real life impact!The stock image falls flat and doesn't begin to convey the depth of the stone and the way it changes color!

At the time of this review I turn 29 tomorrow- While it's sad, at my age, I have to regulate and monitor my blood pressure; it's not a task I want turning into a chore. I'll admit, it's no fun carrying around a BP gauge everywhere one goes, and it's far from sexy. Well, I have to say this is one of the slickest monitor's I've owned, very slim in profile- just a little over the thickness of the AAA batteries it runs on. The backlit screen is bright and the LED is a soft white glow readout so it's very easy on the eyes and quite stylish.All too many time I've had to take multiple readings on multiple devices and average the numbers, or revert to a manual cuff for an accurate measurement. It had gotten to the point my own physician didn't believe I was monitoring my blood pressure at home! Since my medication is highly regulated and taken in very small mG doses, I need to take my BP multiple times a day. This cuff delivers fast readings with a very easy to track system that stores up to 60 records (which is about 2 weeks data for me.) I've actually been able to stretch this closer to a month thanks to the 2 user system (for 120 readings total.)Speaking of the 2 user storage system, this is the first digital cuff I've owned that was so intuitive to use I could actually make use of multiple user profiles. There literally are 2 buttons- one for each user, so even a caregiver new to BP tracking could learn to use this. Visual indicators are quite easy to read as well with number readouts that correspond to a visual meter on the left side. This system is pretty standard with digital cuffs, but I found the Green/Yellow/Red scaling was a lot more accurate in relation to the actual numbers. I've had cuffs place my in the yellow zone at 160/118- when you are relying on a device to alert you to crucial changes in your body's function, that's not safe!As far as accuracy, I actually brought this into my DRs office this past week to compare the readings with the RNs manual cuff readout. It was within a few points each time- which is good enough for me! Similarly, while the manual does say you can use this on either arm, it's best not to take wrist cuff measurements on one's right arm, as variances will occur. I did play around with this and was getting readings over a 5 point variance from one arm to the next.This cuff is very lightweight and comfortable to wear- setup was easy and took less than a minute and all literature for troubleshooting, resetting, and use are thoroughly documented with included instructions, as is a carrying tote (that is a bit over-sized so I store my meds with my cuff.) I received a product discount in hopes I'd share my honest thoughts, yet still paid more than pennies or a few dollars- I have bought a lot of cuffs in my time, and ease of use is important for my busy lifestyle. Consider all notes here genuine- I will likely buy a second for travel and the car.

It feel funny saying we 'love' a shower curtain, but this deserves 5 stars- We've long bought our clear liners on Amazon and have been through several brands. For a while we settled on one that was about $8 with Prime, and replaced it every other month. It was affordable, but it wasn't sturdy enough to clean regularly. We could really only spray it down and give it a gentle wipe and it eventually would get mildew when it was time to replace. We've also had problems with the grommets wearing out and tearing, on previous curtains, so we didn't have any real idea what to expect.*This 10 Guage shower curtain IS heavy duty. It feels thick, and is about twice the weight of our usual liner. We use these clear curtains as actual liners that drape inside the tub while showering- we keep a fabric curtain on the outside of the tub. I was concerned our curtain rod wouldn't be happy to put up with the extra weight of this curtain but there are enough grommets that the weight is very well distributed. As a liner, it's pretty thick- and really more of a clear shower curtain- but suits our needs well.*We truly appreciate the attention to quality and stitching at the top, around the grommets. We can easily scrub the bottom of the curtain (since it is thick enough) and not worry about straining the grommets or fraying the edges.*This was a little stiff to use for the first week or so. It seemed to want to fan out, and folded quite thick at the bottom when pulled back, but has since relaxed a little.*There is a pretty standard, not particularly overwhelming, plastic odor when you first remove this from the package. We placed our liner out on the patio for a day before installing it and the odor seemed to have dissipated.We rarely have no criticism for a product but this is a solid buy all around, I only wish I could subscribe to it, as we will certainly be ordering this liner from here on out. Then again- at this quality it will surely last twice as long as our usual buy! We received a product discount in exchange for our honest thoughts, which we have provided.

I was raised with an analog pressure gauge- we put a lot of wear on our tires from travel and work expeditions and it isn't always convenient to pack a giant professional gauge with ll our other gear and equipment. In the past we've relied on the very basic 'stick' gauges; but those usually fluxuate as much as 3-4 PSI, which is a lot when your tires are gauged to 35. I especially liked the easy of use and portability of this digital tire meter.*It's body is entirely plastic- I like that it is brightly colored and easy to locate in a glove compartment or tool kit. It has a single button operation that is very intuitive. Click the trigger button once to turn it on, and again to cycle through each of the 4 measurements (PSI, Bar, Kpa, or kg/cm.) Hold the button down for an extended 5-7 seconds and the unit will turn off. It will also automatically power off if left unused for more than 30 seconds.*The back-lit screen is very bright and very easy to read in direct daylight or the middle of the night, and even provides a little glow to work by when locating the stem. This is very useful for those 'side of the road' or late night gas stop checks.*The unit seems to measure within a few decimal points accurately when compared to our professional analog meter (PSI.) even better, this measures PSI to decimal points- which is really great when accurate monitoring an measurements are needed (especially to track and detect leaks over time.)*While the gauge is ergonomically designed, it could use a rubber grip- especially if you have to pull this out in foul weather.*The reading is quick, but we've had a little difficulty getting a clean fit. We let out a little air now and then because we can't seem to get a flush connection right off the bat. This really is our only complaint, and a minor annoyance with such an easy to use, accurate digital pressure gauge.*I love the little notch at the bottom to attach to a caribiner or tool belt- it just adds an extra functionality.*This comes with batteries installed- and this might be an issue for some- the unit operates on a total of 4 cell batteries and the only way to get to said batteries is by unscrewing the unit. It's not hard, but not convenient- I suppose it does make for a durable and water resistant gauge though. Speaking of battery- we anticipate a lot of life on the included batteries, since the unit is so efficient at turning off when not in use!In all, this is a great buy at the current asking price of $10- and something everyone should have on hand in their car. Why fuss with trying to read analog and stick measurements when you can enjoy a quick digital read on a back-lit display? I received this product for free in hopes I would share my honest thoughts and experiences, which I have done. Feel free to drop any questions!

I own several Bluetooth speakers and paid well over $200 for our JBL speaker at the time of it's first release- I am very critical of design and execution in portable sound technology but I have to say, right up front, I was blown away with the amount of speaker you get for such a low price here. I do not write glowing reviews, and always have notes of improvement but it's literally hard to pick apart a speaker that does everything it promises to such great execution. I would buy these for gifts in a heartbeat and am looking to invest in a second to test the possibility of surround sound or continuous syncing. Here are my thoughts:Appearance: Very well built, heavy in the hand but very modest in size for the amount of sound it can output. I love the 360 speaker design but find the speaker is a little tall can can be wobbly unless on a very flat surface, since it is slender and tall. We usually place this face down on the buttons/front when we take it out and about to avoid mishaps with falling when at the pier or park.Waterproof: This speaker offers a level of IPX4 protection- this means you shouldn't swim with it or submerge it underwater, but having it out while camping, or in areas where weather may be tentative is acceptable. Minor splashes and water encounters should be fine. The bottom charge ports and on/off switch are protected by a silicone fitted flap. I've had no issue removing the flap (which is securely attached by a small tab at one end,) though it does fit flush with the speaker for waterproofing purposes.Streaming Options: While this is a Bluetooth speaker there is a TF/Micro SD port for you to introduce your own media- I've found that this seems to add extra life to the playback time (about an hour more when directly reading media.) Bluetooth connects and pairs quickly and intuitively. There is a voice acknowledgement system that sounds like an Asian woman with a French accent- it's a little robotic and really livens up our listening experience- we are constantly trying to place her accent.Connectivity + Life: We get about 5 3/4 hours continuous playback via Bluetooth on a full charge (full charge takes about 2.5 hours.) The Bluetooth range is about 30 feet before interference/cutting out. Note: even a human body can disrupt the clarity of the feed, resulting in a crackling/breaking up effect. The field between the Bluetooth device and speaker should be kept directly clear at all times for functionality. This is where the price level of the speaker shows itself- it's truly a minor inconvenience, as I rarely am using my phone while streaming. Like so many people I play music while cleaning up the house, hosting a party, or relaxing in the backyard.The 'Clip': In an effort to market this as more of an active lifestyle speaker a pull out tab and complimentary caribiner style clip has been included with this speaker. The tab doesn't seem like something I'd quite trust clipped to my belt while biking (as in one of the stock images) but is convenient to fasten in a backpack, or to one's belongings while out and about. In my opinion the aluminum clip is by far the cheapest looking element of that is otherwise a very slick speaker package.There is not carry pouch or sleeve like many other speakers on the market have. I suppose that's another thing that refers to the price point, but it's such a gorgeous speaker that I'm sad to note this. We store ours in the original box when not in use....which is pretty much never, since it's usually on display in the living room when not being charged.The Sound: I wanted to dislike this speaker but it's hard to argue with the sheer power of this tiny unit. I am amazed by the amount of sound being pumped out of it and the clarity from all angles. In our 2 bedroom condo I can hear music clearly and comfortably with the volume at about 80 percent! Even more impressive, there is minimal muffling and distortion when up so loud. BASS highs and lows come in fairly clear with decent depth- the only issue with sound quality would be interference when handling the bluetooth streaming device, or when the device gets out of range.We also thought it was worth noting that the device can actively be charged while in use- and will power off the included cable endlessly if used as a power source. Clarity for calling modes seems okay but is not the highlight of this unit. In all, I am blown away at the quality and performance of this speaker, with the added benefit of waterproof protection, for it's price. I did receive a discount, but paid more than a few dollars, in hopes I'd share my honest experiences and thoughts- which I have done. I purchase a lot of speakers at discount and I think this is the first I have given 5 stars; that should stand for something. Feel free to drop us any questions about the device!

For some reason I initially saw this listing and assumed it was fabric or somehow inflated- the product images don't quite convey that i is resin, as the edges are all so smooth. And, while the sizes are written (as pretty much the ONLY product info really given) I envisioned it a little bigger. All this being said, I'm a bit bummed that all the current reviews go on about how cute it is with no real product insight or scrutiny. Don't get me wrong, it IS adorable- and at the current $15 price, it's not a bad buy, however there are some quirks and things worth noting.*This seasonal decor comes in 3 pieces, the main moose body, left hand/arm, hanging solar powered lantern. In truth, it comes in 4 pieces because the lantern handle does not run through the lantern piece and actually is just two nubs  that sit in very shallow drilled out holes in the side of the lantern top. We've actually gone and drilled the holes a little deeper to push the handle nubs in further0 but they are so short it doesn't quite help with the issue that SoCal gets very windy and the lantern has fallen off a few times already. Fortunately, the resin is very durable and nothing has broken.*The lantern is made of resin....and painted. The light coming from within is not very powerful at all. While we have verified that it does charge, and we seem to get over 5 hours of light from the tiny solar cell after a day outside, the light is just much too muffled to do more than add an ambiance glow. I tried hard to get it on camera, but there is too much light pollution on our block to really capture it.*This Christmoose fastens onto pretty much any tree via a 2 screw mount on the body and a one screw mount on the arm. Screws are NOT included but the rest of the hardware is mounted into the resin. When hung by screws the moose body is very secure (minus the issue with the lantern potentially blowing off in heavy winds.) The hand's mount seems to be embedded sideways and the hand would be placed against the curvature, up and down, rather than hugging as shown in the product images, in order to be hung properly. Regardless, with a snug screw fit we are able to secure it easily.*This is not a heavy piece of decor, which we love, and it comes packaged in a box with Styrofoam padding, great for storing year after year for use.*The paint job varies a little here and there but, overall if very slick and looks great. There's no denying this is a unique and cute addition to any holiday decor setup.In conclusion, as a piece of decor, it is adorable- The lantern doesn't quite function as we'd like as far as brightness but does charge with solar power and is easily turned on/off via a push switch on the front (assuming you place the panel side facing back.) I wish the lantern attached to it's handle more securely, that's really the biggest downfall of this decoration, as the lantern is a bit integral to the design of the character holding up it's hand. It's viable without the bright light, but not so much with the lantern on the floor beneath it. With some fussing you can find a solution to this though by adding your own wire as a handle, extending the drill holes, etc. Like many of the reviewers on here at time of posting, I received a discount, but paid more than a few dollars, in hopes I'd share my honest thoughts, which I have done. If the lantern issue were addressed and fixed, this would easily be 4 stars.

I was very skeptical of mounting my phone to my bike when my girlfriend first suggested it. We looked at several options and they all seemed to rely on plastic frames and various friction/grip spring loaded claws. I bike 8 miles to work, roundtrip, daily and often through busy traffic. I never know when I will have to brake hard or swerve and the concept of putting my smartphone on my handles, where the most jerking might occur made me very uneasy. I especially liked the idea of silicone band enhanced mounts that added that extra shock absorbing embrace of security when riding.*The product says, on the packaging, 'to fit any smartphone'- which seems to be a bit of a stretch (pun intended) of the truth. While 3 grip bands are included and one could use two bands to secure the top and bottom of one's phone separately, I would not put my Phablet style (Note) phone in here. The spring loaded grip is VERY tight, which is a great thing, as I feel confident it could hold my phone in place alone, without the silicone netting, but doesn't expand much more than 4", making it a tight fit for larger phones. This being said, I think this mount would work best with most iPhones, and second best with Windows and Android smartphones such as the Lumia and Galaxy models. My Samsung Galaxy S4 is shown and fits snug. You'll note the Apple phone shown in the product images has more grip room on the corners because it is a smaller footprint. Take in mind most protective phone cases you'd want on your phone while biking add a considerable amount of bulk.*This mount was easy to install and did only take a few minutes. We didn't care much for the 'adjustable' method of sizing the frame grip by adding layers of included silicone grips. It works, but it required some cutting/trimming, and seems like the grip should telescope much smaller and simply require less tightening for larger framed bikes.*The phone mount itself snaps into a 360 pivot joint that allows viewing from nearly any angle- which is great when you're out biking in the sun and need to adjust for glare. I suggest investing in a glass screen protector with glare protection if you intend on using this mount, or any mount for regular navigation. I primarily use mine for Bluetooth purposes to screen calls to and from work, and listen to the radio.*This product advertises full phone access- again, I don't quite now how they can claim that for EVERY phone, but on our Galaxy S4 we are able to easily position the expandable clam-shell grips so that they do not interfere with volume buttons. This being said the silicone grip frame DOES cover our touch home and menu buttons. (See photo)In all, my phone feels very secure and I bike confidently with this mount. I have yet to notice any weakening in the pivot joint and the elasticity of the web band. The company offers a 100% satisfaction guarantee, so if you're in the fence about the FIT of the mount and your device (as case thicknesses and such vary,) it's worth a chance in our opinion. Our only real gripe with our unique experiences is the fact that the webbing DOES go over and interfere with our menu and home buttons on the S4. This is to be expected with the design- but contrary to the marketing of the product. We received a discount in hopes we would share our honest thoughts, which I have provided here. Please feel free to drop any questions about our experiences or the mount's performance, we'd be happy to assist.

(Jenna's Thoughts) We own a lot of expensive and fancy pillows- I'll admit, I'm a pillow SNOB. 5 years back I was sleeping on your everyday cheap Wally world $5 value pillows. When Jay moved in I begin really looking at my bedding and my sleeping experience. Getting a good night's sleep is not quite the same game as you move out of your 20s and can't stretch across your bed like you used to when you were single! I also noticed that all of my and his cheap pillows get nasty pretty quick. They either changed color (eew) or turned lumpy and uncomfortable. We were going through $5 pillows once a month- and that adds up quick!I also am the sort who has trouble falling asleep and requires multiple pillows under head and arms to get comfy- so, when I invested in a brand new mattress the salesman talked me into trying memory foam pillows. Ever since then I haven't looked back. While my favorite (main) pillow is the Hydraluxe Cooling Memory Foam Pillow by Comfort Revolution, I still find myself sleeping with two pillows behind my head. During the winter I keep a thin memory foam pillow on top, and during the Summer I prop it up on the bottom. For me, this Slim Sleeper would solve that need perfectly.*The pillow arrived n a clear plastic bag/wrapper that truly is a choking hazard to kids and pets (so dispose of that proper and right away.) Out of the packaging there was no foul odor. Some memory foams tend to have a chemical smell, but even outside the case it was odorless.*The pillow, as seen in product photos, is actually inside a very soft and plus case that removes entirely via zipper for washing.*The 'memory' life of this foam build is very rich- I can press my hand down into it with about an inch and a half to spare and the imprint will hold a good 10 seconds upon pull back. The design has a soft curve to cradle the neck at the widest point and help make slim sleeping ergonomic. I took a nap on the couch with only this pillow and felt quite comfortable- I'd like to think this would be great for travel!*I am primarily using this as a bolster pillow on top of my existing memory foam pillow- Most memory foam pillows tend to be very thick and bulky. I can't stack a cotton blend pillow on top or it will sink and slide (and bunch) and I can't stack another foam pillow on top because it feels too high- until now. This Slim Sleeper is PERFECT for my needs and very comfortable to sleep on- I'd highly recommend it for anyone who wants to take that foam sleeping experience on vacation or to a family's house for the holidays- it;s so light and easy to transport!In all, I'm marking this down a star only for it's price point- I see similar pillows sell closer to $35-40 and wish the maker wold consider lowering it's price so more people could experience the comfort and convenience of such a well made, slim, memory foam pillow. I did receive a discount on my purchase but have provided an honest and unbiased account of my opinions and experiences, regardless. I will update over time with any wear/flattening/discoloration notes as/if they arise.

I got this for my stepdad as a birthday gift- we are a family of photographers and I knew he'd get a kick out of carrying this around on shoots. Ironically the product images don't really do it justice. I'd read reviews before buying it and I was unsure how it would look when it arrived. It almost seems like Amazon might have some old inventory or models in their stock that some other buyers have received? After reading the critical reviews I was really worried about the drinking on the go situation as some had mentioned there being no spout and others mentioned an issue with a gasket seal. Here's what we found (photos attached.)*The box looks a little cheesy and dated and can certainly use an update, however it does arrived boxed, which makes gifting easier.*The outer shell (the part that looks like a lens) seems to be all one piece with the exception of the focus and zoom rings- those are rubber bands that do tend to slide up or down a little with excess handling. We thought the macro indicators were just fancy stickers at first but they actually seem well set and inlaid into the plastic mold, if they are. I was a bit disappointed some of the switches (like the AF/MF) weren't moving parts, but that's just the geek in me. All in all, it looks a lot nicer than I expected for a $10 price point.*The tumbler inside the lens shell (I say shell but it is all one piece, they don't remove from one another) is high quality stainless steel and holds 11oz of fluid. This is a little smaller than I like for a tumbler- if you're a photographer you probably take more than 11ounces out on set/location. In any case it's overall presence is about accurate to a real lens.*The cap has a threading in which it attaches to the inner lip of the stainless steel mug. There is a notch to slide up or down to drink from and the lid comes off fairly easy with a twist to remove format. Because the interior is stainless steel we expect it to hold heat and keep cold things cold for a very long time- but, alas, this is a gift so I can't truly attest to that.*If the capacity isn't quite enough for you I'd suggest taking the lid off and using it on your desk for pens, SD cards, film collection, etc- it would make a wonderful nic nack for any photography fan.Having said all this- I m very critical of things looking cheesy or cheap- I wish this was advertised as being made in the U.S.A., but there's little I can do about that. I paid $7 for our mug (I got a very small discount in hopes I'd share our honest thoughts) and I am quite content giving it as a gift. It's quite clever and well designed in my opinion- I have added the Clear Lens version of this mug to my own wish list!

We own several backup battery banks and 'lipstick chargers' and they all seem to come with their own perks and quirks. I still remember shelling out $60 for my first 10000mAh power bank, and I have to admit it's a bit silly how affordable anything under 15000 mAh is today! That being said, I was skeptical of a 20800mAh power bank for just $35, but our familiarity with the brand's other tech devices made the gamble worth the plunge. We were mainly attracted to this bank because of the bright (top facing) LED indicator lights, dual charging potential, large capacity and secondary flashlight feature. Here's how it stacked up for us:Yays:*We liked the sleek look and rounded edges. It feels soft and easy to grip in the palm and the blue LED lights on the top are very bright (you really can't miss them, they're almost blinding.) While the size may seem big, it's actually equal to or smaller than some of our 15000mAh power banks and the rounded edges make it much more comfortable to carry around in a pocket or handbag.*The dual charge feature is great. We love that we can charge both of our devices while in the car, or at a restaurant, the output can handle both 1A and 2.1A USB output. Along a similar line the intelligent technology built into this power bank helps sense maximum output, depending on the device being charged, and automatically adjusts so as to not over charge.*The front light feature is a nice add on though the blue LED indicator lights almost seem even brighter! The light will function just like a flashlight and has no timeout until manually turned off by holding the power button down for an extended period of time. We own a smaller version of this power bank and have had issues with the buttons sticking and turning the light off. We're happy to report that this model seems very well polished in use from button sensitivity and responsiveness to port fits.*The battery came with a full charge (per the indicator lights.) We usually suggest draining the power bank entirely before charging it further to avoid ghost memory issues and maintain the integrity of the battery's memory- however, in our case, since the battery pack indicated it was full we began out testing immediately.*You can charge the battery pack AND a device at the same time. Naturally the power bank will charge much slower if this is the case. This is convenient if you have a long time and only access to one outlet (or you forgot your phone charger AC adapter at home,) otherwise it's not a huge selling point, just plug your phone into the wall and the charger into another outlet, in our opinion.*The included carry pouch is more of a sleeve and fits a little snug, but there is plenty of room at the top to use the drawstring. Charging cables do fit inside with the bank but the lovely exterior, black, grip materials tends to scuff and mark if given the chance to rub.*This power banks security protection design is intended to prevent against over charging and short circuit, as noted above.*Charge time is fast- from 3% battery health on our Samsung Galaxy S4 to full in just under 45 minutes- which is about  5 inutes more than direct AC output for our Samsung Galaxy S4. This device seems to charge at a slightly slower rate when connected to our iPad.*We clocked 7 full charge cycles and about 87% on our Samsung Galaxy S4- As the Galaxy S4 has a 2600 mAh battery which is about a 97% efficiency rate. This is really one of the devices biggest successes, as more banks tend to average 90% efficiency in this price range.Mehs:*The device comes with a micro to USB adapter but no AC adapter. This is pretty standard as far as power banks go, but it still would be nice to see one with an AC adapter someday. You can easily plugin to most standard smartphone chargers or your laptop to charge.In all, this has quickly become one of our favorite power banks with it's high capacity output and flashlight feature. We feel this will be a great safety aid for the house, let along any professional who commutes or travels a lot. I will update this listing to see if it loses charge memory over time- so far no issues. For the price at the time of this review ($35) we consider this a solid buy worth investing in- and easily on of the best power banks we've tested in this price range within the 15000mAh-20800mAh range. I received a discount in hopes I would share my honest thoughts and experiences, which I have done.

We own a few oven and grill gloves but I was particularly drawn to the unique NOMEX fibers used in the exterior Kevlar weave of these. Many other gloves advertise that they can handle temperatures up to 600F, but in fact have disclaimers about how long they can carry such heat. In our experiences, Anything above 425F usually is too much for 'bargain brand' cooking gloves. Here are our thoughts:*These came to us packages in a clear plastic bag with minimal tags and literature. We like to gift items like this, and the packaging isn't very presentable so they'd have to be bundled with other cooking items, as in a gift set.*These are large. We both have long slender hands and usually order large sizes in gloves and mitts, but there was extra wiggle room for both of this. While this wasn't to the point of making things clumsy, I could certainly see how anyone with petite hands might have difficulties. Word is that the brand is creating a sizing system and a smaller size is on the way.*Some of our other oven/grill gloves have strips of silicone gripping that can make grasping and mobility a bit awkward. The dot pattern used on these gloves helps increase mobility and seems to add extra heat protection and grip over our other pairs. For example, some of our 'strip' styled gloves allow for the side of pans and dishes to slide between the grip material and can build up heat in extended use. The grip pattern is so dense, yet flexible, on these that they are easily some of the most versatile heat resistant gloves we've used.*Speaking of build- The inside is a cotton material which doesn't cause sweating and is actually very comfortable to wear for extended periods. This is especially nice when you're playing grill master. Equally important is the extended wrist design which helps protect forearms from the heat of open flames (when turning steaks at the grill, etc) or carrying large casserole, pie, and roaster dishes from the oven. In all the extra 3 1/2" of coverage is a real selling point for us, as we do a lot of heavy lifting at the grill and in the kitchen.*These washed beautifully- I was hesitant to do a machine wash, per the instruction options, but they did not seem to shrink or warp on a standard wash cycle, air dried.*For those new to the concept of grilling gloves- Heat resistant means that immediate contact with up to 662F will not be felt, however, there are 'bleed' times and consumers should always be aware that these are not intended to be worn for extended periods of contact with hot surfaces. In our experience we were able to comfortably grip a pie dish direct from 460F heat for 18 seconds before feeling warmth come through, and 25 seconds before we felt we should place the dish down. While that may seem short, it's really quite a long time to get what needs to be done, done. You should also be aware that these are still made of fabric, and that contact with water, while in the kitchen can result in burns, so always exercise caution as you would with any potholder/mitt/glove around heat.In all these have performed the more organically in the kitchen, with the versatility and flexibility range exceeding our other mitts. We love that this enable enough dexterity to re-wrap foil on a roasting pan after checking the temperature with a probe. We also love that the extra long wrist protects us when flipping burgers over an open flame. Our only grumble is that they do not come packaged nicer, or in a secondary (smaller) size. We received a product discount in exchange for our honest thoughts and experiences, which we have shared here.

Traditionally I've avoided headbands and relied on hair ties or clips to hold my hair back when cooking or working out because the majority of the fashion bands on the market tend to give me pressure headaches. However, I can't sleep with my hair tied back or in a clip, as I've begun wearing my hair up due to the Summer heat. These seemed like a plausible solution with their unique extra long shape and ability to be layered.Yays:*I actually like that there is no sewing or finishing on the edges of these headbands- I think that makes them more comfortable to wear and do not mind that they curl a little after multiple uses or washing. These are very long and can be doubled or trippled over as an actual headband so they seem they will always be useful for that.*After hand washing and air drying they did not seem to shrink, fray, or thin. There was a little noticed curling on the edges.*The material is very stretchy and very breathable. I noticed NO odors, at all- and I sniffed them- even over my nose as mask I couldn't detect any artificial odors. I found this material quite comfortable to wear and triple rolled into itself a suitable headband for holding hair in place, while still being comfortable enough to lay down or nap in.*These fold up flat when not in use- so they are easy to store in a purse, glove compartment, or gym bag. They do not bunch or wrinkle.*The packaging has several graphics for use/wearing instructions I found easy. I'm not very creative when it comes to that sort of thing and actually loved the idea to twist it overhead and double it down to wear as a beanie. I think this will come in handy to keep my ears insulated under  biking helmet during the Fall months.Mehs:*I'm not crazy about the patterns- I usually love colorful but the multi-color prints in the 6 pack are just too loud and very Rastafarian.*The carry pouch they came in came with a busted zipper so it was pretty much useless out of the gate.*I'm on the fence about the price- if I was going to buy these I'd expect to pay about $3-$3.50 a piece. The 2 pack at $10 is a bit more than I'd like to fork over given the nature of what the product is; a long headband that can be worn multiple ways.My thoughts overall? Buy the 4 pack, it works out cheaper and is a truly great deal for your money- I only wish I could choose the designs included. It does look like the designs shown on each listing are the ones shipped in the package though. These are definitely multi-functional but they are, at the end of the day, long headbands. They breath well, are comfortable to wear, and do not cause headaches. I received a discount in exchange for my honest thoughts, which I have provided.

There seem to be a lot of glowing reviews, and some really negative reviews on this product so I was skeptical when first considering whether I should give this power bank a shot. It's a shame that so many reviewers who review in exchange for discounts post glowing reviews that are basically a regurgitation of the product specs. I've been reviewing products for years and maybe 1 in 25 purchases will arrive absolutely perfection with no notes for improvement- and even then, there's always more a product could have or offer. All this being said, it's hard to decide where product quality lies when looking at a product in this price range, now so far from it's original list value when the negative reviews clearly received defective products and many of the glowing reviews do more than boost star ratings and say things like 'it's really neat,' 'I'll use this a lot' and 'a great deal.' That being said here is our nitty gritty good and the bad after several charge cycles and drains:The Yays:*The complimentary carry case is a gorgeous poly woven charcoal color that fits the power bank with a little extra room. Some of our other chargers and speakers have cases that fit tight like a sleeve and can be a pain to get on and off. I do with the drawstring on this pouch was a little longer though.*It is stylish, which seems to be the main selling point of the brand. Indeed the design is crisp and we love the hex-weave facing on the top and bottom. Unfortunately, this material also seems to love lint, which clings to it a lot so storage in the carry case is a must. I wish I could say that the '8 level' power bar indicator excited me- but, for the 15000 mAh it doesn't seem as necessary as it would be on a 20000+ mAh device. That being said the blue indicator lights are vibrant and easy to see and read in any lighting situation.*Dual charging- We've come to learn not to use cords included with these sorts of devices as the quality tends to not be great and the cords are often short. While the included cord did work for charging purposes we used the cords that came with our devices originally for the majority of our testing. Instead of labeling the class of USB outputs the brand has decided to merely put 'in' and 'out' in the ports so it is hard to judge what should be expected in charge speeds. All this being said, we have times charges for our Samsung Galaxy S4 under the following circumstances with the following results which ranks the speed of dual charge second best out of 6 dual chargers this capacity or higher owned by us:-Single Charge, 1 Port- 3%-100%: 50 minutes-Dual Charge, 2 Ports- 0%-100%: 63 minutes, 74 minutes (it's worth noting that, for some reason, despite both batteries being dead, one charged faster, we assume this has to do with the individual batteries ghost life)-Control: AC Samsung USB Adapter- 0%-100%: 37 minutes*This came with 3/8 bars charge, out of the box. We always like it when a product is able to be tested immediately upon unpacking.*We noticed that this power bank seems to sense it's charging progress and slow or halt charging output once the attached device has reached full capacity. This is especially useful for maintaining the bank's maximum reserve charge as devices that continue to draw or trickle energy on a full battery will eventually deplete reserves.*We clocked 5 full charge cycles and about 58% on our Samsung Galaxy s4- As the Galaxy S4 has a 2600 mAh battery which is about a 95% efficiency rate. This is really one of the devices biggest successes, as more banks tend to average 90% efficiency in this size and price range.The Mehs:*The packaging looked like it had been sitting in a storefront with UV exposure- it was a bit faded, which tends to make me think I received an older model or make. I'm not sure what could have caused this but it's the sort of small thing that weighs heavy on a first impression.*The cord included with this power bank was short, as they usually are. It was also white- which is confusing when we ordered a black power bank....why include a white cord? I know the brand offers this bank in white, but it seems like a small cost to match cords with bank colors. Furthermore I wonder if I will ever see a dual charger bank with 2 charging cables.... Also, as so many of these banks- you do not get an AC-USB wall plug adapter.*The brand offers a pretty impressive 2 yer warranty outside of Amazon and appears committed to customer service. Having said that, it seems they should invest in a customer care team that speaks fluent English if they wish to continue to deal with a customer base primarily in the U.S. Many of the customer concerns and questions on this listing are not addressed properly or to the point due to a language barrier. Customer support seems to be more of a 'replacement' policy which I suppose is fine in the long run, but not truly customer support.The Nays:*Like others have said this power bank is big- it weighs near a pound and is 5 1/4" in length, and a bit thick. We normally cheer products that have heft to them as representing quality materials and build but a power bank that seems to be from this year (as we couldn't find reviews that went back past May 2015) should ideally be more compact for it's 15000 mAh capacity.  We own several 2300 mAh power banks and they are all smaller in footprint than this.*Despite the brand touting that 9 hours is a normal charge time for a power bank of this size, 9 hours is exceptionally long. Yes, you can charge this overnight, and more people will, but we own multiple 15000 mAh power banks that fully charge in 6 hours or less.The bottom line- After going through all these points there are clearly some pros and cons, as you'll find when comparison shopping any power bank. Power banks of this capacity are a dime a dozen and range from $10-$100 on Amazon. It's best to know what is most important to you and make a buying decision based on this. We rate this high for measured efficiency- not because it looks cool or has 8 indicator lights. If you are most concerned with a compact power bank in the 15000mAh range, this is not the device for you. In addition, the 9 hour bank charge time should be taken into account. While we did receive a discount on this product initially, we did pay more than a few pennies for the device and I have invested a great deal of time into honestly testing and providing feedback for potential buyers- please drop a comment or question if you have any concerns when considering this device. We have tested many and are happy to help you find the right power bank for you!

As someone who was forced to take a tablespoon of cod liver oil a day, growing up, I rebelled against the idea of fish oil supplements, when suggested by my doctor for omega-3 benefits and to aid in the lowering of my bad, LDL, level cholesterol. As someone in their late 20's who has made several lifestyle changes to ween off of Lipitor- I knew I had to do more than change my diet and activity levels to keep my hereditary issues at bay. For the past 2 years I have been taking 1000mg Nature's Bounty Fish Oil capsules- these are large horse pills that are NOT friendly for people with pill taking issues, and cause 'fish oil burps' several hours after initial consumption. I'd read a lot of articles, and consulted with my doctor, about Krill oil benefits, over fish oil, which led me to this product.*One bottle contains a 1 month supply, when 2 capsules are taken daily by an adult. Per the label this provides:300mg Antarctic Krill Oil (EPA- 43 mg, DHA 26mg)200mg Sardine/Anchovy Fish Oil500mg Primrose OilI've noticed on many Fish Oil supplements the EPA and DHA are not specifically called out, and generally lumped into generic claims about the oil's potential benefits and measurements.*These pills are very thick gel capsules- I actually bit into one for 1.) an overall taste test- after all its the fish oil pills releasing in your stomach acids that cause the infamous fish burp phenomenon, and 2.) because the gel capsule itself seemed very very thick. I realized the contents were very mild in taste and odor and no more offensive than a piece of sushi. I assumed the thick gel coating is what, in part, causes the lack of fish burps causing absorption to be delayed and take longer.*While these capsules are not fun to take, for someone who has issues taking pills, they re smaller than many fish oil supplements.*I have been very pleased with the absolute lack of presence of side effects and fish burps. There is no aftertaste and no sensation or aromatic impact in the hours that follow taking a serving.*While I am not a doctor, I have been taking omega 3s for years now and seen noticeable drops in negative LDL cholesterol levels. As my physician advised that Krill Oil will offer up to 3 times the impact per dose, I am excited to update this review with my follow up blood work with Fall.*The bottle is a basic screw top cap- if you are concerned about children getting into it you will want to change storage methods or store it out of reach of small hands.*I have noticed a decrease in swelling and joint stiffness due to physical activity in my left knee, which has experienced severe swelling and stiffness at times due to an old injury in the joint tendons. Again, I am not a doctor, but I have also read further into Krill Oil benefits and it seems this might be the cause.In general, as someone who has been relying on Omega 3 supplements for years, I am relieved to have found a quality Krill Oil supplement and alternative to Fish Oil and fish burps. I will update as I continue through several months of this product and let you know of my sucess in blood work numbers. I received a product discount in hopes I would share my honest thoughts here, which I have done.

We own several selfie sticks and they all seem to have an array of different quirks and different positives.  In general, there are 3 types of commercial selfie sticks: direct connect audio jack, remote triggered by Bluetooth, or built in Bluetooth. Let me tell you, once you've tried a Bluetooth capable selfie stick, you will never go back to the wired varieties. That being said, we've tended to lean towards remote based triggers in the past, as this seems to enable a steadier image capture- it's a rare selfie stick with a built in trigger button that does not cause jumping and focus issues when depressed. Here's a little about our experiences with this particular self-portrait monopod:Yays:*First out of the box I noticed how slick this selfie stick looked. The adjustable mount/head seemed very durable and offered a wide range of motion and angles to capture the perfect shot, while the rubberized handle was great for gripping and the trigger button was inlaid beneath the surface material so minimal pressure was required to engage it. Where the design fell a little flat for us was the telescoping portion, which seemed almost to have a plastic shell- this looks a little cheap up front.*The materials are very lightweight being primarily aluminum, so this stick doesn't feel heavy on the wrist when fully extended. This is important not only for comfort, but for a steady, clear, photo opportunity.*Our unit did not come with a charge out of the box- which is something we look for in electronics such as this- however, it did charge in just over an hour and allowed us bout 30 minutes of Bluetooth connective time on that charge.*Bluetooth connection was straightforward and came up on our device as 'iSelfie' in the Bluetooth device menu. We've found about 1 in 5 pairs that our Android phones will not label the device by name, merely a series of numbers and letters. However, unless you're trying t pair several items at once, this is of little consequence.*There are 5 different length settings for the telescoping rod, up to almost 3 feet in length, so you can get that perfect intimate selfie, or scenic panoramic and group shot, all from one device.*The grasping harness at the end of the selfie stick has great range and extends to over 3 inches, making it capable of taking most small end phablets and all current Galaxy and iPhone models. For us, this was one of the biggest highlights of the phone- this joint, it's secure hold on our device, and the numerous angles which we could arrange it while still being able to securely lock it in place for photo-taking. This unit is all one piece and securely affixed to the rest of the device, so it is not removable or interchangeable with other style mounts (such as GoPro) or able to be transferred to singular mono-pods and photography stands. It's our opinion this singular one-piece build makes the unit stronger as a whole and more likely to hold up over time as you don't have to fear parts stripping and becoming weak.*This selfie stick comes with an included wrist strap which actually fit quite snug around Jay's wrist, and a little looser around mine. This device also comes with a carry case that seems to be made of durable nylon.*The device folds up rather compact, as the bracket at the very end actually tucks down along the base making it one of the more compact self-shooting aids we've seen. A device like this should be functional first, and portable second, so we're quite pleased with how small it folds up and how easy ti is to transport.*There is a threading on the base of the stick/handle to mount the device onto a secondary photo aid/tripod- though the bluetooth function must be triggered by the buttons on the handle- so this is only of use to stabilize the image when deing standard/traditional phone photography.Nays:*We had a hard time getting the telescoping shaft to extend and to lock. Even with the twisting motion, which seems quite intuitive, it took two of us to fully extend and lock this selfie stick initially. Because of this I worry that it might lose some of it's stability and ability to lock over time- though we we have not noticed any issues with the joints yet.*The side charging port, located near the trigger buttons, is very tight and at first we couldn't get it to engage properly and charge. Perhaps this is because there is a slight lip where the port is inlaid? While this is an inconvenience, so long as you verify charging status, after plugging it in and, before walking away it's a minor issue.*Not compatible with Window's phones- so it would not be appropriate to gift unless the recipient uses an iOS or Android device.In all, this is our second most used selfie stick in our collection, and a great bargain for the price. We've yet to find another self-shooting aid with such a sturdy mount build and Bluetooth connectivity that offers such portable and discreet transportation. The black finish and design is equally slick and could even pass as professional (rather than touristy) which is important when gifting. We received a product discount in exchange for our honest thoughts and experiences, which we have shared here.

This review is for the WHITE Touch Professional Scale (as shown in our photos,) this product also comes in black and red: We have bought several scales for gifts and use in our own home through the years. Many of our small 'kitchen' scales wind up going to use in the office for packages and postage measurements. When we saw this scale in person, I immediately knew I'd be keeping it in the kitchen for everyday use with ingredients and food portioning.The Yays:*At just under 9" at it's longest, and 3/4 of an inch in thickness this scale is very low profile and easy to store in just about any space. Because of the gorgeous tempered glass top I don't feel comfortable storing it on it's side in my kitchen, but it easily could be tucked away with cutting boards if desired.*2 AAA batteries are included in the box, so one can begin using their new scale right away.*This scale has a great range, covering 4 different measurement units. My Ozeri scale, I've been using up until now, tops out around 10lbs, so the 15lb weight limit here makes a big difference and the wider platform (plus reinforced tempered glass top) make this the perfect versatile scale for use in the home and kitchen. I was impressed that I could actually get it to measure and read out a quantity as low as 3 grams.*Highly accurate- I measured an apple alongside two other kitchen scales and all 3 read out identical. Make sure you always use your scale on a hard, flat, surface. There are gripping feet on the bottom of this scale but it will not measure accurately if on fabric (such as kitchen towels.)*Not only does the tempered glass top make this scale look elegant, it is impressively easy to clean and keep sanitary. I love that all buttons are touch operated and there are no cracks/crevasses/protrusions to collect direct and grime.The Mehs:*The packaging is nothing to write home about- if anything it does this product a disservice- The packaging could use a modernization to make it more appealing and gift friendly.*Okay, the 'no screwdriver needed' easy off battery backing- it looks pretty cheap. I used a butter-knife to wedge it off, with some effort- and after two time it's got some scuffing and deformation at the compartment notch. It just doesn't seem up to par with the rest of the scale.*I wish the back of the screen was back-lit.*While the scale will auto-time out after a short period not in use, I would like to see an on/off switch.I don't give a lot of 5 star reviews, especially when I have previously owned such a wide range of products in higher price points, but this scale is a bargain for the money. I would really love to get my hands on a red one to match my KitchenAid mixer! I received a product discount in hopes I would share my honest thoughts and experiences, which I have done.

I invested in these hoping I could improve my efficiency in the kitchen through an increased confidence in my knife skills- If I'm not focusing so much on not cutting myself then I can cut my fruits and veggies faster and more precise. I ordered a Large, as my hands tend to be long and slender and these arrived true to the advertised measurements.*The packaging is nothing special and these look quite underwhelming when they arrive- I wouldn't gift them, but they are suitable for home use.*The materials seems to be woven with some intensity and overlapping but is not heavy or tough to manipulate. Naturally, the first thing I wanted to go was run a sharpened blade along them. I was quite surprised that I could even recreate the product photo and grasp the blade. The gloves didn't seem to snag at all.*There is a rather large sewn in tag that was pretty bothersome when cutting, which I promptly removed.*The buyer needs to have accurate ideals about this product's protection level and experience; as the listing says t is not puncture proof. I have a knife similar to the product images and the very tip does poke and hurt when it runs directly into the glove. Do not use serrated knives with these gloves, and do not try to re-purpose them for gardening.*These gloves fit very snug, making them easy to manipulate, use, and wear when handling food. I've found I can keep them on to handle pots/ladles/lids in between kitchen prep.*I tested these with strawberries to see how well the fabric would hold up to stains. After rinsing in hot water the material's integrity seems in tact but there is a faint discoloration where the strawberry juices especially soaked in. It's not a big deal for me, as these are for kitchen use- but it's worth a note as I know some more pricey gloves and different materials are stain resistant.In summary, for the price point these are a great pair of cut resistant gloves for the home cook and casual chef. They allow maximum mobility, but could use a larger size to account for the tight fit. I'd like to see the product tag sewn in or 'tagless,' and it would be nice to see some stain resistance. These certainly do the job and are a great tool to have on hand. I received a product discount in hopes I would share my honest thoughts and experienced, which I have done.

Whenever I review an electronic, especially one dealing with audio output, people always wants to compare a high end unit to a value brand, when, in fact, its apples to oranges.I don't use my Infinity One portable speaker for the same sound output, situations, or locations as I do my JBL Charge 2. While part of it has to do with one being valued at almost triple the other- the majority of my reasoning is in the strengths one device has over the other. And yes, even in a much lower end device you are bound to find applications more suited to a $100 speaker than a $300 one. While one may deliver crisp expansive audio, the other may have a significantly longer battery standby life, for example.Primarily, for us, this bluetooth speaker has an appeal in the range of features it boasted at such an expendable price point. No one wants to hear their product is 'expendable,' but our brand loyalty to Sentey comes mostly from their execution of easy to use, functional, gaming products under a $50 price point. The convenience of Bluetooth devices lie in the portability of the product, and the vary nature of being portable puts a tech device in harms way from circumstances such as theft, water damage, and improper use (especially if your devices are used in communal circumstances.) While I would love to take my Infinity One to work at the marina and in the golf cart, my paycheck can't afford any mishaps around water or sticky hands from teenage skateboarders. In that case, I desire portable audio that is quick to setup, long lasting in life, and durable in design- with a price point under $50- so here we are testing the Sentey Bluetooth 4.0:Yays:*We always start with packaging- This speaker looks like it could have just come off Best Buy's shelf- It was packaged in a sturdy box inside an outer packaging sleeve. Not only did the box seem like it could withstand shipping and even continual storage, it was colorful and informative, something you don't often see in a value tech brand.*The design is very attractive- many 'bargain' bluetooth speakers come in bright gaudy colors that look and feel cheap- or targeted towards tweens. The slick black facing and 360 speaker design is very modern and style friendly for any geographic or setting. I love how the buttons on the top are inlaid under the rubber coated material so the speaker's operation is quite intuitive and seamless. While this speaker is not waterproof in a sense it could fall into water, the buttons on the top are all beneath the facing, so one could handle it with damp or wet hands without worry (this would be great in a kitchen when working on a recipe.)*This speaker includes a complimentary carry case, which you will want to use because the rubberized top and bottom coating seems to scuff easily. The case fits a little snug and has a drawstring close.*A big plus for me was the ability to play while plugged in- and the device even seemed to maintain or gain a charge while playing and charging. This mainly means I can use it as a stationary speaker in my office for an entire day without having to fuss with it.*Bluetooth pairing was quick, my devices located it on the first scan and there was no searching or fancy button configurations- simply turn it on and put your streaming device in Bluetooth discovery mode.*The product advertises up to 33 feet of connection thanks to Bluetooth 4.0 technology. This is a direct line of path claim- with minor obstructions such as furniture and a dresser, we maintained about a 15 foot connectivity. I COULD keep connectivity through the wall but this was a pretty direct proximity, best estimated at 8 to no more than 10 feet. When outside with no obstructions we successfully measured 30 feet of crisp, uninterrupted transmission.*I like that there is a direct on/off switch so there is never confusion about whether the speaker is on or off- this helps save battery life.*Speaking of battery life- This DOES have exceptional battery life for the value and clarity. On a full charge of Bluetooth wireless radio app streaming we've clocked 7 hours and 50 minutes play time.*The sound is stereo with 2 5 watt drivers for 10 watts total at about 125-250hz audio output. The bass on this speaker is fairly impressive for the price and size but not the same caliber as high output speakers you'd find over $200. In general, this speaker does beautifully with layered audio and instrumental heavy tracks- vocals can sound a little tinny at times (illustrated on the devices bluetooth calling feature) but in general what this device lacks in precision clarity (and don't get me wrong, it's great audio for the price range) it makes up in volume. Oh so very much volume. I can fill an entire veranda or pool deck with the output from this single portable speaker.Mehs:*While it seemed to turn 'on' out of the box, it would not pair- This is because it had no prior or residual charge. In general it's a pet peeve of mine when electronics don't include batteries, or a partial charge. No one wants to open a gift and have to wait hours to play with it.*Charge time from empty to full was long for a device of this size and output- it took nearly 3 hours (2 hours 45 minutes) to charge out of the box.*The upper and bottom material is a rubberized grip that is soft and slick but seems to scuff very easy.*The included cables aren't the highest quality or length. If you are an audiophile you likely have better quality cabled laying around- the charging cable, in particular fit a little snug for my liking. We use our own cables for aux and charging.*This claims to deliver big sound without the bulk- I feel it is one of the more bulky bluetooth speakers I own, especially for amp and bass output. Bulky can be a good thing, especially when you plan on using the speaker outdoors ad in social stations often. Bulky, in this case, also means it has weight in the hand and feels like it is built well- however, it certainly is not a dainty speaker.*It's hard to determine when you are done charging the speaker, and there's no real way to know how many hours or what percentage of battery life you have left. A visual queue or different colored light/patterns would be nice.In summary, this product performs at a believable range for it's list price of $69, and we've found it a great deal for the current asking price of $34 with prime. I like that this speaker has more of a presence than some of other other 'micro and portable bluetooth audio options and feel confident enough in the product that I would gift one to any casual to moderate music lover. I received a product discount in hopes I would share my honest thoughts and experiences, which I have done.

I bought these so I could transplant some of my bounty of baby tomato plants and expand my harvest... Each of my tomato pods produced 4 sprouts and so when I went to thin them out, I thought why not transfer the extras into spare pods and put them in my other AeroGarden.... Well it worked a treat.  I carefully split the roots and planted them in two of the pods and put them on growth mode in my spare garden.  I expect a bumper crop.  Enough to share.The price on this set is very good savings over other sets, even if you're only buying it for the nutrient bottles.

I love that this case matches my Chiaogoo Interchangeable sets.  I own the regular 5" red set and a custom 4" white set that I use to make hats and sleeves.  I decided I wanted to make myself a set of larger dpn's because I do make a lot of hats in the winter and it seems like I am always hunting down my needles.  This case fits the bill perfectly.There are 6 slots... my first slot actually holds both my size 4 and 5 dpns, then 6 and 7 on the left side in their own slots... the right side holds 8, 9 and 10, even though the 10s are in there very snuggly, they do fit and the case zips up.  I store my cable needles in the outside zipper pocket and they fit there just fine.... I feel very organized now, and all my larger needles have a home... No more hunting down the packets in the bottom of my basket.  I'm very happy.

So many reviews complaining about how small they are when the dimensions are right there in the description, the measurements are accurate.  Good thing tiny is exactly what I wanted and needed for a formal occasion I was invited to.These are NOT too small for an adult woman, they are petite and understated, and don't call attention to themselves even though they do catch the light a tiny bit, they are not sparkly at all... better than a naked earlobe or a tiny gold stud.  They cling closely to the earlobe but there is room between the lobe and earring that allows movement, they don't pinch, they don't get caught in my hair or pull.I am an older woman with multiple piercings... I will probably use these on an upper hole later on instead of my lobe, but for the occasion I bought them for, they were absolutely perfect.... They would also be great for a young girl.

I ordered 3 updated info tags for my cats when I disconnected my house phone and went to only having a cell.The quality of these is very good and the engraving is excellent, better than I expected.  These look like they will last a long time and the price can't be beat.  Shipping was very quick.  I am well pleased.I will not hesitate to buy from IO Tags again.

My figure is quite lopsided - size 22 on top and size 16 on the bottom... I usually am forced to buy for my bust size when purchasing dresses and it leaves me looking/feeling fat even if I add belt to gather in all the extra fabric below, or if I try on something closer to my waist size, my cleavage come flying out at the wrong time.. It is VERY rare I find a dress that flatters my shape and still corrals my breasts in an attractive manner.This dress does it.  I bought it to attend a memorial service and it was totally appropriate for the occasion.  I moved and bent and socialized all day without any bunching or readjustments or discomfort. The neckline looks nice on me, interesting and yet classic. I wore a simple strand of pearls and they were framed perfectly, this dress will easy to dress up or down with different jewelry...  The sleeve length is nice too.  I felt like I looked great all day long and never once worried about my appearance... Better yet, I looked shapely and beautiful in all the family photos.Now for the best news... I am sure this dress runs just a little large.  It's drapey and stretchy enough to hug the curves in a pleasing way.  I would have been better off with one size smaller, but even then, since this is a true wrap dress, it fit me fine and I was able to cinch it up to make my waist well defined even though it was a little big.  This dress travels in the suitcase very nicely too, no wrinkles or fold creases at all. I do plan to wear this dress quite a bit as my "little black dress" over the upcoming holidays.  It looks great on me.Bottom line is that I do think it's a little overpriced for what it is and what it's made of.  If I had seen it in a store I may have thought twice about buying it, but since I was in a hurry, didn't have time to shop and needed a quick dress delivered overnight, I suppose it was worth that convenience... I'll still wear it plenty of times in the future

This fit is amazing.  It's snug and form fitting but not tight and restricting.  The mid rise is exactly right and hits me at a perfect spot. This is the exact amount of bootcut I like too.  I don't have "mom butt".  They don't slice me in half when I sit or eat.  I think I look great in these!  WILL BUY AGAIN!!But these are long long long, the other reviews weren't kidding.  I'm 5'10" and these drag the ground when I am in my stocking feet.  Usually when pants say tall, they hit me at the top of my foot, skim the top of my shoes, but so many reviewers said these were too long so I figured they would be the perfect length.  Nope, these are super long, so I won't be wearing flats with these, and that's OK.  Next time I order these I'll try for the regular length and see how that goes.

I don't know why this has all these glowing reviews??  I bought 12 of these to replace the "kiddie alphabet" snap together blocks I had been using.  I found that some of those had color transfer onto the towel I used to cover the surface.  I always wondered if one day they might transfer onto my knitting... I had just finished a beautiful pi shawl so I decided to reward myself with new tiles.I originally chose these over some of the other professional blocking tiles because a) they had a printed grid, which I think will be necessary and b) you could buy them singly and not be tied into into multiple sets of 9 and c) Boye is a brand I have heard of and thought would be a decent quality product....Reality is different - first off, these tile reek - and not just a little, it's overpowering.  Each one is sealed tight into it's package and it just keeps the chemical smell fresh from the factory straight to your craft room.  I have tried washing them and airing them outdoors, but the smell still lingers.  Worse yet, it attaches itself to your knitting.  I piled towels over the surface before I blocked, but once it's wet it just permeates the whole stack... And piling towels sort of defeats the purpose of having grids.Secondly, these are way thinner and/or less dense than they ought to be.  Even pinning at a severe angle away from your knit edge or blocking wires won't keep the T-pin embedded into the tile (see my photo).  It will not stay taut and wants to creep toward the center of your work which sort of defeats the purpose of blocking, and it's not that I'm blocking tight or overly stretched, it's normal wet blocking that I've done time and time again.  The tiles themselves also tend to bend and bow at the interlocking seam under normal amount of pressure.  I think these were never intended for larger projects like sweaters...  Those pin holes won't heal up either... once they're there, it's always there and very conspicuous.... The only advantage of these thin, light tiles it that they take up very little room in storage.I invested so much money and thought in choosing and buying of these tiles, thinking they would last me for many years to come, but I just cant wait to get rid of them.  I may keep one or two of them to block small kitchen knitting like dishcloths, but never again for a big project like a shawl.  I can't believe that my cheap old playroom tiles are better than these tiles that are made specifically for blocking - I'm very disappointed... My next tiles will be plain white interlocking floor tiles, at least 1/2" thick... anything has to be firmer and denser than these things.  I think I've decided that the grid feature is not worth it after all.BTW - the blocking wires I use are Inspinknity brand flexible blocking wires - They are pretty much perfect in every way.  I love them!

My big winder was out on loan so I bought this one to wind several lace skeins.  The price is excellent and I do not plan to use it often.  I normally use a U-nitt Jumbo ball winder - I highly recommend investing in that large winder if you regularly wind anything over 50g of yarn... They say this one is good up to 4oz (113gr), but that's really pushing it... Smaller balls, this one is perfect and fast.First task once this winder is out of the box is to take an emery board and file off all the sharp and rough plastic bits and edges.  Once this smoothing is done, the winder is fairly wonderful.  Several reviews complain about the eye not staying upright and I found that to be true as well until I figure out that I had not pulled it out far enough to fully secure it into place.  If it seems like it is out as far as it should be, but it is still a bit floppy, pull out just a bit harder and it works better.  Once I did that it stayed firmly in the upright position perfectly through all the rest of the skeins.... I attached mine to a wooden cutting board instead of a table and did many skeins right there from my lap while I watched a couple of movies on TV.Use a swift to keep the tangles at bay, then crank slowly and smoothly and it winds just fine... as expected.  Nice, neat center pull balls, nothing got caught in the gears or went astray.  The key is slow and even cranking while you keep a gentle tension on the yarn while feeding through the eye.

I originally bought this as a joke birthday gift for my son who is a huge Nirvana fan.  Well the jokes on me because he uses it and likes it and loves going around asking girls to smell him and guess what he smells like (yeah yeah -- I know, I'm not proud of this behavior - If the girls would stop burying their noses in his neck and chest area he would stop using this cheesy pick-up line).The smell is sort of like berries, not overly feminine or flowery.  It gets rid of the stink and that's a good thing.

I got my piercing 3 months ago and was finally ready for a new stud, so this is the one I chose... I love it!  It's discrete and yet sparkly.  Many people don't even notice it's there unless it catches the light.I had never tried to put a pigtail stud in before (my original stud is just a straight bend).  Getting the screw in really didn't work well for me and hurt a LOT, but a friend had the solution.  She told me to take my smoothest pliers and gently straighten out just the end so the curve is not so tight.  It worked a charm, and went right in, and rested nicely on my nose.  It feels very secure and looks exactly like I envisioned it ought to.  I'm so pleased with how this looks that I'm not changing it out for a long time.The bonus of this purchase is the darling box the stud came in... It's a little pink drawer with some black foam in the bottom.  Cute cute cute!!  I'm planning on storing my future new studs in this box until I have too many, which may take awhile.  Easy to keep them all in one place and looks sweet sitting on my dresser.  It would be a nice gift box too.

I made lots of these little gingerbread houses for gifts this past Christmas.  The gingerbread I used was Hodgson Mill Whole Wheat Gingerbread Mix and it turned out great.... When they were cooled, I sprinkled the top with a little powdered sugar to look like snow on the rooftop, put them on a small plate, then gave them away.  Everyone loved them and complimented me on them.I'm thinking of making something more colorful at Easter time.  Little bunny houses sitting on beds of green coconut grass... it will be WAY cute!!  Maybe some decorated as beach cottages in the summer... lots of possibilities year round.

I love these.  Easy to customize.  It doesn't mention it in the description, but each one comes with two clear, tabbed dividers too.I put a ponytail elastic around mine to keep the cover shut, and that works very well for me.  It tends to not want to ever stay closed.This size fits nicely in my bag for easy access to my notes any time I need them.  Each binder can hold *almost* 150 cards if you smush them in tight.  Plenty of room to snap a pen into the binder rings before you fold it up.  Keeps it handy.My one and only complaint about this Oxford line is that the refills they expect you to use with this are lined on one side only.  The cards that came in the binder are printed on both sides, but the refills are not the same index cards at all.  I can't seem to find the two sided refills anywhere... but if you are only using one side of the card, they are great and fit the binder really well.

Well I didn't read the description well enough and bought several packs of these to fill up my Oxford Index Card Binder (which I love!!).  The binder came with double sided card and so I wrongly assumed the refill would be the same as what came with it.  I was wrong.  I can't find any pre-punched double sided cards.Other than that, these are great refills, handy to use and fit perfectly in the binder.  Most useful if you are only needing to use one side of the card.

I always wondered why my brewed iced green tea never tasted like the green tea from the restaurant or from a bottle.  I wanted to drink it for the health benefits and stop drinking so many carbonated drinks... Well, my answer was based in time and temperature and the quantity I needed for a whole pitcher, plus a few other factors... I started buying several different brands, but I never did make a nicely brewed iced green tea that satisfied me, until now.... Cold brew!
