For what is essentially a bin (you can't lock it and it isn't locked in place), the price is really too high. And if you have the sub-woofer (meaning you lose one-third of the bin's storage space) it is even less cost-effective. I bought mine through an Amazon Warehouse deal and even with all the discounts I can't see why it costs so much.Having noted my complaints, I will say the quality is pretty good/nice, installation is simple (instructions are clearly-written and very helpful), and it fits as well as it should.But the price.... And oh, the lost real estate....

Bottom line, not a book I really enjoyed. I do not share the same view of Scripture author Hamilton does and I found this got in the way. Having said this, I think the book gets in its own way. The front inside book jacket states that Paul "is second only to Jesus in his influence on Christian faith." What exactly does Hamilton mean? Well, we find out that Hamilton means exactly what he says and nothing more. What we find is that while Hamilton acknowledges influence, he doesn't seem to acknowledge much more than that. I guess it's Hamilton's liberal Christian leanings. As I don't share his theological assumptions, it was hard for me to get past Hamilton saying in the Introduction that while he admires Paul, he sees Paul as a man of his times and disagrees with him.To my mind, that makes Paul just another preacher-commentator. And if this is the case, then why is he in the Bible? But if he is supposed to be in the Bible then what does this say abut the Bible? I know where Hamilton is going and i choose not to accompany him on his journey; Scripture is far more to me than the writings of smart people and nothing more than that.I also had a problem with Hamilton showing up far too much in the book. Maybe I'm being a bit snarky here, but the title of the book perhaps should have been, "The Travels of Paul and Adam."Finally, as one other reviewer has noted, the photos are horribly reproduced as very low pixel, black-and-whites. Looks cheap.I see why so many reviewers rated the book 4 or 5 stars. But I also see why some went 3, 2, or even 1 star. So you - prospective reader - might enjoy. But for me and my household, at best a 3-star book.

This is a delightful book. While the "7 Secret" paradigm is a bit forced, the material presented is both easy to read/understand and absolutely helpful.I suspect "7" was not picked randomly. "7" is often described by Christian (and Jewish?) theologians as the number of completeness. If so, then by working through these seven steps the suggestion seems to be that the reader/couple will have both completed the "coursework" and "perfected" the marriage. Though I may be getting a bit too esoteric here, I did not like the use of "7" with steps that were labelled "Secret." Seems to gnostic to me and a good, healthy marriage should not be the result of some secret knowledge.In any event, the "secrets" (as you surely have guessed, I prefer "steps") are sequential and start with stopping destructive, negative behavior. So while Secret 1 would have the couple "stop," Secret 2 has the couple "Start" (in this case, start putting God first, spouse second, and by implication, self third). This should make absolute sense to any couple, but certainly to a couple that embraces Christian beliefs: Jesus told us that the first and greatest commandment to to love God and the second is to love one's neighbor (in this case, the spouse).Step 3 is about "connecting" (i.e., learning the skills of being present and active listening; as a grad student just about to complete my professional counseling degree program, I can tell you that few people are as present and listen as actively as they think they are). I had some difficulty with this chapter because I think communication styles can impact how one views how well the other person is actively listening and/or being present (and sorry, but it is not always the guy's fault). Step 4 logically speaks about "Engaging." Once properly "connected" engagement becomes the next challenge. The author rightly points out that good connection does not always lead to good engagement. So in this chapter, Dr. Kimberling addresses the delicate subject of "fighting right." Yes, we can have disagreements and yes, we can lose our patience with our other, but we need to learn how to do it in a healthy manner. The authors offers several "steps" and I think the first two are very much worth highlighting. First, ask God into the conversation before any tough discussion takes place. Besides the Christian belief that when two (or more) are gathered in Jesus' name, there He will be also, bringing God into the discussion before difficulties start means that there is less of a chance that all hell will break loose. Second, very few problems come about solely from the efforts of one of the partners (this is not an absolute; there are many examples where one party is primarily responsible for the difficulty, but we're not addressing those here). So while it may be tough to swallow one's pride, eat some humble pie prior to arguing. It's good for both the belly and the mind.Secret 5 is all about "balance." In this case, the author addresses finding a balance among one's life's responsibilities so that the spouse doesn't become third-string. There's quite a bit of good stuff in this chapter, but I think it could have used a short discussion of one more aspect of balance: our emotional balance. Broadly speaking, it does seem that in each marriage one partner seeks to balance out his/her deficiency with a partner who is abundant in what is deficient. All in all, the see-saw is generally balanced, but when the balance is the result of two extremes it's not a healthy balance. So I think the chapter could have addressed this idea a bit (more).Secret 6 speaks to "mingling." "Mingle" in this sense has nothing to do with getting out and making the rounds on the party circuit. Instead, Dr. Kimberling uses this chapter to address sex. Some will find this chapter full of new insight, others will see it as the weakest in the book. Regardless of where one stands, this is a necessary and important chapter to read.Finally, "Fight." Nope, this chapter is not about arguing. Instead, it's about expending effort (and lots of it) to keep on fighting the good fight. And what is the good fight? Well, working together as a team to stay a team. (or partnership or whatever else you might like to call it). Good chapter, if only from the perspective that far too many couples give up the fight far too soon. Too many couples fight and watch their marriage fail instead fight for the marriage.All in all, a really good little book. Has this stuff been written about elsewhere? Yup, and in spades. But what it has going for it is its conciseness, its gimmick (but very useful) packaging of Seven Steps (okay, Secrets), and its unabashed pro-marriage view. Probably best used as a pre-marital counseling aid, but worth a read whenever you are in your married life.5 stars!

I have wanted to start toying around with gadgets like this (at the intersection of computers and music). But I am quite the newbie. So to get a review that does this DJ Controller justice I lent it to one of my kids who plays with these sorts of things so he could put it through its paces. Here are a few of his comments....- The look and feel of this product is great. The design turned out to be a bit more compact than anticipated, but nothing felt crowded. Nothing cheap about the controller as the "feel" is very refined; all of the buttons, knobs, and turntables are polished and well manufactured. Bottom line, it seems well-built and likely to withstand many long nights of music and mixing.- The software was very easy to install (Mac OS X). I demo'ed the product in laptop mode (will probably install the iOS mobile sometime down the road). The interface, while very detailed, is laid out in a fashion that one can understand in no time at all. The computer screen mimics the physical controls on the board to a tee.- To begin mixing I uploaded all of my music from my iTunes library. Be warned; it does take some time for track info (i.e., bpm, key, etc...) to load. Also, you will need a pair of headphones and an external speaker (not your laptop speakers) to fully use this product.- At first glance, the potential of this product seems limited to scratching and mixing one track into another. However, if you take some time, scheme up some clever song medleys, the possibilities are really endless. For starters, slice loops in one track and work them into another. Record this new mix and then extrapolate from there. Then further tweak some EQ's, add some effects, and now you're really going. You really are only limited by your creativity.- The Hercules Universal DJ controller has been really fun to use so far. Though it's a bit time consuming getting all of your timing down, the end result is pretty fun and creative. Going to have to see if my dad will let me borrow this for a bit longer...!Well, there you have it. I probably would have given it 4 stars based on quality of build and what I thought I might be able to get out of it. But my son sees it as a solid 5-star bit of kit. I'll go with his view. 5 stars.

The $595 list price is ridiculously high. At the same time, the actual sell price ($61.00 here on Amazon at the time of this review) is equally ridiculous - low, that is. Frankly, this watch is a steal for that price.The watch looks really good on the wrist. Very large, very heavy, and very stylish, this watch will send a message (just exactly what that message is will probably be determined by the person you are and the group(s) you tend to hang with!).The knob on the left side of the watch (seven o'clock position) controls the "count-up" bezel (or "diver's bezel). The bezel is probably best used for things other than diving as I really don't feel comfortable wearing this on a dive (even though the manufacturer claims water resistance to 330 feet). The 3-position middle knob on the right side (3 o'clock) controls time and date adjustment. The upper right and lower right buttons control the stop watch functions (stop watch time is viewed on the watch face using the left mini-dial (minutes) and lower mini-dial (seconds)). The right hand mini-dial displays the hour in a 24-hour format. The date is displayed at the 4:30 position between the right side and lower mini-dials.In the end, this is a really nice watch with a really nice link band (comes ready to fit King Kong's wrist so be prepared to take some time to remove links (not at all difficult if you're familiar with Seiko or other stainless steel bands)). It's amazing that a watch this nice can be bought for the price Amazon is offering it at: years ago this watch would have gone for several hundreds of dollars (meaning a real heap of change in today's dollars).My only complaint is that this beautiful watch is packaged in a hideously yellow and ugly (faux-?) leather box. The box (I don't care if this is an Invicta tradition) makes you feel like you've bought a $5 wind-up. But get past the box to get to a really nice watch. Without reservation, 5 stars!

If you are expecting a full-fledged devotional to use during apregnancy you'll be disappointed. But if you're looking for a book that is essentially "thought of the day" // "fact of the day" you'll be thrilled (as the back cover states, this a is book of "short, inspirational readings").The layout is quite cute; each day's entry contains a thought and a Bible verse and every once and awhile there is a scientific/medical factoid. I really liked how the authors worked in "the count-down": while the weeks count up, the days count down.Nothing really complicated here, but quite delightful. If I had any complaint it would be that the book's small size leaves little room in the page margins if one wanted to journal as part of the journey.In the end, a delightful, five-star, little bundle to read and contemplate as you wait for the day when your truly delightful little bundle arrives. Wishing you "Happy Reading!" and a safe and healthy pregnancy.

So I pick up this book on authentic living and open to find that it is a book on faith (and what faith can do in our lives). Frankly, not at all what I thought I was going to see.By no means do I have a problem with a book on faith. But I do have a (slight) problem with a book that advertises one thing but delivers something else completely (or fails to make a connection between title and content). (Though to be fair, I guess if I had paid more attention to the inside cover page I would have seen "Faith-Walkers" clearly displayed between the title and sub-title.)Quick comment regarding "Faith-Walkers." I honestly have no idea who or what they are. But I understand Bill Blankschaen is a key figure in the group (did some research and read some of his posts on the Patheos blog). I guess if I had known some of this beforehand then some of my confusion would have been mitigated....This is not to say that the book is bad. It isn't. It's an apologetic of sorts for faith and its importance in building a life that is meaningful. And not a bad one at that. But field guide? Just not seeing it.In the end, if "this" is what you looking to read up on then by all means have at it. It seems like an excellent resource if this is where you are in your life and as a result find this to be an important issue. But while faith has always been and will continue to be an important part of my life this book's presentation of it wasn't something that attracted my interest or demanded my attention at this point. Who knows, maybe some time down the road. Just not now.Summary: 3 stars. Not because it's "bad"; rather, because it just didn't resonate with me on any level or from any appreciable perspective. Struggled mightily to stay engaged; found it very hard not to put down. Evidently, not for me.

I understand that one of the reasons books are successful (or not) is how well the author connects with the reader. So a horrible book just might do well if it's written in a way that grabs its readers. Likewise, a wonderful book may not do as well as it might if the author-material-reader connection doesn't quite click."Joy" - fortunately - is not in the former category. It is in no way a horrible effort. Quite the opposite. Unfortunately, for me anyway, "Joy" is in the latter category. Interesting, informative, easy to read, but not a book that I felt any connection to or with.I was provided an advance reading copy so a few of my concerns may have been addressed in the final publication. First, I wish the foot- / end-noting had been a bit more comprehensive. Second, given the repeated theme of "appearances" throughout the book, the book deserves far, far more photos than were provided (this is not an effort where "orientation photos" suffice; this book should have been jammed full of photos of all the characters we read about). Speaking of characters, as they come in and go out of the book the author identifies certain characters as important, but more often than not I didn't really get a sense of why they were important. Finally, some passages come off as frustrating "non sequiturs" or contradictory (perhaps upon rereading it might not seem so, but I really don't look forward to rereading a book in the hope that it will make more sense the second time around (unless the material is so dense as to demand a second look)).The author wanted to make a very complex woman accessible to a target audience that adores the husband and longs to know more about the enigmatic wife. So the book is written less as a serious, academic life study and more like a popular one (or very long or serialized magazine essay). Okay, no problem. But with the accessible style came a style that I felt was less than tight. I found myself becoming bored and disengaged (and often struggled not to put it down), a surprise given the intensity and complexity of the book's subject. As such, the book could have benefited from a more rigorous editing process. But I concede this might be unfair criticism: I can also see the book's style as indicative of the author's attempt to forge a friendship between herself, the subject, and the book's readers (the book seems to come across as more of a conversation over coffee than a serious biography).This is not to say the book is "bad" or deficient; rather, only that I didn't fall head over heels with it (didn't love it, didn't necessarily like it; it was okay). On the plus side, this book should serve as an excellent introduction to Joy Davidman. But "definitive"? Hardly; that book is waiting to be written. As such, it would be a crime if all the material she uncovered and (supposedly) had first access to never gets the opportunity to be mined further. So I hope the author considers one (or both) of the following: either write a second book that goes deeper or help ensure this material gets to other researchers so that they can do so. Joy Davidman lived a full life and as such deserves a fuller treatment.Summary: 3 stars. Good introduction to Joy Davidman Gresham Lewis. But I did not connect as well as I had hoped I would to the subject, the author, or the material. Finally, not definitive.

I am of two minds regarding this offering from Carolyn McCulley and Nora Shank (hence, the three stars). On one hand, the book is well-written, the points are concisely presented, and the authors' assertions seemingly sound. But the book seems like two essays mashed into one book. I enjoyed the first essay (essentially, a look at the history of "wifehood"), but felt flat reading the second essay (essentially, a series of metrics to help a woman know she is "successful").More importantly, however, the book seemed disconnected from...I don't know, but something. Then I remembered reading in the Preface that this offering is essentially the third book in what amounts to a de facto trilogy. Not having read the first two books I guess I can see why the book seems disconnected; it's connected to books I've yet to read. Perhaps if I had read the other two this book would rate higher (in fact, a quick review of some of the other reviews seems to show that those who are familiar with the authors rate the book more highly).Anyway, even though I gave the book 3 stars, that doesn't mean it's not worth one's time. I'm sure there will be many critics, but I suspect these critics will be coming from a different historiographical perspective or hermeneutic. In the end, I enjoyed the authors' perspectives and did learn a few things. I've passed the book over to my wife; it will be interesting to hear her thoughts on it.Summary: 3 stars. A short read. Interesting in places (1st part), boring "same old-same old" in others (2d part). Perhaps best read after reading the authors' first two books (Did I Kiss Marriage Goodbye?: Trusting God with a Hope Deferred and Radical Womanhood: Feminine Faith in a Feminist World). Personal ideology will drive whether you find the book helpful or cringe.

There's quite a bit to like in this new offering from David Hawkins. I'm not sure that you'll never fight again after reading this book, but there are a bucketful of good nuggets and take-aways. The Carrie Fisher quote to open Chapter 5 is a hoot (and will find a place in my office at some point). The chapter on "power plays" is good reading as well.I do agree that much of what plays out as marital conflict is actually a symptom of unresolved, personal, internal conflict. As such, chapters 5-8 are key (and the main reason why I can recommend this book whole-heartedly).If I have to nit-pick, I would say that I didn't necessarily agree with his assumptions about anger, conflict, negotiation, etc. I do not subscribe to the view that conflict is never good, negotiation is usually another form of power play, etc. Here's an example. At the start of Chapter 8, Hawkins writes that "Fighting, as you recall, occurs from a sense of self-righteousness, entitlement, outright selfishness, and resultant anger." Really, all fighting stems from these issues? There's never a time where fighting is either necessary or a result of some other factors? In the end, I just don't enjoy reading such blanket statements (and there are many throughout).But my objections to the book are, in a way, unfair. I'm complaining that the author doesn't take in-depth looks at all the issues he introduces. In a way, I'm complaining that the book has neither the length of "War and Peace" nor the depth. But the author never intended it to be a deep, philosophical treatise on marriage; instead, the author delivers to the reader what amounts to a handy workbook/study guide that I can see doing a heap of good for couples in trouble. So, in one sense, you can just sweep my objections aside...!Summary: Okay, look. The book is good, but there's nothing really new here (despite the eye-grabbing title). You can find this stuff on marriage and marital counseling in a myriad of other places, books, etc. Biggest benefit is that the book delivers "good stuff" from a respected author in the field of marital counseling in a handy, little package.

I find myself in full agreement with the other 5 star reviews. This may not be an important book (in that you could and can find much of what Goldsmith writes on elsewhere), but it is an excellent book.Goldsmith writes in a style that allows the book to be used in multiple settings. You're from a business setting? You'll like how Goldsmith applies principles to business. You're from the mental health field? You'll like how Goldsmith breaks down and discusses the ABC's of Cognitive-Behavioral theory. You're looking for a self-help book that explains why our good intentions rarely/never result in lasting change? You'll like how Goldsmith discusses the never-ending battle between planner and executor that goes on within each of us.This is  book that you will find yourself going back to time and time again. You'll find yourself rereading it from cover-to-cover. You'll find yourself popping it open for a quick refresher.  You'll find yourself underlining, highlighting, and writing notes in the margins. You'll probably find yourself recommending the book to family, friends, and colleagues.  You may even find yourself buying additional copies to lend or give as gifts. Yup, it's that kind of book. It's that good.Enthusiastic 5 stars.

I expected a mattress protector like the ones I was familiar with back when I was growing up (or my kids were). Fortunately, technology has really moved forward and that was a pleasant surprise.The Perlux protector is soft, does not crinkle like cheap plastic, and does not smell like rubber or feel rubbery. Actually, it feels quite nice. So my first impression was a really positive one.We washed it prior to first use according to the instructions. It didn't really feel that much softer (but that's not a ding on the product: we thought it pretty soft to begin with). The mattress protector fits our queen-size mattress without problem. So my second impression was positive.I know there are folks who prefer a warm/hot bed. But I can only sleep (well) when cool. For example, I cannot sleep on foam-style mattresses except in the coldest winter months as these mattresses trap and keep body heat. And here's where the mattress protector "fails" me: it's too hot.So it seems to me it comes down to this: if you are a "warm" sleeper you probably will love this product, if you are a "cool" sleeper you'll probably have a tough time liking this item. I did not test the waterproof claim, but have no issue in that if it's not entirely water-proof I'm sure it will be sufficiently water-resistant. That would be enough for me for the use we need the protector to meet.Summary: A 5-star product that is docked 1 star (down to 4) because I'm a "cool" sleeper and this protector doesn't let me do that.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book finding it very informative and very accessible (i.e., the authors chose to write in a manner that is very understandable to the lay reader). My first impression was that the book was a long essay masquerading as a book (seemed quite repetitive). But upon further consideration I realized the authors were addressing the book's main actor - your gut's microbiota - not in a repetitive way, but from different angles.First, the authors address the declining number of species of bacteria in the typical Westerner's gut and why this may be a very bad thing. They then tell us not only why diversity in the gut is important, but also why gut bacteria is important in the first place.The authors then discuss how we "get" bacteria in our gut and why some of today's health fads are getting in the way of good bacteria getting where they need to be. I was floored about the authors' comments on society's overuse/improper use of anti-microbials (and antibiotics) and how our phobia of germs may very well be making us less healthy. On the flip side of the coin I also appreciated how the authors explained why "eating a peck of dirt" may actually be good for you and why you might not want to wash your hands all the time (something most parents when I was growing up knew to be true). But I was most floored by the short discussion on non-emergency caesarian deliveries and how they too might be making our children unhealthy. These three discussions alone are worth the cost of the book.There is an interesting (though ultimately unfulfilling) discussion on probiotics, prebiotics, and synbiotics (unfulfilling because I wanted a definitive answer and the authors demonstrate there is no definitive answer: every individual's microbiota is unique and as such no pro/pre/synbiotic can be manufactured to meet every individual's gut's requirements). But they do (helpfully) offer general suggestions (e.g., why fiber is important and the different types of fiber, why bacteria-fermented foods such as yogurt are important, etc.).Anyway, take a look at the table of contents and I think you'll be intrigued (if this is something you're interested in):- Chapter 1: What is the Microbiota and Why Should I Care?- Chapter 2: Assembling Our Lifelong Community of Companions- Chapter 3: Setting the Dial on the Immune System- Chapter 4: The Transients- Chapter 5: Trillions of Mouths to Feed- Chapter 6: A Gut Feeling- Chapter 7: Eat Sh!t and Live- Chapter 8: The Aging Microbiota- Chapter 9: Managing Your Internal FermentationThe book contains about 40 pages of recipes that include/use food items the authors say (throughout the book) are beneficial in establishing and maintaining a healthy gut ecosystem. There is also an excellent presentation of end notes for the references the authors refer to throughout the text.In the end, my gut tells me the authors are on to something, that they are correct in their assertions, and that time will bear out their arguments. But I'm no expert. I do know this is no "fad" book.  As such, even if you choose not to embrace the dietary lifestyle they espouse the book deserves serious consideration.Summary: A solid 4+ stars deservedly rounded up to "5 stars."

I live right on the line between Scotts "North" and "transition" zones. As such, this perennial rye mix may not have been the best choice for a grass seed. But we'll see....As has always been the case when I use Scotts lawn seed, the seed grows quickly into a nice, thick patch of grass. Within days (I exaggerate, but only a little!) it began to look full and fabulous. And I'm sure it will stay so throughout the remainder of the Spring. Where I've had problems is when the late Spring direct sun starts to beat down on the grass. It's not the heat or the humidity; rather, it's the sun. When it starts blazing the grass starts withering and no amount of water helps.This time I'm using the seed in an area that receives far more shade than where I've tried it previously. We'll see if that helps. In the end, I can't fault Scotts if this doesn't take and hold, it will probably be a result of buying a seed that was better suited for a location further north. But so far, so good.Summary: 4 solid stars. I have been a die-hard fan of the company's products since I was a wee, "lawn-mowin' for pocket change" kid. Scotts products are always first-rate and reasonably priced. Bottom line, Scotts products are low on hype and high on performance. This grass seed is no different.

This is a "cut and paste" of the review I did on the Reebok "high boot" version (Reebok Men's Rapid Response RB8895 Safety Boot). Having tried both, the comments equally apply. Here goes....These boots are really, really nice and very comfortable. I wasn't sure if I would like the side zipper, but it works well. The "pull-on" loop on the back is helpful.But if you have narrow feet you will find your feet swim in the forefoot unless you "pad" with additional (or thick) socks. If Reebok would make a "narrow" version (these "medium width" boots felt very much like "wide" boots), then we would have a SIX-star review. I've found that the 5.11 Men's 6" Taclite  Boot is a better fit for my narrow feet (they are equally as comfortable, but lack the zipper). Size of these Reebok boots is about 1/2 size big (I wear size 11, but needed a 10.5 in the Reeboks (the 5.11 Taclite boots ran true: I wear 11 and the boots were an 11)).The zipper makes all the difference in what boot lace-up system is used. You'll note that the 5.11 Taclite boots use eyelets in the fabric while the Reeboks use plastic eyelets. If the Reeboks didn't have the zipper I would not ever touch them because the plastic eyelets are a highly possible point of failure. Given that most will lace up the Rebooks and leave them laced (using the zipper to take off and put on the boot) this is not too much of an issue (ergo, no plastic eyelets on the 5.11 Taclite boots).One other observation. Reviewers have complained that there is no steel toe but that the boots are advertised as safety boots. This is neither misleading nor incorrect. Yes, they are safety boots and yes they do not have a steel toe. But the product literature tells you that Reebok chose to not use steel so that there would be no issue with metal detectors, etc. In any event, the toe may not be steel, but it still seems to offer significant protection. In the end, if you're a lumberjack or the like and need real steel toe protection then these are not the boots for you. But if you are a soldier (etc.) these are perfect boots (and as a former armored vehicle crewman I can tell you not having steel toes is a plus: I remember having a pair of steel-toed boots and they helped my feet to freeze in the winter and roast in the summer).Reebok has done really, really well in these boots. If only they would make a narrow foot version!
