Vine reviewer J.S. Dean wrote an excellent review and really does cover just about everything you might want to know about this unit. So allow me to echo some of his comments and perhaps add one or two of my own....The shipping box this unit arrives in is SO heavy that if you're not a weight lifter it would be best to have a dolly on-hand. As reviewer Dean noted, the box arrived absolutely battered and opened in several places. But he is correct; there is a nice layer of Styrofoam around the unit parts such that (frankly, unbelievably) nothing was damaged (at least that I've been able to see).The build is straight-forward and like just about every other slap-together, particle board piece of furniture. Again, as reviewer Dean noted, the item moves about very easily because it is essentially two items (a stand and a rolling drawer). That's convenient, but also makes the unit less sturdy. Though it looks solid, when you pull out the drawer you see the unit stands on three relatively unsupported legs (see Dean's second picture); I would have really liked it if there was a bottom piece to tie the sides and middle piece all together (instead of relying solely on the back panel). My point is this: if someone accidentally pushed the drawer in too fast and too hard against one of the side pieces you could break the side away from the top and cause the whole thing to come crashing down. This is not far-fetched; I did this once to a piece of particle board furniture. So I respectfully disagree just a bit with reviewer Dean on this point.As such, I don't feel comfortable using this as an AV stand with TV, video gaming system, BD player, etc. Instead, I now think I'll use it as an office printer stand for my multi-function laser printer. Paper and toner cartridges in the rolling drawer, accessories on the shelf, and printer up top.I agree about the roller/casters, but fortunately mine is on a wood floor. I too like the idea of nylon feet to keep the board up off the floor; I plan on using more than a few (probably three each on each side and on the middle piece).In the end, this is not a bad piece of kit. Reviewer Dean thought it relatively sturdy, but over-priced. I thought it less sturdy and at $160 or so not unreasonably priced. But I think we both agree that you are getting what you pay for. In this case that means you get a unit that is a bit bare and lacking in a few things that would make it a nicer unit (like a backing that backs the shelf, a bottom that makes the unit sturdier, and more than casters).As far as "best use," imo it's probably best-suited in a home office, a kid's room/kid's romper room, or a dorm room.Summary: Not super excited about it, but neither am I disappointed. So 3 stars, perhaps even 4 stars. Certainly, no more. Probably cheaper options out there, but it's not bad.

Honestly, I had never heard of Griot's Garage before. Perhaps it's a famous company, but I'm not that much of a car geek. As such, I have generally been satisfied in the past with whatever I could get my hands on (so long as it was of reasonable quality).Anyway, Griot's Garage certainly delivered on their product promises. It is really soapy/sudsy, does have a high viscosity, and does smell nice. Most of all, it really cleans well. We put it through its paces this past weekend washing several cars and we were very pleased with how they all turned out.I cleaned "more car" using less soap than I usually do. So this jug should last a while. That means it is probably less expensive in the long run than other initially cheaper products. I'm impressed and will look to Griot's Garage for post-wash waxing and other products. Reasonably priced and does what it is advertised to do, this Griot's Garage offering is a solid five stars.

Very, very, very nice and very clever installation procedure. Be aware though that these mud flaps not only do not fit Raptors, they do not fit a 2012 F-150 FX4 (correct P/N for an FX4 seems to be 110003).

Very, very, very nice and very clever installation procedure. Be aware though that these mud flaps not only do not fit Raptors, they do not fit a 2012 F-150 FX4 (correct P/N for an FX4 seems to be 120003). Will order them and see what happens.

At $199 this microwave is priced about right. It has Samsung's high quality of build, numerous features, and sharp looks. And it does what it claims: microwave and grill cooking.It looks like a typical microwave, but if you look inside the cooking compartment you will see a grill element (like those found in electric ovens) on the roof of the microwave. It doesn't have the convection cooking feature, but the addition of the grill element means the microwave oven is far more versatile than a simple microwave-only appliance. The addition of the cooking rack and cooking plate adds to the unit's versatility.And therein lies my problem. I would love to use this oven as my "main" cooking appliance, but I can't. I find the compartment too small and the wattage too low. I love the look of the machine but it is about 2 inches too small in every dimension (height, width, and depth). It just doesn't fit all the things we would love to stick in it.My wife and I compared this 1000-watt unit to a 1,250-watt unit and there is a noticeable, appreciable difference. It took almost 30-percent longer to heat a cup of water in the 1000-watt Samsung unit than in our 1,250-watt unit.  This was pretty much the result we encountered in every use.The grill element works as advertised. Very cool. We are still experimenting with it, but initial results have been promising. One reason it's been slow going is that the included manual is simply awful (don't look online for an expanded version; the online manual is the same as the one in the box). There are a number of places in the manual where (to us) the directions are unclear, ambiguous, and confusing. We are still experimenting with the "instant cook" feature (i.e., preset cook times); it's not working as we thought it would, but again that could be an issue of us not understanding the manual.We like the "Eco" feature (allows you to turn off the clock/counter LED; no light and no vampire power drain). We didn't like the lack of rubber feet on the bottom. And we didn't like how cheap the door release felt (too much slop). But it does look nice and performs well.Summary: 4 stars. Nice, but not perfect. Wish it was a little bigger, wish it had a little more oomph, and wish there was a little more attention to detail (e.g., user manual, latch slop, rubber feet).

Once again NOCO delivers a very high quality product at a very reasonable price ($17.95, retail). This is not mandatory in any sense of the word, but if you decide you do need it it makes for a wonderful, high quality accessory.A typical use would be to route the engine block heater plug to this port so that the three prongs of the plug a) do not stick out of the vehicle's front grill and b) do not rust. Routing the block heater plug to the NOCO port protects the block heater's plugs and makes for a far more aesthetically pleasing solution. Another possible application is to "clean up" an installation of a (NOCO) battery charger permanently mounted near an RV's house battery set. It really, really looks sharp.The plastic of the port is high quality; I do not think it will be affected by the sun at all (or, if it is, not for a long, long time). The rubber port cover fits very snugly. The 16-inch cord is long enough to be helpful, but not so long as to get in the way and require "coiling." The wire gauge is appropriate: at 13 amps it will carry the same current as the extension cords most of us will run out from the house to the port. It feels substantial and well-made.I am a huge fan of NOCO's products. I have several of the company's battery chargers (which I use to keep the batteries in my emergency generator, lawn tractors, etc. charged) and find them easy to use, rugged, reliable, and priced at a very fair price point. This port plug accessory continues NOCO's tradition of fine products at consumer-friendly prices.A 5-star accessory.

This is one of those items where the rating depends on whether it works. Flonase is not for everyone; as with most medications much of the effectiveness depends on the person using it. In this field, it is not so much that Product X is better than Product Y; rather, it comes down to whether it works and whether it works depends on whether the med "connects."I have had excellent luck with Flonase, but not because it has been effective as the occasional go-to product; it's not a rescue med and you will be utterly disappointed if you are trying to use it as such. Being a steroid, the mechanism of treatment is long-term relief of irritation and swelling. Long-term relief does not come immediately; instead, it takes several days (at the absolute minimum) to begin to take effect.I use Flonase as the med to relieve chronic inflammation due to "sinus disease." For allergy relief (immediate and long-term) I have to turn to other products.Some reviewers have complained about the floral smell of the product. I can understand the objection, but for me the scent is helpful: it reminds me I've used the product.Competing products have also noted that Flonase contains alcohol. That's true. Whether that is a problem, I don't know. But someone who needs to avoid alcohol might want to know this in order to make an informed decision.At $25.00 per 120-count spray bottle, that's $0.21 per spray. If you spray once each nostril twice a day, that's a bottle per month. Not cheap, but not unreasonable. So it appears this might be a win-win for both the manufacturer and the consumer.In the end, Flonase is a 5-star product as it does what it says it will do and does it well. BUT IT DOESN'T NECESSARILY WORK FOR EVERYONE. So go into the purchase with your eyes open, use it as you're supposed to and evaluate afterwards. If it works, you've found a great product; if not, move on and try something else.

After using Zagg screen protectors for years on my phones and tablets (though - caveat - I use the Moshi-series of screen protectors for my Kindle Fire tablets) I didn't think the product category could be improved upon. But I was wrong. This is a fantastic screen protector at a fantastic price (about $22 on Amazon at the time of this review).No joke, the screen clarity is amazing. And the install process is far easier than the flexible film/plastic types. There's no squirting and squeegeeing. The screen lays down cleanly with a minimal of bubbles. Just make sure you clean the screen with the included wipe and line up the protector correctly. It took me three attempts before I felt the screen had lined up correctly on the S4. But once down and the few bubbles pressed out, it fit perfectly and looks simply amazing. And it's not at all thick and/or cumbersome: the Otterbox Commuter case went back on without problem. There have been a few low-star reviews for this screen protector (e.g., lots of bubbles, too big for the S4), but I encountered none of these problems.Frankly, I'm stunned at how good this accessory is. This is a fantastic product that is backed by Zagg's unconditional replacement policy. Not sure how one can go wrong.Love it. Solid, solid 5 stars.

My first foray (about a year or so ago) into Powerline Ethernet technology was with the ZyXEL PLA407 HomePlug AV 200 Mbps Powerline Wall-Plug Adapter (Starter Kit - 2 Units). In the end (and I still can't quite figure out why) I could never get the adapters to work correctly.It was then with trepidation that I took a stab at this Netgear kit. My experience with these adapters couldn't be more different than the one I had with the Zyxel kit. It really is as simple as plug the adapters in, connect them to the router and device to be networked, and watch the magic happen. Within two-three minutes the adapters had recognized each other and a connection was established between the device I was connecting (A WD NAS device) and the network router. I was moving files to the NAS shortly thereafter. The transfer rate was only slightly less than transfers that used only the Ethernet cabling; in other words, moving data using the home electrical system causes only a slight degradation of speed.Powerline adapters add an encryption feature because theoretically (actually, more than just theoretically) they open your private wired network to the world via your house electrical circuit. So using the encryption feature is more than just a convenience; in this day and age it is a necessity. And it is here where the Netgear package stumbles. The install manual states that one shouldn't push the "encrypt" button (located on the side of the unit) until the "Pick A Plug" LED is blinking. The system has now been up and running for quite some time and still no blinking "Pick A Plug" LED. Running out of patience I eventually pressed the "encrypt" button (for 2 seconds) and as expected the "Pick A Plug" LED went dim. Before the allowed 2 minutes were up, I pressed (for 2 seconds) the "encrypt" button on the other adapter. As the directions state, the "Power" LED will start blinking showing that an encrypted connection is being established. Within a few seconds both "Pick A Plug" LEDs were fully green. So here's my quibble: after looking through the install booklet, the user manual, and (online at) Netgear support I still can't find anything that tells me I have established a secure, encrypted connection between adapters. For all I know I have exposed my network and the data on it. Simply put, unacceptable.I'm going to email Netgear to see if they can help. If they can clarify the encryption procedure or tell me I do have an encrypted connection (and what I should see to confirm this), then we will have a serious 5-star product (and I'll update this review accordingly). Until then, even though it looks good, functions well, and is priced right it will remain a 4-star product at best.One final thought. It occurred to me that I might want to give the Zyxel adapters a try again. I'm guessing the Zyxel adapters will not be compatible with these Netgear ones. Would certainly like to know if anyone has a more definitive answer.

Once again OXO hits a home run. The quality of build, ingenuity, and price point are right on target and in line for what OXO seeks to accomplish/achieve.The stainless steel feels really nice and there were no obvious weld points. The plastic tray is equally nice and sturdy. The suction cups are really cool: just wet and push down to achieve a solid lock and seal. The padded hanger fits the shower pipe snugly. And it's HUGE; it really seems that you can easily store 6-7 sizable shampoo, body wash, or the like on the shelf and have no fear that the whole thing will come tumbling down.Though I gave this product 5 stars, it's not perfect (at least in my view). First quibble: it's HUGE! Aesthetically, it really takes over the shower. And it is so big that I felt I could use it as a book shelf! I guess if one wanted to have a water-proof radio or bluetooth speaker in the shower but had no place to put it this shelf would do the trick.One further quibble: we put the soap on this shelf, so I wish there was a third hole in the middle (where we put the soap). Right now the soap scum(?) collects on the shelf and we have to remember to wipe nightly.And one final quibble. This shelf could really use a hook (or something) to hang face cloths or back scrubbers (etc.). In the end, I think we would be better served (and get more use from) this OXO product: OXO Good Grips 3-Tier Shower Caddy.Quibbles considered, this is still a solid offering from OXO and fully deserving of a 5-star rating.

I was very pleasantly surprised when I finally got this product in my hands. I expected that the display rail would allow for a single row on the top and one on the bottom for securing notes, envelopes, photos, etc. But the film (the material that acts to hold/catch whatever one is seeking to display) is "looped" so that there is actually two channels each on the top and bottom.The rail is constructed of a very nice feeling plastic and seems to be quite well made. The film loop seems like it will not degrade over time (but only time will tell if it, in fact, does stand up). I like the "command strip" Velcro-type attachments: the rail need not be "stuck" in any one particular location; you can have several mounting locations (we have one location in our kitchen and a second in a travel trailer).So what we have is a really neat product that fits in any number of categories: home organization, business, memento display, etc. To me, then, it comes down to cost: is $21.50 (at the time of this review) money well-spent? Probably (it's in line with comparable products), but I would prefer to see the price about $5.00 cheaper (in the $15.00-16.50 range). It's still a 5-star product, but would be a slam dunk 5-star product if it could be offered at a bit cheaper price.Nice job, Post-It folks!

I'm afraid I cannot share other reviewers' enthusiasm for this product. At almost $10.00 (at the time of this review) the product simply fails to deliver. At $5.00 maybe, but $10? No.Unless the material used is some form of "super fiber" that I'm not aware of, this sleeve looks and feels like a cheap vinyl/plastic throw-away item. It feels awful and looks equally so. The zipper is cheap and doesn't work very smoothly. The exterior mesh pocket is essentially worthless as the Velcro tab used to close it off covers only the middle third of the opening. The "Five Star" logo was silk-screened crookedly.But what I dislike the most is that though the product description says it will fit a 7-inch tablet the reality is not so straight-forward. It depends on which tablet and which case (if any). For instance, this sleeve does not work with my 7-inch Kindle Fire HDX unless I take off the Fire HDX out of its Atlas Waterproof Case for Kindle Fire HDX 7" by Incipio, Black (which pretty much defeats my protection scheme). In the interest of writing a relatively comprehensive review I did remove the Fire from the case and found that it swims in the sleeve (which then makes it far more likely to fall out). The Kindle Fire HDX fits fairly well if it's in a Belkin Chambray Cover for Kindle Fire HDX (will only fit Kindle Fire HDX 7"), Blacktop. Interestingly, it almost fits my Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 (8-inch): while it's a bit too short, it holds the Tab far more snugly than the 7-inch Kindle Fire. In other words, whether this bag will work for you really depends on what you do with your tablet: with no case, your tablet will swim in this sleeve, with some cases you'll get a "just right" Goldilocks solution (the Belkin case), and with others it just won't work (the Atlas Incipio case or OtterBox Defender Standing Case for Kindle Fire HDX 7", Black). But I guess that's what you get when you go with a generic solution: something that's neither fish nor fowl.Being generic I can't fault it for really not fitting any of my devices. But I can fault it for being too cheap a sleeve at too high a cost. Either give me a better solution that's worth the money or price it accordingly. Given that I generally like and purchase Five Star's products (I've found that they do generally deliver good value for the dollar), I was hoping for much more and it's only my like of Five Star that keeps this from being a 1- or 2-star review.Summary: this sleeve is a bust and something that I can only grudgingly give 3 stars. Not a fan.

I was first introduced to "dry" lubes when I started using Park Tool CL-1 Synthetic Blend Chain Lube Bottle (4 oz) to keep my bike chains lubricated when I went out for a ride in wet or other sloppy conditions. After only one or two uses I became a believer: this stuff works. So when I found out about this 3-in-ONE dry lube I had to give it a try. And I wasn't disappointed.My usual go-to product for door locks and other items that needed lubrication was WD-40 Multi-Use Product Spray, 3 oz.. But WD-40 evaporates relatively quickly and can leave an oily residue. So while I love WD-40 as a "break free" application and quick squeak silencer, I wasn't completely satisfied with it as a longer-term lubricant. Enter this 3-in-ONE product.Over the past several weeks I used this dry lube on exterior door locks, a quick lube on a bike, and on several items that needed a bit of lube/squeak silencing. Absolutely excellent results. The locks work more easily (even in the recent cold [below freezing] weather) and there have been no "runs and drips." All-in-all I'm very satisfied. It's not so good on a bike chain that I will put the Park CL-1 aside (the cost differential is not so much as to cause me to put aside an excellent specialty product for a cheaper general one), but as a quick fix this dry lube does the trick.As the president of that hair club used to say, "I'm not just the president, I'm also a client," in this case, "I'm not just a Vine reviewer, I bought one too!"Summary: 5 stars. Very pleased. Worth every cent of the 5 dollars and change it costs.

The TP-LINK Archer C20i dual-band wireless router is a very nice, very reasonably priced multi-standard router. The box contains the router, AC adapter (110v dual prong), ethernet cable, and Setup (mini) CD.The router can be initialized either by using the CD or by logging in to the router via web browser. I found basic initialization far easier if the the mini CD is used. Advanced settings are accessed via web page log-in after basic setup is completed.I've been using Netgear and D-Link routers for years and have grown accustomed to their menu skins. I may now have a new favorite; I thought TP-Link's setup wizard and menu layout really pleasing to look at, logically organized, and easy to understand (the help panel (on the right side of the screen) offers some of the best help that I've seen lately).Just about "everything" is customizable, so given the opportunity I did quite a bit of customizing. Nothing fancy, but I feel like I have a router that is "mine." For instance, (and I admit right up front that it may be a silly thing, but) I like that I can change the router settings log-in username from "admin" to a username of my choosing.I had absolutely no problem completing the setup and putting the router into service. The (standard) 2.4 GHz band worked flawlessly. A few reviewers have noted issues/problems with the 5.0 GHz band, but none so far for me; when I have had 5.0 GHz issues (with other routers) it has always been traced back to an intermittent issue with the wireless card on one of my laptops. Turning off the wireless function (leaving the router to solely manage the 4 wired ethernet ports (on the back side) is as easy as it should be: flip the switch on the right side (right above the power button)).Adding a network storage device via the single USB port was a bit of a challenge as accessing the device took a bit of reading (whatever documentation you need can be found on the mini CD or on TP-Link's support page for the Archer C20i; go here: http://www.tp-link.us/support/download/?model=Archer+C20i&version=V1). I downloaded & read through the Archer_C20i_V1_Storage_Sharing_Application_Guide and found (using Windows 7) I had to open the "Run" application and type "\\tplinklogin.net" in the dialog box. Once I cmpleted this simple step it was easy to see and access the attached USB drive.Because USB setup wasn't as intuitive as other aspects of the set-up routine I'm "forced" to deduct a 1/4 star. The other 1/4 star is admittedly a matter of preference: I really do not like the form factor (preferring, I guess, the more traditional "slab" form factor (see, for instance, the Netgear WPN824N N150 Wireless Router)).In the end, I really like this router and (if you like the looks of it) recommend it. It's easy to set up, it does what it is advertised to do, and is not at all expensive. At least 4.5 stars.

There are already a number of excellent reviews for this product (e.g., "zhabazon" and "G. Hearn"). "Zhabazon" points out that this dispenser has siblings in the OXO family and provides suggestions for flushable wipes, while "G. Hearn" adds additional points and suggests other wipes. So there's no need to say what has already been so well said.I pretty much agree that this dispenser is really nice and pretty much a 5-star product. Well-made, good-looking, and at a reasonable price point, what's not to like? Honestly, very little. But there are two things that I feel need to be pointed out. First, it's much larger in the hand than in the product pix. I had hoped to put this in the bathroom on a small shelf above the toilet, but it's too big (i.e., too deep [front to back]). I thought it would be about the same size of the wipes we use, but the wipes are just swallowed up by the dispenser. Not a big deal at all, but something I think one should know about....Second, I can't get past how distracting the gap is when the lid is closed. Compare the product pic for this dispenser and the product pic for another OXO dispenser (OXO Perfect Pull Wipes Dispenser, Aqua). With this product there is a gap between the lid and bosy when closed whereas in the other (OXO Perfect Pull Wipes Dispenser, Aqua) it appears that there is no gap. Every time I look at this reviewed product I keep thinking either the lid is busted or not properly closed. It's neither and no real big deal, but (for me) it's utterly distracting....In the end, what a nice dispenser. Looks good in the bathroom, at the dinner table (when having juicy/greasy finger foods), or in the baby's room. Large size means it will fit just about any size wipe, quality construction means it will last for quite some time. Another top-notch OXO product. If they would only fix that gap...!

Bottom line, my wife says that this "serum" doesn't do much more than (lightly) moisturize. She never felt that the product burned (as some reviewers have noted), she saw no elimination of age lines (as others have triumphantly noted), and no real "green apple" smell (disappointing, as both of us really like green apple). Maybe my wife (or her skin) isn't old enough to see any difference, but after using this "serum" for several weeks she feels more than comfortable going back to her favorite and far less expensive moisturizer.The cosmetics industry is notorious for making claims that have absolutely no basis in objective truth/reality; beyond a certain level of performance, customers are paying for nothing more than hype. Not saying that's the case here, but truth be told I am leaning strongly in that direction. Take, for example, the copious use of the word "organic" on the product packaging. What's that mean? In the end, what we have is a marketing ploy as the manufacturer wants the buyer to equate "organic" with "healthy." Maybe so, but "organic" really means that something has carbon in it (like gasoline. Or charcoal). Continuing in this cynical vein, I would also be curious to see how well the manufacturer's claim (that the product has been "clinically validated") would stand up to rigorous scrutiny. I suspect the claim's suspect: go to the product's webpage (http://www.juicebeauty.com/about-us/clinically-validated/) and decide for yourself.Anyway, having had the opportunity to witness the use of this product for several weeks it seems to me that a sizable percentage of the claimed results are at best temporary fixes and more likely "placebo effects" (roughly, you can believe/will an absolutely inert product into working (at least to some extent)). The "age defy" aspect probably isn't so much an actual change; rather, it's probably the result of a positive application of "you're as old as you feel." So if you believe you are getting at least some of the promised benefits and feel comfortable spending $59 (at the time of this review) for them, then go for it: the "placebo effect" may be just that, but it is real!Summary: 3 stars because this "serum" does at least moisturize. Beyond that, not so much.

Short and sweet: not bad/really nice (I try to write for both the "glass half full"/"glass half empty" crowds!).Buying polymer Backup Iron Sights (BUIS) means you save on weight and cost over a metal BUIS system. These polymer sights weigh less than half than my "iron" BUIS (in fact, both the front and rear weigh less than my metal front flip-up sight alone). And they cost about half of what you would pay for an "iron" set (compare with Diamondhead FRONT & Rear Combat Sights - Integrated Sighting System (I.S.S.) w/ Diamond (Black) (Sold as Set) (Flip-Up) - LIFETIME WARRANTY). You don't have to settle on the feature set because it's a polymer BUIS (e.g., the rear aperture on this set is metal and not plastic). (Speaking of features, I don't have a PhD in "gun stuffology," so I defer to the product description and other reviewers for the more esoteric details. After 30 years in the Army, iron sights are, well, iron sights: point rifle downrange, put your target inside the circle and above the post, and pull the trigger. Up to 300 yards the result was usually bad for the target and good for me. I'm so old school Army that I am only now making the move to scopes, still like the A2 carry handle, and find the lack thereof on an AR platform disconcerting!) Anyway, so far, so good.Back to the BUIS. If your front sight mount sits on a gas block these sights (at least the front one) are not for you: says right on the package that the sight will melt. Speaking of heat, I wonder if the opposite also holds true: will they crack in cold weather? Not sure, but it's one reason I'm leery of plastic; having spent an entire career among fellow G.I.s, there's a reason why things in the military tend to be made of metal: metal doesn't break so easily. Probably an irrational fear, but I'll take metal (if I can afford it) over plastic almost every time if the item is a mission-critical one. And now that they are in my hands I must admit I'm not too keen on the angled (as opposed to rounded) approach Diamondhead took (to my mind, the sights looked cooler in the pictures than they do in my hand). But that's really a matter of aesthetics (a secondary aspect) and not one of function (the primary concern (I think) one should have in buying a BUIS.In the end, I put this Diamondhead polymer BUIS set next to my "competing manufacturer" steel/aluminum BUIS set (roughly similar to Troy Industries Inc. Front Folding HK Style Battle Sight and Troy Industries Folding Battle Sight Rear) and find that in almost every way I like the steel set more (to include the rounded geometry). For me, this BUIS will be a BUBUIS. But that's not to say the Diamondhead BUIS set is second-rate or substandard. It's not, the set is actually quite nice. Reasonable cost, good feature set, and well-manufactured, this BUIS set has only a few minor drawbacks (i.e., polymer limits application and I wonder about durability). If you have an application that will support polymer, are careful that the sights are polymer, and dig the diamond-shaped approach you can't go wrong. And as I mentioned at the beginning of the review you'll save a bunch of cash "going polymer" over steel/aluminum. This BUIS set is fully deserving of a solid 4-plus star rating.

Unless a rectangular paper plate is an absolute necessity (and I can see that it might be in a cutting board) I'm really finding it hard to justify the cost of this item. At $0.20/piece it is just about three times the cost/piece of the circular, yet comparably-sized Dixie HD Paper Plates, 10 1/16 Inches, 240 Count (Packaging May Vary).I can see uses for these plates - er, cutting boards - er, serving trays. With a waxy surface, they're fairly heavy duty, not unpleasant to look at, and useful. I guess the idea of a disposable cutting surface/board so that cross-contamination doesn't occur makes sense. But they are flimsy (flimsier than many paper plates we've used), the dish of the tray/board is not very deep, and the bag they come in isn't even resealable (important if we're talking about sanitation being a top concern). But it's the cost - my, oh my, I can't get past the cost.Bottom line, unless shape matters I can't see any reason whatsoever to buy this (rectangular) item over a far less expensive (circular) paper plate. Juliet (in "Romeo & Juliet," Act II, Scene 2) said it best: "A paper plate by any other name would still be a paper plate...."

My wife has had the opportunity to put this baster through its paces and finds she absolutely loves it. Here are her observations....Angled baster tip is a real plus. That it is removable for cleaning is an excellent bonus. The tip has a rubberized connection, so even though it is removable it does not leak.The stand (near the baster top; see photo) keeps the baster from rolling around. Put it down, it stays where you put it. (As an aside, I too found this feature really cool: during the very few times I've used a baster it always seemed to roll around and usually off the counter top! So yes, a simple idea that should have been self-evident a long time ago.)The baster bulb is "perfectly" sized (at least for my wife's hands). Not too squishy, not too inflexible. It also removes easily for cleaning.The included baster brush means that not only is the baster easy to clean you get the correct tool to do the cleaning. Fits perfectly and has a rubberized safety tip.Never thought something as simple as a baster could evoke such an enthusiastic review, but it has. 5 stars!

Pretty much everything that can be said about the benefits of this magazine extension has been said. And I absolutely agree with these numerous, positive assessments. So no need to comment further.Instead, I will comment on the value for the money. There is absolutely no way these are worth $9.95 apiece (current Amazon price at the time of this writing). Not even close. These are no more than a $2-3 per piece item at best. It's utterly ironic that people buy these things in order - in one scenario - to not get ripped off get ripped off in doing so. Sorry, no "economy of scale" argument works here. Not buying it. Surely someone out there can make these and bring them in at a far more reasonable price point.Item: 5 stars; price: 1 star. As the old saying goes, "highway robbery."

Honestly, I didn't know what to make of this when it arrived. A flexible silicon ice tray, my first thought was - considering the price - that this was a solution in search of a problem. But it's really not fair to review/rate until the product is actually used, so in with the water and into the freezer.The next day we had six ice cubes. It did just what it promised to do, but is it worth the cost or space? In the end, I kinda think so. I do like that the ice/water is enclosed so that it doesn't pick up unwanted odors/flavors. I do like that the flexible silicon allows for very easy removal of the ice. I do like that the trays can be stacked. I think it will clean very easily. I like how you know how much water to add: hold the tray upright (with the opening up) and fill to the marked "fill line" on the side of the tray (when you move from the vertical to the horizontal the correct amount of water fills each of the cube "slots").Not so sure I like how small the cubes were or that each tray takes up more room than they should. As such, I would like to see a tray that makes more than 6 cubes and one that is half the height. Then one would get the benefits of both a traditional ice cube tray and this item.Finally, I'm not sure a $10.00 price point (Amazon price at the time of this review) makes for an attractive purchase. Unless silicon is really far more expensive than I think it is, $7.50 is at the very top end of what I would happily pay (perhaps 1 at $7.50, 2 for $10.00?). The product would also be a bit more attractive to buyers if various colors were offered.In the end, this is a very cool little gadget that - if money and size are secondary to function - should serve as a nice addition to anyone's freezer. Since price and size are important to me my first inclination was to say it was okay and give it 3 stars. But I can see the value in it, so let's bump it up to "I like it!" and give it 4 stars.

When I started playing high school soccer back in the early-mid 1970s the mindset seemed very much to be on the offense. Back then the preferred formation was 5-3-2 (5 forwards, 3 midfielders, and 2 fullbacks)! On the front line there was a left & right wing, a center, and an inside left and an inside right. "Attack!" was the motto of the day and even the formation listing listed the offense first. In this mindset, the 5 attackers attacked and the opposing team's 5 defenders (the 3 midfielders and 2 fullbacks) defended.Sometime between then and now coaches at all levels realized that while winning meant their jobs might be safe, losing meant they definitely weren't. So the emphasis slowly shifted from winning to not losing. And the point structure helped: if a coach knew his team stood a slim chance of winning, he could be rewarded for "packing the box," hunkering down, and leaving the stadium with a point. In the end, that one point might just have been what the coach needed to keep his job. That this was so was reflected in the change - at some point - from an offense-oriented formation formula (e.g., 5-3-2) to a defense-oriented one (e.g., 4-4-2).Fast forward to today and we see - for a variety of reasons - a slow switch back to the offense. The boxes are still packed (coaches can ill-afford to give up a goal), but it's no longer enough to do simply that. Team formations still reflect an emphasis on the defense, but finally we are seeing coaches thinking about getting goals too (and not just talking about getting them).Here's where this book comes in. The book seeks to introduce an offensive mindset from the goal line forward. We have chapters on generating offense from the mid-field, from the defensive third, from the goalie. We even have chapters on generating offense off of the opponent's set pieces. Chapters generally start with a short "philosophy" essay that introduces drills designed to generate the "offense always" mindset. Not bad.For a book that has just been published, some of the essays contain some out-dated factoids (e.g., people being in certain jobs: one essay still had Kenny Dalglish managing Liverpool FC). Annoying, but minor. So no ding.If I have to complain, I would say the book would really benefit from an introductory chapter that addresses offense "as a whole," as a coherent, over-arching game strategy. It's great that there are chapters on "offense in the midfield," "offense in the defensive third," etc., but it would have been nice to see all of it tied together and introduced in one essay right up front (even if it would seem somewhat redundant). Coaches first, and then players, need to know from the start (i.e., page 1) that the best soccer/football, most exciting soccer/football, and potentially most successful soccer/football is "full participation" soccer/football (where everyone is involved in every phase of the game: the offense, the defense, set pieces, etc.). This book is, thus, much needed and more than a step in the right direction.

I bought this (Camco) stand to go with the Camco 40631 EVO Premium Water Filter. As the stand looks to be a perfect companion to the EVO Premium Water Filter I bought it without hesitation. But they are not perfectly mated.On the plus side, the stand is really well-constructed. I like the foot rung: it provides both a way of getting the stand into the ground and keeping the stakes in line. The zinc coating should keep the stand from rusting.BUT THE CIRCUMFERENCE OF THE FILTER HOLDER IS FAR LARGER THAN THE CIRCUMFERENCE OF THE EVO FILTER UNIT! So the only way the filter stays in the stand is by resting on the inlet and outlet hoses! I could understand this if I was using a non-Camco stand, but I'm not. IMHO, either Camco needs to rethink the size of this item or sell one mated specifically to the EVO unit.Bottom line, pay attention to the second photo for this product (which shows the EVO unit in the stand) or the photo for the EVO Filter itself. I didn't and wish I had; not sure I would have bought this if I had been more attentive. In the end, it's easier all the way around to keep the stand (rather than return it) so the next step is to figure out a better means of supporting the filter in the stand (one possible solution: use the filter wrench provided with the EVO unit).

I wasn't looking for these name tapes to go on a uniform or battle rattle. As I just needed to mark a couple of private-use rucksacks, I wasn't expecting much. And that's pretty much what I got.I agree with reviewers Lance H., Gordon, & B. Meade: these name tapes are of a much lower quality than the buyer should expect (lettering crooked, thin material). Also, the "coyote brown" is much, much darker than what you will see on your computer; so dark, in fact, that it is difficult to see the black lettering used for my name. I should have went with "coyote tan."I was drawn in by the "free shipping" and as such failed to realize that I probably wasn't going to get the same quality as from the Marine Corps Exchange (something's gotta give, right? If you're gonna offer free shipping, then the materials costs have to be lower). So lesson learned: next time I'll hit the MCX and order through their Clothing Sales.

Saw these at a local discount store and tried them on. I wasn't too sure what to make of them at first since they basically look like imitation Converse Chuck Taylors. However, the price at $20 and initial fit and comfort is what sold me. After two weeks on wearing them during Julyaround NYC I've found these to be better for fit, comfort, quality, and price than any Converse sneakers I've owned in the past.In fact these Levi's Stan Bucks reminded me of the original MADE IN USA Chuck Taylors that sold for $20-$30 back in the 1980s/1990s before Nike took over Converse raised prices of shoes and moved manufacturing to China.The quality is much better. Stitching is precise, the fabric and rubber are put together very well (no glue smears or loose threads). I also find the rubber soles and toe rand doesn't get dirty or wear down as quickly as Converse.With regards to price: for $20 to $30 these shoes are a steal. I honestly feel Levi's could sell these for $70 to $100 and at that price it would be a bargain.The comfort is way better than Converse Chucks. I can walk all day in these with or without socks and I have cool dry feet even on the hottest day. The foot bed is actually a foot bed with arch support and not a flat canvas sheet-glues-to- rubber outsole combo that Converse employs on their Chucks. So you don't have that bare feet feeling with these Levi's that you normally get from wearing Chucks. Also the rubber toe rand cap is tailored wider than Chucks so there should be no hard rubbing against your toes.Fit is also exact for the size and Levi's include half sizes for a better fit. Converse tends to fit big with little access to half sizes for many shoes. Here it is easy to get an exact fit.At the end of the day you can't go wrong for the price. In fact I am so impressed I came online to buy at least another pair of these which is why I am here.

Very good quality lamps! I just replaced the original Philips DS2 in my 2001 BMW 330i.I believe those were the original factory bulbs that came with the car and they lasted 15 years.I was looking to get the same Philips DS2 that cost much more than these Kensun bulbs but theAmazon reviews were better on these bulbs. So my choice was based on reviews before the price.After two weeks of usage I am pleased to say that these 5000k Kensun's are a great replacement to the factory standard.They appear brighter on the road than the slight-yellowish 4000k factory HIDs. The bulbs themselves look pure white in the lenswith a slight-blue tint. My car is topaz blue so it is a great match.I've had them in my car for two weeks and I have had no issues what so ever. The BMW E46 Xenon HID lowbeam replacement is really easy, requiring no tools at all, and foolproof, requiring absolutely no technical skills or knowledge.The BMW and Luxury car dealerships charge over $1,000 to replace bulbs and diagnose lighting issues. Do it yourself in mere minutes with these Kensun bulbs and save yourself the money, hassle and time.

7/25/2015 EDIT: This ONLY works with the newer 9/2001 E46/ 3 Series BMW cars and I assume the later years after 2001 BMW vehicles. The seller offers NO refunds but refuse to properly list what cars this part will work with. I would have NOT made this purchase had I known this information. Even with the correct 9/2001 module I could not get it coded for my car. It is easier to get your insurance company to replace your windshield at the BMW dealership instead of Safelite (which uses aftermarket windshields) so that you can get this part for free as it already comes attached to the BMW OEM windshields.ORIGINAL REVIEW: If you have an older 1999 to 2001 pre facelift 3 series then you need to upgrade the rain sensor module. This only fits the newer rain sensor modules. Other than that shipping was quick and professional. Everything arrived as described. This is only the hard plastic purple sensor lens and not the actual hardware sensor module so as long as you install it correctly and your sensor works then it will work

I loved this style so much I went back and bought this Mazarine 3D Riley after owning the Comfort Pint Arc 3D Zip Jacket for a few months. I own the Comfort Pintt in an XL which fit my 5'8"tall/155lb frame perfect with lots of room to layer medium-weight sweater underneath (Basically XL fits like a medium 38R in this style). But I was only able to find a L in this Mazarine fabric thinking it would fit slim and look good with only a thin t-shirt underneath. I can barely get into this jacket with just a thin t-shirt it fits that small. The shoulders and armpits are very tight and worse the Mazarine denim fabric is 100% stiff cotton so there is absolutely no stretch or give to the fabric when putting it on or moving your arms above your head.Great style and color but sizing should be more accurate.

I've been using the slowly disintigrating Zagg for a full year before it fully broke on it's own.  That keyboard had a lot of issues some of which included normal wear "rub" damage to the chrome edges of my Note 12.2. The Samsung keyboard is a much better choice and the only issue I have with it is that Samsung and Best Buy didn't announce that this was coming out when I got the Zagg. I only discovered its existence when I walked into Best Buy to look at the Galaxy Note Edge phone. Even then at the time (Fall 2014) they only had the white color keyboard available. Very frustrating for someone  with a black Note 12.2.Overall the Samsung keyboard is great. I wished the keys had more travel to them but they are comfortable during long bouts of typing.  The weight of the entire thing is heavier than the Zagg but it is a heft that exudes more quality that bulk. It feels like you can throw it across the room and it will still work fine and come out unscathed.  The Bluetooth connection is much quicker and autonomous than the Zagg.  With the Zagg you have to confirm the connection every time or ESC the pop up box telling you the Zagg is connecting, here the Samsung just connects. As for battery life these keyboards are really good. As for the case function when the tablet is closed inside the keyboard the locking tabs at the corner is weaker than I would like. It is not a firm clip in.  There is also no sleep function for the tablet when nestled in the shell. As far as I can see the screen is still on when you close the tablet in the case. At least the keys don't seem to touch the screen like it does on the Zagg.Two things I would add: Firmer locking tabs and a sleep function!Nevertheless I turn off the tablet and I use a padded laptop carry sleeve when toting around the samsung tablet & keyboard in my briefcase.The asking retail price is $99.99+ which is a lot to pay for what you get but many online stores and Amazon sellers sell these for half that retail price. Definately worth the buy especially if you do heavy typing work on your tablet.

This jacket was a spontaneous buy for me. I didn't need it since I just got the similar Kenneth Cole Moto Jacket but it was on sale for $63.99 one-day sale at my local G Star boutique. Even if it was $200 or $300, after trying it on I couldn't leave the store without it. The Forc Across looks way better in person than it does in any picture you will ever see online.At $63.99 this jacket was a gift.I especially lucked out because the only size left was a LARGE which fit my medium 5'8"  160 lb frame perfectly.I can wear just a T-shirt or a T-shirt/medium sweater-combo underneath and the Forc still fits and looks the same. The faux fabric has a bit of stretch to it so the jacket wears comfortably independent on how many layers you wear underneath it.One potential concern I had early on was discovering the sleeves on the Forc were not articulated (which means whenever you move your arms above your head or when driving a car the jacket can ride up and bunch up around your torso). This worry was quickly quelled because the fabric does stretch along the arms and back so it compensates for the lack of articulation when you move your arms around. It doesn't ride up or bunch up that much.The outer pockets all zip close and the one interior chest pocket button-snaps to close. I would have wanted another interior chest pocket but all the pockets are cavernous and comfortable.The jacket does not have an insulation fill between the cotton inner lining and outer faux leather. As a result I did not find it to be warm in temperatures below 45 F degrees. It is also not all that windproof so even on a windy 50 to 60 F degree day you will be cold if you do not layer well underneath or wear a scarf. The neck collar has a wool/acrylic fleece lining that can work to keep your neck warm when the jacket is zipped up and the collar cinched closed. That is the only protection against the cold you will get so prepare to layer up and put on a scarf if you tend to get cold.The cotton inner fabric collects a lot of lint. I would have preferred a polyester or nylon lining.I also own the Kenneth Cole Reaction Moto jacket and I found that Moto jacket to be much warmer and more wind resistant since it has a quilted polyester lining with an insulation fill inside.The plus side to this for the G Star Forc is that I found in temps above 70 F to 85 F degrees that I did not overheat or get hot at all. The jacket vents/breaths very well in warmer temps even when zipped up. So this is an ideal Spring into Summer season jacket whereas the Moto (or similar jackets) are mainly Spring up to Summer jackets.For my tastes I prefer the G Star Forc jacket. It looks very slick since it is not riddled with zippers and pockets and of all the Faux Leather bikers it's leather quality looks the richest and realest.$310 retail is asking a lot for it but even those paying that price will be VERY HAPPY with the product!

Really great piece of denim!The Comfort Delm fabric feels rugged yet very comfortable when worn. It has a bit of stretch to it so it wears very well. The Dark Aged finish is notas dark as I would like but it is more of a medium denim wash exactly like the pictures show.Unlike most of G Star's fancier fare this stretch mid-weight denim is easy to wear in literally any situation. Put on some tan suede loafers, chukka's or oxfords with a baby blue sheen business shirt and you will fit in amongst the trust fund folks brunching life away on Madison Avenue. Put on a pair of Timberlands or Air Jordan's and a G Star hoodie and you will find yourself on stage rapping next to Bobby Schmurda!All Radar Slim fit slimmer than your average G Stars. I'm normally a 32 x 32 but sized up to a 33 x 32 in these for an exact fit. They do have a bit of stretch so it would be okay if you get your exact size for a tighter fit. It would not be un comfortable at all.Definitely a great piece of denim for everyone's G Star Collection.One thing I noticed when looking for these online is the European Product Code is listed as 50740.6083.89 while the North American/USA Product Code is 50740-6083-020 for the same New Radar Slim Comfort Delm Denim Jeans.

This was totally worth it! My wife sleeps thru the night now. I highly recommend this even though the price is high compared to the $9 straight body pillow. This one is better because it is curled in the shape and firmer so it offers much better support.We didn't get the cover since the covers for this are very overpriced at about $30+! Compared to the pillow itself which cost us $37 on sale.The white color doesn't get dirty and the material is stain and fuzz/pile resistant. The whole thing is also machine washable.

First pair of G Star Jeans I owned that I sized down from my normal G Star size  32 x 32  to a 30 x 32. I won't say they fit big but it seems 32 x 32 , 31 x 32 and 30 x 32 all fit the same!Yeah I was lucky enough to find a couple of these left at my local Lords & Taylors for $60 on sale. For me I could have bought any size but I found the 30 x 32 to fit the best with the Slim Taper cut.The Taper style for this 5620 3D tend to fit slim on the waist, baggy in the thigh and slim in the calf and ankle. I'm not sure if I got an irregular but the Taper 30 x 32 in these particular pants fit exactly like a Slim 32 x 32 in all my other Slim Fit G Stars.That said I am extremely happy with the over all style and function of these 5620 3D although I won't  buy anymore of this Taper 5260 3D. It is not really my style compared to Arc 3Ds, Radar Slims and the Attacc/Nattacc. Stylistically 5620 3D seem boring and dated by comparison. Actually had I not found them for $60 I definitely would not have bought them over any other G Star jeans at their original $180 retail price tag.One thing to add I've notice the dark blue dye on these particular jeans comes of much easier than my other dark blue dyed G Stars. I haven't washed them yet but I expect them to most likely fade in time.Remember G-Star says to never wash their dark denims but if you do turn them inside out and  use ONLY ice cold water (literally put ice cubes in the machine if you have to) and hang dry in a dark place.Over all I am happy I got these even though they are not my favorite G Star jeans.

This is a beautiful piece of denim! The pictures do not give justice to how amazing this denim wash is. These look absolutely amazing when you put them on. The blue color here is the most perfect wash of indigo blue I have ever seen on jeans in all my life. I don't think G Star or any other top denim maker will EVER procure a more brilliant indigo blue denim wash. The whisker and fading patterns are simply electrifying when seen in person. These would be the perfect jeans except for two things;1. The Nolds fabric is a really thick and rigid 13 oz weave and as a result I needed to size up from my normal G Star size 32x32 to a size 34x32 just to get a proper fit in the waist. G Star recommends the normal size because even though the first wear will be tight as heck their fabrics all stretch out or break in to fit to your body in time. With the Nolds I really did not feel this thick of a weave would ever stretch out.2. If I was rich I would have kept them but for $300 I found the price to be extremely high relative to other Arc 3D denim that G Star sells.I replaced these Nolds with the Wisk Medium Aged Arc 3D and the Neill Dark Aged Arc 3D and still had money left over to buy a couple of G Star t shirts.I think later in the year if I can find these Nolds on sale for cheaper or when my tax returns come in and I have cash to spare I will buy these again.The denim wash color of the Nolds will leave you speechless.It is a joke how the pictures on Amazon don't do these pants justice.

Great phone. If you have this phone and also carry something like an iPhone 5 or Samsung Android Galaxy 4 then you would literally have the most powerful pairing in mobile telephony in your pockets.PROS:> All 9790s come factory unlocked to accept Sim cards and work anywhere on this planet! What other phone does that?> Small. It not only fits in your denim jeans pocket but you will forget it is in there.> Powerful. Get the OS upgrades and you will find that this is a fast and smooth phone. It does everything well.> Free Mobile Hotspot. Can't beat that. It is free and FAST! You can add internet up to 5 devices. I've streamed entire Netflix movies via this phone onto my Smart HDTV and did NOT have one blip or hiccup!> QWERTY hard keyboard is still the best for texting, typing and emails. I have written out many 5-10 page papers for school on this phone and didn't even realize how many pages I have written until after printing it out or transferring it to a word document.> Good Auto Focus camera and video camera.> Good standard software and apps.> Fast and smooth movie and HD video playback. The sound is also REALLY GOOD!> Touch screen is awesome! It is smooth and the sensitivity is well balanced. Coming from a 9780 it took some time to get use to it but now I love it.> BBM still rules! I don't care how much you text on an iPhone or Android nothing beats the world accessibly of BBM.> LED Alerts are still very useful.> Very GOOD phone features. Most newer phones tend to bury phone features inside menus and apps but here the 9790 still remembers what it means to be a telephone.> Lots of skins, cases and accessories available on the world market for this phone. I had a tough time at first finding stuff for it in the USA market but once I went on eBay Canada and eBay UK there were hundreds of pages showing products for this device from battery extenders, cases, skins, desktop chargers, car hotspot chargers, etc...CONS:> All 9790s may come unlocked for phone calling BUT they are TWO types of 9790s that are 3G/4G/Data locked to specific Bands. The RED71UW 9790 use Bands 1,2,5, and 6 (AT&T, Rogers and Telus) whiles REC71UW 9790 use Bands 1,4 and 8 (T-Mobile, O2, Wind, Mobilicity, UK carriers). This variation ONLY affects the 3G/4G Data Antenna and not the phone calling ability of the 9790. This isn't stated anywhere in the packaging or by most online merchants who simply state the 9790 comes unlocked. It is UNLOCKED for Sim cards and phone calling/texting but it is permanently LOCKED to a specific Band group and hence a LOCKED to specifics carriers if you need to use this for 3G/4G Data.> Blackberry Apps are EXPENSIVE. Some Apps, especially the productivity ones, can be as much a $79.99!> Blackberry Apps are lacking. DO NOT buy this phone for Apps! You will be 100% disappointed. There is no Instagram for one and many of those coupon Apps that require touch screens don't exist here. However the basic fare of Facebook, WhatApp, Twitter, eBay, YouTube, etc... all work well here and are all FREE!> No front facing camera. Being business savvy Blackberries in 2012/2013 should all come with hardware set up to cater to video conferencing and video chatting. This is something 10 years ago you would have thought that Blackberry would have done first and done by now.>No touch screen based unlock/lock screen apps. Or rather no decent apps for locking/unlocking the screen USING solely the touch screen (like you get with the Samsung Galaxy phones). There is one trial app that can screw up your phone power and memory usage when the trial-ware expires. It is only then you realize the 9790 actually doesn't have many apps that cater or enhance the touch screen feature that this phone does so well.> Screen can feel too small for extending movie watching. Media playback is easy to do and the sound quality is GREAT but the screen can be small for movie viewing. I just watched Pacific Rim on this 9790 and later when I saw it in theaters I realized there was a lot of detail I missed out on when I saw it on my phone.> I'm not sure how this is done but my 9790 does not provide Bluetooth streaming of music into my car. Although the bluetooth does extend over the voice dial features it does not automatically prompt for music streaming. Then again, I am not sure if this can be done via an app or OS upgrade. However the fact remains there is no bluetooth music streaming on this 9790 out of the box.Overall this is still a great phone. I have had it for over a year now and it still feels new in my pocket.
